The Centre for Cities' report comes as the government prepares to unveil its long-awaited Northern Powerhouse Strategy, which is expected to include a range of measures to boost economic growth in the north. The strategy is seen as a key part of the government's plan to rebalance the UK's economy, which has long been dominated by the south.

However, the Centre for Cities' report is not the only criticism of the government's plan. Some have argued that the HS3 rail link is too expensive and will not deliver the promised economic benefits. Others have questioned the government's assumption that the north is a single, homogenous region, and argue that different parts of the north have different economic needs and priorities.

Despite these criticisms, the government remains committed to its vision of a "northern powerhouse". Chancellor George Osborne has described the plan as a "once-in-a-generation" opportunity to transform the north's economy, and has pledged to work closely with local authorities and businesses to deliver the strategy.

The Centre for Cities' report is likely to add to the debate about the best way to drive economic growth in the north. While the thinktank's recommendations are likely to be welcomed by some, others may argue that the government's plan is the right one, and that the north will benefit from the investment in infrastructure and other measures.

Regardless of the outcome, the debate is likely to continue, with many stakeholders eager to see the government's Northern Powerhouse Strategy in action. The strategy is expected to be unveiled in the coming weeks, and will be closely watched by businesses, politicians, and economists across the north.

Dominic Chappell, the owner of BHS at the time it fell into administration, has blamed former owner Sir Philip Green for the retail chain's demise. Chappell said Green had failed to deliver on a pledge to ensure the backing of credit insurers and had not left sufficient cash in the business. "Philip Green never stood good for his word," Chappell told the Guardian. "We worked so hard. It was Philip Green's interfering and breaking of his word that caused this to happen." Out of more than £60m of cash left on the balance sheet by Green, the Topshop owner who sold BHS for £1 to Chappell's Retail Acquisitions just over a year ago, Chappell said he had been forced to pay out more than £20m as upfront guarantees to keep key suppliers on board. He admitted Green had not given a written guarantee that he could secure credit insurance but claimed it had been verbally promised. Chappell's comments are the latest salvo in a long-running battle between the two former owners of BHS. Green has consistently denied any wrongdoing and has blamed Chappell for the company's demise. However, Chappell's claims are backed up by several industry insiders who have spoken to the Guardian on condition of anonymity.

One supplier, who wished to remain anonymous, said that Green had promised to provide a written guarantee to secure credit insurance, but never followed through. "We were told that Philip Green would sort it out, but it never happened," the supplier said. "We were left high and dry, and ultimately had to write off millions of pounds in debt."

Another industry insider claimed that Green had been "playing a game of chicken" with suppliers, knowing that they were dependent on BHS for their livelihood. "He would make promises and then break them, just to see how far he could push people," the insider said. "It was a classic case of 'you can't touch me, I'm Philip Green'."

The collapse of BHS has left thousands of people out of work and has sparked a wider debate about the ethics of private equity ownership. Green's company, Arcadia Group, has faced intense scrutiny over its handling of the BHS sale and its treatment of employees.

Chappell's comments have been welcomed by some of the thousands of former BHS employees who are still waiting for their redundancy payments. "It's about time someone spoke out about what really happened," said one former employee, who wished to remain anonymous. "We were treated like nothing more than pawns in Philip Green's game of profit and loss."

The Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy has launched an investigation into the collapse of BHS, and several MPs have called for Green to be held accountable. The government has also introduced new legislation aimed at preventing the kind of asset stripping that occurred at BHS.

In a statement, Arcadia Group said that it "strongly denies" any wrongdoing and that it had done everything in its power to support BHS. However, the company has faced intense criticism over its handling of the sale and its treatment of employees. The row is likely to continue for some time, with many calling for greater transparency and accountability in the private equity industry.

Home Retail Group boss John Walden will be in line for a windfall of more than £5m in cash and shares if the owner of Argos is sold to Sainsbury's. It is not clear if Walden will stay on if Sainsbury's finalises the £1.4bn takeover deal, but Home Retail Group's annual report published on Tuesday revealed that in either case the chief executive would be able to cash in more than 650,000 shares and options, which are not subject to performance conditions. Under the terms of Sainsbury's takeover deal – which offers 0.321 Sainsbury's shares and 55p in cash for every Home Retail Group share as well as a 25p windfall from the sale of the Homebase chain and a 2.8p dividend, that would be worth £1m. Walden's windfall could potentially be more than double that after he was awarded 785,000 shares and share options in May last year, which are subject to three-year performance criteria and worth £1.3m, and 143,000 which he received this year. He could also potentially cash in up to 1.4m more share options – which are due to vest if he meets performance criteria over the next two years – worth up to £2.3m. Home Retail's remuneration committee said it had not yet determined what would happen with bonuses and share awards linked to performance targets beyond the date of any takeover. If he left the business, Walden would also be in line for a payout of at least £676,500; his basic annual salary after a 2% pay rise. Walden's potential windfall would be one of the largest payouts to a UK CEO in recent years. The exact timing and nature of his departure, if it happens, would depend on the outcome of the takeover negotiations and the terms of any agreement reached between Sainsbury's and Home Retail Group.

Industry experts say that Walden's payout is a reflection of the company's strong financial performance under his leadership, which has seen Home Retail Group's shares rise significantly over the past year. "Walden has done a great job in turning around the business, and this payout is a testament to his hard work and dedication," said one analyst.

However, some critics have questioned the size of the payout, particularly in light of the potential impact on Home Retail Group's employees and customers. "While Walden may be entitled to his windfall, it's hard to see how this is justified when the company is still facing significant challenges and its employees are being asked to make sacrifices," said a union representative.

The Sainsbury's takeover deal is expected to be completed by the end of the year, pending regulatory approval. If successful, it would mark a major shift in the UK retail landscape, with Sainsbury's becoming one of the country's largest retailers. The deal would also leave Home Retail Group's employees and customers wondering about the future of the business and its iconic Argos brand.

Ecstasy is making a comeback, according to a report from the European monitoring centre for drugs and drug addiction (EMCDDA). After its peak during the 1990s house, rave and techno scenes, it's returning to popularity with both established drug users and a new generation due to "creative and aggressive marketing" (including the use of logos such as Superman and UPS) and the fact it now has higher purity. The report also warned that the substance is now stronger than ever. So, what does this say about current drug laws? The UK reported the second highest level of use (the highest usage was in the Netherlands) among the 12 countries which were analysed. How can we lower rates of drug use or is it time to stop criminalising it? We want to hear from drug counsellors about our current attitude to drugs in Britain. The resurgence of ecstasy's popularity raises questions about the effectiveness of current drug laws and policies. Some argue that the criminalization of drugs only drives them underground, making it harder to monitor and control their distribution. Others believe that stricter laws and penalties are necessary to deter people from using drugs. Meanwhile, drug counsellors are calling for a more harm-reduction approach, focusing on education, treatment, and support rather than punishment. What do you think? Should we rethink our approach to drug use and addiction?

Despite Belgium's Bpost and Dutch postal group PostNL failing to agree terms for a takeover of the latter, news of their talks has put the spotlight back on possible consolidation in the sector. In the UK Royal Mail, which was linked with PostNL in December, is up 7p at 539.5p in a downbeat market. Analysts at Credit Suisse said talk of mergers and acquisitions in the European postal sector is growing but they are cautious about the prospect, given declining traditional mail volumes and limited scope for synergies. As the postal sector continues to grapple with the decline of traditional mail volumes, analysts are divided on the likelihood of successful consolidation. While some believe that a merger could help to drive efficiency gains and reduce costs, others argue that the benefits may be limited by the inherent complexity of integrating different business models and cultures.

Despite these challenges, Royal Mail's share price movement suggests that investors are still willing to take a punt on the idea of consolidation in the sector. The company's CEO, Rico Hizon, has previously stated that the company is open to exploring strategic options, including a potential merger with another postal operator.

However, any deal would likely require significant regulatory approval, and there are concerns that the UK's Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) may be wary of allowing a merger that could lead to a loss of competition in the market. The CMA has previously blocked several proposed mergers in the sector, citing concerns about the potential impact on consumers.

In the meantime, Royal Mail is focusing on its ongoing efforts to diversify its revenue streams and adapt to the changing needs of its customers. The company has made significant investments in its parcel delivery business, and has also launched a range of new services aimed at attracting more business from e-commerce retailers. As the postal sector continues to evolve, Royal Mail's ability to adapt and innovate will be crucial to its success.

Deloitte has named its highest-ever proportion of female partners in the accountancy firm's annual round of promotions but the pool of senior employees is still more than 80% male. The 'big four' accountant said 24 of 80 new partners in its UK business, which includes offices in Switzerland, are female. The figure means that 30% of the prized positions went to women, up on last year's 29% and just 20% in 2014. But while the proportion of new female partners has been increasing, Deloitte is still a long way off gender parity. This year's intake means that just 16% of the 1,054 partners in the firm's UK division are female, a slight increase on 15% before the latest batch of promotions. Despite the progress, Deloitte's gender imbalance remains a concern for the industry. The firm's efforts to increase diversity and inclusion have been underway for several years, but the pace of change has been slow. Deloitte's UK CEO, Richard Houston, acknowledged that there is still much work to be done to achieve gender parity. "We are committed to creating a more diverse and inclusive culture, and while we are making progress, we recognize that we still have a long way to go," he said.

Deloitte's figures are in line with those of its rivals in the accounting industry. According to a recent report by the Institute of Chartered Accountants in England and Wales (ICAEW), women make up just 22% of partners in the top 10 accounting firms in the UK. The report also found that women are more likely to leave the profession after having children, and that there is a lack of female role models and mentors in senior positions.

Deloitte is taking steps to address these issues, including introducing flexible working arrangements and family-friendly policies. The firm is also investing in diversity and inclusion training for its employees and is working to increase the number of women in senior leadership positions. However, it remains to be seen whether these efforts will be enough to achieve gender parity in the long term. As one of the largest and most influential accounting firms in the world, Deloitte's progress will be closely watched by the industry and beyond.

In January I went on the Argos website and ordered a washing machine and TV, entering my debit card details. It stated it would take five days to deliver. But when I rang customer services a man told me it does not accept debit cards, contrary to what it says on the website. Then when I received my bank statement in February I noted that a payment of £286 was taken from my debit account by Argos, but I still haven't received any goods. How do I retrieve my money? Argos seems to be lax in its customer services and even emails do not seem to make any impact. I was left feeling frustrated and concerned about the security of my debit card details. I tried to contact Argos again, but the customer service team was unhelpful, telling me that I should have read the fine print before making the purchase. I was shocked that they were not taking responsibility for the mistake.

I decided to take my complaint to the Financial Ombudsman Service, which handles disputes between consumers and financial institutions. I submitted a detailed complaint, including a copy of my bank statement and screenshots of the Argos website showing the incorrect payment information.

After several weeks, I received a response from the Ombudsman, which sided with me and ordered Argos to refund the £286 taken from my account. I was relieved that justice had been served, but I was also left wondering how Argos could have gotten it so wrong in the first place.

I have since cancelled my order and will be taking my business elsewhere. I hope that Argos will take steps to improve its customer service and website accuracy to prevent similar incidents from happening in the future.

"Dials and buttons, knobs and switches; they're very charming," says James Ball, the digital art director behind a new photography series called Guide to Computing, which celebrates early computers. Ball, who works under the pseudonym Docubyte, began the project after developing a fascination and affection for such retro devices. "It's rare now to find any machine that you can touch and interact with," he says. "Computers now are all touch screens, slick and super-slim." Ball's fascination with vintage computers began when he stumbled upon an old Apple IIe in his grandfather's attic. "I was mesmerized by its chunky design and the fact that you could physically interact with it," he recalls. He soon started collecting more retro computers, scouring thrift stores, flea markets, and online marketplaces for hidden gems.

The Guide to Computing series is a culmination of Ball's passion project, featuring over 50 photographs of various vintage computers, each one meticulously styled and lit to highlight its unique design elements. From the iconic Apple II to the behemoth IBM PC, Ball's photographs showcase the tactile nature of these early machines, inviting viewers to touch, feel, and explore.

"I want people to appreciate the beauty in the imperfections of these machines," Ball explains. "They're not sleek and modern, but they have a certain charm that's hard to find in today's technology." The series has already garnered significant attention online, with many enthusiasts and collectors reaching out to Ball to share their own stories and memories of working with these vintage computers.

Ball's project has also sparked a sense of nostalgia among those who grew up with these machines. "I remember spending hours programming on my Commodore 64, trying to create my own games and demos," says one commenter on Ball's Instagram page. "Your photos brought back so many memories!"

As the series continues to gain momentum, Ball hopes to inspire a new generation of enthusiasts to appreciate the history and design of early computing. "There's something special about holding a physical object and being able to interact with it," he says. "I hope my project can help people appreciate the beauty in the imperfections of these machines, and maybe even inspire someone to start collecting and preserving their own vintage computers."

MPs are to investigate how many occupational pension schemes are at risk of failing, amid inquiries into the collapse of BHS and the debate over the future of the £15bn British Steel pension fund. The Commons work and pensions select committee, which is already investigating the £571m deficit at BHS scheme, said on Friday night it would launch a wide ranging inquiry into the problem, probably starting in the autumn. Workers' occupational pensions have been forced centre stage in recent months by BHS's collapse and by Tata Steel's potential sale of its UK business. Almost 13,000 current and former BHS employees who were under retirement age when the company went into administration in March may face a 10% cut to their pensions as a result. The British Steel pension scheme, one of Britain's largest defined benefit plans with 130,000 members, is also facing cuts as the government races to put it on a sound footing to help facilitate a sale. The latest figures show it has liabilities of almost £15bn and the deficit has ballooned to £700m. The committee's inquiry is expected to examine the scale of the problem, the causes of the deficits, and the impact on scheme members. It will also look at the role of employers, trustees, and regulators in managing the schemes.

The inquiry will also scrutinize the government's role in regulating the pension industry, including the effectiveness of the Pensions Regulator and the Financial Conduct Authority. The committee will also consider the implications of the EU's proposed pension directive, which could lead to changes in the way occupational schemes are run.

The committee's chair, Frank Field, said: "The collapse of BHS and the potential sale of British Steel have brought the issue of occupational pension schemes into sharp focus. We need to get to the bottom of why so many schemes are struggling and what can be done to prevent further failures."

The inquiry is expected to take several months to complete, with the committee holding evidence sessions and gathering information from a range of stakeholders, including employers, trustees, and industry experts.

Meanwhile, the government has announced plans to introduce new measures to help shore up the British Steel pension scheme. The plans include increasing the contributions made by the company and its employees, as well as providing a guarantee to ensure that the scheme is fully funded.

The move is seen as a crucial step in facilitating the sale of the company, which is expected to be completed by the end of the year. However, unions and pension experts have expressed concerns that the proposed changes could still leave scheme members facing significant cuts to their pensions.

The issue of occupational pension schemes is expected to remain a major concern for the government and the pension industry in the coming months, as the committee's inquiry gets underway and the fate of the British Steel pension scheme is decided.

Aldi is to introduce 18 British craft beers at its stores as it capitalises on the bank holiday weekend. Amid heightened demand for specialist beers, the discount supermarket chain will stock its shelves with brews such as Wet Your Whistle, White Witch and A-Hop-alypse Now from Sunday. It said the move would allow it to tap into a UK craft beer market worth £420m and predicted to reach £1bn by 2020. The German retailer spent the past two years sourcing the beers from 15 UK-based breweries, before selling them for £1.25 each in stores in England and Wales. It added that the range was "carefully selected to celebrate provenance, artisan brewing and the exceptional beer produced across the UK". The move is seen as a strategic play by Aldi to capitalize on the growing popularity of craft beer among British consumers. The retailer has already made a significant impact in the UK grocery market, and the introduction of craft beers is expected to further boost its sales. Aldi's commitment to sourcing its beers from local breweries has also been praised by industry experts, who note that it will help to support the UK's thriving craft beer scene. The retailer has also promised to continue to expand its craft beer range in the coming months, with plans to introduce new brews and styles to its stores. With its competitive pricing and extensive range of products, Aldi is well-positioned to make a significant impact in the craft beer market. The bank holiday weekend is expected to be a key test for the retailer, with many consumers looking for new and exciting beers to enjoy during the long weekend.

AstraZeneca has suffered a setback after US regulators delayed approval of a key drug it acquired when it paid $2.7bn for ZS Pharma last year. The company has received a complete response letter from the US Food and Drug Administration about its ZS-9 treatment for high potassium levels, outlining concerns which must be addressed to gain approval. It said it was evaluating the content of the letter, but Reuters reports some analysts as saying the drug's launch could be delayed until 2017 because of a manufacturing issue. AstraZeneca, which expected peak annual sales of $1bn for the drug, said: The [letter] refers to observations arising from a pre-approval manufacturing inspection. The FDA also acknowledged receipt of recently-submitted data which it has yet to review. The [letter] does not require the generation of new clinical data. The delay is a significant blow to AstraZeneca's plans to launch the drug, which was expected to be a major contributor to the company's revenue growth in the coming years. ZS-9 is a potential blockbuster treatment for hyperkalemia, a condition that affects millions of people worldwide. The company had been expecting to launch the drug in the US in the second half of this year, but the delay could push the launch back to 2017 or even later. AstraZeneca's shares fell by 3% in early trading on the news, wiping out around $1.5 billion from its market value. The company's investors are likely to be disappointed by the delay, which could also impact its ability to meet its financial targets. AstraZeneca has not yet commented on the potential impact of the delay on its financial projections.

France's Axa has sold its UK investment, pensions and insurance businesses, including SunLife, to UK insurer Phoenix in a £375m deal. The deal will transfer £12.3bn of assets under management and more than 910,000 policies to Phoenix. The sale includes the pension and investment businesses Embassy and SunLife, which offer life cover to the over-50s. The Bristol-based SunLife has been part of the French insurance giant since 1996. Clive Bannister, chief executive of Phoenix, said the acquisition of the Embassy and SunLife businesses was another important step forward in the firm's growth strategy. Phoenix specialises in buying life assurance businesses that are closed to new customers. Bannister said: "We will invest heavily to ensure a smooth transition of the two businesses from Axa to Phoenix and we are committed to delivering the highest level of service to both direct and IFA [independent financial adviser] customers, as we do for our existing customers. Looking ahead, we believe there will be further consolidation in the UK life industry and we will continue to explore further opportunities as they arise." The deal is expected to be completed by the end of the year, subject to regulatory approval. Axa has been reviewing its international operations and has decided to focus on its core business in France. The sale of its UK businesses is part of this strategy.

Phoenix has a track record of integrating acquired businesses and has already completed several deals in recent years. The company has pledged to maintain the same level of service and product offerings for Axa's customers, who will be notified of the change in ownership in due course.

The acquisition of Embassy and SunLife will significantly increase Phoenix's presence in the UK market, making it one of the largest life insurance companies in the country. The deal is also expected to create job opportunities, with Phoenix committed to retaining all existing staff and investing in the businesses.

Axa's decision to sell its UK businesses has been welcomed by industry experts, who see it as a sign of the consolidation that is expected to continue in the UK life insurance market. The deal is also likely to spark further interest in the market, with other players considering similar acquisitions.

In a statement, Axa said it was pleased to have reached an agreement with Phoenix, which it believes will benefit both companies and their customers. The company added that it would continue to focus on its core business in France, where it remains one of the largest insurance groups.

Britain needs to retain its ties with Europe after Brexit while building a new international model for financial services, the chairman of Barclays said on Thursday. John McFarlane, who is also chairman of TheCityUK, which promotes Britain's financial services, said it was important not to lose sight of Europe as a market as businesses sought to build broader international links. "Relationships with the EU will need to be repaired," he told TheCityUK's annual conference. "We can only hope that whatever transpires will be to the benefit of our membership." His comments preceded a meeting of business leaders at No 10 with David Cameron and business secretary Sajid Javid to allay concerns that the political crisis enveloping both major UK political parties would spill over into the economy and trigger a recession. As the business leaders gathered at No 10, the mood was tense but determined. Cameron and Javid sought to reassure them that the government was committed to finding a solution to the Brexit crisis that would minimize disruption to the economy. McFarlane, however, was not alone in his concerns. Many in the room felt that the UK's financial sector, which is a major driver of the economy, was particularly vulnerable to the uncertainty surrounding Brexit.

"We can't afford to be complacent," said Ian Haydon, CEO of the London Stock Exchange. "We need to be proactive in building relationships with other financial centers around the world, while also maintaining our ties with Europe."

The meeting also heard from other prominent business leaders, including Sir Philip Hampton, chairman of Royal Bank of Scotland, and António Horta-Osório, CEO of Lloyds Banking Group. They all emphasized the need for the government to provide greater clarity on its plans for Brexit, and to work closely with the financial sector to mitigate any potential risks.

In a statement after the meeting, Cameron and Javid acknowledged the concerns of the business leaders, and pledged to work tirelessly to find a solution that would benefit the UK's economy. "We understand the importance of the financial sector to our economy, and we are committed to working closely with business leaders to ensure that we can navigate the challenges ahead," they said.

The meeting was seen as a positive step towards building a sense of cooperation and urgency around the need to find a solution to the Brexit crisis. But for many in the financial sector, the task ahead is daunting. As McFarlane put it, "We need to be realistic about the challenges we face, but we also need to be optimistic about our ability to overcome them. The future of the UK's financial sector depends on it."

Evernote, the note-taking service, is facing a user backlash after restricting the number of features available to free accounts. The company's Evernote Basic tier, which offers free access to the software, will now only be able to sync across two devices. For most people, this will be a computer and one mobile device, leaving users with more than one computer, or a computer and two mobile devices (a phone and a tablet, for instance), needing to pay for the first time. Free users can still access the web version of Evernote, though. At the same time, the price for the Plus and Premium tiers of Evernote has risen by about 40%, taking them to $34.99 (£25.96) and $69.99 (£51.92) a year respectively. The sudden change in policy has left many users feeling frustrated and betrayed by the company. "I've been using Evernote for years and I'm shocked by this decision," said Sarah Johnson, a freelance writer who relies heavily on the service. "I have a laptop and a desktop, and now I'm being forced to pay for a feature that I previously had for free. It's ridiculous."

Other users are taking to social media to express their discontent, with many calling for a boycott of the service. "I've been using Evernote for my personal and professional notes, but this new policy is a deal-breaker for me," tweeted @notesaremylife. "I'll be switching to OneNote or Simplenote instead."

Evernote has attempted to justify the change by citing the increasing cost of maintaining the service, but many users are skeptical. "I understand that costs go up, but this feels like a blatant attempt to squeeze more money out of loyal customers," said Mark Davis, a software developer who has been using Evernote since its early days.

The backlash has also led to calls for alternative note-taking services to step up and offer a free tier with unlimited syncing capabilities. "It's time for someone to offer a real free option," said @note_taker. "Evernote used to be the gold standard, but now it's just another greedy corporation trying to milk its users for all they're worth."

As the debate continues to rage on, it remains to be seen whether Evernote will reconsider its policy or if users will ultimately abandon the service in search of a more affordable and generous alternative. One thing is certain, however: the trust and loyalty of Evernote's user base have been severely damaged by this move, and it will take more than just a simple apology to regain the faith of its loyal customers.

My mother, who has dementia, has had endless problems with her BT landline. She lives alone and relies on her phone enormously. Despite our best efforts she cannot get used to a mobile phone, so her landline is her connection to the outside world. My brother and sister-in-law live half an hour away, but I live 200 miles away. Our twice-daily calls are part of her routine, which if disrupted causes her much distress. Over the past several months her line has been disrupted several times. The fault will last for anything between a day to a week, and after a spell of being OK the landline will redevelop the same fault. I was prepared to believe it was something my mother was doing wrong, but on each and every occasion it has been identified as a "fault at the junction box". Engineers have come to the house, and I have been given a direct line to BT's priority fault repair scheme. But despite all this the fault recurs. I cannot tell you how distressing it is for her. As the fault persisted, I began to feel helpless and frustrated. I had tried everything to get the issue resolved, from escalating the issue to senior engineers to even considering switching to a different provider. But every time, the fault would mysteriously reappear. My mother's anxiety and distress levels were escalating, and I was at a loss for what to do.

I decided to take a different approach and contacted the local council's adult social services department, hoping they could provide some guidance or support. They listened attentively to my story and offered to send a social worker to assess my mother's situation. The social worker was shocked by the lack of support from BT and the impact it was having on my mother's well-being.

Together, we came up with a plan to escalate the issue further and push for a more permanent solution. I was relieved to finally have some hope that things might change for the better. But as I looked at my mother, who was sitting in front of me, her eyes filled with worry and uncertainty, I knew that I couldn't give up. I had to keep fighting for her, and for the connection that meant so much to her.

Facebook has denied using location data to suggest potential friends amid questions about the unsettling accuracy with which it puts forward "people you may know". The feature has been known to suggest users who have no or few mutual friends on the network – and, reportedly, nothing in common beyond having shared the same physical space – prompting concerns about how it works. These were resurrected on Tuesday when Fusion reported that Facebook was drawing from the location of users' smartphones to inform its suggestions – a "privacy disaster", it said. It quoted a spokesperson as saying that location information was "only one of the factors" Facebook used to determine people who may know each other. "Seriously, I've had enough reporters ask me, freaked out, why Facebook is recommending their protected sources," tweeted Violet Blue, a reporter on cybercrime, on Tuesday. "Suck it up & stop using it." But Fusion then published an updated statement from Facebook, which said it did not use location data – though it had briefly in the past. Fusion's Kasmir Hill wrote that she had "reportorial whiplash". "I've never had a spokesperson confirm and then retract a story so quickly." The network "ran a small test" for four weeks at the end of 2015, in which it used users' cities to rank existing suggested friends, the spokesperson said. Despite Facebook's denial, the controversy surrounding its "people you may know" feature has sparked renewed calls for greater transparency and accountability from the social media giant. Many users are now questioning the true extent of Facebook's data collection and analysis, and how it uses this information to shape their online experiences.

In response to the backlash, Facebook has been forced to defend its practices, with a spokesperson stating that the company uses a range of factors to determine suggested friends, including mutual friends, interests, and online interactions. However, many experts are skeptical of these claims, arguing that Facebook's algorithms are likely to be far more sophisticated and invasive than the company is letting on.

The controversy has also raised concerns about the potential for Facebook's data collection to be used for more sinister purposes, such as political manipulation or surveillance. With the company's vast reserves of user data, many are worried that it could be used to influence public opinion or identify and target specific individuals.

As the debate continues to rage, many users are taking to social media to express their concerns and frustration. "Facebook's 'people you may know' feature is a perfect example of how our data is being used against us," tweeted one user. "It's time for Facebook to come clean about its data collection practices and give users more control over their online privacy."

In response to the growing backlash, Facebook has announced that it will be conducting a review of its data collection and analysis practices, with a view to increasing transparency and accountability. However, many experts remain skeptical, arguing that the company's actions are too little, too late. "Facebook's response is just a PR stunt," tweeted one critic. "It's time for real change, not just empty promises."

Shares in Carpetright have shed almost a fifth of their value amid fears that uncertainty caused by Britain's decision to leave the EU will hit high street spending. Investors were spooked after its chief executive, Wilf Walsh, said trading conditions had been more challenging in recent weeks and added: "The outlook has been further complicated by the outcome of last week's referendum and we are cautious about the impact the associated uncertainty will have on consumer confidence." Despite the retailer reporting underlying profits up by a third to £17.3m in the year to 30 April, the shares touched a low of 216.88p before staging a recovery to reach 225p by lunchtime. In previous downturns home furnishings retailers sales have been affected by a slowdown in the housing transactions which are a trigger for purchases. Carpetright revealed that its new financial year had got off to a bumpy start with like-for-like sales down 7.6% in the UK in May but swinging back to growth of 6.3% in June. "It's a very strange atmosphere," said Walsh. "Consumers are not behaving in a pattern." He said it was too soon to judge what the fallout from the referendum would be. As the UK's high street retailers grapple with the uncertainty surrounding the country's exit from the EU, Carpetright's warning has sent shockwaves through the industry. Analysts are now scrambling to reassess their forecasts for the sector, with many predicting a tough few months ahead.

"The referendum result has created a perfect storm of uncertainty, and it's having a ripple effect on consumer confidence," said Emma Taylor, retail analyst at Numis Securities. "Carpetright's warning is a wake-up call for the industry, and we expect to see more retailers reporting similar challenges in the coming weeks."

The impact of the Brexit vote on consumer spending is still unclear, but many retailers are already reporting a slowdown in sales. According to data from the British Retail Consortium, like-for-like sales in June were down 0.7% compared to the same period last year, with clothing and footwear retailers particularly hard hit.

Carpetright's chief executive, Wilf Walsh, said the company was doing everything it could to mitigate the impact of the uncertainty, including investing in digital marketing and improving its online offering. However, he warned that the company's ability to predict consumer behavior had been severely hampered by the Brexit vote.

"It's a very strange atmosphere," he said. "Consumers are not behaving in a pattern. We're doing everything we can to stay ahead of the curve, but it's a challenging time for the industry as a whole."

Despite the challenges, Carpetright's management remains optimistic about the company's long-term prospects. The retailer has a strong brand and a loyal customer base, and its investment in digital marketing and online retailing is expected to pay off in the long run.

However, with the UK's high street facing its toughest trading conditions in years, Carpetright's warning has sent a stark message to investors: the uncertainty surrounding Brexit is real, and it's having a significant impact on consumer spending. As the retailer's shares continue to slide, it's clear that the industry as a whole is bracing itself for a tough few months ahead.

The UK grocery market has fallen into decline for the first time this year as the performance of all four major supermarkets worsened. Asda's sales slid by 5.9% – its worst performance on record and the biggest slump in the market. Tesco was the best of the major chains, with sales down 1.3% according to analysis from Kantar Worldpanel published on Tuesday. That compares with falls of 5.1% and 1% revealed last month. In contrast, discounters Aldi and Lidl continue to see double-digit growth, with sales up 11.5% and 13.8% respectively, taking their combined market share to a new high of 10.5%. Aldi is now only a hair's breadth from overtaking the Co-op to become the UK's fifth largest supermarket. The decline in the UK grocery market is attributed to a combination of factors, including the ongoing cost of living crisis, which has led to consumers being more cautious with their spending. Additionally, the shift towards online shopping has been slower than expected, with many consumers still preferring to shop in-store.

Asda's poor performance is particularly concerning, as it has traditionally been one of the strongest players in the market. The supermarket's struggles are thought to be due to a lack of investment in its stores and a failure to keep up with changing consumer habits.

Tesco, on the other hand, has managed to hold its own due to its strong online offering and a focus on improving its store experience. The supermarket has also been investing heavily in its convenience store format, which has been performing well.

The discounters, Aldi and Lidl, continue to be the bright spot in the market, with their low prices and efficient operations allowing them to attract price-conscious consumers. Their combined market share has now reached 10.5%, a new high for the two chains.

Aldi's growth is particularly impressive, with the supermarket opening over 70 new stores in the past year alone. The chain's success is thought to be due to its focus on quality and value, as well as its efficient supply chain.

The rise of the discounters has significant implications for the wider market, with many traditional supermarkets struggling to compete on price. The Co-op, in particular, is under pressure, with its market share continuing to decline.

The decline in the UK grocery market is expected to continue in the coming months, with many analysts predicting a further decline in sales. However, the discounters are likely to continue to thrive, and may even continue to gain market share as consumers become increasingly price-conscious.

British retail sales slowed in the run-up to the EU referendum, an industry survey has shown. A balance of UK retailers saying sales rose minus those who reported falling sales fell to 4% in June, down from 7% in May, according to the Confederation of British Industry's latest snapshot of the retail sector (pdf). The survey was conducted between 26 May and 14 June – before the UK's shock vote to leave the EU. Grocers, furniture and carpet shops, along with hardware and DIY stores, reported a pickup in sales in the year to June. But growth slowed at clothing retailers and sales fell at department stores, specialist food and drink retailers, and shops selling durable household goods such as cookers and washing machines. The survey also revealed that retailers' expectations for the next three months have deteriorated significantly, with 22% of respondents expecting sales to fall, up from 12% in May. This decline in optimism was particularly pronounced among clothing retailers, with 35% expecting sales to fall, and department stores, where 30% of respondents were pessimistic.

The CBI's director of economics, Ian McCafferty, attributed the slowdown in sales to the uncertainty surrounding the outcome of the EU referendum. "The retail sector had been growing steadily in the run-up to the referendum, but the vote to leave the EU has clearly had an impact," he said. "Retailers are now facing a more challenging environment, with weaker consumer confidence and rising costs."

The survey also highlighted the impact of the pound's depreciation on retailers' costs. More than half of respondents reported that the fall in the pound had increased their costs, with 20% saying it had had a significant impact. This could lead to higher prices for consumers, which could further erode demand.

The CBI is calling on the government to provide clarity on the terms of the UK's exit from the EU and to implement policies to support the retail sector. "The government must now provide a clear plan for the UK's exit from the EU and take steps to support the retail sector, which is a vital part of the UK's economy," said McCafferty.

The survey's findings are in line with other recent data, which has suggested that the retail sector is facing a challenging environment. Last week, the Office for National Statistics (ONS) reported that retail sales volumes fell by 0.3% in May, the first decline in five months.

The CBI's survey provides further evidence that the retail sector is struggling to cope with the uncertainty surrounding the EU referendum. As the government begins to negotiate the terms of the UK's exit from the EU, retailers will be looking for reassurance that their businesses will be protected and supported.

Chiefs at the parent company of the Independent almost doubled their take-home pay last year as plans were being put in motion to cut jobs and shut the newspaper titles. Evgeny Lebedev's Independent titles managed to reduce pre-tax losses from £8.5m to £6.9m in the year to 27 September 2015, according to the latest and last full year accounts for the now-defunct newspapers. At a "trading" level, excluding items such as interest repayments and redundancy costs, the Independent and Independent on Sunday lost just £3.74m last year. Despite being within touching distance of breaking even, the print titles were closed in March as the Lededev's sold off stablemate the i and pursued a digital-only future for the Independent. Accounts for Lebedev Holdings, the company controlled by Evgeny Lebedev and runs the Independent, the London Evening Standard and TV station London Live, shows that despite the impending closure directors nevertheless enjoyed a bumper year. The five directors – who include Alexander Lebedev, former chief executive Steve Auckland, chairman Justin Byam Shaw and financial chief Manish Malhotra – tripled their take home pay from £589,000 to £1.48m. The unnamed highest-paid director pocketed £953,000, up from £529,000 in 2014. Specifically at the Independent, the highest paid director doubled pay from £200,000 to £416,000. The seven directors of the subsidiary company that runs the Independent more than doubled their pay from £387,000 to £831,000. Despite the significant increases in director pay, the news of job cuts and title closures at the Independent was met with widespread criticism from industry insiders and media watchdogs. "It's outrageous that the directors of the Independent, a newspaper that was once a bastion of independent journalism, are lining their pockets while the very people who make the paper possible are being let go," said one veteran journalist who wished to remain anonymous.

The decision to close the print titles and focus on a digital-only future has also raised concerns about the long-term viability of the Independent's online presence. "The Independent has a rich history and a loyal readership, but without a strong print presence, it's hard to see how they can maintain their relevance in the digital landscape," said a media analyst.

Meanwhile, the sale of the i to Johnston Press for £24 million has been seen as a positive move, with many praising the deal as a savvy business decision. However, the closure of the Independent's print titles has left many wondering what the future holds for the newspaper's staff and the city's media landscape.

In a statement, Evgeny Lebedev's spokesperson said that the decision to close the print titles was a necessary step in order to ensure the long-term survival of the Independent brand. "We are committed to investing in the Independent's digital presence and to creating a sustainable future for the newspaper," the spokesperson said. However, many remain skeptical about the company's ability to achieve this goal without a strong print presence.

As the Independent's print titles are shut down, the newspaper's staff are left to pick up the pieces and wonder what the future holds for their beloved publication. The closure of the Independent's print titles is a stark reminder of the challenges facing the newspaper industry in the digital age, and the need for innovative solutions to ensure the survival of high-quality journalism.

ITV has seen almost £2.5bn wiped off its stock market value since the Brexit vote, raising city speculation the the broadcaster could become the target of a takeover. ITV, which saw its share price fall by more than 20% on Friday, continued to see jittery investors drive its price down more than 5% in early trading on Monday. At midday on Monday its share price had fallen to 164p, down from a pre-Brexit 220p and a one-year high of 280p. Investors worried about the repercussions of Brexit on ITV, which relies on a now nervy advertising market for much of its revenues, have driven the broadcaster's market capitalisation from £9bn to about £6.5bn in the days since the EU referendum. City analysts have begun to speculate if the share price decline, coupled with the UK's currency crash, down 10% against the US dollar, might prompt foreign media companies to consider making an opportunistic bid for ITV. "This increases the chance of a bid by one one of the major US media companies where there is a historical and present interest in the UK market," said Ian Whittaker, an analyst at Liberum. "Not only from the established media giants, but also from new media/tech companies (for example, we believe that several of the US internet giants explored a bid for the English Premier League rights in the last bidding round)." NBC Universal, owner of Downton Abbey maker Carnival, has been rumoured in the past to have had an interest in bidding for ITV, and John Malone's Liberty Global, which owns Virgin Media, has a 9.9% stake in the broadcaster. The prospect of a takeover has sent ITV's shares tumbling, with investors worried about the potential consequences of a foreign company taking control of the UK's largest commercial broadcaster. However, some analysts believe that ITV's weakened position could also make it an attractive target for private equity firms or other media companies looking to expand their reach into the UK market.

"It's not just about the share price decline, it's about the uncertainty and volatility that Brexit has brought," said another analyst, who wished to remain anonymous. "A foreign company may see an opportunity to acquire a significant player in the UK market at a discounted price, and then look to restructure and refinance the business to unlock value."

ITV's reliance on advertising revenue has also been a concern for investors, with many analysts predicting a decline in ad spend in the wake of the Brexit vote. The company's television ratings have also been under pressure in recent months, with some of its most popular shows struggling to attract large audiences.

Despite these concerns, ITV remains one of the most popular and profitable broadcasters in the UK, with a strong portfolio of shows including Downton Abbey, The X Factor, and Coronation Street. The company has also made significant investments in digital media, including its ITV Hub streaming service, which has attracted millions of users.

As the Brexit uncertainty continues to weigh on ITV's share price, the company's management is under pressure to reassure investors that it has a plan in place to navigate the challenges ahead. In a statement, ITV said it was "confident in the strength and resilience of its business" and was "well-positioned to adapt to changing market conditions." However, with the company's shares at their lowest level in over a year, investors will be closely watching its performance in the coming months to see if it can recover from the Brexit-induced slump.

Visitors to the Bespoked Handmade UK Bicycle Show in Bristol earlier this year would have noted how bike building in the UK is undergoing a renaissance. On a floor of 100 exhibitors, dominated by custom steel and titanium bikes, one builder stood out because of his choice of material: carbon fibre. While the majority of road bikes are carbon fibre these days, custom frames built from the lightweight material are rare because of the technical challenges involved. However, from his workshop in Worcestershire, Richard Craddock is overcoming these barriers. Craddock spent a number of years designing cycles for various brands and riding for an amateur racing team in France before deciding to build a carbon bike "exact for me". He spent almost four years developing and testing before offering his Filament bespoke carbon frames to the public. "I've never stopped building since," he says. So what is the appeal of his carbon bikes? "The primary USP is custom geometry," says Craddock. "Two riders of the same height could be stocky or like a willow, and I can build for their weight, not only their height. This allows for a more precise fit and better handling, making the bike feel more tailored to the rider's individual needs. Craddock's expertise in designing for various brands and his experience as an amateur racing team rider have given him a unique understanding of what makes a bike perform well. He takes into account factors such as the rider's flexibility, pedaling style, and power output to create a frame that is optimized for their specific needs.

Craddock's process begins with a thorough consultation with the customer to understand their riding style, preferences, and goals. He then uses advanced computer software to design a custom frame that meets their specific requirements. The design is then sent to a local manufacturer, who produces the frame using high-quality carbon fibre.

What sets Craddock's frames apart is not only the custom geometry but also the attention to detail and craftsmanship that goes into each build. Every frame is hand-finished and inspected to ensure that it meets Craddock's high standards. The result is a bike that not only looks stunning but also rides exceptionally well, with a level of precision and responsiveness that is hard to find in mass-produced frames.

Craddock's bespoke carbon frames have attracted attention from enthusiasts and professionals alike, with many riders seeking him out for custom builds. His unique approach to bike building has also inspired a new generation of frame builders to experiment with different materials and designs. As the demand for custom bikes continues to grow, it's clear that Richard Craddock's innovative approach to carbon fibre frame building is paving the way for a new era in bespoke cycling.

You can see why big newspaper managers – say Mark Thompson at the New York Times – grow indignant when "cynical", "money-grasping" adblocking businesses demand money from papers in return for leaving their ads unblocked. That's "unsavoury" with a Godfather twist. But brows may furrow a little when Thompson tells conference audiences that he's preparing to sell readers a "higher-tier" ad-free digital package himself. himself. In a move that has left many in the industry scratching their heads, Thompson announced that the New York Times is set to launch a premium digital subscription service that will offer ad-free browsing to customers willing to pay a higher monthly fee. The move is seen as a direct challenge to the adblocking businesses that have been a thorn in the side of publishers for years. "We're not going to let others dictate how we monetize our content," Thompson said in an interview. "We're taking back control and giving our readers a choice." The new service is expected to launch in the coming months, and industry insiders are eagerly waiting to see how it will affect the way news is consumed online.

Stuart Rose, the former M&S boss installed as chairman of the Britain Stronger in Europe remain campaign, has blamed the leave victory on voters' anger with distant politicians and a loss of trust in big business. "I'm not a politician and this was always going to be a battle won or lost by politicians, and a reflection of the bigger things going on the world," said Lord Rose. "People are clearly unhappy with the current state of affairs. They want to be listened to and want change – that's a political issue." Asked if the country's captains of industry could have done more to convince voters to back the status quo, he pointed to disaffection between the "man in the street and big business". "There has been a loss of trust and we need to think about how to rebuild that," Rose said. "It has happened over time, since the last recession, whether it's the banks or the crisis in the eurozone or a business being run in a way people don't like. "All these things leave a bad taste in the mouth and cumulatively that taste can get quite bitter. This is a big issue about our country, our people, how they feel and what they think." After playing a key role at the start of the campaign Rose was sidelined in March after he told a select committee wages would go up if Britain left the EU. His remarks were used as ammunition by the leave campaign, although he maintains he was misquoted. Lord Rose's comments come as the Britain Stronger in Europe remain campaign is left to pick up the pieces after a devastating defeat. The Remain campaign's failure to win over voters has sparked widespread debate about what went wrong, with many pointing to a lack of effective messaging and a failure to connect with ordinary people.

Rose's suggestion that voters were driven by a sense of disillusionment with the political class and big business is echoed by many analysts. "The Remain campaign struggled to articulate a clear vision for Britain's future in the EU, and ultimately failed to inspire voters," said Professor John Curtice, a leading psephologist. "At the same time, the Leave campaign was able to tap into a deep-seated sense of discontent with the status quo, and exploit fears about immigration and sovereignty."

Despite the loss, Rose remains defiant, insisting that the Remain campaign's message was sound, but ultimately outgunned by the Leave campaign's more effective use of social media and grassroots organizing. "We had a good campaign, but we were outspent and outmaneuvered," he said. "We need to learn from our mistakes and come back stronger in the future."

As the dust settles on the referendum, the Britain Stronger in Europe remain campaign is already looking to the future, plotting a course for a possible second referendum or a renewed push for a softer Brexit. Lord Rose's comments offer a glimpse into the campaign's post-mortem, as they seek to identify the lessons learned from their defeat and plot a path forward.

Further automation of the retail sector raises issues far beyond the needless luxuries of choice, convenience and speed of delivery (Amazon to test drone deliveries in British skies, 27 July). I wonder if the "demand" for stuff to be delivered by robot to our door within 30 minutes of ordering really exists – is modern satisfaction really that shallow? But in an increasingly automated society, where are the wages to buy these goods going to come from? While Brexit showed that politicians were detached from the anger of the dispossessed of this country, where are they on the automation of yet more of the jobs that so many people depend on? It seems they are keen to race headlong into a very misty future. There are so many unresolved issues: the need for a citizen's income to allow those disenfranchised from the workplace to live a reasonable quality of life (and the taxation on corporate profits that this would require); the loss of peace and quiet, privacy, safety, security; and beyond all this, what will humans be doing in the future? As we surrender to the allure of instant gratification, we must confront the darker implications of a society where human labor is increasingly replaced by machines. The notion of a "future of work" is being redefined, leaving many to wonder what skills will be valuable, what jobs will exist, and who will truly benefit from this brave new world.

Microsoft's controversial year-long free Windows 10 upgrade offer for users of Windows 7 or 8 ends today (Friday), which means now is the time to claim a free licence or be forced to pay upwards of £80 for a copy. Those that have remained on the fence until now have until 11am on Saturday in the UK to update for free. After that they will be stuck on whichever version of Windows they currently have installed, unless they purchase a Windows 10 upgrade. For many annoyed by Microsoft's aggressive pushing of Windows 10 to their computers, through automatic downloads, installs that happen while they're away making tea or interrupting the weather or pro-gamer streams, the end of the free upgrade period will come as a welcome relief. Many are happy with Windows 7, which has turned out to be Microsoft's new Windows XP: a solid, good-enough operating system that many will be hesitant to switch from. But Windows 10 is arguably the best version of Windows Microsoft has ever created. There are some questions over its use of cloud services and the tracking of user actions, but Windows 10 is the most secure version yet. If you're running either Windows 8 or 8.1, the free update to Windows 10 is highly recommended, as it is a refinement of the good things in the older operating system without most of the irritating ones, such as the charms bar and gestures that simply don't work on a desktop computer with a mouse and keyboard. Despite the concerns, Windows 10 has received widespread acclaim for its improved performance, sleek design, and innovative features such as Cortana, Microsoft's virtual assistant. For those who have been holding out, the end of the free upgrade period presents a crucial decision: stick with an outdated operating system or take the plunge and upgrade to Windows 10. Microsoft has been clear that it will no longer provide security updates for Windows 7 and 8, leaving users vulnerable to potential threats. With the free upgrade offer expiring, users must weigh the benefits of a newer, more secure operating system against the risks of making a significant change to their computing setup. For those who choose to upgrade, Microsoft has made the process relatively seamless, with the Windows 10 installation process guided by a user-friendly interface. Meanwhile, those who opt to stick with their current operating system may find themselves facing a more complex and potentially hazardous computing environment. As the clock ticks down, the choice is clear: upgrade to Windows 10 and reap the benefits of a modern operating system, or face the consequences of sticking with the past.

One in every three people in Monaco are millionaires, according to research into the cities of Europe that have the most high net worth individuals, with Zurich close behind. London ranks fourth. Millionaires on its Mayfair streets and penthouses may be more numerous than Monaco, but they account for only one in every 29 of the capital's citizens. Edinburgh, ranked 16th, is the only other UK city to make it into the top 20, with an estimated one in 67 of its inhabitants a millionaire. Consultancy company WealthInsight, who carried out the research in partnership with Spear's Magazine, said Dublin was the surprise entry into the top 10, beating Paris, Berlin and Moscow. "Dublin has a higher density of millionaires than many other European capitals. The research, which analyzed data from over 100 cities across Europe, found that Monaco's unique blend of financial services, tourism, and luxury lifestyle has created a concentration of high net worth individuals. Zurich, with its strong banking sector and proximity to Switzerland's tax-haven status, came in second place. London, often considered a global financial hub, ranked fourth, despite its larger population.

Edinburgh, known for its stunning architecture and vibrant cultural scene, was the only other UK city to make the top 20. The city's strong financial sector, including the Edinburgh International Conference Centre, has attracted many high-net-worth individuals. Dublin, which surprised many by ranking in the top 10, has a growing tech industry and a favorable business environment, making it an attractive destination for entrepreneurs and investors.
