British Gas lost almost 400,000 customers in the first six months of 2016 as greater competition among suppliers encouraged households to switch. The company's parent, Centrica, said falling gas and power prices had brought new suppliers to the market, intensifying the rivalry for customers. The 3% fall in UK home customers was also the result of a significant number of long-term contracts coming to an end at the same time, leaving British Gas with 14.26m accounts. Customer numbers started rising again in June, it said. Despite the decline in customer numbers, British Gas reported a 2% increase in revenue for the first half of 2016, driven by a 4% rise in average energy prices. The company's revenue grew to £10.3 billion, up from £10.1 billion in the same period last year.

British Gas's performance was affected by the cost of integrating its energy and services businesses, which added £100 million to its costs. However, the company's operating profit rose 5% to £1.3 billion, helped by a reduction in administrative expenses.

The company's CEO, Iain Conn, said: "We're adapting to a changing market and investing in our business to ensure we remain competitive. We're focused on providing excellent service to our customers and delivering value to our shareholders."

British Gas is facing increasing competition from smaller, agile suppliers that are able to offer cheaper prices and more flexible tariffs. The company has responded by launching its own cheaper tariffs and improving its customer service.

In addition to its UK home customer base, British Gas also supplies energy to businesses and industries, as well as providing energy and services to households in the United States. The company's international operations generated £1.4 billion in revenue in the first half of 2016, up 6% on the same period last year.

Despite the challenges it faces, British Gas remains one of the largest energy suppliers in the UK, with a market share of around 25%. The company's parent, Centrica, is committed to investing in British Gas and ensuring its long-term success.

Britain's top company bosses went on a share-buying spree in the immediate aftermath of the EU referendum, spending more money on their own stock than at any time in the last decade. Directors of FTSE 100 and FTSE 250 companies have spent more than £18.5m buying shares in their own firms since the 23 June vote, according to data compiled for FT Money by the broker Olivetree Financial. "This is the largest amount of individual director buys in at least 10 years," Olivetree said. The sectors that were hardest hit by the news of Brexit – banks, housebuilders, retailers and travel companies – saw the biggest director purchases. Many boardroom directors have done well out of these deals as stock markets bounced back following days of dramatic falls when tens of billions of pounds were wiped off the London stock market. The biggest share buys came in late June and early July. As the dust settled on the initial market volatility, company directors continued to snap up shares in their own companies, with many opting to buy during a period of relative calm. According to Olivetree Financial, the total amount spent by directors on their own stock reached £20.2m by the end of July, with the majority of transactions taking place in the weeks following the referendum.

The buying spree was led by directors at companies such as Barclays, Royal Bank of Scotland, and HSBC, which saw significant declines in their share prices in the immediate aftermath of the Brexit vote. However, as markets stabilized and the UK's economic outlook began to come into focus, these same directors saw an opportunity to bolster their personal wealth.

In a statement, Olivetree Financial said: "The level of director buying activity is a clear indication of the confidence they have in their companies' prospects. While the immediate impact of Brexit was negative, many directors believe that the long-term outlook remains strong and are taking advantage of the opportunity to increase their stake in their own firms."

The buying activity has sparked concerns among some investors, who fear that the directors' purchases may be a sign of insider knowledge or a lack of transparency around the companies' financial prospects. However, many analysts argue that the directors' confidence in their companies is a positive sign for investors, and that the buying activity is a reflection of the underlying strength of the businesses.

McDonald's plans to create more than 5,000 new jobs in the UK by the end of 2017, in a vote of confidence in the economy after the EU referendum. The company will open 25 new restaurants, extend opening hours at existing sites and introduce new initiatives such as table service. Greg Clark, the business secretary, said the announcement was "great news for the UK economy". He added: "The government is committed to ensuring businesses have the support they need to thrive and today's announcement underlines that businesses are confident that the UK remains open for business." McDonald's is pushing ahead with its expansion plans despite Britain voting to leave the EU, which has sparked fears of a slowdown in the economy and businesses pulling investment out of the country. Paul Pomroy, the chief executive of McDonald's UK, said all of the jobs would be permanent, with full-time and part-time roles. The new jobs will be created across the UK, with a focus on areas where the company already has a strong presence. McDonald's plans to invest £100 million in the UK in 2017, with a significant portion of that going towards the creation of new jobs and the opening of new restaurants.

The company's expansion plans also include the introduction of new menu items and promotions, which are designed to appeal to a wider range of customers. McDonald's is also investing in its digital capabilities, including the introduction of mobile ordering and self-service kiosks in its restaurants.

The announcement has been welcomed by the government, which has been keen to demonstrate that the UK remains an attractive place to do business despite the uncertainty surrounding Brexit. Business Secretary Greg Clark said: "This is great news for the UK economy and shows that businesses are confident in the UK's future."

The news has also been welcomed by local authorities and communities across the UK, who will benefit from the creation of new jobs and the investment in local infrastructure. McDonald's has a long history of investing in the communities where it operates, and the company is committed to continuing this tradition as it expands across the UK.

The company's plans are part of a broader trend of investment in the UK economy, which has seen a number of major companies announce new projects and investments in recent months. Despite the uncertainty surrounding Brexit, many businesses remain confident in the UK's long-term prospects and are continuing to invest in the country.

For McDonald's employees, the announcement is a welcome boost, with many set to benefit from the creation of new jobs and the introduction of new initiatives. The company's chief executive, Paul Pomroy, said: "We are committed to providing a great place to work for our employees and are excited to be creating new opportunities for people across the UK."

Pro-EU newspaper the New European is to continue publishing beyond its four-week trial period after beating its sales targets, its publisher has announced. Billed as the newspaper for the 48% of the UK that voted to remain in the EU in the 23 June referendum, the New European's first edition is thought to have sold more than 40,000 copies. Subsequent issues have also sold well, leading publisher Archant to decide to continue producing it on a rolling basis, though the company has made it clear it will pull the plug if interest wanes. The decision to continue publishing the New European is a significant boost to the Remain campaign, which has been struggling to find its voice in the aftermath of the Brexit vote. The newspaper's editor, Iain Hollingshead, said he was "thrilled" by the response to the paper, which has been praised for its in-depth analysis of EU affairs and its commitment to holding the government to account.

"We're delighted that our readers have responded so positively to the New European," Hollingshead said. "We believe that there is a real need for a newspaper that is dedicated to covering the EU and its impact on the UK, and we're proud to be filling that gap."

The New European's success has also been welcomed by pro-EU politicians, who see the newspaper as a vital part of the campaign to keep the UK in the EU. "The New European is a fantastic addition to the media landscape," said Liberal Democrat leader Tim Farron. "It's a newspaper that is committed to telling the truth about the EU and its benefits, and I'm delighted to see it doing so well."

The newspaper's success is also a significant coup for Archant, the company that publishes it. The company has been struggling in recent years, and the New European's success is seen as a major boost to its fortunes. "We're thrilled that the New European is doing so well," said Archant's chief executive, John Fry. "It's a great example of our ability to adapt to changing market conditions and to produce high-quality content that resonates with readers."

First it was Grexit, then it was Brexit. Now the looming threat for Europe is Quitaly, the fear that Italy might decide it has had enough of the single currency and go back to the lira. Put simply, Italy's economy is floundering and has been for the past two decades during which time there has been virtually no growth and Italian goods have become less and less competitive in export markets. Sluggish growth and high levels of unemployment are reflected in the high level of non-performing loans that are now hobbling Italian banks. Potential bad debts have almost doubled to €360bn (£300bn) in the past five years and now account for 18% of all outstanding loans. What is clear, though, is that the non-performing loans reflect a non-performing economy. They are the symptom of the problem and not its cause. As the Italian economy continues to stagnate, the pressure is mounting on the government to take drastic action. The European Union has been urging Italy to implement reforms to boost growth and competitiveness, but so far, the country has been slow to respond. The EU has also been providing financial support to Italian banks to help them absorb the bad debts, but this has only delayed the inevitable.

The fear of Quitaly is not just a theoretical possibility, but a real concern for many economists and financial experts. Italy is the third-largest economy in the eurozone, and if it were to leave the single currency, it could have a devastating impact on the entire region. The consequences would be far-reaching, with potential repercussions for global financial markets and trade.

The Italian government has been trying to reassure the markets that it has a plan to get the economy back on track, but so far, the measures have been piecemeal and ineffective. The country needs a comprehensive strategy to address its structural issues, including a bloated public sector, high taxes, and a lack of investment in infrastructure and innovation.

As the situation continues to deteriorate, the risk of Quitaly is growing, and the EU is scrambling to find a solution. The European Central Bank has been providing emergency loans to Italian banks, and the EU has been offering financial support to the government. However, these measures are only a temporary fix, and the underlying problems need to be addressed. The fate of the eurozone and the global economy hangs in the balance, as the world waits with bated breath to see what will happen next.

Google is taking action against spam callers with a new version of its phone app for Android devices that identifies and helps blocks spammers. The phone app update, which is part of Google's efforts to separate core phone features from operating system updates, is available for the company's Nexus line of smartphones and Android One devices, including the Nexus 6P and Nexus 5X. The new spam-blocking feature is an extension of Google's caller ID system, which helps identify businesses not stored in your address book, and has been available for several years now. The phone app checks incoming call numbers against an updating database and flags those that appear to be from spammers with a big red banner. The new feature will also allow users to report suspicious calls, which will help Google's database of spam numbers to stay up-to-date. This will enable the app to become even more effective at blocking unwanted calls in the future. Additionally, the update includes a new "screened calls" feature, which will allow users to send suspicious calls directly to voicemail, preventing them from ringing through to the user's phone.

Google's move to combat spam calls is a welcome one, as many users have been frustrated by the growing number of unwanted calls they receive. According to a report by the Federal Trade Commission, Americans received over 48 billion robocalls in 2018 alone, with the average person receiving over 22 calls per month. Google's new feature is just one part of a larger effort to combat spam calls, and it is hoped that it will help to reduce the number of unwanted calls that users receive. The update is available now for Nexus and Android One devices, and is expected to roll out to other Android devices in the coming weeks.

Almost half of lettings agents are reporting nervous landlords following Brexit, with 12% reporting asking rents have fallen over the past 10 days. In a report published on Monday, the Association of Residential Letting Agents (Arla) says last month's referendum vote has not rocked the rental market "yet", however, uncertainty over the future of Britain's role in Europe is making landlords jittery. One in nine agents told Arla they have experienced an immediate dip in rents following last month's Brexit result. Soaring rents, particularly in London and the south-east, have been partly pushed upwards by recent arrivals from abroad, as well as a lack of available properties to rent. David Cox, managing director of Arla said the rental market has so far responded to Brexit in a calm fashion but warned continued uncertainty could cause turbulence in the rental market over the coming months. However, despite the calm initial reaction, many agents are bracing themselves for a potential downturn in the rental market. The uncertainty surrounding the UK's future relationship with the EU is causing landlords to become increasingly anxious, with some already starting to pull out of the market or delaying decisions to invest in new properties.

According to the Arla report, 44% of agents reported that landlords are now more cautious about investing in the rental market, with 22% saying they are delaying decisions to purchase new properties. This is likely to have a ripple effect on the wider economy, as the rental market plays a significant role in supporting local businesses and communities.

The impact of Brexit on the rental market is also being felt in terms of the types of properties that are being rented out. Agents are reporting a surge in demand for short-term lets, such as holiday lets and short-term rentals, as investors seek to diversify their portfolios and mitigate the risks associated with the uncertainty surrounding the UK's future in the EU.

Meanwhile, the supply of long-term rentals is drying up, with many landlords opting to sell their properties rather than continue to rent them out. This is likely to lead to a shortage of available rentals in the coming months, which could drive up prices and make it even more difficult for renters to find affordable accommodation.

Overall, while the rental market has so far responded to Brexit in a calm fashion, the uncertainty surrounding the UK's future in the EU is likely to have a significant impact on the sector in the coming months. As the situation continues to unfold, it remains to be seen how the rental market will adapt and whether the sector will be able to weather the storm.

The number of applications to build new shops fell by 9% in the past year, according to a report on Monday, marking the seventh decline in a row. There were 6,700 applications for new retail developments in 2015, down from 7,360, according to commercial law firm EMW. They are down by nearly a half from the pre-recession peak of 11,900 in 2008. The fall shows the continuing pressures on shopkeepers as consumers desert the high street in favour of online shopping with e-commerce companies. The decline in applications to build new shops is a stark reminder of the challenges facing the retail industry, which has been grappling with the rise of online shopping for several years. The report highlights the difficulties faced by shopkeepers as they struggle to compete with the convenience and competitive pricing offered by e-commerce companies.

According to EMW, the decline in applications is not limited to any particular region or type of retail development. Cities, towns, and rural areas have all seen a decrease in the number of applications, suggesting that the problem is widespread.

The decline in physical retail spaces is also having a ripple effect on the wider economy. Many local communities rely on their high streets as a hub of activity, providing employment and services to residents. As more shops close, these communities are at risk of losing their vitality and character.

Despite the challenges, some retailers are finding ways to adapt to the changing retail landscape. Many are investing in their online presence, offering click-and-collect services, and creating immersive in-store experiences to attract customers.

However, not all retailers have the resources to make these changes, and many are struggling to stay afloat. The decline in applications to build new shops is a worrying sign for the industry, and it remains to be seen how it will evolve in the coming years.

In the meantime, policymakers and business leaders are calling for action to support the high street. This includes measures to reduce business rates, improve transport links, and increase footfall through initiatives such as street festivals and events.

Ultimately, the future of the high street will depend on the ability of retailers to adapt to changing consumer habits and the willingness of policymakers to support them. As the retail landscape continues to evolve, one thing is clear: the decline in applications to build new shops is a wake-up call for the industry to rethink its strategy and find new ways to thrive.

PricewaterhouseCoopers has been fined £2.3m by the accountancy watchdog over its auditing of the subprime lender Cattles and its biggest division, Welcome Financial Services, in 2007. The Financial Reporting Council (FRC) also issued the accountancy firm with a severe reprimand. The fine was reduced from £3.5m after mitigation and a settlement discount. In addition, PwC has to pay £750,000 towards the FRC's costs. The FRC said the £3.5m original fine would have been the largest ever. In early 2015, Deloitte was fined £3m over its dealings with the collapsed carmaker MG Rover after that was reduced from a £14m penalty following an appeal. The fine and reprimand are the latest in a string of high-profile penalties imposed on major accountancy firms in recent years. The FRC's decision comes after a lengthy investigation into PwC's auditing of Cattles and Welcome Financial Services, which collapsed in 2009 owing billions of pounds to creditors.

The FRC's investigation found that PwC had failed to properly assess the financial health of the companies, and had not adequately warned investors about the risks associated with their business. The watchdog also found that PwC had not properly documented its auditing procedures, and had not adequately supervised its staff.

PwC has accepted the fine and reprimand, and has agreed to implement new measures to improve its auditing practices. The firm has also apologized for its mistakes and has promised to do better in the future.

The fine is a significant blow to PwC's reputation, and is likely to have a negative impact on the firm's business. However, it is worth noting that the fine is significantly lower than the original £3.5m penalty that the FRC had initially proposed.

The FRC's decision is the latest in a series of high-profile penalties imposed on major accountancy firms in recent years. In 2015, Deloitte was fined £3m over its dealings with the collapsed carmaker MG Rover, and in 2016, KPMG was fined £3.5m over its auditing of the collapsed construction company, Carillion.

The FRC's investigation into PwC's auditing of Cattles and Welcome Financial Services is the latest in a series of investigations into the auditing practices of major accountancy firms. The watchdog has been critical of the industry's practices, and has called for greater transparency and accountability.

The fine and reprimand are a reminder of the importance of proper auditing practices, and the need for accountancy firms to prioritize transparency and accountability. The FRC's decision is a significant step forward in promoting greater transparency and accountability in the accountancy industry, and is likely to have a positive impact on the industry as a whole.

Microsoft has been forced to apologise after its Bing translation service suggested that the Arabic name for Islamic State "Daesh" meant "Saudi Arabia" in English. The blunder was spotted by Saudi social media users, who called for a boycott of all Microsoft products, causing the mistranslation to go viral, and leading to a public outcry. The mistake was quickly flagged by Saudi social media users, who took to Twitter to express their outrage and demand an explanation from Microsoft. The hashtag #BoycottMicrosoft began trending in the region, with many users vowing to delete their Microsoft accounts and switch to rival services. Microsoft's mistake was seen as a grave insult to the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, and many users felt that the company's lack of cultural sensitivity was unacceptable.

In a statement, Microsoft apologized for the error and promised to take immediate action to correct the translation. "We are deeply sorry for the mistake and any offense it may have caused," the company said. "We understand the importance of accurate and respectful translation, and we will take steps to ensure that our services meet the highest standards of cultural sensitivity and accuracy." The company also offered to meet with Saudi officials to discuss the issue and prevent similar mistakes in the future.

Fiona Millar (Education, 23 August) lists arguments made for grammar schools, including the "thoroughly unscientific idea that there are 'clever' children and the rest". Those who believe 11-year-olds are inherently of two types, academic sheep and practical goats, should consider some real-life examples. Is the child who excels at maths but finds it hard to string two sentences together a sheep or a goat? What about the one who likes reading and writing but loves drawing and making things? Or the talented refugee who performs poorly in the 11-plus because she's not yet fluent in English? Is the child who falls just below the dividing line in test results because he's missed weeks of schooling through homelessness really a goat? Is the one who scrapes through because of private tuition really a sheep? The whole idea is a nonsense, as is the idea that two types of school are needed to provide sheep-education and goat-education. Janet Dobson London • I was delighted to read the letter from Michael Liversidge (24 August) in which he outlined his academic successes despite his poor performance at O-level. It's refreshing to hear from someone who has personally experienced the limitations of the traditional academic route. Michael's story serves as a powerful reminder that success is not solely dependent on grades or academic achievement. His experiences highlight the importance of recognizing and valuing diverse strengths and abilities.

It's also worth noting that the notion of "sheep" and "goats" is not only simplistic but also ignores the complex interplay of factors that influence a child's academic performance. Factors such as socio-economic background, access to resources, and individual learning styles all play a significant role in shaping a child's educational journey.

The debate around grammar schools often focuses on the benefits of academic selection, but what about the children who are left behind? The ones who don't make the cut, who are deemed "unacademic" or "not suitable" for grammar school education. What about their needs and aspirations? Don't they deserve an education that values their unique strengths and abilities?

In reality, our education system should be designed to cater to the diverse needs of all children, not just those who excel in traditional academic subjects. By recognizing and celebrating individual differences, we can create a more inclusive and supportive learning environment that fosters creativity, critical thinking, and personal growth.

It's time to move beyond the outdated and misguided notion of "sheep" and "goats" and towards a more nuanced understanding of what it means to be a successful and well-rounded individual. By doing so, we can create a more equitable and effective education system that benefits all children, regardless of their academic abilities or backgrounds.

My 19-year-old son seems to have developed a phobia of interviews and refuses to apply for any job that involves one. This means he is restricted to either not working or doing contract labourer jobs where he is self-employed, the rates are terrible and the work day is long and hard. He is introverted and not a great talker. He left school with six GCSE's at C grade, including maths, English language and science, which we thought was pretty good, considering he never liked school and struggled with most subjects (I think he is dyslexic). He started a BTec in engineering but dropped out without completing the course. The problems seemed to start when he was 16, when he applied for weekend work at two big supermarkets. He did his best at the interviews, but was asked at one to give a two-minute presentation, which frightened the life out of him. Since then, he has become increasingly anxious about interviews, often citing the presentation at the supermarket as the catalyst for his phobia. His lack of confidence has led to a vicious cycle of avoidance, where he refuses to apply for jobs that might lead to an interview. We've tried to reassure him that it's normal to feel nervous, but he's convinced that he'll fail or make a fool of himself. His self-employment options are limited, and he's struggling to make ends meet. As a parent, it's heartbreaking to see him struggle, especially when he's capable of so much more. We're at a loss for how to help him overcome his phobia and get back on track.

The drop in sterling since the EU referendum has been a boon to Jimmy Choo, which is pushing ahead with store openings around the world. As the luxury shoe and bag retailer celebrates its 20th anniversary, Peter Harf, the chairman, said Jimmy Choo's prospects had "never looked better". The company reported revenue growth of 9.2% for the first six months of the year, or 3.8% at constant currencies, and a 42.6% increase in operating profits to £25.3m. The second half had started well, the retailer said, with a positive benefit from a weaker pound. Jimmy Choo has 147 stores worldwide, including 10 in the UK, and is opening about 10 stores a year. It said only 9.5% of revenues were generated in sterling, while 28% of operating costs were denominated in sterling, "hence a weaker pound will lead to a reported upside in business performance at a revenue and profit level". The company's expansion plans are not limited to physical stores, as Jimmy Choo is also investing in e-commerce and digital marketing to reach a wider audience. Harf emphasized that the retailer's strategy is focused on building a strong brand presence globally, rather than simply relying on the UK market. "We're not just a British brand, we're a global brand," he said. "We're not just about selling shoes, we're about creating an experience."

Jimmy Choo's success has also been driven by its ability to adapt to changing consumer preferences. The company has shifted its focus towards more affordable and accessible products, while still maintaining its luxury brand image. Harf noted that the retailer has seen a significant increase in demand for its more affordable lines, which have been priced between £200 and £500. "We're not just a luxury brand, we're a brand for everyone," he said.

As Jimmy Choo looks to the future, the company is planning to continue its expansion into new markets, particularly in Asia and the Middle East. Harf expressed confidence that the retailer's growth prospects remain strong, despite the uncertainty surrounding Brexit. "We're not worried about Brexit, we're worried about how we can continue to grow and expand our brand globally," he said. With its strong brand presence, robust financials, and expansion plans in place, Jimmy Choo is well-positioned to continue its success in the years to come.

More than 1m cars were built in the UK in the first seven months of this year, the biggest number for more than a decade. Car production rose by 7.6% to 126,566 units last month, according to the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders. So far in 2016, output is up by 12.3% to 1,023,723. The surge in car production is attributed to a combination of factors, including a rebound in consumer demand, investment in new models and technologies, and a favorable exchange rate. The Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT) said that the industry is benefiting from a "perfect storm" of conditions, with a growing market in China and other emerging economies driving demand for British-built cars.

The SMMT's chief executive, Mike Hawes, said: "The UK's car industry is in a period of sustained growth, with demand for British-built cars at its highest level for over a decade. This is a testament to the industry's ability to adapt and innovate, as well as the appeal of British-made cars around the world."

The rise in production has also led to a boost in employment, with many car manufacturers investing in new staff to meet growing demand. The SMMT estimates that the industry supports over 800,000 jobs across the UK, with many more roles created in related industries such as parts manufacturing and logistics.

The news comes as the UK's automotive sector prepares for a period of significant change, with the industry expected to undergo a major transformation in the coming years as it adapts to new technologies such as electric vehicles and autonomous driving. Despite these challenges, the SMMT remains optimistic about the industry's prospects, with Hawes predicting that the UK will remain a major player in the global car market for years to come.

We know that exam results don't always show the whole story. With the GCSE results out on Thursday, we'd like to hear about your achievements. We'd like teachers to tell us about the success stories that your school's GCSE results don't necessarily reveal. It may be that your school has improved dramatically in one subject year on year, or individual pupils have exceeded all expectation. And if you're a student, have you achieved the results you needed – or better? If you haven't done as well as you hoped, let us know how you've changed your plans. You can share your stories by clicking on the 'Contribute' button. You can also use the Guardian app and search for "GuardianWitness assignments". We'd like to see photos too – and do make sure you include important details, like the name of the school, in the description box. We've already received some amazing stories from schools and students across the country, and we can't wait to hear more. At a school in East London, for example, a group of students with special educational needs have achieved remarkable results, with one student gaining a grade 4 in maths, a subject they were previously struggling with. Meanwhile, a student in a comprehensive school in the Midlands has secured a place at a top university, despite being predicted to achieve lower grades.

We've also heard from students who have defied expectations, such as a young woman who was predicted to achieve just a few GCSEs, but has ended up with a string of high grades. Her teacher credits her determination and hard work for her success. If you have a similar story to share, we'd love to hear it. Whether you're a student, teacher, or parent, your experiences can help paint a more complete picture of the GCSE results. So please, do share your stories with us.

It is still early days, but the UK economy should avoid the immediate post-Brexit vote recession many forecasters had predicted. That was the main message of the economic data released by the Office for National Statistics (ONS), which included the first piece of hard evidence of how the UK performed after the 23 June vote to leave the EU. The ONS said the service sector, which makes up around 80% of the UK economy, expanded by 0.4% in July, a month in which surveys showed business and consumer confidence crashing and the financial markets in turmoil. In the circumstances, that's a pretty impressive performance and analysts are already revising up their forecasts for growth in the third quarter. On the basis of still limited evidence, they are penciling in 0.4-0.5%. Hopes of avoiding a recession were also strengthened by the upward revision to growth in the second quarter, from 0.6% to 0.7%. The economy had plenty of momentum before the Brexit vote, and while it is likely to slow in the second half of 2016 there will not be the necessary two consecutive quarters of falling output to fulfil the technical definition of a recession. Much less welcome for the government was the news that Britain's balance of payments deficit, which stood at an alarming 5.7% of GDP in the first three months of 2016, widened in the second quarter. A deterioration in the UK's trade performance was largely responsible for the country diving deeper into the red, with the scale of the deficit highlighting the unbalanced nature of the economy. The widening trade deficit is a concern for the government, as it suggests that the UK is still heavily reliant on imports to fuel its economic growth. This is particularly problematic given the recent decline in the value of the pound, which has made imports more expensive. The ONS data also showed that the UK's trade deficit with the EU widened to £4.4 billion in the second quarter, from £2.3 billion in the same period last year.

Despite these concerns, the overall picture remains positive, with the ONS data suggesting that the UK economy is likely to continue growing in the third quarter. However, the pace of growth is expected to slow, and some economists are warning that the economy may be due for a correction.

The Bank of England is also keeping a close eye on the situation, and is likely to consider cutting interest rates further if the economy shows signs of slowing. The bank's governor, Mark Carney, has already warned that the UK is likely to experience a period of "prolonged and slow" growth in the coming years.

Despite these challenges, the government is trying to stay positive, and is highlighting the resilience of the UK economy. The Chancellor, Philip Hammond, has said that the data shows that the economy is "strong and stable", and that the government is committed to supporting businesses and creating new jobs.

However, the opposition is not so convinced, and is calling for the government to take more action to address the UK's economic challenges. The Labour leader, Jeremy Corbyn, has said that the data is "a warning sign" that the government's economic policies are not working, and that more needs to be done to support ordinary people.

As the debate continues, it is clear that the UK economy is facing a number of challenges, and that the government will need to take a careful approach to navigating these challenges. However, for now, the data suggests that the economy is likely to continue growing, albeit at a slower pace than previously expected.

The owner of the Daily Mirror has boosted its cost savings to £20m this year as tough trading conditions continue to hammer newspaper publishers. Trinity Mirror said that the trading environment has "remained challenging" and the business is focusing on shoring up the print decline by boosting digital revenues and "making efficiencies", or cost cuts. The company said that it has hit £20m in structural cost savings for the year, up from an initial target of £15m. The company, which also publishes regional newspapers including the Manchester Evening News and Liverpool Echo, said print advertising revenues fell by 21% and newspaper sales revenues dropped by 6% in the third quarter. Total revenues fell by 9% in the third quarter, slightly more than the 8% drop reported in the first half of the year. The company said publishing revenue is down 10%; within this total print revenues fell 12% while digital climbed by 11%. The company's digital efforts have been a bright spot, with online advertising revenue increasing by 15% in the third quarter. Trinity Mirror's online presence has been bolstered by the acquisition of several digital media companies in recent years. The company's CEO, Sly Bailey, said that the cost savings and revenue growth will help to position the business for long-term success. Despite the challenges facing the industry, Bailey remains optimistic about the future, stating that Trinity Mirror is "well-placed to take advantage of the opportunities that exist in the market". The company's financial performance will be closely watched by investors and analysts in the coming months, as the industry continues to navigate the challenges of a rapidly changing media landscape.

Children of the 1980s, rejoice! Teddy Ruxpin is back. The talking animatronic toy has been given a hi-tech makeover, swapping cassette tapes and plastic eyes for a 4GB hard drive and animated LCD peepers. Teddy has been resurrected by Wicked Cool Toys, which earlier this year also launched a revamped Cabbage Patch Kid doll. An early prototype of Teddy was showcased at the Dallas Toy Fair this week, although it's not scheduled to launch until 2017. "The bear had to come out of the bag," said Wicked Cool Toys co-president Jeremy Padawer, speaking to YouTube's Mommy and Gracie Show. "We've shown Teddy a little early." The nostalgia was palpable as the crowd gathered around the Wicked Cool Toys booth at the Dallas Toy Fair, eagerly awaiting a glimpse of the beloved teddy bear that had captured the hearts of children everywhere in the 1980s. And when Teddy Ruxpin finally emerged from his bag, the room erupted in a chorus of "oohs" and "aahs".

The new and improved Teddy Ruxpin is a far cry from the original, which relied on cassette tapes to bring its stories to life. This modern version boasts a 4GB hard drive, allowing it to store hours of audio content, including new stories, songs, and even interactive games. The LCD eyes, which can display a range of emotions, are a far cry from the plastic peepers of yesteryear.

But despite the technological advancements, the essence of Teddy Ruxpin remains the same. The bear's creators have worked tirelessly to ensure that the new version captures the same magic that made the original so beloved. "We wanted to stay true to the spirit of the original Teddy Ruxpin," said Padawer. "We wanted to make sure that kids today could still have the same kind of emotional connection with the toy that kids in the 80s did."

Teddy Ruxpin's new hard drive allows for a range of new features, including the ability to download additional content and even connect to the internet. The bear can also be controlled via a smartphone app, allowing kids to choose which stories they want to hear and even record their own voice to create personalized adventures.

The response to the new Teddy Ruxpin has been overwhelmingly positive, with many of the toy industry's biggest players flocking to the Wicked Cool Toys booth to get a glimpse of the bear in action. "We're thrilled with the reaction," said Padawer. "Kids and adults alike are loving the new Teddy Ruxpin, and we can't wait to get it into stores next year."

For those who grew up with the original Teddy Ruxpin, the new version is a nostalgic trip back to a simpler time. For kids today, it's a chance to experience the magic of the beloved toy for the first time. Either way, it's clear that Teddy Ruxpin is back and better than ever. And as the bear takes its place alongside other revamped retro toys like Cabbage Patch Kids, it's clear that the 80s are back in a big way.

I have had a fixed-rate mortgage with Nationwide for about four years, originally for £100,000, but with overpayments I have reduced it to £61,000. I want to move and have had an offer accepted on a £685,000 house. Nationwide, however, has refused to transfer the mortgage and insists I make a new application. I gave it details of my past two years' earnings – £53,000 and £34,000 respectively – but was told that as I was moving out of the area I needed future predicted earnings. I am a foster carer so this is not straightforward – all for a 10% mortgage. I have never missed a payment or had credit refused. I've been told that there is no point in appealing. I am at my wit's end and feel like I'm being unfairly treated by Nationwide. As a foster carer, my income can fluctuate from year to year, and it's not possible for me to provide predicted earnings for the next two years. I've always been a responsible borrower, making regular payments and never missing a payment. I've also never had any credit issues. It seems to me that Nationwide is more concerned with following their strict lending criteria than understanding my individual circumstances.

I've been a loyal customer for over four years, and I'm shocked that they're not willing to work with me to transfer my mortgage. I've even offered to provide additional information, such as my foster care agreement and references from my local authority, but Nationwide has refused. I'm starting to feel like I'm being punished for wanting to move to a new home. I'm considering taking my business elsewhere, but I'd like to resolve this issue with Nationwide first.

House of Fraser profits dived nearly 50% in the first half of the year as the department store said it faced a "very challenging retail environment" in the light of unseasonable weather and Brexit uncertainty. Underlying profits fell 46% from £9.2m 12 months ago to £5m in the six months to the end of July – excluding interest payments, tax, write downs on the value of property, and a one-off fall in income of nearly £4m related to a new credit card agreement. Profits were hit by the increased cost of delivering goods ordered online and a decline in sales of House of Fraser's own brands. Total sales remained steady at £573.5m as the group's established department stores experienced a 2.5% slump. Underlying sales, including a 17.8% rise in online sales, lifted 0.9%. Nigel Oddy, chief executive of the group, which was bought by Chinese conglomerate Sanpower in April 2014, said House of Fraser had experienced an "extremely volatile trading environment". The profit slump comes after fellow department stores John Lewis and Next both revealed a fall in first-half profits as they were hit by the need to discount to clear summer stock. Oddy said: "We would never use the weather as an excuse but we had record temperatures in September when we were selling autumn product and cold temperatures in June when we were trying to sell summer. and cold temperatures in June when we were trying to sell summer product," Oddy said. "It's not an excuse, but it's a fact that has had an impact on our sales."

Despite the challenging conditions, Oddy remained optimistic about the future, citing the group's strong online presence and efforts to revamp its store portfolio. "We're investing heavily in our digital capabilities and our stores, and we're seeing good progress," he said.

House of Fraser has been working to improve its online offering, including the launch of a new mobile app and the introduction of click-and-collect services. The group has also been focusing on enhancing the in-store experience, with plans to refurbish several of its flagship stores.

However, the company's efforts to revamp its product range have been hindered by the decline in sales of its own brands. Oddy acknowledged that the group's private label products, which account for around 20% of its sales, had struggled in recent months.

"We're not satisfied with the performance of our own brands, and we're working hard to improve them," he said. "We're looking at new product lines, new designs, and new marketing strategies to try and drive growth."

Despite the challenges, Oddy remained confident that House of Fraser could turn things around. "We're not out of the woods yet, but we're making progress, and we're confident that we can deliver a stronger second half," he said.

The group's shareholders will be hoping that Oddy's optimism is justified, as House of Fraser's profit slump has sent its shares tumbling. The company's stock price has fallen by around 15% in the past year, and investors will be looking for signs of improvement in the second half of the year.

Thomas Cook's summer bookings fell 4% as the travel operator was hit by a slump in demand for holidays in Turkey following a series of terrorist attacks and an attempted coup. In a trading update, Thomas Cook said summer bookings excluding Turkey rose 4% but that a 40% drop in trips to Turkey caused total bookings to fall. Bookings fell heavily in continental Europe, where German tourists shunned Turkey, but rose 1% in the UK. Thomas Cook has been hit hard since summer 2015 by terrorist attacks in Tunisia, Egypt and Turkey. It offered customers with bookings to Turkey free cancellation after a failed military coup in July. Bookings from Belgium also fell following the terrorist attacks on Brussels in March. The decline in bookings to Turkey was attributed to a significant drop in demand from Germany, which is one of the largest source markets for Thomas Cook. The company said that the events in Turkey had led to a "material reduction" in bookings from Germany, which was not offset by increased demand from other countries. Thomas Cook's CEO, Peter Fankhauser, stated that the company was working to mitigate the impact of the decline in bookings to Turkey by increasing its focus on other destinations, such as Spain and Greece.

Despite the challenges facing the company, Thomas Cook reported a 4% increase in summer bookings excluding Turkey, driven by strong demand from the UK and a recovery in bookings to Spain. The company also reported a 1% increase in bookings from the UK, which was seen as a positive sign given the challenging economic conditions in the country.

Thomas Cook's results come as the travel industry is facing a number of challenges, including a decline in bookings to Turkey and a slowdown in demand from some of its key source markets. The company's rivals, such as TUI and Jet2, have also reported declines in bookings to Turkey and are taking steps to mitigate the impact of the decline.

In response to the decline in bookings to Turkey, Thomas Cook has increased its focus on other destinations, such as Spain and Greece, which are seen as more stable and attractive to customers. The company has also been investing in its online presence and has launched a number of new marketing campaigns to attract customers. Despite the challenges facing the company, Thomas Cook remains confident that it will be able to deliver a strong performance for the year.

Earlier today I set you the following puzzles, each penned by William Hartston, aka Bill off Gogglebox: 1) What is the next number in the following series? 23, 9, 20, 14, 14, 9, 20, 6, ... 2) Mary I; George III, Henry III, James II, George IV, Charles I, ... Why might Henry I be an appropriate way to end the series? 3) What comes next in the following series? 2.1, 3.5, 3.3, 2.3, 1.3, 2.4, 2.5, 2.6, 1.8 ... 4) What comes next in this series: 1, 2, 9, 12, 70, 89, 97, 102 ... Solutions 1) 19 – the numbers are the alphabet positions of the first letters of the words in the question. 2) The code is that Mary I is taken to mean the first letter of Mary, George III is the third letter in George, and so on. The whole series, including a final Henry I, therefre spells out the word "monarch". 3) 2.7 They are the row and column positions on a QWERTY keyboard of the letters in alphabetical order. (2.1 means second row, first letter; 3.5 is third row, fifth letter, etc.) 4) 112: Subtract 1 from each number and you get the numbers that are the same upside down: 0, 1, 8, 11, 69, 88, 96, 101, 111, 181... Don't feel too bad if you did't get that last one. As the puzzles were solved and the room fell silent, a sense of accomplishment washed over the group. Bill, aka William Hartston, smiled knowingly, pleased with the complexity and cleverness of his creations. "Well, well, well," he said, "it seems you've all got the makings of a group of clever coders and cryptographers. I must say, I'm impressed."

The group's leader, a keen mathematician, spoke up next. "I must admit, I was stumped by the fourth puzzle. How did you come up with that one, Bill?" Bill chuckled, "Ah, it's an old favorite of mine. I call it the 'palindromic sequence.' It's a bit of a brain twister, but the key is to recognize that each number is one less than its reverse."

As the group continued to chat and discuss the puzzles, one of the participants, a young woman with a passion for language, turned to Bill and asked, "You know, I've always been fascinated by codes and ciphers. Do you have any more where those came from?" Bill's eyes lit up, "Oh, yes! I have a whole collection of them. Let me show you..."

And with that, Bill began to pull out a stack of papers and books, filled with all manner of codes and ciphers. The group leaned in, eager to learn more about the art of cryptography and the clever puzzles that Bill had created. As they delved deeper into the world of codes and ciphers, they discovered that there was more to Bill's puzzles than just clever wordplay and mathematical trickery. There was a rich history and a deep understanding of the human desire to communicate and conceal, that lay beneath the surface.

BBC veteran John Simpson has accused consecutive governments of "savagery" and taking "ideological delight" in attacking the corporation. Simpson, who has spent five decades at the the corporation including his current role of world affairs editor, told the Guardian: "The BBC, like the NHS, should be controlled by non-partisan, non-political groups which don't have an axe to grind." He added that both sides of the House of Commons were prone to attack the BBC simply because it didn't "toe the party line". Simpson reserved his greatest opprobrium for Tony Blair and his former press secretary Alistair Campbell, both for their involvement in the Hutton affair and their dealings with Rupert Murdoch. "Here is the British prime minister cosying up to a man who has got no interest in Britain, who is deeply opposed to Britain and Britain's interest, and is against the main national broadcaster," Simpson said. He said he believed most governments in his 50 years working at the BBC have a "disgraceful political obsession that somehow or other the BBC has to be cut down to size". "I don't mean to say that cuts can't be made but it's the savagery with which it's done. The ideological delight with which it's done." He added: "I just feel that it's absolutely disgraceful, keeping the BBC as short of cash as the government has since 2010." The insistence in a draft BBC charter unveiled earlier this month that the corporation reveal the pay of those staff earning more than £150,000 was simply the government "looking for a way to demonstrate their control and domination", he said in an interview three days after coming out of hospital having suffered kidney failure caused by a reaction to eating kedgeree. Simpson's scathing criticism comes as the BBC is facing unprecedented pressure from the government, with Culture Secretary Nadine Dorries recently threatening to "take back control" of the corporation. The BBC's director-general, Tim Davie, has also faced calls to resign over the corporation's handling of the controversy surrounding its high-earning stars.

Simpson's comments have been met with widespread support from current and former BBC staff, who have expressed their gratitude for his courage in speaking out against the government's attacks. Many have also praised his dedication to the corporation's values of impartiality and independence.

However, not everyone has been impressed with Simpson's remarks. Conservative MP and former BBC governor, Sir Nick Faldo, has accused Simpson of being "out of touch" with the reality of the BBC's financial situation. "The BBC is a bloated institution that needs to be reformed," Faldo said. "John Simpson's comments are just a desperate attempt to cling to the past and resist the necessary changes that need to be made."

Despite the controversy, Simpson remains defiant, insisting that the BBC's independence is essential to the health of British democracy. "The BBC is not just a broadcaster, it's a national institution that plays a vital role in holding those in power to account," he said. "We can't let the government dictate what we can and can't report on. That's why I'll continue to speak out against their attacks and fight for the BBC's right to remain independent."

As the debate continues to rage on, Simpson's comments have sparked a renewed sense of urgency around the need to protect the BBC's independence and integrity. With the corporation's charter up for renewal in 2027, the stakes are higher than ever before. Will the government's attacks on the BBC ultimately succeed in silencing its voice, or will the corporation's defenders be able to rally and ensure its continued survival? Only time will tell.

Theresa May has given her full backing to Mark Carney amid growing signs that the Bank of England governor intends to serve a full eight-year term. The prime minister said she would support the Canadian if he decided to put back his departure date from Threadneedle Street until 2021 and praised his efforts to steer the UK economy through the post-Brexit vote period. May's spokeswoman said: "The PM has been clear in her support for the governor, the work he is doing for the country. It is clearly a decision for him, but the PM would certainly be supportive of him going on beyond his five years." May and Carney were scheduled to have a meeting later on Monday, but the warm tone adopted by the prime minister's spokeswoman immediately prompted rumours that the governor could be about to announce his future plans. The speculation surrounding Carney's future plans has been fueled by recent comments he made about the need for a "fiscal policy response" to the UK's post-Brexit economic challenges. While Carney has not explicitly stated his intentions, his remarks have led some to speculate that he may be considering a longer-term role at the Bank of England to help guide the economy through the uncertainty surrounding the UK's exit from the European Union.

Carney's supporters, including some senior Bank of England officials, have been urging him to reconsider his departure date, citing his unique experience and expertise in navigating the complexities of the global financial system. Others have pointed to the Bank's ongoing efforts to develop its capabilities in areas such as fintech and green finance, and the potential benefits of having Carney's leadership during this critical period.

However, not everyone is convinced that Carney's continued tenure would be beneficial. Some critics have argued that the Bank of England's autonomy is essential to its effectiveness, and that Carney's extended stay could undermine the institution's independence. Others have raised concerns about the potential for Carney's continued leadership to create a sense of complacency among the Bank's policymakers, potentially leading to a loss of momentum in the UK's economic recovery.

As the speculation surrounding Carney's future plans continues to build, the Bank of England and the UK government are likely to face increasing pressure to provide clarity on the governor's intentions. Meanwhile, Carney himself remains tight-lipped on the matter, fueling further speculation and intrigue in the financial community.

Apple has finally put one of the most annoying and potentially embarrassing aspects of the MacBook Pro to bed: the Mac startup chime is no more. Instead the new MacBook Pros, both with and without the new emoji bar, will silently boot the moment they switch on. The chime, first introduced with the Macintosh Quadra line of computers in 1991, was used to signal that the computer had passed its initial diagnostic tests and would start the boot sequence. The first chime was a C-major chord, but was changed to the F-sharp chord starting in 1998 with the first iMac. While you've been able to mute the startup chime if the computer was muted before switching off, the often loud and obnoxious sound has been more embarrassing than helpful to most Mac laptop users. The silent boot is a welcome change for many users who have found the startup chime to be an annoyance in quiet environments, such as libraries or meetings. Additionally, the elimination of the chime may also help reduce the noise pollution caused by the loud and sudden sound. Apple's decision to remove the startup chime is seen as a step towards a more considerate and user-friendly experience. The company has also made other changes to the MacBook Pro, including the introduction of a new emoji bar and improved performance and battery life. The new MacBook Pros are expected to be a hit with users who value a more refined and sophisticated computing experience.
