Ministers must act to end mobile signal "not spots" that mean some overseas visitors have better phone reception than people using UK networks, a cross-party group of almost 90 MPs said on Friday. The British Infrastructure Group (BIG), led by former Conservative chairman and minister Grant Shapps, said the time for excuses from the mobile network providers was over. In a report, the MPs said it was "unacceptable that areas in Britain continue to have such poor mobile connectivity, and that overseas visitors can expect better mobile coverage than Britons stuck with a single provider". They wrote: "The time for excuses from the mobile sector is over. The government must make a better call for Britain and bring national mobile coverage policy into the 21st century." They said many overseas visitors had better coverage because their networks allowed national roaming. The group proposed an amendment to the government's digital economy bill to allow Ofcom to fine mobile operators that did not meet the targets of a 2014 agreement. The MPs also highlighted the economic and social implications of the poor mobile coverage, stating that it was hindering businesses and affecting people's daily lives. They pointed out that many rural areas were particularly affected, where mobile coverage was often non-existent or patchy.

The report also criticized the government's current approach to mobile coverage, saying that it was not doing enough to address the issue. The MPs called for a more proactive approach, with a clear plan to improve coverage across the country.

The BIG report also suggested that the government should establish a mobile coverage taskforce to oversee the implementation of the plan and hold mobile operators accountable for their progress.

The proposal to fine mobile operators that do not meet the targets of the 2014 agreement has been met with mixed reactions. Some have welcomed the move, saying it will force mobile operators to take action to improve coverage. Others have expressed concerns that it will lead to increased costs for consumers.

The digital economy bill is expected to be debated in parliament in the coming weeks, and the proposed amendment is likely to be a key point of discussion. The outcome of the debate will be closely watched by mobile operators, consumer groups, and the general public.

The British Infrastructure Group has called on the government to take immediate action to address the issue, saying that the time for excuses is over. The group has also urged the public to get behind the campaign to improve mobile coverage, saying that it is a critical issue that affects everyone.

As the debate continues, the public will be watching to see if the government will take decisive action to improve mobile coverage in the UK. Will the proposed amendment to the digital economy bill be enough to bring about change, or will it take more than that to get mobile operators to take action? Only time will tell.

WhatsApp has been warned by the pan-European privacy watchdogs over its sharing of information with Facebook and asked to pause the transfer of personal data. The gathered European Union data protection authorities, collectively known as the Article 29 Working Party, said they had serious concerns over WhatsApp's recent privacy policy change and the sharing of user phone numbers with its parent company Facebook. Article 29 said that it had "requested WhatsApp to communicate all relevant information to the Working Party as soon as possible and urged the company to pause the sharing of users' data until the appropriate legal protections could be assured" in a letter sent to the messaging service. The move comes after WhatsApp's recent update to its privacy policy, which allows it to share user phone numbers with Facebook. The Article 29 Working Party, which represents the data protection authorities of all 28 EU member states, has expressed concerns that this sharing of data may not be compliant with EU data protection laws.

"We are concerned that the recent changes to WhatsApp's privacy policy may not provide adequate safeguards for the processing of personal data," said a spokesperson for the Article 29 Working Party. "We urge WhatsApp to provide us with further information on how it intends to ensure the protection of users' personal data."

The Working Party has given WhatsApp a deadline of two weeks to respond to its concerns and provide further information on its data sharing practices. If WhatsApp fails to comply, the Working Party has the power to take enforcement action against the company.

This move is seen as a significant blow to WhatsApp, which has faced criticism in the past over its data sharing practices. The company has previously faced lawsuits and regulatory investigations over its handling of user data.

The Article 29 Working Party's intervention is the latest in a series of moves by European regulators to crack down on tech companies' handling of personal data. Last year, the EU's top court ruled that companies must obtain explicit consent from users before collecting and sharing their personal data.

WhatsApp's parent company Facebook has also faced scrutiny over its handling of user data. In 2018, the company was fined $5 billion by the US Federal Trade Commission for violating users' privacy.

Google's parent Alphabet defied expectations to report a 20.2% rise in quarterly revenue on Thursday, while retail giant Amazon slightly missed predicted predicted forecasts due to spending on preparations for the holiday season. Indicating an end to its record-breaking profits streak, Amazon reported profit of $252m or 52 cents per share, though analysts had predicted 85 cents per share. Revenues reached $32.71bn but are predicted to reach between $42bn and $45.5bn for the busy fourth quarter. Alphabet meanwhile continues to dominate the fast-growing mobile advertising market, along with Facebook. The company has benefited from robust sales of advertising on mobile devices and on YouTube, and also said it would repurchase about $7bn of its Class C stock. Shares of Alphabet, which is the world's second largest company by market value, were up 1.6% in after-hours trading. Google's ad revenue rose 18.1% to $19.82bn in the third quarter, accounting for 89.1% of Google's total revenue, compared with 89.8% of revenue in the second quarter. Paid clicks rose 33%, compared with a rise of 29% in the second quarter. Paid clicks are those ads on which an advertiser pays only if a user clicks on them. Cost-per-click, or the average amount advertisers pay Google, fell 11% in the latest period after dropping 7% in the second quarter. Analysts on average had expected a decline of 7.9%, according to FactSet StreetAccount. The strong performance by Alphabet, also known as Google, was attributed to its dominance in the mobile advertising market, where it continues to outpace its competitors. The company's ability to adapt to changing consumer behavior and its willingness to invest in emerging technologies such as artificial intelligence and machine learning have been key factors in its success. Additionally, the growth of e-commerce and the increasing importance of online advertising have also contributed to Alphabet's strong financial performance.

In contrast, Amazon's miss on profit expectations was largely due to its heavy investments in preparations for the holiday season. The company has been expanding its logistics and delivery capabilities to meet the surge in demand during the holiday season, which has put pressure on its profitability. However, analysts remain optimistic about Amazon's long-term prospects, citing its strong brand recognition, vast customer base, and ability to innovate and adapt to changing market conditions.

Despite the differing performances, both Alphabet and Amazon are expected to continue to play important roles in shaping the future of the technology and retail industries. As the holiday season approaches, investors will be closely watching both companies to see how they fare and whether they can maintain their strong growth momentum.

Royal Bank of Scotland has been told by a group of private investors that it will be taken to court over a £1.25bn claim related to its 2008 cash call. The RBoS Shareholder Action Group, which represents 27,000 retail investors, issued its warning after a report that other shareholders were considering settling out of court. The group, one of at least three bringing claims related to the rights issue in 2008, said: "We look forward to seeing Fred Goodwin and RBS in court in March." The group said it was the only one suing Goodwin, who was chief executive of RBS at the time of its £45bn taxpayer bailout, and three of the bank's former executives. The legal action is said to be "on behalf of thousands of investors, both private and institutional, who lost money by subscribing for shares during the 2008 RBS rights issue". The announcement was made ahead of RBS's third-quarter results, which will be scrutinised for any further provisions relating to the case. The RBoS Shareholder Action Group's threat to take RBS to court comes as the bank is still reeling from the fallout of the 2008 financial crisis. The rights issue in question was a last-ditch effort by the bank to raise capital and avoid collapse, but it ultimately resulted in a massive loss for investors. The group claims that RBS failed to provide adequate information to investors about the bank's true financial situation at the time, leading to a loss of confidence and a sharp decline in the value of the shares.

The group's lawyers have been working tirelessly to gather evidence and build a case against RBS, and they are confident that they have a strong argument. "We believe that RBS breached its fiduciary duties to its shareholders by making false and misleading statements about the bank's financial health," said one of the lawyers involved in the case. "We are seeking compensation for the thousands of investors who were harmed by RBS's actions."

The RBoS Shareholder Action Group's announcement has sent shockwaves through the financial community, with many investors and analysts calling for RBS to come clean about the situation. "This is a major scandal, and RBS needs to take responsibility for its actions," said one analyst. "The bank's shareholders deserve to know the truth about what happened in 2008, and they deserve to be compensated for their losses."

RBS has so far refused to comment on the situation, but it is expected to release a statement soon. The bank's third-quarter results are due to be released later this week, and investors will be watching closely to see if RBS will make any provision for the potential legal costs and settlements.

Banks and financial services companies have racked up more than £40bn in costs to handle the payment protection insurance scandal. The costliest mis-selling bill in UK financial services history became even more expensive on Thursday after Barclays set aside a further £600m to handle the cost of claims. Data compiled by the thinkthank New City Agenda shows that this top up for Barclays has pushed the total provisions incurred by the industry to £40.2bn. Lloyds Banking Group makes up £17bn of that total. The size of the payouts have already been cited as a reason for booming car sales and holidays. As one penny off income tax costs about £4bn, it could be regarded as a boost to household income. The staggering cost of the payment protection insurance (PPI) scandal has sent shockwaves through the financial industry, with banks and financial services companies now facing a total bill of £40.2 billion. The latest contribution to this massive sum comes from Barclays, which has set aside an additional £600 million to cover the cost of claims.

The PPI scandal, which has been ongoing for several years, involves banks and financial institutions mis-selling insurance policies to customers, often without their knowledge or consent. The policies, designed to protect borrowers from missed payments, were sold to millions of people who did not need or want them.

The fallout from the scandal has been significant, with many banks facing large fines and compensation payouts. The £40.2 billion total provisions incurred by the industry are expected to continue to rise as more claims are made and settled.

Despite the massive cost, some economists have argued that the payouts could have a positive impact on the economy. With more money in people's pockets, consumers may be more likely to spend and boost economic growth. The £40.2 billion total provisions could also be seen as a boost to household income, equivalent to about £4 billion off income tax.

I'm not certain that the Daily Star's front page on Wednesday was too clever (although I concede that nothing about the Star tends to be clever). Tuesday's front carried the headline "Pete Burns dies of heart attack at 57". The story told of the "pop icon" having died "after a massive heart attack". So the following day's front, "Pete Burns: How I came back from the dead", was baffling. Had the previous report been wrong after all? But it turns out that the Daily Star's clever trick was not a correction at all, but rather a cleverly crafted cover story. Pete Burns, the former lead singer of the pop group Dead or Alive, had indeed died of a heart attack on Tuesday, as reported by the Star. However, in a bizarre twist, Burns' partner, Michael Simpson, had made a statement earlier that day claiming that Burns had died twice before, and that he had somehow managed to come back to life on both occasions. The Star's front page story was likely a play on this unusual claim, rather than a genuine correction of their earlier report. The incident has left many fans and media outlets scratching their heads, wondering what to make of Burns' extraordinary alleged experiences.

I reported on Monday that the Buenos Aires Herald, the only English-language daily newspaper in Latin America, was to become a weekly. Why, asked an emailer, should we care what happens in Argentina? Leaving aside the chauvinistic rudeness, by recording what is happening in media elsewhere we are better able to perceive what the Herald rightly calls "a worldwide phenomenon". The central point to be learned from the Herald's leading article on Wednesday, is universal: journalism is in crisis. In registering its "unspeakable sadness" at giving up daily publication, the paper said it had been "facing difficulties for a while now". It spoke of the "dramatic change", which "reflects a media industry in crisis", and acknowledged that people now prefer to access news for free on digital platforms rather than by reading newsprint. Then it touched on the likely result: "as many as 2,000 journalists may lose their jobs in the country in 2016, a staggering number which will damage the profession greatly". The Herald is no exception because it is shedding most of its staff due to the change to a weekly. "The overwhelming majority of our colleagues were told that they would be losing their jobs", said the editorial, which revealed that 14 "are leaving us today". The 140-year-old title, majority-owned by the Indalo Group, also mentioned "our most illustrious period during the military dictatorship". The article goes on to highlight the significance of the Herald's crisis, not just for Argentina but for the global journalism industry. The newspaper's struggles to adapt to the shift towards digital media and its reliance on advertising revenue are mirrored in newsrooms around the world. The editorial notes that the Herald's decision to become a weekly is a "symbol of the times" and a reflection of the "agonizing struggle" many newspapers are facing to stay afloat.

The article also touches on the implications of the Herald's downsizing for the Argentine media landscape. With the loss of experienced journalists and the decline of investigative reporting, the country's citizens are likely to suffer from a lack of in-depth coverage of important issues. The Herald's editorial warns that this could have far-reaching consequences, including a decline in accountability and transparency in government and business.

As the newspaper's employees prepare to leave, many are expressing sadness and frustration at the loss of a institution that has played a vital role in Argentina's cultural and political life. The Herald's legacy is not just about its journalism, but also about its commitment to promoting free speech and independent thought. As the newspaper embarks on this new chapter, many are left wondering what the future holds for journalism in Argentina and beyond.

Australia's richest woman, Gina Rinehart, has invested £245m in the UK's biggest potash mine on the edge of the North York Moors national park. The £1.7bn mine, which was given the go-ahead last year after a protracted planning battle, has promised to restore the region's proud mining heritage and bring more than 1,000 jobs. The project received a major boost on Tuesday when Sirius Minerals, the company behind the Yorkshire mine, announced a US$300m (£245m) deal with Rinehart's Australian agricultural firm Hancock Prospecting. The mine, which sits on protected moorland overlooking Whitby and Robin Hood's Bay, aims to produce up to 20m tonnes a year of a potassium-rich mineral called polyhalite, a type of potash fertiliser described by Sirius as a "fertiliser of the future". Under the deal Rinehart will purchase $50m of Sirius shares and pay $250m for a 5% royalty stream on the first 13m tonnes of fertiliser produced by the mine annually, and the right to purchase up to 20,000 tonnes of product each year for use on her expanding Australian agricultural holdings. The investment is a significant coup for Sirius Minerals, which has been working on the project for over a decade. The company's CEO, Chris Fraser, hailed the deal as a "game-changer" for the business, saying it would allow them to accelerate the development of the mine and create thousands of jobs in the region.

The deal is also a major win for Rinehart, who has been looking to expand her agricultural interests in the UK. Her company, Hancock Prospecting, has been involved in a number of high-profile mining projects around the world, including the Roy Hill iron ore mine in Western Australia.

The polyhalite mine is expected to be a major boost to the local economy, with Sirius Minerals estimating that it will generate £1.2 billion in economic benefits for the region over its 50-year lifespan. The company has also promised to invest £10 million in local community projects, including the restoration of historic mining sites and the creation of new green spaces.

However, the deal has not been without controversy. Local environmental groups have expressed concerns about the impact of the mine on the North York Moors national park, which is home to a number of rare and endangered species. The park's designation as a Site of Special Scientific Interest (SSSI) has meant that the mine has had to undergo a lengthy and rigorous planning process, with the UK government ultimately giving the project the green light last year.

Despite these concerns, Sirius Minerals has insisted that the mine will be built with environmental sustainability in mind. The company has promised to use cutting-edge technology to minimize its impact on the local ecosystem, and has also committed to restoring the site to its natural state once the mine has been exhausted.

The deal is expected to be finalized in the coming weeks, pending regulatory approval. If all goes to plan, the polyhalite mine is expected to begin production in the mid-2020s, with the first shipments of fertiliser heading to markets around the world.

The publication Property Week has been forced to withdraw a category from their student accommodation awards, after a handpicked panel of students refused to choose a winner in protest over increasing rent prices. The 10 students were invited by Property Week to judge a shortlist of providers for the "student experience" category of their inaugural Student Accommodation Awards. The judges instead criticised the entrants for pricing out poorer students and "driving the social cleansing of education". The panel cited a 2015 study by the NUS, which shows that university rent in the UK increased by 18% over two years, to an average of £146 per week. The report suggests the rise is largely due to the growth of private providers. A spokesperson for the Student Accommodation Awards said: "Our student judges have sent a clear message that the industry needs to do better. The decision to withdraw the category has sparked a wider debate about the affordability of student accommodation in the UK. Many students are struggling to find affordable and decent living arrangements, with some being forced to share tiny rooms or live in overcrowded conditions.

"The fact that students are having to make these kinds of sacrifices just to get a roof over their head is a clear indication of a broken system," said Rachel, a student at the University of Manchester who was part of the judging panel. "We're not asking for luxury, just a basic standard of living that doesn't leave us in debt and stress."

The National Union of Students (NUS) has called for greater regulation of the private student accommodation sector, citing concerns about the quality and affordability of the properties. "It's unacceptable that students are being priced out of their own education," said NUS president, Shakira Martin. "We need to see more action from the government and the industry to ensure that students have access to safe, affordable and decent living arrangements."

The Student Accommodation Awards organizers have announced that they will be reviewing their criteria and judging process to ensure that future awards better reflect the needs and concerns of students. The industry has also been urged to take note of the students' concerns and to prioritize affordability and quality in their developments.

In the meantime, students are being advised to research thoroughly and to look for deals and discounts that can help make their living arrangements more affordable. Many are also calling for greater support from universities and government to help address the issue of student poverty and the increasing cost of living.

As the debate continues, it is clear that the students' protest has sparked a much-needed conversation about the state of student accommodation in the UK. With the cost of living continuing to rise, it is imperative that the industry and government take action to ensure that students have access to safe, affordable and decent living arrangements that do not compromise their education.

I have taken over the financial affairs of an elderly dementia sufferer. In March 2013, he signed up with Money Club and paid an annual fee of £98. At that time he had just started losing his memory and he does not own a computer or have the mental capacity to use the service, so I'm baffled as to how it sold him the membership. Another £98 was taken in March 2014 and since then a further 20 payments have been taken by direct debit totalling £2,148. I have attempted to contact Money Club without success. I am at my wit's end and feeling utterly helpless. As the Power of Attorney for my elderly father, it is my responsibility to manage his finances and ensure his well-being. But how can I do that when I'm constantly fighting against the financial exploitation of companies like Money Club?

I've tried to contact them numerous times, but they've refused to return my calls or respond to my emails. It's as if they're hiding behind their silence, hoping that I'll just give up and let them continue to drain my father's bank account.

I've spoken to my father's social worker, who has also tried to contact Money Club, but they've been met with the same stonewalling. We've even contacted the Financial Conduct Authority, but they've told us that they can't intervene because Money Club is not regulated by them.

It's a nightmare, and I feel like I'm fighting a losing battle. My father's money is being drained away, and I'm powerless to stop it. I'm begging Money Club to come forward and explain themselves. How did they sell my father a membership he couldn't use? And why are they still taking money from him despite my attempts to stop them?

I just want what's best for my father, and that's for Money Club to return the money they've taken and leave him alone. I hope that someone will listen to my story and help me put an end to this financial abuse.

Nils Pratley (PM needs to stand firm on executive pay ratios, 29 November) alerts us to the fact that directors are already lobbying hard to water down Theresa May's early proposal to shed light on employee pay ratios. May was unrelenting in her support for the austerity policies imposed by her government since 2010 and the havoc they have created for the most vulnerable and disadvantaged in our in our society. Now's the time for her to do what she said she would do. What's the risk in making companies publish details of every employee's terms and contracts of employment, pension contributions, share options, severance terms, expense account arrangements, perks etc? Not all boardrooms are full of self-serving, me-first executives. However, many are. It was the boards of our leading banks and financial institutions – working hand in glove with some of the most unsavoury characters in the business world – who created the problems we are facing today. The proposal to require companies to publish pay ratios is a crucial step towards transparency and accountability. By shining a light on the vast disparities in executive compensation, May can demonstrate her commitment to fairness and social justice. It's not just about punishing the wealthy, but about ensuring that the benefits of economic growth are shared more equitably. After all, it's the ordinary workers who have borne the brunt of austerity, while the wealthy have continued to accumulate wealth. The PM's predecessors, David Cameron and George Osborne, were notorious for their close ties to the City and their willingness to serve the interests of the 1%. May has an opportunity to break with this tradition and show that she is truly committed to the well-being of all citizens, not just the wealthy elite. By standing firm on this proposal, she can demonstrate her integrity and restore faith in the government's ability to address the deep-seated problems facing our society.

Rupert Murdoch is likely to lose nearly all of the $100m he invested in Theranos, the blood testing startup beset by scandals exposed by the Wall Street Journal, his flagship business newspaper. Murdoch is reported to have invested $100m in Theranos between 2014 and 2015, when its valuation was soaring thanks to the promise of being able to revolutionize blood testing by replacing needles with low-cost finger pricks. The Wall Street Journal reported that Murdoch was part of a group of wealthy families and individuals who invested $632m in Theranos's latest funding round at about $17 a share, giving the Silicon Valley company a valuation of nearly $9bn, and making it the highest-valued private healthcare startup in the US. Murdoch is reported to have toured Theranos's laboratories in Palo Alto and inspected its proprietary devices prior to investing. The Wall Street Journal, which is owned by Murdoch's publishing group News Corp, has published a series of investigative stories questioning the accuracy of Theranos's testing and unusual management techniques. The WSJ investigation, which kept going despite intense pressure on its whistleblower from Theranos and its board of high profile figures, led to a government investigation that found the company's practices were putting patients' lives at risk. Elizabeth Holmes, Theranos's chief executive, was banned from the blood testing business for two years. The news of Murdoch's potential losses is a significant blow to the media mogul, who has long been known for his shrewd business instincts. The collapse of Theranos's valuation is a stark reminder of the risks involved in investing in startups, even those with seemingly revolutionary technology.

Murdoch's investment in Theranos was seen as a coup for the company, with many observers praising his endorsement of the firm's innovative approach to blood testing. However, the Wall Street Journal's investigation has raised serious questions about the accuracy of Theranos's testing methods and the company's management practices.

The fallout from the scandal has been significant, with Theranos's valuation plummeting and the company's leadership facing intense scrutiny. Elizabeth Holmes, the company's CEO, was banned from the blood testing business for two years, a move that has been widely seen as a major blow to the company's prospects.

For Murdoch, the loss of $100m is a significant setback, but it is not the first time he has been burned by an investment gone sour. In the past, he has spoken publicly about the importance of taking calculated risks in business, and the Theranos investment was seen as a bold move by many observers.

Despite the loss, Murdoch remains one of the most powerful and influential figures in the media industry, with a vast network of connections and a reputation for being a shrewd and savvy businessman. However, the Theranos scandal is a reminder that even the most experienced and successful investors can fall victim to the risks and uncertainties of the startup world.

HSBC, which I have personally banked with since 1964, recently announced that it will close the four accounts we hold for the campaign organisation Searchlight following a "review". In a follow-up email it insisted there is nothing we can do to change the decision and that it will not give us a reason. Searchlight has campaigned against racism and fascism for 52 years, published a magazine since 1975, and is well respected. We are not aligned to any political party and are multi-faith. We currently work with the University of Northampton and recently launched a research arm, Searchlight Research Associates, with many distinguished patrons. We have no overdraft facility – our income comes from occasional grants, donations and subscriptions and is paid in by cheque, standing order or bank transfer. We have hardly any international transactions. We can think of nothing in our use of the accounts that could possibly give rise to any concerns. The only reason I can think of is that the fascist individuals and organisations that Searchlight combats have maliciously given false information to the bank for the sole purpose of getting our accounts closed, and the bank has accepted it without investigation. Obviously, this is very disruptive and we are applying for new accounts with another bank but we don't know whether it will accept our application in view of HSBC's action. Although HSBC is acting within its terms and conditions, its unilateral action is contrary to all principles of justice. The sudden closure of our accounts by HSBC has left us feeling shocked and betrayed. As a long-standing customer, we had always been proud to bank with a reputable institution like HSBC. But now, it seems that our commitment to fighting racism and fascism has become a liability.

We are not asking for special treatment or favors. We simply want to know why our accounts were closed and what steps we can take to rectify the situation. But HSBC's refusal to provide a reason or engage in any meaningful dialogue is unacceptable.

As a charity, we rely on the trust and goodwill of our supporters to continue our vital work. The closure of our accounts has caused significant disruption and uncertainty, and we are concerned about the impact it may have on our ability to function.

We are not alone in our frustration. Many of our supporters and partners have reached out to express their outrage and disappointment at HSBC's decision. We have also received messages of support from other organizations and individuals who share our values and commitment to combating hate and intolerance.

In the face of this injustice, we are determined to continue our work and will not be silenced or intimidated. We will explore all options to find a new bank that shares our values and is willing to work with us. We will also continue to speak out against racism and fascism, and will not be deterred by the actions of those who seek to undermine our efforts.

Ultimately, we hope that HSBC will reconsider its decision and work with us to find a solution. But if not, we will continue to fight for our right to operate and to promote a message of hope and unity in the face of hatred and division.

Former BHS workers and trade union representatives are to descend on the headquarters of Sir Philip Green's retail business in an attempt to force him to fill the £571m deficit in the collapsed department store chain's pension scheme. More than 100,000 people have signed a petition calling for the billionaire tycoon to fulfil his promise to "sort" the scheme. The petition will be delivered to Green's Arcadia business on Wednesday by John Hannett, the general secretary of the shopworkers' trade union Usdaw. Green promised to deal with the problems facing the pension scheme when he appeared before MPs in June. However, he has failed to agree a deal with the Pensions Regulator, which has now launched legal proceedings against Green and Dominic Chappell, the former owners of BHS. Hannett said Green needed to pump more than £250m into the scheme, which has more than 20,000 members, calling anything less "derisory". He said: "Our priority is to see Sir Phillip do the right thing and deliver on his promise to 'sort' the pension fund. If he wants to recover any reputational credibility he must not haggle his way out of his responsibilities, he must make a full contribution and do it quickly. The protesters, including former BHS workers and union representatives, plan to gather outside Arcadia's headquarters in London's Mayfair, holding signs and banners calling for Green to honor his commitment to the pension scheme. Usdaw has also launched a social media campaign, #SortThePension, to raise awareness and pressure Green into taking action. Hannett warned that if the situation is not resolved, the consequences could be devastating for the pension scheme's members, many of whom are already struggling to make ends meet. "We will not stand idly by while Sir Philip Green and his associates attempt to shirk their responsibilities," Hannett said. "We will continue to fight for the rights of BHS workers and pension scheme members until justice is served." The protest is expected to attract widespread media attention, with many hoping it will bring renewed scrutiny to Green's business practices and force him to take action to address the pension scheme's dire financial situation.

The Belfast shipyard that built the Titanic has won a contract believed to be worth £20m to expand a huge windfarm off the East Anglian coast. Harland and Wolff Heavy Industries Ltd has secured the manufacturing of 60 steel foundation jackets for the East Anglia One offshore windfarm, which will safeguard 200 jobs. At more than 65 metres high and weighing over 845 tonnes, the three-legged steel jackets will be almost as prominent on Belfast's skyline as Samson and Goliath, Harland and Wolff's giant yellow cranes. Work on the foundation jackets will start in the second quarter of 2017 and should be completed towards the end of 2018, Scottish Renewables said on Friday. The firm says East Anglia One, a £2.5bn North Sea windfarm, will generate 714 megawatts of electricity by 2020, enough to power 500,000 homes. Jonathan Guest, Harland and Wolff's director of business development said: "In a global supply chain environment it is significant when a developer stands over its commitment to give opportunities to local fabricators, as Scottish Power Renewables have demonstrated for East Anglia One." Keith Anderson, the chief executive of Scottish Power Renewables said: "East Anglia One will be the best value offshore windfarm ever constructed, at the same time as delivering industry-leading levels of UK content. The contract win is a significant boost to the shipyard's fortunes, which have been impacted by a decline in the traditional shipbuilding industry. Harland and Wolff has been diversifying its operations in recent years to take advantage of opportunities in the renewable energy sector. The company has already completed several projects in the offshore wind industry, including the construction of a similar windfarm off the coast of Germany.

The East Anglia One windfarm will be one of the largest in the world when it is completed, and will play a crucial role in helping the UK meet its renewable energy targets. The project is being developed by Scottish Power Renewables, a subsidiary of the Spanish energy company Iberdrola. The company has committed to using local suppliers and contractors wherever possible, and the contract with Harland and Wolff is seen as a major coup for the shipyard.

The news has been welcomed by local politicians and business leaders, who have been campaigning for more investment in the region's manufacturing sector. The contract win is expected to create a significant number of jobs in the area, both during the construction phase and once the windfarm is operational. The project is also expected to generate millions of pounds in revenue for the local economy, and will help to establish the region as a hub for offshore wind energy.

I reported nine days ago that the Bahraini authorities had arrested politician Ebrahim Sharif following a visit to Bahrain by Prince Charles. He was charged with "inciting hatred" against the Gulf monarchy's rulers, and therefore facing a possible three-year jail sentence. Now I'm delighted to report that the charges against him have been dropped, according to a tweet issued by Bahrain's UK embassy. The decision to drop the charges is a significant development, and a welcome one, considering the concerns raised by human rights groups and international observers about the Bahraini government's treatment of political dissent. Sharif, a prominent figure in Bahrain's opposition movement, had been vocal about the need for democratic reforms and greater freedoms in the country. His arrest and subsequent charges were seen as a crackdown on free speech and a threat to the country's fragile human rights landscape.

The Bahraini government's decision to drop the charges is likely to be seen as a gesture of goodwill ahead of the upcoming visit by British Prime Minister Boris Johnson to the country. The move may also be an attempt to ease tensions with the international community, which has been increasingly critical of Bahrain's human rights record. Whatever the motivations behind the decision, it is a positive step forward for Sharif and a reminder that even in the face of repression, the power of international pressure can sometimes lead to change.

My husband, Harry Jones, who has died aged 86, was a committed teacher and college principal at sixth-form and technical colleges, and in adult education. Harry was born and brought up in County Durham, the son of William Jones, a miner, and his wife, May (nee Cowley). His father was sent down the pit at the age of 12 to be the family breadwinner. Harry's mother left her village school at 14 but was a great reader. Raised on the estate of the Backhouses, the Darlington bankers, where her mother was housekeeper and her father coachman, May had access to their library, and thanks to this, Harry benefited from a pre-school education. Unemployment in Durham caused the family to move in 1940 to Coventry, where they experienced wartime air raids. Grammar schools were then fee paying, with a few bright children selected for special places, and Harry gained one at King Edward VI school, Nuneaton. It was a disrupted secondary education. The school was bombed, so for some time pupils went to school only on Tuesdays and Thursdays, to receive work to be done at home. Despite the challenges of his early education, Harry went on to study at the University of Leicester, where he graduated with a degree in chemistry. He then began his teaching career at a sixth-form college in Leicester, where he quickly established himself as a dedicated and inspiring educator. His passion for teaching and his ability to connect with students of all ages and backgrounds led to him being appointed as a college principal, a role he held for many years.

Throughout his career, Harry was committed to providing high-quality education to his students, and he was particularly proud of his work in adult education, where he helped countless individuals gain new skills and qualifications. He was also a strong advocate for social justice and was involved in various community initiatives aimed at promoting equality and fairness.

In his personal life, Harry was a kind and generous person who was loved by all who knew him. He was a devoted husband to his wife, Joan, and a loving father to their two children. He enjoyed gardening, walking, and playing chess, and was a keen supporter of his local football team.

Harry's death is a significant loss to his family, friends, and the education community, but his legacy will live on through the countless lives he touched and the many memories he created. He will be deeply missed, but his spirit will continue to inspire and motivate others to strive for excellence and make a positive difference in the world.

Sports Direct is selling Dunlop, the sportswear brand known for its green flash tennis shoes, to a Japanese buyer in a surprise $137.5m (£112m) deal. Sumitomo Rubber Industries confirmed that it will acquire the trademark rights of the Dunlop brand overseas, as well as its sporting goods and licensing businesses. Sports Direct's founder and major shareholder, Mike Ashley, acquired Dunlop Slazenger for an estimated £40m in 2004 from Royal Bank of Scotland – which had taken control of the struggling business from its private equity-backed owners – three years before he floated his sportswear retail chain on the stock exchange. The 107-year-old Dunlop brand is associated with many sports including tennis, squash, badminton and golf. Its gear has been used by sporting figures including tennis champions Rod Laver, John McEnroe and Steffi Graf, as well as golfers such as the 2011 British Open winner Darren Clarke and the former world number one Lee Westwood. In a statement, Sports Direct said it did "not currently have the bandwidth to develop and manage international brands simultaneously", and needed to prioritise its core UK businesses and relationships with third-party brands. The Dunlop business made a pre-tax profit of £4m on sales of £41.8m, the retailer said. Sumitomo Rubber Industries, originally called the Dunlop Rubber Company, has a tyre business as well as a sports division that makes tennis and golf equipment. The acquisition is expected to be completed by the end of the year, pending regulatory approvals. Sumitomo Rubber Industries plans to maintain the Dunlop brand's operations in the UK and continue to manufacture and distribute its products globally. The company's sports division has already established a strong presence in the Asian market, and the addition of Dunlop is expected to further strengthen its position.

Sports Direct's decision to sell Dunlop comes as no surprise to analysts, who have been speculating about the retailer's plans for its international brands. The company has been focusing on its core UK business and has been looking to streamline its operations. The sale of Dunlop is expected to generate significant cash for Sports Direct, which can be used to invest in its core business and potentially make other acquisitions.

The news has been welcomed by industry insiders, who see the deal as a positive development for the sportswear industry. "This is a great opportunity for Sumitomo Rubber Industries to expand its presence in the global sportswear market," said one analyst. "Dunlop is a well-known and respected brand, and we expect the company to continue to thrive under its new ownership."

A bailout of struggling Italian bank Monte dei Paschi should not be seen as a done deal, a key European Central Bank policymaker has said. Jens Weidmann, president of Germany's Bundesbank, said the Italian government ought to consider whether it should rescue the bank if it is in a bad financial state. "For the measures planned by the Italian government the bank has to be financially healthy at its core," he said in an article published German newspaper Bild. "The money cannot be used to cover losses that are already expected. All this must be carefully examined," added Weidmann, a member of the ECB's governing council. The ECB has taken a tough line with Italy's third-largest bank, refusing to give it more time to find private investment. The Italian government approved a state bailout plan last Friday after the Siena-based bank, which can trace its roots back to 1472, failed to convince investors to fund a €5bn (£4.25bn) cash injection. It plans to dip into a €20bn fund approved by the government earlier this month for the purpose of propping the bank up if no rescue plan could be secured elsewhere. Weidmann's comments come as a surprise to many, as the ECB has been seen as a strong supporter of the Italian government's efforts to rescue Monte dei Paschi. The bank's struggling financial situation has raised concerns about the potential impact on the wider Italian economy, and the government has been under pressure to act quickly to prevent a crisis.

However, Weidmann's warning highlights the concerns that some policymakers have about the bank's financial health. Monte dei Paschi has been struggling for years, and its financial situation has only deteriorated in recent months. The bank has been trying to raise capital to shore up its balance sheet, but its efforts have been unsuccessful.

The Italian government's plan to dip into the €20bn fund to prop up the bank has been criticized by some as a short-term fix that does not address the underlying problems. Weidmann's comments suggest that the ECB is not convinced that the plan is sufficient to restore the bank's financial health.

The news has sent shockwaves through financial markets, with shares in Monte dei Paschi falling sharply in response to Weidmann's comments. The bank's future is now uncertain, and investors are waiting to see how the situation will unfold.

The Italian government has been working to finalize the bailout plan, which is expected to be completed in the coming weeks. However, Weidmann's comments have raised questions about whether the plan will be sufficient to address the bank's financial problems.

The situation is also likely to be closely watched by other European policymakers, who are concerned about the potential impact on the wider European economy. The ECB has been working to stabilize the financial system in the wake of the financial crisis, and any major problems at a major bank like Monte dei Paschi could have far-reaching consequences.

In the meantime, Monte dei Paschi's customers and employees are left wondering about the future of the bank. The bank's problems have already led to concerns about the stability of the Italian financial system, and the uncertainty surrounding the bailout plan is only adding to the anxiety.

Ten years ago I studied for a masters in peace and development in Leeds. I used to rejoice as I walked through the municipal gardens near my home as we learned about the need for "capacity building" in the developing world. How grateful I was for all the local municipal provision that we lived with here: the parks, halls, toilets, youth centres, libraries. With central-government austerity policies (Cuts at catastrophic level, says Birmingham council chief, 13 December), they are now all vanishing, or hard-pressed local volunteers are struggling to deal with community-asset transfer, taking over the running and the management of such amenities, if they are not sold off to unaccountable private companies. As I walked through those gardens, I felt a sense of security and community that I had taken for granted. But now, as I return to Leeds, I'm met with a stark reality. The very same gardens I once enjoyed are now overgrown and neglected, a symbol of the devastating impact of austerity policies. The halls, once bustling with community activities, are now empty and silent. The toilets, once clean and well-maintained, are now often out of order. The youth centres, once a hub of activity for young people, are now closed or struggling to stay afloat.

The once-thriving libraries, where I spent countless hours studying and researching, are now on the brink of closure. It's as if the very fabric of our community has been ripped apart. The volunteers who used to run these amenities are now exhausted and demoralized, struggling to cope with the demands of taking over their management and maintenance. And all the while, private companies are circling, waiting to swoop in and take control of these public assets for their own profit. It's a bleak future, and one that fills me with a sense of despair and disillusionment. How did we let it come to this?

Thousands of consumers may be holding worthless car hire bookings for the Christmas period after the company they booked through, Atlaschoice, apparently failed to pay firms providing the actual cars. Customers of the website have reported being told at car hire desks that their booking would not be honoured unless they paid again – in some cases many hundreds of pounds – because Atlas had not paid the car's actual provider. Frustrated customers of the west London car hire booking firm, which acted as booking agent for all the big car hire brands, have reported the problem on Twitter and other social media in recent days. "Cancelling my rental car, keeping my money and providing no other option two days before I fly home for Christmas. Seriously?" wrote Tom Richards on Twitter. Another customer, Chris Clifton-Brown, wrote online: "Booked through them recently and when I turned up to collect my car the hire firm made me aware that Atlaschoice are not paying the actual hire firms. I had to pay the hire firm for the car again even though Atlaschoice have already taken my money." The company, which has been in business since 1990, did not return calls or reply to emails. The website was still operating, but not apparently taking new bookings. Although Atlaschoice is not a household name many customers will have used the booking agent website via the popular TravelSupermarket comparison site – part of the MoneySupermarket group. As the holiday season approaches, thousands of travelers are left scrambling to find alternative transportation arrangements, while also trying to get refunds for their cancelled bookings. Many customers have taken to social media to express their frustration and disappointment with Atlaschoice, with some even sharing photos of empty car rental desks and unhelpful customer service representatives.

TravelSupermarket, the comparison site that partnered with Atlaschoice, has issued a statement apologizing for the inconvenience and promising to assist customers in finding new bookings. However, many customers are left wondering how this could have happened and why Atlaschoice was allowed to continue operating despite reportedly failing to pay its suppliers.

The situation has also raised concerns about the lack of regulation in the car rental industry, with some experts warning that similar scams could occur in the future if companies are not held accountable. "This is a classic case of a middleman not paying its bills, and it's unacceptable that it's happened to so many people just before Christmas," said John Smith, a travel industry expert. "We need to see stricter regulations in place to protect consumers from these types of scams."

In the meantime, customers are left to navigate the complicated process of getting refunds and finding alternative transportation arrangements. Many are also sharing their own horror stories on social media, with some even offering words of advice and support to those affected. As the holiday season gets underway, it remains to be seen how this crisis will be resolved and what steps will be taken to prevent similar situations from occurring in the future.

Urgently needing some new glass for windows in my house, I Googled local window companies, and found one called Emergency Response Group. I gave the measurements and it quoted me £400 to replace six windows. I agreed as I needed the work doing fast. It took my card details, which would be charged once the windows were replaced. When the glaziers showed up they said two of our windows needed safety glass (something not mentioned on the phone) and that they would have to come back. They suggested this would happen within the next week. We then heard nothing, so I assumed they had lost interest. As the days turned into weeks, I began to feel frustrated and concerned about the state of my windows. The initial quote had been for £400, and now I was starting to wonder if I had been taken for a ride. I decided to take matters into my own hands and contacted the company to inquire about the status of the job. After being put on hold for several minutes, I finally managed to get through to a representative who assured me that the glaziers were still working on the job and would be back to complete the installation soon.

I was skeptical, but decided to give them the benefit of the doubt. Another week went by, and still there was no sign of the glaziers. I started to feel like I had been strung along, and my patience was wearing thin. I decided to take a different approach and contacted the company's customer service department, explaining the situation and asking for a resolution. To my surprise, the representative was apologetic and sympathetic, and offered to send someone to complete the job the very next day.

The glaziers arrived on schedule, and finally the windows were replaced. But the experience had left a sour taste in my mouth. I had been misled by the initial quote, and had wasted valuable time and energy dealing with the company's lack of communication. I was relieved to have the new windows, but I couldn't help but wonder how many other customers had been similarly affected by the company's subpar service. I decided to share my experience with others, in the hopes that it might serve as a warning to those considering using Emergency Response Group for their window needs.

I note the current negotiations over the future of the ATM network (Fees row may lead to charge for Link cash machine withdrawals, 19 January). In 2005, I led a Treasury committee inquiry into cash machine charges which found hundreds of local areas where consumers were being hit with high charges. In Speke, a low-income area in Liverpool, consumers faced charges of £1.50 for making cash withdrawals. I established a working group including banks, consumer groups and ATM operators. The banks unanimously committed themselves to the long-term future of a large network of free cash machines and a "financial inclusion premium" was introduced for operators of free cash machines in 1,500 under-served low-income areas. The importance of the free-to-use ATM network has increased as banks have closed 1,000 branches in the past two years. Since then, the free-to-use ATM network has become even more crucial, particularly for vulnerable communities who rely on these machines to access their cash. The recent announcement that some banks are considering introducing fees for Link cash machine withdrawals has sparked concerns that this could exacerbate the problem.

As a result, I am calling on the banks and ATM operators to revisit their commitments to maintaining a large network of free cash machines. It is unacceptable that some areas are still facing high charges for cash withdrawals, and it is the responsibility of the financial institutions to ensure that everyone has access to their money without incurring unnecessary costs.

Furthermore, the introduction of fees for cash machine withdrawals could have a disproportionate impact on low-income households who are already struggling to make ends meet. They may be forced to pay exorbitant fees to access their cash, which could push them further into debt and financial hardship.

In addition, the closure of 1,000 bank branches in the past two years has already left many communities without easy access to banking services. Introducing fees for cash machine withdrawals would only serve to further isolate these communities and make it even more difficult for them to manage their finances.

I urge the banks and ATM operators to reconsider their plans and prioritize the needs of their customers. They must work together to maintain a large network of free cash machines, particularly in under-served areas, to ensure that everyone has access to their money without incurring unnecessary costs.

In conclusion, the introduction of fees for cash machine withdrawals would be a retrograde step and would have far-reaching consequences for vulnerable communities. I hope that the banks and ATM operators will take heed of my concerns and work together to maintain a free and accessible cash machine network for all.

Platinum miner Lonmin has come under attack over its record on conditions for its workers, nearly five years after dozens of people were killed in violence at its Marikana mine in South Africa. Speaking as protesters displayed placards bearing the names of the dead, the chief executive, Ben Magara, told shareholders at the group's annual meeting that progress on building homes for 33,000 staff had been "slower than we would have liked". But he said rock-bottom platinum prices made it impossible for the company to resolve the housing issue and stay financially sound. Thirty-four people were killed near the Marikana mine in August 2012, after workers went on strike, demanding a living wage from Lonmin in a complex dispute that escalated into violence. The former bishop of Pretoria Johannes Seoka, who was on the phone to one of the victims when the police opened fire, said the company should take more responsibility. "We're convinced that what happened is the result of their own reaction to demands of the workers," he said. "If they had talked with the workers that massacre would not have happened." The incident has left a lasting scar on the community, with many families still struggling to come to terms with the loss of their loved ones. "The pain is still fresh," said Thembi Ntombela, whose brother was among those killed. "We want to see some tangible action from Lonmin to address the issues that led to this tragedy." The company has faced repeated criticism for its handling of the strike and its response to the violence. Amnesty International has accused Lonmin of being "culpably responsible" for the deaths, citing a failure to protect workers and to engage with them in a meaningful way. Despite the company's efforts to rebuild trust, many in the community remain skeptical. "Words are cheap," said Sello Mokoena, whose father was killed in the violence. "We want to see concrete actions, not just promises." As the company struggles to find a solution to the housing issue, many are calling for greater accountability and transparency from Lonmin. "The company must take responsibility for its actions and ensure that such a tragedy never happens again," said Archbishop Seoka. "The workers are not asking for the moon, just a decent place to live and a fair wage." The company's struggles to address the housing issue come as it faces increasing pressure to improve its working conditions and safety record. The incident has also highlighted the broader issues of poverty and inequality in South Africa, with many workers still struggling to make ends meet. As the company and the community work to rebuild and move forward, many are calling for a more just and equitable society.

Shareholders appear to have blocked a pay rise for Alison Cooper, chief executive of Imperial Brands, in a move that may affect other FTSE 100 companies aiming to hike the bonuses of their bosses. The maker of Gauloises and John Player cigarettes issued an unexpected announcement to the stock exchange on Thursday to say it would not put its new pay policy to a vote as originally planned at the annual meeting on 1 February. The policy, which must be voted on every three years, would have had the effect of increasing Cooper's pay from £5.5m to a potential £8.5m a year from increased bonus opportunities. The move demonstrates that the company did not expect to win overwhelming support for the proposal from investors. The decision by ISS, the proxy voting agency which is influential with major US investors, to recommend a vote against the policy had signalled that a sizeable revolt was on the cards. Imperial's chairman, Mark Williamson, said investors had changed their minds about backing the plan. The unexpected move by Imperial Brands has sent shockwaves through the business community, with many analysts speculating that it may be a turning point in the debate over executive pay. The company's decision to withdraw its new pay policy from the vote at the annual meeting has been hailed as a victory for shareholders, who have long been frustrated by the generous compensation packages handed out to CEOs.

"It's a major win for investors," said one analyst, who wished to remain anonymous. "For too long, CEOs have been rewarded with lavish pay packages, regardless of how well the company is performing. This decision shows that shareholders are finally starting to push back."

The decision by ISS to recommend a vote against the policy was seen as a major factor in the company's decision to withdraw the proposal. ISS, which advises institutional investors on how to vote on corporate issues, had cited concerns over the potential for the pay package to create a "culture of complacency" at the company.

Imperial Brands' decision may also have implications for other FTSE 100 companies that are considering hiking the bonuses of their CEOs. With the spotlight now firmly on executive pay, other companies may be forced to rethink their own compensation packages.

"This is a wake-up call for all CEOs," said a spokesperson for the Shareholder Action Group, a campaign group that has been critical of excessive executive pay. "It's time for CEOs to start putting the interests of shareholders first, rather than lining their own pockets."

The decision has also sparked concerns over the potential impact on Imperial Brands' ability to attract and retain top talent. The company's CEO, Alison Cooper, had been expected to receive a significant pay rise under the new policy, which would have seen her compensation package increase from £5.5m to a potential £8.5m a year.

However, some analysts believe that the company's decision to withdraw the proposal may actually be a blessing in disguise. "This decision shows that Imperial Brands is willing to listen to its shareholders and take their concerns seriously," said one analyst. "It may actually help the company to attract more investors in the long run."

Tim Peake has announced he will return to the International Space Station for a second mission with the European Space Agency. The British astronaut unveiled his plans to revisit the space station at the Science Museum in London, where the charred Soyuz capsule that brought him and two spacefaring companions back to Earth in June has gone on display for the first time. "Reunited with Soyuz TMA-19M now on display, showing a few scars from reentry," Peake tweeted on Thursday morning. His next mission has not yet been named or scheduled and is unlikely to take place before 2019. Most European Space Agency missions to the space station last about six months. The next European astronaut to launch into space will be the Italian Paolo Nespoli in May. "It's what every astronaut wants to do," Peake told Sky News. "Myself and my classmates from 2009, we are all going to get the second mission to the space station, which is wonderful. "The work that is being done on board the space station is incredibly important and also tremendously exciting as well. It is only natural to want to return," he added. "The one thing you miss is the view of planet Earth, of course. It is the most spectacular thing you can possibly see." Peake's second mission will likely involve conducting scientific experiments and maintenance tasks on the space station, as well as participating in spacewalks. He expressed his excitement to be returning to the station, saying "It's a privilege to be able to go back and be part of the team that's working on the space station." When asked what he was looking forward to most about his second mission, Peake replied, "I think it's the opportunity to be part of the team that's pushing the boundaries of what we can do in space. The space station is an incredible facility, and I'm excited to be able to contribute to its success." Peake's first mission to the space station, which lasted from December 2015 to June 2016, was marked by a number of notable achievements, including the completion of a series of spacewalks and the testing of a new spacecraft system. He has also been involved in a number of outreach and educational activities, including giving talks to schools and participating in social media campaigns. Despite his excitement about his upcoming mission, Peake acknowledged that there are challenges involved in being an astronaut, saying "It's not easy, it's a tough job, but it's a job that I love."

The Bank of England governor has warned that a new breed of internet-only lenders are beginning to pose risks to the financial system and without tighter regulation they could trigger the next financial crash. Mark Carney said high street banks were being displaced by online lenders that were untested in a recession, when bankruptcies might make their loans worthless. Cyber-attacks could also strip customers of digital money, leaving them to face huge losses without the traditional protection offered by regulators, he said. The warning follows a speech last year by Adair Turner, the former chief financial regulator, who said losses on loans made over the internet could make the worst bankers look like "lending geniuses". Speaking at a conference in Germany, Carney said digital money held out the prospect of allowing millions of people excluded from the mainstream banking system to access loans securely. Threadneedle Street has several initiatives under way to allow peer-to-peer online lenders access to central bank funds and facilitate transactions. Carney's warning comes as the UK's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) is set to introduce new regulations on online lenders, aimed at ensuring they are operating in a safe and transparent manner. The FCA has been criticized for being slow to react to the rise of online lending, with some arguing that the lack of regulation has allowed unscrupulous lenders to take advantage of vulnerable consumers.

Despite the warning, online lenders have argued that they are providing a vital service to millions of people who have been excluded from the traditional banking system. They claim that their innovative approach to lending has allowed them to offer more competitive rates and more flexible repayment terms than traditional high street banks.

However, Carney's comments have been echoed by other experts in the industry, who warn that the lack of regulation and oversight of online lenders poses a significant risk to the financial system. "The problem is that these online lenders are operating in a regulatory vacuum," said one industry expert. "They are not subject to the same level of oversight as traditional banks, and that makes them a potential ticking time bomb for the financial system."

The Bank of England is also working with other regulators to develop a new framework for regulating online lenders. The framework is expected to include stricter capital requirements and more stringent risk assessments for online lenders.

Despite the challenges posed by online lenders, Carney believes that they have the potential to revolutionize the way people access credit. "Digital money has the potential to be a game-changer for financial inclusion," he said. "It could allow millions of people who have been excluded from the mainstream banking system to access loans securely and at a lower cost than traditional banks."

However, Carney's warning has been seen as a wake-up call for regulators and policymakers, who must now balance the need to promote financial inclusion with the need to protect the stability of the financial system. "The key is to find a balance between promoting innovation and ensuring that it is done in a safe and sustainable way," said a spokesperson for the Bank of England. "We are working closely with regulators and policymakers to develop a framework that will allow online lenders to thrive while also protecting the financial system."

Snapchat is tightening up its guidelines for publishers on its Discover service, banning the posting of risque images without editorial value, and clarifying guidelines intended to prevent the spread of fake news on the platform. The changes, according to a spokeswoman for Snap, Snapchat's parent company, are intended to "empower our editorial partners to do their part to keep Snapchat an informative, factual and safe environment for everyone". Toeing the line between keeping Snapchat age appropriate for younger users – the app bars children from under 13 from making accounts, but allows 13- to 17-year-olds on the service – and allowing publications on Discover editorial freedom has been difficult for the company, particularly when media organisations know one way to appeal to the app's millennial user base is with prominent use of risqué images. The Daily Mail, for instance, has attracted user complaints for frequently posting semi-nude images as its "cover" on the service. "I find it incredibly offensive that I can't opt out of seeing these images and that I am forced to see these images every time I open up the app to see my friends' stories," one user told the Guardian. The new guidelines, which take effect immediately, will also require publishers to clearly label opinion pieces and commentary as such, and to provide accurate and transparent information about the sources of their content. This move is seen as a response to concerns about the spread of misinformation on social media platforms, including Snapchat.

Snapchat has faced criticism in the past for its lack of transparency around its editorial policies and the types of content that are allowed on its platform. The company has also faced backlash for its handling of user complaints about offensive or inappropriate content.

In addition to the new guidelines, Snapchat is also introducing a new "flag" feature that will allow users to report content that they believe violates the company's community guidelines. The feature will be available in the app's settings and will allow users to report content that is "offensive," "inappropriate," or "spammy."

The changes come as Snapchat faces increased competition from other social media platforms, including Facebook and Instagram. The company has been working to improve its Discover service, which is a curated feed of content from publishers and other media organizations. The service has been a key part of Snapchat's efforts to attract more users and to increase engagement on the platform.

The new guidelines and features are intended to help Snapchat maintain its reputation as a platform that is safe and informative for users. The company has faced criticism in the past for its handling of user complaints and its lack of transparency around its editorial policies. The new guidelines and features are seen as a response to these concerns and are intended to help Snapchat build trust with its users.

There have been many tributes to Steve Hewlett these past few days. Here's another – which doesn't touch on his brilliance as a journalist or his resilience in the face of death. My point is simply that, when you occasionally joined him in the Media Show studio – walk in, sit down, start talking – he was utterly in command. His voice told you so. Politicians go through months of training to try to learn to speak with matter-of-fact honesty. Steve did that instinctively. His honesty was up front, the moment the green light came on. And that was a boon when the subject for discussion was the BBC itself. Steve knew the corporation inside out. He loved it in his way. As a result, his interviews with senior BBC executives were always enlightening, often uncomfortable, and occasionally explosive. He had a unique ability to extract candor from even the most reticent of subjects, and his probing questions left no stone unturned. Steve's passion for the BBC was matched only by his passion for telling the truth, and it was a privilege to watch him work his magic in the studio. His legacy will be remembered for years to come, not just for his remarkable journalism, but for the countless hours of compelling television he brought to our screens.

The sucker punch has been coming ever since the press – with hundreds of local newspaper editors up front – tried to fend off the supposed royal charter regulatory menace of article 40 (the one where publishers pay legal costs, win or lose). Lord Justice Leveson's insistence on a regulator offering cheap arbitration was a terrible sticking point, the editors said: a final burden on a struggling industry. Which, of course, made arbitration itself the litmus test for MPs and ministers wondering what to do next. Thus the culture, media and sport committee now gives Ipso (the non-Leveson-compliant regulator almost everyone has joined) a year to implement an acceptable arbitration scheme. If it doesn't, the baton of section 40 recognition passes to its sanctified (but scantily favoured) rival Impress. Either Ipso gets its act together, or nemesis – and the secretary of state – follows. Yes, but which scheme do you pick? The decision has sparked debate among industry insiders, with some arguing that Ipso's existing scheme is flawed and needs a complete overhaul. "The current system is a mess," said one editor. "It's a patchwork of different rules and procedures that are often confusing and unclear. We need a system that is fair, transparent, and easy to navigate."

Others, however, are more skeptical of Impress's ability to deliver a workable arbitration scheme. "Impress is a new and untested entity," said a spokesperson for the Newspaper Society. "We have concerns about its ability to provide a robust and independent arbitration service. We need to see more detail about its plans before we can consider it a viable alternative."

Meanwhile, the government has been accused of playing politics with the issue, with some arguing that it is using the arbitration scheme as a way to punish the industry for its opposition to section 40. "This is a classic example of the government using its power to try to silence the press," said a senior source at a major newspaper. "We will not be bullied into accepting a scheme that is fundamentally flawed."

The debate is set to continue in the coming weeks, with the culture, media and sport committee expected to take evidence from both Ipso and Impress. In the meantime, the industry remains on high alert, waiting to see which scheme will ultimately be chosen and what the implications will be for the future of journalism in the UK.

Channel Nine has apologised to billionaire Gina Rinehart for its depiction of her in its 2015 miniseries The House of Hancock, and agreed not to circulate the program again. Rinehart had instigated legal action against Nine and the production company responsible for the program, Cordell Jigsaw, over the two-part miniseries recounting the family drama of one of Australia's wealthiest mining dynasties. Nine and Cordell Jigsaw apologised to Rinehart in a statement on Friday that clarified the program "was a drama, not a documentary, and certain matters were fictionalised for dramatic purposes". "Nine and Cordell Jigsaw accept that Mrs Rinehart had a very loving and close relationship with her mother, father and husband, and has with [her children] Hope and Ginia ... "Nine and Cordell Jigsaw accept that Mrs Rinehart found the broadcast to be inaccurate. That was certainly not the intention of Nine or Cordell Jigsaw, and each unreservedly apologises to Mrs Rinehart and her family for any hurt or offence caused by the broadcast and its promotion." The statement also acknowledged Rinehart's "significant contribution" to Australia's industry and economy, as well as her "longstanding support of elite sport and numerous worthwhile charities". The program makers agreed to pay Rinehart's legal costs, likely to be a six-figure sum, and confirmed that the miniseries would not be sold to streaming channels, foreign markets or released on DVD. The agreement brings an end to the long-running legal battle between Rinehart and the media companies, which had been ongoing since the program's broadcast in 2015. Rinehart had claimed that the miniseries was defamatory and caused her significant distress, and had sought damages and an injunction to prevent further broadcast of the program.

The apology and settlement are seen as a significant victory for Rinehart, who had been vocal in her criticism of the program and its portrayal of her family. The settlement is also expected to be a costly one for Nine and Cordell Jigsaw, with Rinehart's legal costs likely to be in the hundreds of thousands of dollars.

The agreement has also sparked debate about the level of scrutiny and criticism that public figures are subject to, and the potential consequences of inaccurate or misleading reporting. Many have questioned whether the media has a responsibility to ensure the accuracy of its reporting, particularly when it comes to high-profile individuals such as Rinehart.

The settlement is also seen as a significant blow to Nine's reputation, which has already taken a hit in recent months due to a series of controversies surrounding its reporting practices. The network has faced criticism for its handling of several high-profile stories, including its coverage of the Christchurch mosque attacks and the COVID-19 pandemic.

In a statement, Rinehart's lawyers said that their client was "pleased" with the outcome of the case, and that the apology and settlement would bring an end to the "distress and harm" caused by the program. The statement also acknowledged that the settlement was a "significant victory" for Rinehart, and that it would serve as a reminder to the media of the importance of accuracy and fairness in its reporting.

Name: South Ribble. Age: 43. Population: 109,000. Appearance: Non-metropolitan district in Lancashire. Never been. What's it like? It's the best place to live in Britain. Is it really? No, sorry – I meant, it's the best place to live in Britain for people in their 20s. Is it good for clubbing? It has an active Rotary Club branch, yes.
