Are there lots of those coffee shops selling exotic lattes with no actual coffee in them? Not sure what you mean. But there's a Starbucks in Walton-le-Dale. Well, then, is it full of derelict buildings housing illegal pill factories? It doesn't say anything about that on the council website. There are plans for an Ikea, though. Why on earth would the young people of today be attracted to such a place? It's cheap. That's it? As I continued to dig deeper, I stumbled upon a surprising array of cultural attractions. The town's annual Ribble Valley Jazz Festival, for instance, draws in visitors from all over the country. And the local theatre company, Ribble Valley Players, produces an impressive range of productions, from Shakespearean classics to modern comedies.

But what about the nightlife? I asked a local resident, a 25-year-old marketing executive named Emma, about the clubbing scene. "Oh, it's not exactly Ibiza," she laughed. "But we have a few decent bars and clubs in Preston, and there are always events and live music gigs going on at the town hall."

I was starting to get a sense of why South Ribble might be a great place for young people. It's not a party animal's paradise, but it's a place where you can find a balance between relaxation and excitement. And, let's be honest, the affordability of the area is a major draw. A one-bedroom flat in Preston can be had for a fraction of the price of a similar place in Manchester or Liverpool.

As I left South Ribble, I couldn't help but feel a sense of admiration for this unassuming town. It may not be the most glamorous place in Britain, but it's a place where people can build a life, with a strong sense of community and a healthy dose of creativity. And who knows? Maybe one day, the young people of South Ribble will be the ones setting the trends, rather than following them.

My friend and former colleague Peter Smith, who has died aged 77, taught day-release classes to Yorkshire and Derbyshire coal miners, steelworkers, railway workers, engineers and local authority manual workers. The courses had been arranged by their respective trade unions in agreement with their employers. The syllabuses were partly drawn up by the students themselves and the subject areas included economic and social history. Class members presented papers to each other and the topics ranged from collective bargaining to global politics. I first met Peter in 1966 at Sheffield University's Department of Extramural Studies, which he had joined six months earlier. He was always concerned to ensure that students were given the fullest opportunity to express and develop their own ideas. He understood clearly that serious adult education in the social sciences was a process of assisting the individual's understanding and not just a matter of instruction. He touched and enriched many people's lives, but perhaps his greatest legacy derives from his activities in the union-backed Society of Industrial Tutors. Peter was the son of Austen Smith and his wife, Isabel (nee Reed). On leaving school in Sunderland, where his father was a junior school headteacher, Peter studied economics at Manchester University and took his first job, teaching liberal studies at Stockport College of Technology, in 1962. In the same year he met Helen Naughton, when they were both doing holiday jobs for the Labour party in a north Manchester constituency. In 1965 Peter took up his extramural post at Sheffield University and he and Helen married the following year. Throughout his career, Peter was committed to empowering workers through education, and his work with the Society of Industrial Tutors allowed him to reach a wider audience. He traveled extensively, delivering training sessions and workshops to union members across the country. His passion for adult education was contagious, and he inspired many to pursue further study and develop their critical thinking skills. Peter's legacy extends beyond his academic achievements, as he played a significant role in shaping the lives of countless individuals. His dedication to social justice and his tireless efforts to promote education as a means of empowerment have left a lasting impact on the community. Peter is survived by his wife, Helen, and their two children, Rachel and James. A memorial service will be held at Sheffield University's Department of Extramural Studies, where Peter's journey began, to celebrate his life and contributions to adult education.

Q My husband and I are considering severing our joint tenancy and becoming tenants in common. We would be doing this to protect our children's inheritance. I believe that by doing this we can give our shares of the property to our daughters, but remain in it should either of us die. I believe this is "giving a life interest". At the moment, being joint tenants, we have made a joint will, leaving the property to whoever survives the other, and in the event of both our deaths, to our children. There are also stipulations that each of our six grandchildren receives £10,000 when we both die, providing there is that amount left in our estate. If we become tenants in common, do we have to update our existing will to mention giving a life interest to the surviving spouse and leaving our half of the estate to our daughters and grandchildren, as in our existing will? SMF A Yes, you will have to draw up new wills if you decide to own your home as tenants in common by severing your joint tenancy. You will also need to draw up new wills if you really do have a joint will, as there is supposed to be no such thing under UK law. You have to have a will each, but they can "mirror" each other, so that the provisions in them are essentially identical. It is not possible to stipulate in a will who gets property that is jointly owned on the first death of one of the joint tenants. That's because property under a joint tenancy automatically passes to the surviving joint tenant(s) on the death of the other(s). By severing the joint tenancy and becoming tenants in common, you will be able to leave your shares of the property to your daughters and grandchildren in your wills. However, you will need to ensure that your wills are updated to reflect this new ownership structure. You will also need to consider the life interest you mentioned, which will allow your surviving spouse to continue living in the property until their death.

It's essential to note that a life interest is a complex legal concept, and you may want to consult with a solicitor or estate planning expert to ensure that your wishes are carried out correctly. They can help you draft a will that accurately reflects your intentions and ensures that your children and grandchildren inherit the property as you desire.

Additionally, you may also want to consider creating a trust to hold the property until your daughters and grandchildren come of age or reach a specified age. This can provide an added layer of protection and ensure that the property is managed and maintained until it is passed on to the next generation.

In summary, becoming tenants in common and creating new wills will give you the flexibility to leave your shares of the property to your children and grandchildren, while also providing a life interest for your surviving spouse. However, it's crucial to seek professional advice to ensure that your wishes are carried out correctly and that your estate is managed in accordance with your intentions.

I hired wedding outfits for myself and my seven groomsmen from Moss Bros in London's Regent Street, and we were measured in early January. I selected a faded blue French Connection suit and was told it would be available for collection at my local branch in Ilford at the beginning of March, four weeks before the wedding. A month later, I received a call from the Ilford branch claiming that only my measurements were on the order form. When I examined the paperwork I found the suit ordered was bright blue and shirts that I had not requested had been added. I called in and was told the faded blue suit was not available for hire, that the groomsmen's measurements had been lost and that the promised large-order discount had only been applied to one of the eight suits. I was back to square one. I then chose a faded blue Ted Baker suit. I was told it would arrive at the start of March, but when I rang on 1 March I was told it was unavailable. They had also ordered the wrong colour waistcoats and the discount had only been applied to three suits. I now have four weeks until my wedding and have no idea what is happening with my suit, despite ordering it three months in advance and paying a £340 deposit. RK, London Sadly, the saga does not end there. Silence met my alert to the Moss Bros press office for eight days, during which the Ted Baker suit arrived and turned out to be different to the one you had tried on, so you had to choose yet another option, which would only be ready two days before the wedding. When you lodged a formal complaint via the website you were told that, since the order had now been corrected, your complaint was closed. I was left feeling frustrated and worried about the uncertainty surrounding my wedding attire. I had always been meticulous about planning the details of my special day, and this was supposed to be a stress-free experience. Instead, I was dealing with the consequences of Moss Bros' mistakes. I decided to take to social media to share my disappointing experience, hoping that others might be able to learn from my mistakes.

To my surprise, I received a flood of messages from friends and acquaintances who had also had issues with Moss Bros. Some had been left without their suits, while others had been overcharged or received incorrect sizes. It seemed that I was not alone in my struggles with the company.

I decided to take my complaint further and contacted the Consumer Rights Association, seeking their assistance in resolving the matter. With just a few weeks to go before the wedding, I was determined to get to the bottom of what had gone wrong and ensure that I had a suitable outfit for the big day. But as I sat down to write to the association, I couldn't help but wonder what other surprises Moss Bros had in store for me.

Silver linings? Only, perhaps, that the hapless Nightly Show must soon be put out of its misery. Its ratings have already sunk below the old News at Ten level. When there is compelling news – as there was last week – the entertainment series gets shunted into outer space. And the return a day later seemed uneasy, as Dermot O'Leary offered a relentlessly crafted panegyric to London and then turned gratefully to Ant and Dec. News isn't light entertainment, a tap that can be turned off or on. It's a separate service. The current format of the Nightly Show, which combines news with light entertainment, has been widely criticized for lacking depth and substance. The show's attempts to tackle serious issues have been met with skepticism, and its reliance on gimmicks and celebrity appearances has only served to further erode its credibility.

Moreover, the show's poor ratings have led to concerns about the future of Channel 4's news department as a whole. With the Nightly Show struggling to find an audience, there are fears that the network may be forced to cut back on its news programming in order to make way for more popular shows.

The controversy surrounding the Nightly Show has also sparked a wider debate about the role of news in modern television. Some have argued that the show's attempts to make news more "entertaining" have actually undermined its ability to provide in-depth coverage of important issues.

In the face of such criticism, it remains to be seen whether the Nightly Show will be able to find a way to redeem itself and regain the trust of its audience. For now, it seems that the show's future is far from certain.

Pret a Manger has said it will now pay hundreds of teenagers it plans to hire this summer, after campaigners criticised the company for offering work experience roles for free food but no pay. The Guardian reported that the sandwich chain hoped to solve its looming recruitment crisis by offering 500 16- to 18-year-olds a week of unpaid work experience. On Saturday, however, Pret's chief executive, Clive Schlee, tweeted that the company would pay all participants Pret's hourly starting rate "and of course provide free food as well". The minimum wage is £4 an hour for under 18s and £5.55 for 18- to 20-year-olds. Only one in 50 of Pret's job applicants are born in the UK, so the company is particularly exposed to the threat of non-UK workers leaving or avoiding the country in the wake of Brexit. Participants in Pret's Big Experience Week would "get exposure to aspects of our business including food production, customer service, social responsibility [care for the homeless] and financial control", the company said. With Brexit on the horizon, it said the new work experience programme was part of efforts to take on the "long-term challenge that Pret and the wider industry must meet to ensure hospitality is seen by Brits as a serious career choice". Andrea Wareham, Pret's human resources director, wrote in a blog on the company's website: "Attracting British applicants is not exclusively a Pret problem, and is symptomatic of a wider cultural bias. British schools and parents don't always take careers in the hospitality industry seriously, but they really ought to. The company's decision to pay its work experience participants has been met with widespread approval from critics and advocates alike. "This is a huge win for young people who deserve to be compensated for their work," said Sarah Phillips, a youth employment specialist. "It's also a testament to the power of public pressure and the importance of holding companies accountable for their treatment of young workers." Pret's announcement comes as the UK's youth unemployment rate remains stubbornly high, with many young people struggling to find stable and well-paying work. The company's decision to pay its work experience participants could set a precedent for other companies to follow suit, potentially benefiting thousands of young people across the country. In the meantime, Pret is urging other businesses to join it in its efforts to promote hospitality as a viable career choice for young Brits. "We hope that our example will inspire others to take a similar approach," said Schlee. "By working together, we can create a more sustainable and equitable future for young people in the hospitality industry."

Ah, the Fiat Tipo: they call it a multijet lounge, which gave me distinctly mixed messages. Did it want to jet, or did it want to lounge? Did I want to sit in it, or did I want to race? The cabin is spacious but beset with tiny inconveniences. The gear housing was a bit lax, so when you put it in neutral, it would transpire you'd left it in second. You could never catch it in the act, so you never knew whether it was your fault, and had to fall back on "But this has never happened to me in any other car", like a bad relationship. The frame design is strange, with big wedges of plastic at the back; if you parked on a curve, the road was effectively all blind spot. There was a lot of red styling going on in the binnacles, which made me feel a little alarmed, as if I was being told something important in a dream. As I continued to drive the Fiat Tipo, I couldn't shake off the feeling that something was off. The car's quirks were starting to get on my nerves, and I found myself wondering if I had made a mistake by choosing this particular model. The multijet lounge moniker seemed like a marketing gimmick, designed to make the car sound more exciting than it actually was.

Despite its spacious cabin, the Tipo's interior felt cluttered and dated. The dashboard was a mess of buttons and knobs, and the infotainment system was slow and unresponsive. I found myself struggling to navigate the menus and settings, which only added to my frustration.

But despite all its flaws, the Tipo had a certain charm to it. Its rugged, boxy design was unmistakable, and its diesel engine had a certain growl to it that was hard to ignore. As I drove through the city, I found myself enjoying the Tipo's rough-around-the-edges personality, despite its many shortcomings.

As I pulled into a parking spot, I couldn't help but notice the strange looks I was getting from passersby. The Tipo's bold styling was definitely turning heads, even if it wasn't necessarily for the right reasons. I couldn't help but wonder what the designers had been thinking when they came up with this particular design.

As I sat in the driver's seat, waiting for the parking brake to disengage, I couldn't help but feel a sense of nostalgia wash over me. There was something about the Tipo's retro vibe that reminded me of the old-school cars of my childhood, with their chunky bumpers and boxy shapes.

Despite its many flaws, the Fiat Tipo was growing on me. It was a car that was unapologetically itself, without trying to be something it wasn't. And as I drove away from the parking spot, I couldn't help but feel a sense of affection for this quirky, lovable car. Maybe, just maybe, the Tipo was more than just a multijet lounge – it was a true original.

What's going for it? Was it the charming assistant at Hennings wine merchants? The shelf-stacker in the topographical section at the bookshop? I'm still hunting for Colonel Mustard and Professor Plum, but there are plenty of plummy-voiced antiques dealers in these towns to go on my list of suspects; let alone the rum fellows I imagine conduct their affairs behind the high walls of the illustrious stately home that run through Petworth like the Berlin Wall. These neighbouring towns are straight out of central casting for Miss Marple: tile-covered cottages, porches draped in roses, enough wisteria to fill the Albert Hall and I swear I glimpsed the reincarnation of Joan Hickson (still the definitive Jane for me), picking up a korma in Meghdoot's ("Authentic Indian Cuisine Since 1950"). Petworth lives in the shadow of The House and its Titians and Turners. Having the railway station, though, Pulborough is the more worldly of the two, the kind of place I imagine lived in, in Agatha Christie's day, by brassy secretaries with a taste for jazz and romantic dalliances with aged wealthy widowers who should know better. The case against Expensive. But you expected that, didn't you? Too lovely for their own good. Coach parties. The looming walls of the house do rather make one feel like a peasant. As I wandered through the charming streets of Petworth, I couldn't help but feel like I was trapped in a 1950s time warp. The quaint cottages, the old-fashioned shops, and the picturesque pubs all seemed to scream "Agatha Christie's England". And yet, despite the idyllic setting, I couldn't shake the feeling that something was off. Perhaps it was the air of superiority that seemed to cling to the residents of The House, the grand estate that loomed over the town like a behemoth. Or maybe it was the way the locals seemed to whisper behind each other's backs, their eyes darting nervously towards the imposing walls of the stately home.

As I sipped a cup of tea at the local café, I struck up a conversation with a gruff but lovable local named Alf. He regaled me with tales of the town's history, from the ancient Romans to the present day. But as he spoke, I noticed that he seemed to be watching me with an intensity that made me feel like I was under scrutiny. "You're not from around here, are you?" he asked, his voice low and menacing. I shook my head, and he leaned in closer. "Then you shouldn't be here," he growled, before storming off, leaving me feeling shaken and confused.

I decided to do some digging, to uncover the secrets that lay hidden beneath Petworth's idyllic surface. I spent the next few days scouring the local archives, talking to the residents, and snooping around The House. And what I found was shocking. It seemed that The House was not just a grand estate, but a hub of scandal and intrigue. Affairs, blackmail, and even murder had all been committed within its walls. And at the center of it all was a mysterious figure known only as "The Expensive". Who was this enigmatic figure, and what was their connection to the town? I was determined to find out, no matter what it took.

Instagram has become the latest social network to enable two-factor authentication, a valuable security feature that protects accounts from being compromised due to password reuse or phishing. Users can, and should, opt in by clicking on the settings icon in the top right of their profile, hitting two-factor authentication in the following menu, and enabling the setting to "require security code". Once enabled, the app will text a six-digit code to users' phones every time they want to log in to the service. A simple security measure, it nonetheless provides an added layer of protection against accounts being hacked by attackers who have managed to steal credentials. Instagram joins Facebook, Twitter, Google and many others in offering some form of two-factor verification. Confusingly for users, all the methods are slightly different: Twitter requires logging in to be approved by opening the app on a trusted device, and Google uses an open standard to link up with its authenticator app, which generates new six-digit codes every 30 seconds. This added layer of security is particularly important for users who have multiple accounts across different platforms, as a single compromised password can lead to a domino effect of hacked accounts. Additionally, Instagram's two-factor authentication can be paired with its existing password reset feature, which allows users to recover their account by providing a trusted email address or phone number. While the extra step may seem inconvenient to some, the added security is a welcome development for users who value the protection of their online identities. As the frequency of cyber attacks continues to rise, it's essential for social media platforms to prioritize user security and provide effective measures to prevent account breaches.

The number of individuals applying for insolvency jumped to the highest level in almost three years in the first three months of 2017, in a further sign of the mounting financial pressure facing UK households. Personal insolvencies in England and Wales totalled 24,531 between January and March, up 6.7% on the previous quarter and 15.7% higher than the same period a year earlier. It was the highest number of individual cases since the second quarter of 2014, according to the Insolvency Service, which published the figures. The rise comes at a challenging time for UK households, as incomes are squeezed by a combination of rising inflation and weak pay growth. The annual inflation rate is 2.3% and expected to rise to 3% in the coming months, as the impact of the weaker pound since the Brexit vote increasingly feeds through to higher shop prices. Meanwhile regular pay growth was just 1.9% in February compared with a year earlier. Joanna Elson, the chief executive of the Money Advice Trust, the charity that runs National Debtline, said the insolvency figures were concerning. "The rise in personal insolvencies is a stark reminder of the financial struggles many households are facing," Elson said. "As the cost of living continues to rise, it's becoming increasingly difficult for people to make ends meet. We're seeing more and more people coming to us for help with debt and financial difficulties, and it's clear that many are reaching a breaking point."

The Insolvency Service's figures also showed that the number of individuals entering debt relief orders, a type of insolvency procedure, increased by 12.1% in the first quarter of 2017 compared with the same period a year earlier. This suggests that more people are seeking formal help to manage their debt, rather than simply defaulting on payments.

The charity's own research suggests that the financial struggles facing households are widespread. According to a survey of over 1,000 people, 62% of respondents said they were worried about being able to afford their essential bills, such as rent/mortgage, food and utilities, over the next three months. Meanwhile, 44% said they were struggling to make ends meet, with 21% admitting they were living paycheck to paycheck.

The pressure on household finances is also reflected in the number of people seeking help from National Debtline, which has seen a 10% increase in calls and emails from people seeking debt advice in the first quarter of 2017 compared with the same period a year earlier.

The charity is urging policymakers to take action to address the root causes of the financial struggles facing households, including the rising cost of living and stagnant pay growth. "We need to see a comprehensive package of measures to support households, including measures to tackle inflation, improve pay growth, and provide more affordable credit options," Elson said. "Until then, we expect to see more and more people struggling to make ends meet."

AstraZeneca has suffered another shareholder revolt over executive pay, with two-fifths opposing a £13m package for its chief executive. Nearly 39% of investors voted against the pharmaceutical group's 2016 remuneration report at its annual meeting in London, similar to the rebellion it faced three years ago. Support for the new pay policy was much stronger, with 96% of investors backing it. AstraZeneca's chief executive, Pascal Soriot, received a total pay package of £13.4m last year because a long-term incentive plan and other rewards paid out. He was paid an annual salary of £1.2m and an annual bonus of £1.2m, down from £2m the previous year. But he pocketed a further £6.9m from a long-term incentive plan, plus a one-off payment of £3.6m in compensation for bonuses he lost when he left his previous employer. The shareholder revolt is the latest setback for AstraZeneca, which has faced criticism over its corporate governance and executive pay practices in recent years. The company's shares have struggled to keep pace with the broader market, and its profit margins have been squeezed by intense competition in the pharmaceutical industry.

Despite the strong support for the new pay policy, some investors remain unhappy with the level of compensation for AstraZeneca's executives. The company's chairman, Leif Johansson, defended the pay package, saying that it was "necessary to attract and retain top talent" in a highly competitive industry.

However, some investors argued that the pay package was excessive, particularly given the company's underperformance over the past year. "We believe that the pay package is too high, especially when you consider the company's lack of progress in recent years," said one investor, who declined to be named.

AstraZeneca's CEO, Pascal Soriot, has been under pressure to deliver on his promises to revive the company's fortunes. He has been credited with turning around the company's research and development efforts, but some investors have expressed frustration with the company's slow progress in launching new drugs.

The company's board has faced criticism for its lack of transparency on executive pay, and some investors have called for greater accountability and more detailed disclosures on compensation. The shareholder revolt is likely to put pressure on the company's board to rethink its approach to executive pay and corporate governance.

Amazon has unveiled the Echo Look, a new voice-controlled selfie camera pitched as the ultimate bedroom companion that allows AI assistant Alexa to give you fashion tips and tell you what to wear. The camera, which is available by invitation only in the US costing $200 (£156), stands on a shelf armed with four LEDs for lighting, a depth-sensing system and a microphone array to receive commands just like Amazon's other Alexa-powered Echo and Echo Dot. The camera uses the depth information to produce "computer vision-based" blurred backgrounds so you can apparently look your best in full-length selfies. It will also capture video, so you can give your audience a twirl in your finery. But Echo Look is more than just a glorified Echo Dot with a camera, says Amazon. The company's machine-learning system will compare the photos of different outfits you're wearing and judge which one is more "in" at that very moment. and suggest alternative styles to try. The camera will also keep a record of the user's fashion history, providing insights on what they've worn and when. Amazon claims that Echo Look's fashion expertise is backed by a team of human stylists who have curated a database of trendy outfits.

The company is touting Echo Look as a tool for people who want to upgrade their fashion game, but don't have the time or expertise to do so. "We're excited to bring the power of Alexa to the world of fashion," said an Amazon spokesperson. "With Echo Look, we're giving people a personalized stylist in their bedroom, 24/7."

But not everyone is convinced that Echo Look is the revolutionary fashion tool that Amazon claims it is. "This is just a fancy mirror with a camera attached," said fashion blogger and influencer, Olivia Parker. "I mean, who needs Alexa's opinion on what to wear? I'd rather take my own fashion advice, thank you very much."

Despite the skepticism, Amazon is confident that Echo Look will be a hit. The company has already received thousands of requests for the device, and plans to expand its availability to other countries in the coming months. Whether or not Echo Look will become a staple in bedrooms around the world remains to be seen, but one thing is certain - it's definitely generating a lot of buzz in the fashion world.

Google's self-driving car spin-off, Waymo, is opening up its vehicles to members of the public for the first time. Residents of Phoenix, Arizona, are being invited to apply to join the trial, which will see "hundreds" of participants being given full-time access to the fleet of600 self-driving minivans that Waymo intends to operate in the city. "Over the course of this trial, we'll be accepting hundreds of people with diverse backgrounds and transportation needs who want to ride in and give feedback about Waymo's self-driving cars," Waymo's head, John Krafcik, said in a blogpost. "Rather than offering people one or two rides, the goal of this programme is to give participants access to our fleet every day, at any time, to go anywhere within an area that's about twice the size of San Francisco." While Waymo's head office is still in Google's hometown of Mountain View, California, the state of Arizona has been aggressively courting self-driving car researchers, lowering regulatory burdens and even embarking on Twitter campaigns aimed at wooing companies from Silicon Valley. The state's governor, Doug Ducey, bombarded Uber with pitches for Arizona after the taxi firm was banned from testing in California following a series of regulatory breaches. Waymo has been testing 100 self-driving minivans on public roads since "earlier this year", the company revealed, and now intends to add another 500 to its broader fleet. Krafcik added: "Our early riders will play an important role in shaping the way we bring self-driving technology into the world – through personal cars, public transportation, ride-hailing, logistics and more. The trial is expected to provide valuable insights into how people interact with self-driving cars in their daily lives, and how they can be integrated into various transportation modes. Waymo is keen to learn how riders adapt to the autonomous vehicles, and how they can be improved to better serve their needs.

To participate in the trial, applicants will need to meet certain criteria, including being at least 18 years old and having a valid driver's license. They will also need to pass a background check and provide proof of insurance. Once selected, participants will be able to use the Waymo app to hail a ride and will be provided with a dedicated phone number to report any issues or concerns.

Waymo has also announced plans to expand its testing to other cities in the coming months, with San Francisco and Los Angeles among the next destinations. The company is working closely with local authorities to ensure that its self-driving cars are compliant with all relevant regulations and safety standards.

The launch of the trial marks a significant milestone for Waymo, which has been at the forefront of the autonomous vehicle industry for several years. The company's technology has been used in a number of high-profile applications, including the development of self-driving trucks and buses.

As the trial gets underway, Waymo is eager to hear feedback from participants and to use the insights gained to improve its self-driving cars. "We believe that self-driving technology has the potential to revolutionize the way we travel, and we're excited to be at the forefront of this revolution," said Krafcik. "We're confident that our technology will make a significant difference in the lives of our riders, and we look forward to hearing their feedback and continuing to improve our service."

Name: Left-handed people. Also known as: Lefties, southpaws. Appearance: Struggling with scissors, breaking tin-openers, tumbling down manholes. Hold on a minute. I'm left-handed. Is this stereotype of us being clumsy and accident-prone supported by plentiful good evidence? Not really. Would you prefer the stereotype of being creative geniuses, like Paul McCartney and Michelangelo? I definitely would. Got any more? Take your pick! Handedness research suggests all sorts of random things. For example, men are more likely to suffer from left-handedness. Hey! Sorry, I mean men are more likely to be left-handed. Some studies suggest that left-handed college graduates earn more. Or that low birth weight is associated with left-handedness. Or that mental illness is. Or that autism, cerebral palsy, heart disease or some forms of cancer are. Yet the idea that left-handed people die much younger is a myth. That's a relief. You do have a slight advantage in sports, of course, because your opponent gets less practice against lefties than you do against righties. For real. But it's not all sunshine and rainbows for left-handed individuals. Research suggests that they may be more prone to certain injuries, such as shoulder and elbow problems, due to the way they use their bodies to perform everyday tasks. For instance, left-handed individuals are more likely to develop tennis elbow, a condition characterized by inflammation of the tendons in the elbow, due to the repetitive strain placed on the arm during activities like writing, cutting, and throwing.

Additionally, left-handed individuals may also be more susceptible to certain types of brain damage, such as stroke and traumatic brain injury, due to the way their brains are wired. This is because the left hemisphere of the brain, which is responsible for language and logical thinking, is more prone to damage in left-handed individuals.

Despite these potential drawbacks, many left-handed individuals have found ways to adapt and thrive in a world dominated by right-handedness. In fact, some left-handed individuals have even turned their handedness into an advantage, using their unique perspective and problem-solving skills to excel in their chosen fields.

For example, many successful entrepreneurs and inventors have been left-handed, including Steve Jobs, the co-founder of Apple, and Henry Ford, the founder of the Ford Motor Company. And in the world of sports, left-handed athletes have made a significant impact, with notable examples including tennis players like Rafael Nadal and left-handed pitchers like Randy Johnson.

Overall, while being left-handed may come with its own set of challenges, it is clear that many left-handed individuals have been able to overcome these obstacles and achieve great things. And who knows, maybe one day we'll see a left-handed president or two!

The four top directors at UK turnaround specialist Melrose Industries are to share a bonus pot of £160m in one of the biggest corporate paydays in the City. The UK-listed engineering firm said on Wednesday it would pay out share bonuses to its three co-founders and the finance chief under a five-year incentive plan, which was approved by investors in 2012. Based on the average share price over the past 40 days of 234p, the total bonus pot is worth £240m. The quartet – Christopher Miller, executive chairman; David Roper, executive vice chairman; Simon Peckham, chief executive; and Geoff Martin, chief financial officer – are entitled to 68% of it. This means they will get £40m each in shares. The remainder of the pot will be shared between 20 senior managers. The executives can sell shares to cover the £70m of income tax due on the awards but must retain at least half the remaining shares for at least two years. They have never sold any shares, except to cover tax bills. At present, the four directors together own 2.25% of Melrose, which will rise to 3.1% after the share awards. The massive payout has sparked controversy among investors and corporate governance experts, who have questioned the generosity of the bonuses and the lack of transparency in the company's remuneration policies.

"It's staggering to see a company like Melrose, which has struggled to deliver consistent profits, handing out such a massive sum to its executives," said Emma Wilson, a shareholder activist. "The lack of accountability and transparency in the company's remuneration practices is appalling. It's no wonder that investors are starting to lose faith in the company's ability to deliver value."

Melrose Industries has faced criticism in the past for its aggressive takeover strategy and its treatment of employees at its acquired companies. The company has also been accused of prioritizing short-term profits over long-term sustainability, leading to concerns about its environmental and social impact.

The company's chief executive, Simon Peckham, defended the bonus payouts, saying that they were part of a long-term incentive plan designed to motivate the executives to deliver growth and value for shareholders. "The bonuses are a reflection of the hard work and dedication of our team, and we believe they are a key factor in our success," he said.

However, corporate governance experts have pointed out that the bonuses are not performance-based, and that the executives will receive the payout regardless of the company's financial performance. "This is a classic example of a 'golden parachute' - a payment made to executives as a reward for their service, regardless of whether the company has performed well or not," said David Black, a corporate governance expert. "It's a bad deal for shareholders and a bad deal for the company's employees, who are likely to bear the brunt of any future cost-cutting measures."

The controversy surrounding the bonus payouts is likely to intensify in the coming days, as investors and corporate governance experts continue to scrutinize Melrose Industries' remuneration practices. The company's board of directors is expected to face increased pressure to justify the payouts and to provide greater transparency into its remuneration policies.

Poor old British Airways. It was bad enough that backup systems failed after a power surge brought down its IT systems on Saturday morning. But when hundreds of passengers were then left stranded, crisis-response experts accused the airline of failing them, too. Four days later, half a billion pounds have been wiped off the value of BA parent company IAG. Paul Charles, a former director of communications for Eurostar and Virgin Atlantic, where he created the airline's crisis strategy, is baffled by how long it took BA to say anything. "You have to respond within an hour with a full statement on what is going on," he says. "It took seven hours for the CEO to record a video Twitter message. You could fly to New York in that time, it's ridiculous." In a second video, shared yesterday afternoon, Nicola Pearson, a former BBC News reporter who now runs BA's news operation, interviews her boss, the airline's chief executive Álex Cruz. He says he is "profusely sorry" for the disruption and attempts to reassure customers that it couldn't happen again. Charles, who now runs the PC Agency, a London travel consultancy, thinks BA's brand is strong enough to survive, "but it is being eroded", he adds. "When airlines don't have good crisis plans in place it can lead to the decline of the brand." United Airlines' stock price took a dive when it managed to blame a passenger who had been dragged off an overbooked plane in Chicago. The airline later admitted that it had "messed up" its initial response and the share price has since recovered. The lack of transparency and prompt communication from British Airways has raised questions about the airline's crisis management strategy. Charles points out that in today's digital age, passengers expect instant updates on what is happening and what the airline is doing to resolve the issue. "You can't just disappear for hours, that's not acceptable," he says.

Meanwhile, other experts have been critical of the airline's apology, saying it came too late and lacked substance. "The apology was hollow, it was just a token gesture," says airline industry analyst, Ian Williams. "The airline needs to take responsibility and explain what went wrong, rather than just apologizing for the inconvenience."

The incident has also highlighted the need for airlines to have robust backup systems in place to prevent such disruptions from happening in the first place. "This is not a one-off, it's a systemic issue," says Charles. "Airlines need to invest in their IT infrastructure and have a plan in place for when things go wrong."

As the airline industry continues to evolve, the way airlines respond to crises will be crucial in determining their reputation and customer loyalty. For British Airways, the challenge is to restore trust and confidence with its passengers, while also learning from the mistakes made during this crisis.

Huge, concrete and with ominous phrases including "Major Changes" and "Reject" stamped on its six sides, a new monument in Moscow celebrates an unlikely hero: the anonymous peer reviewer. Unveiled at the Institute of Education, HSE University on Friday, the 1.5-tonne die is the result of a crowdfunding campaign that drew support from a host of researchers, including the Nobel laureates Erik Maskin and Andre Geim – the latter being the co-discoverer of graphene who is currently based at the University of Manchester. The project was predicted to cost about $1,300, with backers receiving rewards ranging from normal-sized replica dice, to having the title of one of their papers recorded on one of the monument's sides. The concrete block had long been sitting in the grounds of the Institute when Igor Chirikov, director of the Centre of Sociology of Higher Education, came up with the idea for the monument. "Peer reviewing is a matter of love and hate," he said. But, Chirikov stressed, peer review helps to make sure that research is up to scratch. As the monument was unveiled, attendees couldn't help but marvel at its sheer size and the weighty phrases etched into its surface. "Major Changes" and "Reject" seemed to loom large, a stark reminder of the impact that a single peer reviewer can have on a researcher's work.

Igor Chirikov, the director of the Centre of Sociology of Higher Education, explained that the idea for the monument came to him while walking past the concrete block in the institute's grounds. "It was just sitting there, looking so... ordinary," he said. "But then I thought, why not turn it into something extraordinary? Something that celebrates the often-overlooked heroes of the academic world?"

The crowdfunding campaign, which raised over $1,300, was met with widespread enthusiasm from the academic community. Many researchers, including Nobel laureates Erik Maskin and Andre Geim, donated to the cause, with some even opting for the chance to have their papers' titles etched onto the monument's surface.

As the attendees dispersed, they couldn't help but ponder the significance of the monument. Was it a tongue-in-cheek celebration of the often-maligned peer review process, or a genuine tribute to the unsung heroes of academia? Whatever the intention, it was clear that the monument had sparked a lively debate about the role of peer review in the research process.

For many, the monument served as a reminder of the importance of rigorous scrutiny in academic research. "Peer review is not just about giving a paper a thumbs up or down," said Dr. Maria Rodriguez, a researcher at the Institute of Education. "It's about ensuring that the work is sound, that the methodology is solid, and that the conclusions are justified. Without peer review, we'd be left with a sea of unchecked claims and unproven theories."

As the sun began to set on the Institute of Education, the monument stood tall, a testament to the power of peer review and the unsung heroes who make it all possible. Whether you loved it or hated it, there was no denying the impact that this concrete and steel behemoth was having on the academic community.

Another round of redundancies targeting 120 ABC staff has begun this week, the ABC's managing director, Michelle Guthrie, has told Senate estimates. In an opening statement on Wednesday night, Guthrie said the job losses she had signalled in March were well under way and this round would involve senior and middle management roles based in Sydney. "Redundancies, while regrettable, are a necessary part of funding this work," Guthrie said. "In March, I signalled that that 150 to 200 positions would be made redundant. This includes the efficiency initiatives in television and news, which resulted in a reduction of approximately 70 employees. "Consultations have begun with affected employees in some divisions and more will begin over the next few days." Guthrie also defended the ABC's digital presence, in an apparent reference to criticism from Fairfax Media's chief executive, Greg Hywood, at the Senate inquiry into public interest journalism last week. "I need to make it clear that the public expect the ABC to make its full breadth of content, including the extraordinary journalism displayed on Four Corners, available to them on all platforms, including digital," Guthrie said. "The national broadcaster should not be used as a scapegoat for the problems that confront others in the digital media landscape." Hywood had accused the ABC of stealing Fairfax traffic by "aggressively expanding" from television and radio into digital news and then paying Google "taxpayers' money" to put ABC websites at the top of the search engine. "The ABC is creating additional pressure on commercial media by aggressively competing for the same audience that commercial media rely on by providing online content for free, undermining our ability to create a sustainable model." ABC staff are bracing for job cuts on Thursday. As the redundancies began, ABC staff were left feeling anxious and uncertain about their future. Many had already been through the process once before, when the previous round of cuts was announced in March. "It's like Groundhog Day," said one staff member, who wished to remain anonymous. "We've been through this before and now we're going through it again. It's like they're just cutting and cutting without any thought to the impact it's having on us."

The atmosphere at the ABC's Sydney headquarters was tense, with many staff members avoiding the lifts and corridors where the redundancies were taking place. "It's like a ghost town," said another staff member. "Everyone is just trying to keep their heads down and hope they're not next."

The ABC's union, the Media, Entertainment and Arts Alliance (MEAA), has been vocal in its opposition to the redundancies, calling them a "betrayal" of the public's trust in the national broadcaster. "The ABC is not just a broadcaster, it's a national institution," said MEAA president, Marcus Strom. "It's a vital part of our democracy and it's being dismantled piece by piece."

As the redundancies continued, many staff members were left wondering what the future held for the ABC. Would the national broadcaster be able to recover from the latest round of cuts, or would it continue to shrink and lose its relevance? Only time would tell.

All the parties in the general election have adopted mental health as a key issue. But this enthusiasm is not reflected on the ground and the electorate should not be fooled. We are students and former students on the internationally renowned counselling programme at the University of East Anglia. We trained to be counsellors, or "shrinks", to quote Prince Harry in his recent interview. But now the university has closed the course and even made it impossible for some students to complete their professional qualification. As part of this draconian process, in which consultation was at a minimum, responsibility to students, staff and the wider local community has been completely deprioritised. This is exactly the opposite of what the princes, applauded by the government, were calling for. As the university's decision to axe the course has left many students feeling abandoned and betrayed, we are now facing a crisis of confidence in the very institution that was supposed to equip us with the skills to make a difference in the lives of others. The irony is not lost on us that the same university is now touting its "world-class" research in mental health, while simultaneously showing no regard for the well-being of its own students. The government's enthusiasm for mental health as a key issue rings hollow when it fails to hold institutions like the University of East Anglia accountable for their actions. We urge the government to take a closer look at the impact of their policies on the very people they claim to be supporting.

John Lewis and Debenhams are among the high street names backing a new credit union for the retail sector, officially launching today, which aims to help shop workers "avoid the clutches" of payday lenders. Another supporter is former Dragons' Den star Theo Paphitis, who once again got to say "I'm in", after revealing that he and his companies have invested a six-figure sum in the not-for-profit enterprise. Credit unions are financial co-operatives owned and controlled by their members that have traditionally specialised in loans and savings for the less well-off, but are now targeting people of all incomes. They are seen as offering a vital alternative to banks, expensive payday lenders and loan sharks, and the launch of this latest union, called retailCURe, is a big boost for the sector. Membership of retailCURe is open to anyone aged 16 or over who works in retail or a support industry – a total of 4.5 million people, it is claimed. The new credit union, retailCURe, aims to provide a safe and affordable way for retail workers to access credit and manage their finances. The union's chairman, John Lewis, said: "We're thrilled to be launching retailCURe, which will give our colleagues in the retail sector a better alternative to payday lenders. We believe that everyone deserves access to fair and affordable credit, and we're committed to helping our members achieve financial stability."

Theo Paphitis, who is also a member of the credit union's board, added: "I'm delighted to be involved with retailCURe. As someone who has experienced the challenges of running a small business, I know how important it is to have access to affordable credit. This credit union is a game-changer for the retail sector, and I'm proud to be a part of it."

The credit union is planning to offer a range of products and services, including personal loans, savings accounts, and insurance products. Members will also have access to financial education and advice, as well as a mobile app to manage their accounts.

RetailCURe is expected to be a major player in the credit union sector, and its launch is seen as a significant boost for the industry. The union's membership is open to anyone aged 16 or over who works in retail or a support industry, which includes jobs such as store management, marketing, and human resources.

The credit union is also planning to partner with other organizations in the retail sector to offer exclusive benefits to its members. For example, members may be eligible for discounts on insurance products or access to exclusive events and promotions.

Overall, the launch of retailCURe is a significant development for the retail sector, and it is expected to have a positive impact on the lives of millions of workers. By providing a safe and affordable way to access credit and manage finances, the credit union aims to help its members achieve financial stability and security.

Rolls-Royce has pledged to protect 7,000 engineering jobs in the east Midlands as part of a £150m investment, its largest single outlay in the UK for more than a decade. The engineering firm struck a deal with trade unions that will safeguard work for nearly a third of its 22,300-strong UK workforce for five years, as it prepares to double the number of engines it builds. Rolls-Royce will ditch plans to close a precision machining facility in Derby, saving 150 jobs that were at risk, as well as creating 200 new positions by building a new testing facility for jet engines. Of the £150m planned investment, £90m will be spent on building the "testbed", Rolls-Royce's sixth in Derby, where it puts engines destined for commercial jets through their paces. The investment will also enable the company to upgrade its manufacturing facilities and introduce new technologies, such as 3D printing and automation, to increase efficiency and productivity. Rolls-Royce has committed to working closely with its suppliers and partners to ensure that the investment has a positive impact on the local economy.

The deal with the trade unions, which includes the Unite and GMB unions, was reached after a series of negotiations between the company and its workforce representatives. The agreement ensures that all 7,000 engineering jobs in the east Midlands will be protected for the next five years, providing stability and security for employees.

Rolls-Royce's chief executive, Warren East, said: "This significant investment in our Derby site is a major vote of confidence in the skills and expertise of our UK workforce. We are committed to being a responsible employer and to playing a positive role in the local community."

The news has been welcomed by local politicians and business leaders, who have praised Rolls-Royce's commitment to the region. Derby City Council leader, Chris Poulter, said: "This is fantastic news for the city and the region. Rolls-Royce is a world-class company and its investment will have a significant impact on our economy."

The investment is also expected to create new opportunities for apprenticeships and training programs, which will help to develop the skills of the next generation of engineers. Rolls-Royce has a long history of innovation and excellence in the aerospace industry, and this investment is a testament to its commitment to remaining a major player in the sector.

The company's plans to double the number of engines it builds will also help to drive growth and job creation in the wider economy. With the UK's aerospace industry expected to continue to grow in the coming years, Rolls-Royce's investment is a major boost for the region and a sign of confidence in the country's manufacturing capabilities.

Researchers have captured the first footage of cockatoos bashing out drum solos with little sticks and seedpods in what are believed to be musical displays to impress the opposite sex. Scientists took the extraordinary footage after stalking the shy and elusive Cape York palm cockatoos for seven years through the unspoilt wilderness of the peninsula in far north Queensland. The recordings show 18 males knocking out more than 130 drum solos which sometimes start with a flourish and nearly always contain a signature pattern distinct to each bird. Most of the musical outbursts were performed in front of females, apparently to win them over, with males embellishing their drumming efforts with calls, periodic blushing, and raising the feathers on their crests. Robert Heinsohn at the Australian National University in Canberra and others witnessed the birds tweaking sticks and seedpods before banging out sequences of 27 to 92 beats long. The researchers were thrilled to capture this unique behavior, which has never been seen before in the animal kingdom. "It's like they're having a rock concert in the forest," said Dr. Heinsohn. "The males are putting on a show to impress the females, and it's an incredibly complex and coordinated display." The team believes that the drumming is a key part of the cockatoos' mating ritual, and that the males are competing with each other to attract the females. The females, on the other hand, seem to be very particular about their drumming preferences, often watching the males with great interest before deciding which one to mate with. The researchers are now studying the different patterns and styles of drumming to see if they can learn more about the cockatoos' behavior and social dynamics. With their findings, they hope to shed new light on the fascinating world of animal communication and mating rituals.

Miguel Gómez Garza was on his final expedition to the Yucatán Peninsula to gather information for his book Parrots of Mexico when it happened. He heard a group of parrots in the distance, but their call was like none on record. So he loitered by a tree full of pods that parrots like for lunch, hoping they would come and feed. The wait was worth it. When half a dozen parrots flew over to the tree, Gómez Garza noticed their intense red fronts and the beautiful blue tips on their wing feathers. The plumage set them apart from the two species known to live in the area, which both have distinctive white fronts. "I could not believe it. The different noise belonged to a different parrot," said Gómez Garza, a vet and ornithologist at the Autonomous University of Nuevo León in Monterrey, Mexico. In research published on Tuesday, an international team of scientists describe the new parrot for the first time. Named the blue-winged Amazon parrot, or Amazona gomezgarzai in honour of its discoverer, the bird stands 25cm or so tall and has a loud, short and repetitive call that would not sound out of place on the soundtrack to Alfred Hitchcock's Psycho. One of the calls the bird makes imitates that of the hawk, a natural enemy of parrots. While scientists are not sure why the parrot mimics the predator, they speculate that it scares other birds from the surrounding trees, leaving more seeds, fruit and flowers for the parrots to eat. Having spotted the birds in their habitat, Gómez Garza got permission from the Mexican authorities to capture a male and a female for further study. The team of scientists, led by Dr. Maria Rodriguez from the University of California, Berkeley, worked tirelessly to study the behavior and habits of the newly discovered parrot. They observed that the blue-winged Amazon parrot is a social bird that thrives in small flocks, and is particularly fond of the pods of the Cecropia tree, which are rich in nutrients.

The researchers also discovered that the parrot's mimicry of the hawk's call is not limited to just the one sound. In fact, the bird can imitate a wide range of sounds, including other birds, animals, and even human voices. "It's like they have a built-in sound effects library," said Dr. Rodriguez. "We've even recorded them mimicking the sound of a chainsaw!"

The study also found that the blue-winged Amazon parrot is an important seed disperser in the Yucatán Peninsula, playing a crucial role in the ecosystem. By mimicking the calls of predators, the parrot is able to scare other birds away from the trees, allowing it to feed on the seeds and fruits without competition.

The discovery of the blue-winged Amazon parrot has sent shockwaves through the scientific community, and has raised hopes for the conservation of this unique and fascinating species. The Mexican government has already announced plans to establish a protected area for the parrot's habitat, and international efforts are underway to study and protect this remarkable bird. As Dr. Gómez Garza put it, "This is a momentous day for ornithology, and we are honored to have played a part in its discovery."

The three billionaire shareholders who sparked Ten's voluntary administration will step in to prop up the network's cash flow until it finds a new owner, administrators KordaMenthe have revealed. Ten was forced into a trading halt and then voluntary administration last month when financial backers Lachlan Murdoch and Bruce Gordon failed to guarantee a new $250m loan. On Monday, after the first creditors' meeting was held in Sydney, Ten's administrators said leading shareholders Gordon and Murdoch, who now jointly own 22.5% of Ten, and James Packer, have agreed to provide the funds needed to keep the network on air. "We have adequate cash resources at the present time but, by the end of this week, the shareholder guarantors will put a financing facility in place to ensure Ten has sufficient cash to continue to operate," partner Mark Korda said. Ten posted a disastrous half-year loss of $232m and warned in April that its future as a "going concern" was in doubt if it could not secure another loan. Monday's meeting was the first for creditors since the MasterChef and Bachelor broadcaster went into voluntary administration on 13 June. A 14-member creditors' committee was appointed to oversee the administration of Ten. The administrators also announced that a 14-member creditors' committee has been established to oversee the administration process and ensure that the interests of all stakeholders are represented. The committee will be chaired by independent director, Susan Pei, and will include representatives from various creditor groups, including banks, bondholders, and other lenders.

According to Mark Korda, the administrators are working closely with the committee to identify potential buyers for Ten and are in discussions with several interested parties. "We are making good progress in identifying potential buyers and we are confident that we will be able to find a suitable buyer for Ten," Korda said.

The administrators have also announced that they will be conducting a thorough review of Ten's financial situation and operations to identify areas for cost savings and efficiency improvements. This review is expected to be completed by the end of July and will provide a roadmap for the network's future operations.

In the meantime, Ten's employees and staff have been assured that their jobs are safe and that the network will continue to operate as normal. The administrators have also committed to maintaining the network's programming and operations, including the broadcast of its popular shows such as MasterChef and The Bachelor.

The creditors' meeting was attended by representatives from various creditor groups, including banks, bondholders, and other lenders. The meeting was held in a secure location in Sydney and was attended by around 50 people. The administrators have said that they will provide regular updates to creditors on the progress of the administration process and any significant developments.

Google will stop scanning the content of emails sent by Gmail users in an attempt to reassure business customers of the confidentiality of their communications. The company did read the emails in personal Gmail accounts in order to target users with personalised adverts but said in a blogpost it would stop doing so in order to "more closely align" its business and consumer products. Its business offering, part of G Suite, has never involved scanning emails. "G Suite's Gmail is already not used as input for ads personalisation," wrote Diane Greene, the senior vice president in charge of Google Cloud. "Google has decided to follow suit later this year in our free consumer Gmail service. Consumer Gmail content will not be used or scanned for any ads personalisation after this change." Although G Suite customers, who pay Google for business use of a portfolio of web apps including Gmail, Google Docs, Calendar and Contacts, have never had their messages scanned for use in advertising, many potential customers were nonetheless put off the product by the mistaken impression that they were, Greene told Bloomberg. The decision to stop scanning emails in personal Gmail accounts comes as Google faces increased scrutiny over its handling of user data. The company has been under pressure to address concerns over the use of personal data for advertising purposes, and this move is seen as a step towards rebuilding trust with its users.

Google's decision to stop scanning emails in personal Gmail accounts is also seen as a strategic move to compete with other cloud-based email providers such as Microsoft's Outlook and Amazon's WorkMail. By aligning its business and consumer products, Google aims to create a seamless experience for its users and to differentiate itself from its competitors.

The company has not provided a specific timeline for when the change will take effect, but it has promised to provide more information to its users in the coming weeks. Google's decision to stop scanning emails in personal Gmail accounts is a significant development in the ongoing debate over the use of personal data for advertising purposes, and it remains to be seen how this move will impact the company's relationships with its users and competitors.

So the Mail responded "with both barrels" (Letters, June 23). That trigger-happy metaphor says it all. Lefties don't reach for their guns or express "hatred" against others – including Daily Mail readers – they use satirical cartoons and mild rebukes. The increasing numbers of death threats in our society virtually all come from "alt-right" extremists, as even Charles Foster might agree. The irony of the Mail's response is not lost on us. Rather than engaging in a constructive debate, they chose to resort to name-calling and misinformation. It's a tactic all too familiar to those who dare to challenge their right-wing agenda. The article goes on to highlight the Mail's long history of promoting divisive and xenophobic rhetoric, which has contributed to a toxic atmosphere of intolerance and hatred.

The author argues that it's no coincidence that the rise of far-right extremism has coincided with the Mail's increasing influence in the media. They point to the numerous examples of hate speech and incitement to violence published by the paper, and question whether the Mail's editors are truly committed to promoting a culture of respect and inclusivity.

The article concludes by calling on the public to reject the Mail's divisive rhetoric and to instead promote a culture of empathy and understanding. It's a timely reminder that in these uncertain times, we must stand together against hate and intolerance, and work towards a more compassionate and just society.

Santander has reduced its mortgage lending and its loans for car purchase amid Bank of England warnings about reckless lending and a "spiral of complacency" over mounting consumer debt. Its total mortgage lending fell by £1bn to £11.6bn in the first half of 2017 compared with 2016, with lending for buy-to-let down significantly. Net lending – which takes into account how many people remortgaged away from Santander – fell over the half year by £200m. Net consumer finance lending – covering car loans and credit cards – fell to £97m from £266m, partly due to "a decrease in the stock of new car registrations". Nathan Bostock, the Santander UK chief executive, said: "We do face uncertainty and that was my view at our last results. Generally we have done less unsecured and credit card lending, and are probably down 10% on balances." Bostock said intense competition is driving down interest rates to historically low levels, and accused competitors of offering better rates on car loans and credit cards than are charged to much more secure mortgage customers. "This is a concern, as it's not sustainable in the long term," Bostock said. "We're trying to be more disciplined in our lending, focusing on higher-quality customers and products that are less likely to go wrong."

Santander's decision to reduce its lending comes as the Bank of England has warned about the risks of reckless lending and a "spiral of complacency" over mounting consumer debt. The Bank's governor, Mark Carney, has expressed concerns that low interest rates are fuelling a credit bubble, and that lenders are taking on too much risk.

The reduced lending by Santander is likely to have a ripple effect across the industry, as other banks may follow suit to avoid taking on too much risk. The move is also expected to have a positive impact on the overall health of the financial system, as it will help to reduce the amount of debt in the economy.

However, the reduced lending may also have a negative impact on the economy, as it could make it more difficult for people to access credit and buy homes. The Bank of England has already warned that a slowdown in lending could have a negative impact on the economy, and that it is closely monitoring the situation.

In a statement, the Bank of England said: "We are monitoring the situation closely and will take action if necessary to ensure the stability of the financial system. We urge lenders to remain cautious and to prioritize the long-term sustainability of their lending practices."

The reduced lending by Santander is also likely to have a impact on the housing market, as it could make it more difficult for people to access mortgages. The Bank of England has already warned that a slowdown in lending could have a negative impact on the housing market, and that it is closely monitoring the situation.

In a statement, the Council of Mortgage Lenders said: "We are concerned about the impact that reduced lending could have on the housing market. We urge lenders to continue to provide access to credit for homebuyers and homeowners, while also prioritizing the long-term sustainability of their lending practices."

Turkey is back on the tourist map for UK visitors despite growing tensions between its government and Germany. The tour operator Thomas Cook said it was seeing a pick-up in demand for Turkish holidays because they were good value for money. The chief executive, Peter Fankhauser, said Turkey was proving attractive at the moment, even though Berlin has warned its citizens to be careful when travelling there. Visitors shunned the country last year after a failed military coup, which led to the company offering free cancellations to customers with existing bookings. Overall bookings for summer this year were up 11%, said the company. This surge in demand is a welcome boost for Turkey's tourism industry, which was severely impacted by the coup attempt and subsequent travel warnings. The country's all-inclusive resorts and beach destinations, such as Antalya and Izmir, are proving particularly popular with UK tourists. Thomas Cook's sales team reports that customers are attracted to Turkey's affordable prices, with package deals starting from as little as £300 per person for a week's holiday.

The company is also seeing a rise in bookings for city breaks, with Istanbul and Ankara emerging as popular choices. "Turkey is a fantastic destination, with a rich history and culture," said Fankhauser. "We're seeing a lot of interest from families and couples alike, and we're confident that the country will continue to be a popular choice for UK tourists this summer." Despite the ongoing tensions between Turkey and Germany, Thomas Cook is not expecting any significant impact on bookings, with the majority of its customers still planning to travel to the country.

A regulatory regime intended to crack down on the behaviour of bank bosses is to be extended to 47,000 firms including dentists, gyms and tool hire companies that offer credit to customers. The Financial Conduct Authority estimated that the new regime would cost firms £550m, with up to £190m of ongoing costs for the firms involved. It had been expected that the additional firms would be covered by the senior managers and certification regime (SMCR) from 2018, although the FCA's consultation document does not indicate if this is still the timetable. The SMCR came into force for almost 900 banks and building societies in March 2016 and was intended to tackle the fact that no bank bosses were held to account when their firms collapsed in 2008. It requires the responsibilities of top managers to be spelt out and for them to certify their key staff are suitable for their roles. This certification must now happen annually, whereas under the previous system the FCA approved individuals only once, unless they moved roles. The extension of the SMCR to 47,000 firms will require these businesses to implement significant changes to their governance and risk management practices. This includes the appointment of senior managers, the creation of certification regimes for key staff, and the establishment of clear responsibilities for top managers. The FCA has indicated that it will provide guidance and support to help firms comply with the new regime, but critics have expressed concerns that the costs of implementation will be too high for some smaller businesses.

Industry experts have also raised concerns about the potential impact on the availability of credit to customers. "The SMCR is a well-intentioned regime, but it's unclear how it will affect the availability of credit to small businesses and consumers," said Sarah Johnson, a financial services expert at KPMG. "Firms may need to increase their capital requirements or reduce their lending to customers to comply with the new regime, which could have unintended consequences for the economy."

The FCA has sought to reassure firms that the costs of implementation will be manageable, but the regulator has not provided a specific timeline for when the new regime will come into force. The extension of the SMCR to 47,000 firms is part of a broader effort by the FCA to strengthen the regulatory framework for financial services in the UK. The regulator has also announced plans to introduce new rules for investment firms and to increase scrutiny of financial market infrastructure providers.

Televisions, fridges and other internet-connected home appliances should carry cyber security ratings alongside energy efficiency ratings, a police chief has suggested. Durham chief constable Mike Barton said customers should be given the at-a-glance information for internet-ready equipment in the same way fridges, freezers, TVs and other appliances have to display their energy efficiency ratings before sale. Barton, the national policing lead for crime operations, proposed the idea as part of efforts to protect households from fraudsters and hackers in the era of the Internet of Things, where otherwise "dumb" devices can be put online and be interconnected for automation and smart appliance activities. Analysts have forecast that by 2020 there will be as many as 21bn connected devices around the world, with the surge in the number and variety of internet-ready products sparking a string of security warnings. Earlier this year, an official report warned that smartphones, watches, televisions and fitness trackers could be targeted by cyber criminals seeking to hold users to ransom over their personal data. There have even been reports that baby monitors and pacemakers could be vulnerable to hacking. Barton's proposal is the latest in a series of warnings from law enforcement and security experts about the growing threat of cyber attacks on internet-connected devices. "We need to make sure that consumers are aware of the potential risks and are taking steps to protect themselves," he said. "By providing clear and simple ratings for the cyber security of devices, we can empower people to make informed choices about the products they buy and use."

The idea of cyber security ratings for devices is not new, but it has gained momentum in recent months as the Internet of Things (IoT) has become more widespread. In the UK, the government has already launched a review of the cyber security of IoT devices, and has called on manufacturers to take steps to improve the security of their products.

Barton's proposal has been welcomed by some experts, who say that it could help to raise awareness of the cyber security risks associated with IoT devices. "This is a great idea," said Professor Alan Woodward, a cyber security expert at the University of Surrey. "By providing clear ratings for cyber security, we can help consumers to make informed choices about the products they buy and use. This could be a game-changer in the fight against cyber crime."

However, others have raised concerns about the practicality of implementing such a system. "It's not as simple as just slapping a rating on a device," said one industry expert. "Cyber security is a complex issue, and it's difficult to distill it down into a simple rating. We need to be careful not to create a system that is misleading or ineffective."

Despite these concerns, Barton remains convinced that his proposal is a step in the right direction. "We need to take action to protect households from the growing threat of cyber crime," he said. "By providing clear and simple ratings for cyber security, we can empower consumers to take control of their own security and protect themselves from the risks associated with IoT devices."

The bankers running JPMorgan Chase and Goldman Sachs saw their shareholdings rocket in value by $314m last year due to the stock market surge following Donald Trump's election as US president. The JPMorgan boss, Jamie Dimon, and the Goldman Sachs chief executive, Lloyd Blankfein, enjoyed rises of more than $150m (£115m) each in the value of their stock and options in the banks they run, according to an annual review of bank CEO pay by Equilar for the Financial Times (paywall). The other 18 best-paid bank chief executives in the world fared less well, with average gains of $4m in their stock-related holdings last year. Dimon was also the best-paid banking boss in the world for the second year running, raking in $28.2m of pay, bonus and pension contributions last year. The Morgan Stanley chief executive, James Gorman, came second at $22.5m, followed by Blankfein at $22.3m. The figures, which were released by Equilar, a firm that tracks executive compensation, also showed that the total compensation package for the 20 top-paid banking CEOs increased by 12% last year, to an average of $15.4m. This was largely driven by the surge in bank stocks, which has been fueled by expectations of deregulation and tax cuts under the Trump administration.

However, the review also highlighted the growing divide between the pay of top bankers and that of their employees. According to Equilar, the median total compensation for a JPMorgan Chase employee was $83,000 last year, while at Goldman Sachs it was $72,000.
