This means that the top bankers were earning hundreds of times more than the average employee at their own banks.

The figures have sparked criticism from some quarters, with some arguing that the pay of top bankers is too high and out of touch with the rest of the workforce. "The massive pay increases for the top bankers are a symbol of the broken system that has created a culture of greed and inequality," said Sarah Anderson, a senior researcher at the Institute for Policy Studies.

However, others have argued that the pay is justified, given the significant profits made by the banks in recent years. "The CEOs of JPMorgan Chase and Goldman Sachs are paid what they are because they are generating enormous profits for their shareholders," said one banking analyst. "If the pay is too high, it's because the banks are making too much money, not because the CEOs are overpaid."

Can they fix it? John Lewis reckons it knows someone who can. Middle England's favourite retailer has signed up an army of plumbers, electricians, decorators and gardeners to offer a new home maintenance service launching next month. The retailer, which has built up one of the most trusted brands in the UK partly thanks to its highly rated customer service and "never knowingly undersold" pledge, is now aiming to make employing a tradesperson a lot less hit and miss. The Home Solutions service is part of the department store's effort to fend off competition from online upstarts such as Amazon by providing more services. New boss Paula Nickolds said the business needed to bring in more beauty salons, home design, personal styling and other services as shoppers' behaviour changes "profoundly and fast." In a bid to add pizzazz to shopping trips the company is also sending store staff to theatre school to teach them entertainment skills and its new Oxford store, which opens in October, will have an experience manager dedicated to organising daily in-store events. The new Home Solutions service has already been tested in Milton Keynes and is being extended to Bristol, Cardiff, Cheltenham, Gloucester and Taunton from 12 September. About 150 tradespeople have been signed up to the scheme so far and the number is expected to increase as the trial expands this year. They will remain independent contractors rather than becoming partners, the term John Lewis uses for its staff who jointly own the company. The Home Solutions service will allow customers to book a range of maintenance tasks, from fixing leaky taps to decorating a room, through a dedicated website or in-store. The tradespeople will be vetted and trained by John Lewis, and customers will be able to rate and review their services online.

Paula Nickolds, the company's new boss, said: "We know that employing a tradesperson can be a daunting experience, and we want to take the stress out of it for our customers. Our Home Solutions service will provide a convenient and reliable way for customers to get the help they need for their homes."

The service is part of John Lewis's efforts to stay relevant in a rapidly changing retail landscape. The company has been focusing on enhancing the shopping experience, with initiatives such as in-store events and personalized styling services.

John Lewis has also been investing in its online presence, with a new website and mobile app designed to make it easier for customers to shop and manage their accounts. The company is also expanding its click-and-collect service, allowing customers to order online and collect their purchases in-store.

The Home Solutions service is expected to be a major draw for customers, particularly those who value the convenience and reliability of John Lewis's brand. With its army of tradespeople and dedicated website, the company is positioning itself as a one-stop-shop for all home maintenance needs.

As the service rolls out across the country, John Lewis is confident that it will be a hit with customers. "We're excited to offer this new service to our customers," said Nickolds. "We believe it will be a game-changer for the way people approach home maintenance, and we're looking forward to seeing the impact it will have."

Credit card lenders appear to be targeting people struggling with unaffordable levels of debt, according to a new report calling on Britain's financial watchdog to intervene. Research from Citizens Advice finds almost one in five people struggling with debts have had their credit card limit raised without them requesting it. The charity has demanded the Financial Conduct Authority bans the practice, amid growing concerns over a boom in lending. Unsecured lending is returning to levels unseen since the 2008 financial crisis, raising alarm bells at the Bank of England that consumers may struggle to repay loans in another economic downturn, thus putting financial stability at risk. The Citizens Advice chief executive, Gillian Guy, said: "It's clear that irresponsible behaviour by some lenders is making people's debt situation worse – such as offering more credit when they already have thousands of pounds of unpaid debt." She said lenders must act responsibly to direct people struggling with debt towards free and independent advice and support – rather than offering them more credit. People with long term outstanding balances were more likely to have their spending limit raised, with 18% of struggling credit card users seeing their limit increased in the past year without requesting it, compared to 12% of all credit card holders, Citizens Advice found. People with credit card debts were also more likely to get into long-term debt than those with personal loans, and were less able to pay their debt down. The report also highlights the alarming trend of lenders targeting vulnerable individuals, such as those on low incomes or with a history of debt. Citizens Advice found that 15% of those with credit card debt were also receiving benefits, compared to 10% of the general population. Furthermore, 22% of those with credit card debt had a history of debt, compared to 15% of the general population.

The charity is calling on the Financial Conduct Authority to take immediate action to address these concerns. "The FCA must take a closer look at the practices of credit card lenders and take steps to ensure they are not exploiting vulnerable individuals," said Gillian Guy. "It's unacceptable that lenders are offering more credit to people who are already struggling to pay off their debts. This is not only unfair, but it also perpetuates a cycle of debt that can have devastating consequences for individuals and families."

Citizens Advice is also urging consumers to be aware of the risks associated with credit card debt and to seek free and independent advice if they are struggling with debt. "It's crucial that consumers are aware of the potential risks associated with credit card debt and take steps to manage their debt responsibly," said Gillian Guy. "We urge anyone struggling with debt to seek help from a trusted organization, such as Citizens Advice, and to avoid falling into the trap of taking on more debt to pay off existing debts."

The news comes as the Bank of England has also expressed concerns over the rise in unsecured lending. "The recent growth in unsecured lending is a cause for concern, as it increases the risk of consumers taking on debt they may struggle to repay," said Andrew Bailey, Governor of the Bank of England. "We urge lenders to exercise caution and to prioritize the financial stability of their customers."

As the debate over credit card lending practices continues, one thing is clear: consumers must be vigilant and take steps to manage their debt responsibly. With the risks of debt and financial instability growing, it is crucial that individuals and families prioritize their financial well-being and seek help if they are struggling with debt.

Moving out of London (to Salford for the BBC, shortly to Birmingham for C4) comes at a price. Just look at the figures, as assembled by Enders Analysis. The BBC lost 62% of its staff when it moved departments to MediaCity: that was twice as much per person on redundancy (£48,000) as on relocation (£27,000). The Office for National Statistics, incidentally, lost 90% of its London staff when it moved to Newport. Only 620 C4 employees are involved. They are commissioning and support staff. They do not make programmes and carry no manufacturing base with them. They are also highly skilled men and women, many of them also tied to London because of their partners' jobs. The move to Birmingham is expected to be a more complex and costly process, with the channel's entire production base, including studios and offices, being relocated. According to sources, the relocation package for C4 staff is expected to be around £30,000 to £40,000 per person, although this figure may vary depending on individual circumstances. Despite the significant costs, Channel 4 is adamant that the move will be a net benefit to the company, citing the availability of a larger, more modern facility in Birmingham and the potential for increased collaboration with other industries in the region. The move is expected to be completed by 2025.

A new register naming firms that find themselves under shareholder pressure over executive pay is to be launched later this year as part of government plans aimed at curbing boardroom excess and increasing transparency. In what was described by the government as a world first, the new register will name firms where a fifth of investors have objected to proposed executive annual pay packages. However, the unveiling of the policy marks a retreat from the much more radical approach which had originally been touted by Theresa May in the form of promises to increase the frequency of binding shareholder votes on corporate pay policies. The policies of listed British companies are currently subject to a binding vote every three years. The Liberal Democrat leader, Vince Cable, accused the prime minister of capitulating to pressure from her own party and watering down the original proposals. The new register, which is expected to be launched in the autumn, will provide a detailed breakdown of the level of shareholder dissent on executive pay packages. It is hoped that the increased transparency will help to curb excessive pay practices and encourage companies to take a more responsible approach to remuneration.

However, the launch of the register has been met with criticism from some quarters. The Trades Union Congress (TUC) has accused the government of "crying wolf" and failing to take meaningful action to address the issue of excessive executive pay.

"This register is a tokenistic gesture that will do little to curb the scourge of excessive executive pay," said Frances O'Grady, the TUC's general secretary. "What we need is a fundamental overhaul of the corporate governance system, not just a fancy new register."

The launch of the register comes as the issue of executive pay continues to dominate the headlines. Last week, it was revealed that the boss of the FTSE 100 company, GlaxoSmithKline, had received a pay package worth over £10 million.

The government's decision to launch the register has also been met with criticism from some business leaders. The Confederation of British Industry (CBI) has warned that the new register could create "unnecessary bureaucracy" and "increase costs" for companies.

However, the government has defended the move, saying that it is necessary to increase transparency and accountability in the corporate sector. "We are committed to ensuring that our corporate governance system is robust and effective," said a government spokesperson. "The new register will provide a valuable tool for shareholders and investors to hold companies to account for their executive pay practices."

The launch of the register is seen as a significant step forward in the government's efforts to curb excessive executive pay. However, it remains to be seen whether it will be enough to satisfy the demands of shareholders and critics of the corporate sector.

Reclaiming mis-sold payment protection insurance can be a quick and easy process. There is no need to use a claims handling company that will rake off 30% of any compensation you are awarded. Can I claim mis-sold PPI? If you took out any kind of consumer loan, store card, credit card or mortgage in the 1990s or 2000s, you may have been mis-sold PPI. Go back through all your old loan and mortgage statements and check for any mention of an insurance to cover your payments if you lost your job through accident, sickness or unemployment. What if I have no statements? If you don't have them or simply cannot remember which lenders you've borrowed from, check your credit report. It lists any loans, mortgages or other debts within the last six years, even if they're now closed. Many lenders will now tell you if you call them up to ask whether you had PPI. How was it mis-sold? Was the fact that the insurance was optional made clear to you? According to financial experts, PPI was often mis-sold because the salespeople failed to inform customers that the insurance was optional. Many people were led to believe that the insurance was a condition of the loan or mortgage, and were not told that they could decline it. Others were not made aware of the high costs associated with the insurance, or were not given a clear explanation of what the policy covered.

Some lenders also used high-pressure sales tactics to sell PPI, which led to customers feeling pressured into purchasing the insurance. In addition, some lenders did not properly assess the customer's ability to pay the insurance premiums, which meant that many people were paying for a policy that they could not afford.

If you believe that you were mis-sold PPI, you can make a claim to reclaim the premiums you paid, as well as any interest that was charged on those premiums. The process is relatively straightforward, and you can do it yourself without the need for a claims handling company.

To make a claim, you will need to gather together all of your old loan and mortgage statements, as well as any documentation that you have regarding the PPI policy. You will then need to contact the lender or the bank that sold you the policy and explain that you were mis-sold the insurance. They will then assess your claim and let you know whether you are eligible for compensation.

If you are successful in your claim, you can expect to receive a significant amount of money back. In some cases, this can be thousands of pounds. It's a good idea to seek the advice of a financial advisor or a claims expert to help you navigate the process and ensure that you get the compensation you are entitled to.

Sir Philip Green's Arcadia retail empire has agreed to pay £30m to unsecured creditors of BHS following the collapse of the department store chain with the loss of 11,000 jobs. Arcadia, which owned BHS until it was sold to a consortium led by Dominic Chappell for £1 in 2015, on Friday agreed the deal with BHS's liquidators, FRP Advisory, which will drop legal action filed against Green's company. A spokesman for FRP said: "The liquidators of SHB Realisations, formerly BHS, reached an agreement with Arcadia Group in relation to a number of matters, including Arcadia's floating charge dated 14 April 2015. "We can confirm that as part of the agreement, over £30m was released from reserves held in relation to Arcadia's secured claim into the monies available for BHS unsecured creditors and the floating charge is to be released." The settlement avoids the prospect of the retail billionaire fighting a lengthy legal battle over the demise of BHS. Green avoided another legal battle with the pension regulator by agreeing to pay £363m to rescue the BHS pension scheme. The deal marks a significant step towards closure for both Arcadia and BHS's creditors, who had been waiting for a resolution to the complex and contentious issue. The agreement also brings an end to the bitter feud between Sir Philip Green and the pension regulator, which had threatened to drag on for years. The £363m payment to rescue the BHS pension scheme is a major relief for thousands of former employees who were at risk of losing their hard-earned retirement savings. The settlement is a testament to the importance of transparency and accountability in corporate governance, and serves as a reminder that even the most powerful business leaders must be held accountable for their actions. The agreement is expected to pave the way for a fresh start for BHS's creditors, who can now focus on rebuilding their lives and businesses.

The government is seeking to negotiate a deal over data sharing with Europe in which there are no substantial regulatory changes as a result of Brexit. The ambitious strategy emerged on Thursday in the last of a series of summer policy papers published by the Department for Exiting the European Union ahead of the next round of talks in Brussels on Monday. In it, the government argues that its "unique" status as a leading player in the world of electronic commerce means that it should be able to demand special treatment from the EU when agreeing future standards. Regulation of online data is an increasing international flashpoint as technology companies and national security agencies both come under fire for infringing personal privacy. Since the Edward Snowden revelations and other high-profile privacy challenges against companies such as Google, it has been a particular source of tension between the EU and US. The paper, titled "A new era for the UK's data relationship with the EU", suggests that the UK's digital economy, which is worth over £100 billion annually, should be taken into account when negotiating data sharing agreements. The government argues that the UK's unique position as a global leader in fintech, artificial intelligence, and cybersecurity means that it should be exempt from certain regulatory requirements.

The proposal has been met with skepticism by some experts, who argue that the UK's attempt to carve out special treatment is a thinly veiled attempt to undermine the EU's data protection standards. "This is a clear attempt to weaken the EU's data protection regime, which has been a cornerstone of consumer protection in the digital age," said Dr. Rachel Thomas, a data privacy expert at the University of Cambridge.

However, the government remains committed to its strategy, insisting that the UK's digital economy requires a tailored approach. "We believe that our unique status as a global leader in digital commerce means that we should be able to negotiate a deal that reflects our specific circumstances," said a spokesperson for the Department for Exiting the European Union.

The UK's proposal is set to be discussed at the next round of talks in Brussels on Monday, where the EU is expected to push back on the UK's demands. The negotiations are seen as a key test of the UK's ability to strike a deal with the EU, and the outcome will have significant implications for the future of data sharing between the two sides.

House prices are still going up around the UK, and despite low mortgage rates increasing numbers of people are locked out of the property market. The problem is particularly acute for ethnic minorities, with figures showing those from BME backgrounds are much less likely to be homeowners than white Britons. We would like to hear from people from BME backgrounds about their experiences of the housing market, whether they are thinking of buying or not and whatever their personal circumstances. Share your experiences Do you or your family hope to buy a home in the future? Are you a homeowner already or have you been put off? As the UK's housing market continues to soar, many are left feeling priced out of their own neighborhoods. For Rukhsar Ali, a 32-year-old marketing professional from Birmingham, the dream of homeownership seems increasingly elusive. "I've been saving for a deposit for years, but the prices just keep going up," she says. "I'm starting to wonder if I'll ever be able to afford a place of my own."

My uncle Saad Mahmood Hikmat, who has died aged 79, played a pivotal role in musical education in Iraq and Jordan. Saad worked as a sound engineer in Iraqi TV and radio and helped establish reputable recording studios in Baghdad. From 1960, he worked as a music teacher in the Institute of Hope, for children with sensory impairments, and developed many innovative ways to teach and communicate with the students. Perhaps the project closest to his heart was the music and ballet school established in Baghdad in 1968. Saad was a key member of its staff and played a major role in directing the school. Its students remember him fondly, and his three children and four of his nieces and nephews are graduates of this school. Saad was the fourth of six children of Mahmood Jasim Hikmat and Kadria Raoof Al-Attar. He was born in Baghdad, where his father worked for the Iraqi government. From a young age, Saad showed a talent for music and playing the accordion, in which he was encouraged by his father. Following high school education, he was admitted to the Institute of Fine Arts (later the Academy of Fine Arts) in Baghdad in 1952. He studied music with western and Iraqi teachers (including Julien Hertz and Beatrice Ohanessian), and graduated as an accomplished pianist, accordion player and piano tuner. He further developed his talents by travelling to Italy, Greece, Poland and the former USSR. Saad loved jazz. When Duke Ellington visited Baghdad in the 1960s, Saad met him, tuned his piano and privately played a few jazz pieces for him. Saad's passion for jazz was contagious, and he soon found himself at the center of a thriving music scene in Baghdad. He formed a jazz ensemble, which became a staple of the city's cultural calendar. The group's performances were always well-received, and Saad's unique blend of traditional Iraqi music and American jazz standards earned him a reputation as a true innovator.

In the 1970s, Saad made the difficult decision to leave Iraq and move to Jordan, where he could continue to share his love of music with a new generation. He established a music school in Amman, which quickly gained a reputation for producing some of the region's most talented young musicians. Saad's dedication to his students was unwavering, and he spent countless hours mentoring and guiding them as they developed their skills.

Throughout his life, Saad was driven by a desire to use music as a force for good. He believed that music had the power to bring people together and transcend cultural and linguistic barriers. He spent many years working with refugees and displaced persons, using music as a way to help them heal and rebuild their lives. Saad's legacy is a testament to the enduring power of music to bring people together and inspire positive change. He will be deeply missed by his family, friends, and the countless people whose lives he touched through his music.

In Japan robots can serve as companions, helpers for the elderly, entertainment bots and even sexual partners, but now SoftBank's humanoid robot Pepper has put itself up for hire as a Buddhist priest for funerals. Taking the German blessing bot's idea and running with it, Pepper's new code will let it chant sutras in a computerised voice while tapping a drum, providing a cheaper alternative to a human priest to see your loved ones off into the eternal sleep. The robot was on display on Wednesday at a funeral industry fair, the Life Ending Industry Expo, in Tokyo, shown off by plastic molding maker Nissei Eco. With the average cost of a funeral in Japan reaching in excess of £20,000, according to data from Japan's Consumer Association in 2008, and human priests costing £1,700, Nissei Eco is looking to undercut the market with Pepper available for just £350 per funeral. With Japan's population ageing and shrinking, many Buddhist priests receive less financial support from their communities, prompting some to find part-time work outside their temple duties, said Michio Inamura, Nissei's executive adviser, who suggested Pepper could step in when a human wasn't available. The response from the funeral industry has been mixed, with some seeing Pepper as a innovative solution to the rising costs of funerals, while others have expressed concerns about the robot's ability to provide the same level of emotional support as a human priest. "It's not about replacing human priests, but about providing an alternative for those who cannot afford one," said Michio Inamura. Despite the initial skepticism, Pepper has already received several inquiries from funeral homes and temples interested in hiring the robot for services. With its ability to chant sutras and perform traditional Buddhist rituals, Pepper is poised to revolutionize the way Japan says goodbye to its loved ones. As the robot continues to make its rounds at the funeral industry fair, it's clear that Pepper is here to stay - and bring a new level of innovation to the funeral business.

Reviewing Ken Burns' brilliant new series (An epic and meticulous documentary tracing the history of the Vietnam war, 26 September), Tim Dowling says creating moving images from still pictures is widely known as the Ken Burns effect. That may be true in the US but here it's much more often associated with the great Ken Morse, whose skill with the rostrum camera was such that he's said to be the world's most widely credited cameraman. Morse's name and techniques are indeed now used on software that does the same job with less physical effort but possibly also less creative imagination. However, despite the global recognition of Ken Morse's work, it's Ken Burns who has been credited with popularizing the technique, making it a staple of documentary filmmaking. Burns' innovative use of the rostrum camera in his Vietnam War series is a masterclass in storytelling, weaving together archival images and audio to create a visceral and emotional experience for the viewer. As a result, the term "Ken Burns effect" has become synonymous with the technique, and it's likely to remain so for many years to come.

The Wall Street Journal will stop publishing its Asian and European editions, the paper has said, amid a wider editorial restructuring and falling revenue. In an end to a 40-year history, the company will stop publishing its separate edition for Europe on Friday while its Asian edition will cease publication on 7 October. The decision comes after the paper's parent company, News Corp, reported a loss of $643m (£479m) for the most recent fiscal year, which ended on 30 June. That compares to a $235m profit during the previous year. The paper began publishing a separate Asian edition in 1976 and its European edition followed in 1983. The US edition of the WSJ will be available in some cities at a later unspecified date, the paper said. Despite recent losses, digital subscriptions are on the rise and the WSJ plans to focus on encouraging customers in Asia and Europe to read the paper online. Those gains in online-only subscriptions made "continuing the foreign editions no longer cost-effective", the newspaper said. The newsstand price for the paper in Hong Kong, the company's Asian headquarters, is about £2.20, while a six-month digital subscription costs £82. The paper added 322,000 digital subscriptions in the most recent financial quarter for a total of 1.27m. The move is seen as a cost-cutting measure by the company, which is trying to adapt to the changing media landscape. The Wall Street Journal's print circulation has been declining in recent years, and the company has been shifting its focus to digital subscriptions. The decision to stop publishing the Asian and European editions will likely result in job losses, although the company has not specified how many positions will be affected.

The WSJ's digital subscriptions have been growing steadily, with the company reporting a 15% increase in digital-only subscribers in the most recent quarter. The company plans to continue to invest in its digital offerings, including its online news coverage and its popular newsletters.

The decision to stop publishing the Asian and European editions is seen as a blow to the company's global ambitions, but the WSJ remains one of the most widely respected and influential business newspapers in the world. The company will continue to publish its flagship US edition, which is widely read by business leaders and investors around the world.

The tobacco firm Imperial Brands is working on a rescue deal for the wholesaler Palmer & Harvey, which supplies tobacco to Tesco and other retailers. Palmer & Harvey is the biggest cigarette supplier in the UK and employs 4,000 people. Imperial and Japan Tobacco International, which were involved in a refinancing round in early April and each gave Palmer & Harvey a £30m loan, are expected to provide enough funding to keep the firm afloat, allowing it to hammer out a rescue deal with Carlyle, a private equity firm. Imperial, maker of Davidoff and Gauloises cigarettes, said in a trading update that it was working with others to create a sustainable future for Palmer & Harvey, stressing its "close trading relationship". Another key partner is Tesco, which accounts for about 40% of Palmer & Harvey's revenues. Any rescue deal is expected to include an extension of the supermarket's three-year distribution deal with Palmer & Harvey. The potential rescue deal is seen as a crucial lifeline for Palmer & Harvey, which has been struggling financially in recent months. The company's troubles have been exacerbated by a decline in the UK's cigarette market, as well as increased competition from discount retailers and online sellers. In addition to Imperial Brands and Japan Tobacco International, other investors are also believed to be involved in the rescue talks, including the private equity firm Carlyle, which has a significant stake in Palmer & Harvey. A successful rescue deal could help to secure the future of the company's 4,000 employees, as well as its suppliers and other stakeholders. The deal is expected to be finalized in the coming weeks, pending the approval of Palmer & Harvey's creditors and other stakeholders. If successful, the rescue deal could help to stabilize the company's finances and allow it to continue operating as a major player in the UK's tobacco distribution market.

British consumers have been dipping further into their savings amid a squeeze from rising prices and falling real wages, figures show, as growth in personal bank deposits fell to the slowest annual rate since the height of the financial crisis. Annual growth in personal deposits with high street banks fell to 2.2% in August, in the weakest month since May 2009, according to figures published by banking trade body UK Finance. There was also about £1bn withdrawn from cash Isa accounts, with tax changes allowing up to £1,000 of interest to be earned tax free. The trade body said: "It seems households are saving a bit less each month, rather than borrowing more, as growth in personal deposits has slowed recently, alongside a slowdown in growth of consumer credit borrowing." Annual growth in credit card borrowing was at 5% in August, compared with 5.3% the previous month, while the use of personal loans and overdrafts fell by 1.6% on an annual basis, from a contraction of 1% in the year to July. The figures suggest that households are becoming increasingly cautious with their finances, as they struggle to make ends meet in the face of rising living costs and stagnant wages. The slowdown in deposit growth is particularly concerning, as it could have implications for the overall health of the economy.

"Households are being squeezed by the combination of rising prices and stagnant wages, which is making it difficult for them to save," said Paul Hollingsworth, chief economist at BNP Paribas. "The slowdown in deposit growth is a sign that households are being forced to dip into their savings to cover their living expenses, rather than building up a buffer for the future."

The figures also highlight the impact of tax changes on consumer behavior. The introduction of the new tax-free allowance on cash Isa accounts, which allows individuals to earn up to £1,000 in interest without paying tax, has led to a surge in withdrawals from these accounts. This has resulted in a £1 billion withdrawal from cash Isa accounts in August alone.

"This is a sign that households are taking advantage of the tax changes to reduce their tax liabilities," said a spokesperson for UK Finance. "However, it's also a sign that households are being cautious with their finances and are looking for ways to reduce their costs."

The slowdown in deposit growth is also reflected in the growth of consumer credit borrowing, which slowed to 5% in August, down from 5.3% in the previous month. The use of personal loans and overdrafts also fell by 1.6% on an annual basis, from a contraction of 1% in the year to July.

"The slowdown in consumer credit borrowing is a sign that households are becoming more cautious with their finances," said Hollingsworth. "It's also a sign that the economy is facing headwinds, as households are becoming less willing to take on debt to finance their spending."

Overall, the figures suggest that households are becoming increasingly cautious with their finances, as they struggle to make ends meet in the face of rising living costs and stagnant wages. The slowdown in deposit growth and the decline in consumer credit borrowing are signs that households are becoming more risk-averse and are looking for ways to reduce their costs.

London and Frankfurt will lose out to New York and Singapore unless a free trade deal on financial services after Brexit is agreed, according to leading City businesses. The report from key banks, law firms and fund managers in the UK proposes a "bespoke" free trade agreement once Britain leaves the EU. Such a deal would allow British and EU-based financial companies to sell their products and services without tariffs, taxes or quotas in each other's markets after Brexit. A new joint "dispute resolution body" made up of judges and independent experts would rule on breaches of the agreement. There have been warnings of the dire effects on British pensioners and other consumers living in the EU if "passporting" rights, which allow UK financial companies to trade freely in the single market, are lost when Britain leaves the EU. UK businesses might not be legally able to pay out personal pension or insurance contracts to British expats and other citizens living in the EU. Potential solutions to those problems have been drawn up by the International Regulatory Strategy Group, which is sponsored by the City of London Corporation and the lobbying body TheCityUK. Taking soundings from institutions such as JP Morgan and BlackRock, it has produced a plan for a free trade agreement. The report was launched in Brussels by the chair of the ISRG council, Mark Hoban, a former City minister, who said it would be "straightforward" to set up the free trade area because the EU and UK have regulatory regimes that are "essentially the same". The report's authors argue that a bespoke free trade agreement would not only protect the interests of British financial companies but also ensure that EU-based firms can continue to operate in the UK without disruption. This, they claim, would help to maintain London's status as a global financial hub and prevent a brain drain of talent to other cities.

The plan would also address concerns about the impact on British expats and other citizens living in the EU. According to the report, a "grandfathering" clause would be included in the agreement, allowing existing contracts to be honored without interruption. This would prevent British pensioners and other consumers from being affected by the loss of "passporting" rights.

The report's authors are confident that the EU and UK can agree on the terms of a free trade agreement, citing the "essentially the same" regulatory regimes in both jurisdictions. They also believe that the proposed dispute resolution body would be an effective mechanism for resolving any disagreements that may arise.

However, not everyone is convinced. Some experts have raised concerns about the complexity of negotiating a bespoke free trade agreement, particularly given the tight timescale before the UK's planned departure from the EU. Others have questioned whether the EU would be willing to agree to such an arrangement, given its own concerns about financial regulation and competition.

Despite these challenges, the report's authors remain optimistic about the prospects for a free trade agreement. "This is a pragmatic solution that would benefit both the UK and the EU," said Mark Hoban, chair of the ISRG council. "We believe that it is in the interests of all parties to reach an agreement that protects the integrity of the financial sector and ensures continuity for consumers and businesses alike."

The BBC's political editor, Laura Kuenssberg, is being protected by security guards at the Labour party conference this week following abuse she has received over her role, according to reports. Kuenssberg, who has previously been jeered by some Labour supporters, will be accompanied by a security team inside and outside the conference zone in Brighton, the reports said. Kuenssberg has frequently been targeted with sexist abuse online and the BBC is understood to have given her access to a bodyguard during the general election campaign. The corporation did not comment on the reports of her protection at the Labour conference, telling the Sun on Sunday that it does "not comment on security issues". The decision to provide Kuenssberg with a security detail has been met with criticism from some quarters, with some accusing the BBC of "coddling" its journalists and creating a "culture of fear". However, others have expressed concern for Kuenssberg's safety, citing the increasing vitriol and hostility towards journalists and politicians in the current political climate.

Kuenssberg has faced intense scrutiny in recent years, with some Labour supporters criticizing her reporting and perceived bias. Her presence at the conference has been met with protests and heckling from some attendees, with some calling for her to be "boycotted" or "muzzled".

Despite the controversy, the BBC has maintained that Kuenssberg is a professional journalist who has the right to report on the conference without fear of intimidation or harassment. The corporation has also faced criticism for its handling of the situation, with some accusing it of prioritizing the safety of its journalists over the needs and concerns of the public.

As the Labour conference continues, attention is likely to remain focused on Kuenssberg and the measures being taken to protect her. The incident has sparked a wider debate about the safety of journalists and the need for greater protections against harassment and intimidation.

Price: £18,555 Top speed: 121mph 0-62mph: 9.4 seconds MPG: 45.6 CO2: 144g/km It's Italian, it's stunning and its name references the greatest love story ever written… But spend a week with Giulietta from Alfa Romeo and you'll soon be booking sessions with Relate. Like most relationships, it started so well. You spotted the car across a crowded car park and your eyes were drawn by those dramatic lines. The rimless headlamps and plunging codpiece grille added to the appeal. You took the key from your pocket, you wanted to get to know this car a little better. You pressed unlock and… eergh… the car emits a long, dreadful jarring beep. I've "beeped" a lot of cars in my time, but the tone on this one is awful. It sounds crazy to dismiss a car because the security tone is too harsh, too long and too unnecessary, but every time I locked or unlocked Giulietta that noise put my teeth right on edge. Clamber in and the disappointment continues. It's a mid-size hatchback with a decent-sized boot, but the seats feel so cramped. There is very little leg room for passengers in the back. The quality of materials used throughout is not great. The plastics are unyielding. A driver makes direct contact with their car in so few places: door handle, steering wheel, gear stick. So these touch points have to feel generous and tactile. It doesn't matter if the rest of it is like sandpaper, these three have to feel pleasantly rubbery. Hmmm, you think to yourself, this isn't going as well as I'd hoped. Your eyes fall on the instrument panel, or they would if they could see it. The type on the display is so tiny it's indecipherable, which is hardly the point. Oh well, let's get on with it. You turn the key and the engine comes to life. This sounds more promising. As I pulled out of the parking space, I was initially impressed by the Giulietta's smooth acceleration and responsive handling. The 1.4-liter turbocharged engine had a pleasant hum to it, and the six-speed manual transmission was a joy to use. However, as I navigated through the busy streets, I began to notice some issues with the suspension. The ride was a bit choppy, and the car seemed to bounce over even minor bumps. It wasn't a deal-breaker, but it was noticeable and slightly annoying.

As I continued to drive, I found myself struggling to get comfortable behind the wheel. The seat was too firm, and the steering wheel was too small. I kept having to adjust my position to try and find a sweet spot, but it was like trying to find a needle in a haystack. The rest of the interior was just as disappointing. The plastics were indeed unyielding, and the overall design felt dated and uninspired.

Despite these issues, I was determined to give the Giulietta a fair shake. So, I decided to take it on a longer drive, hoping that the road would help to smooth out some of the rough edges. Unfortunately, the car's quirks only seemed to become more pronounced. The engine began to sound a bit rough, and the transmission started to hunt for gears. It was like the car was struggling to find its rhythm, and it was making me feel anxious and uncomfortable.

As the day drew to a close, I couldn't help but feel a sense of disappointment. The Giulietta had started out so promisingly, but it had failed to deliver on its early promise. It was a shame, really, because I had been looking forward to spending time with this car. Alas, it seemed that our relationship was doomed from the start.

In August I rented a car from Hertz through Holiday Autos. We collected the car at Memphis airport and arranged to return it in Brooklyn, New York, eight days later. The cost was £548, paid upfront. We were two hours late arriving at the drop-off location and found it had closed at noon. The Hertz helpline told me to take the car to another location – West 34th Street. The staff at the drop-off location were pleasant, said that I did not need to complete any paperwork and that I would get an email confirmation. But I did not receive anything. I subsequently noticed a second charge of £579 from Hertz on my credit card. I was eventually told that this was for the late return and a "one-way fee" for returning the car in a different place. I accept the late charge, but a fee of more than £500 for dropping the car at an office just seven miles away is outrageous. I have complained and appealed to Holiday Autos but it is refusing to provide a refund or get one from Hertz. I have since contacted Hertz's customer service department multiple times, only to be met with a lack of empathy and a refusal to reconsider the excessive fee. They claim that the one-way fee is a standard charge, but I find it hard to believe that a seven-mile journey is equivalent to a long-distance trip. I've also been told that the fee is non-negotiable, which is unacceptable.

I'm at my wit's end and feeling frustrated and ripped off. I've had to spend hours on the phone and emailing back and forth, and I'm still no closer to getting a fair resolution. I'm urging other customers to be aware of these hidden fees and to carefully read the fine print before renting a car. I hope that by sharing my experience, I can help others avoid the same situation and get a fair deal from Hertz.

Parents will no longer be able to use a legal loophole to dodge paying child maintenance under new rules to be rolled out within months. Ministers are to overhaul laws that mean parents can avoid supporting their child by holding their money in a joint account with a new partner. Current rules mean only money held in a sole account can be seized for payment. Under new rules that will come into force early next year, the Department for Work and Pensions will ensure that money held in a joint account can also be liable for maintenance payments. Ministers believe that closing this loophole could lead to more than £390,000 of additional child maintenance being collected. Safeguards will be put in place to ensure that only funds belonging to the paying parent will be targeted. The changes are expected to benefit thousands of children who are currently being denied the financial support they are entitled to. The new rules will also help to ensure that parents who are deliberately hiding their income or assets in a joint account with a new partner are held accountable. A government spokesperson said: "We are committed to ensuring that all parents do their fair share in supporting their children. Closing this loophole will help to make sure that more parents are held accountable for their financial responsibilities." The new rules are part of a wider review of the child maintenance system, which is aimed at making it more effective and efficient. The government has also announced plans to increase the maximum child maintenance payment to £2,000 per month, up from the current maximum of £1,200. The changes are expected to come into force in the spring.

Brian Cathcart (Letters, 19 October) describes Impress as an "independent" regulator and the Press Recognition Panel as "a body which is itself independent of government". But this is a strange sort of independence: the royal decree establishing the panel sets out detailed rules for who can be a member, how they are to be appointed and how the panel is to operate, and similarly detailed rules for how any regulator must operate in order to be "recognised". This raises important questions about the extent of government influence over the panel and its decisions. How can the panel truly be considered independent when its rules are set by the government, and how can it be said to be independent of government when its members are appointed and its operations are overseen by government officials? Furthermore, what guarantees are there that the panel's decisions will not be influenced by political considerations, rather than a genuine commitment to promoting press freedom and independence? The public has a right to know how the panel will operate and how it will ensure that its decisions are truly independent of government interference.

In your regular update on awful tech products, may I present the "Smile mirror", a mirror designed for cancer patients that becomes reflective only when the user smiles. Designed by someone actually called Berk, the idea behind the mirror is that smiling, even if faked, can make us genuinely feel better (known as the facial feedback hypothesis), and that laughter can improve immune function and even ostensibly make us live longer. The evidence for the effect is dubious, but more to the point … it is possible to smile when looking into a normal mirror. The product is a screen fitted with a camera that uses facial recognition to tell when an individual is smiling, which turns the screen reflective. The product was designed by a man and it is noticeable that a woman has been used in the mirror's promotional photography, which speaks to the "cheer up, love" element of which this product smacks. Berk Ilhan says that he created the mirror while a student at the School of Visual Arts in New York, after consultation with oncologists and cancer patients. One of whom told Ilhan that it was difficult to face up to having the illness. Ilhan clearly took "face up" in its most literal sense. As the mirror's reflective surface flickers to life, it's hard not to feel a twinge of skepticism. Is this really the best way to tackle the complexities of cancer treatment and patient mental health? Berk Ilhan's motivations, while well-intentioned, seem to be rooted in a simplistic understanding of the human experience. The mirror's promotional video shows a montage of cancer patients smiling, laughing, and seemingly feeling more positive after using the device. But what about the patients who can't muster a smile, even with the mirror's encouragement? What about those who are struggling to cope with the emotional toll of their diagnosis?

Despite these concerns, the Smile Mirror has gained a surprising amount of attention online, with many praising its "innovative" design. Some have even compared it to the "talking cure" of psychoanalysis, where patients would speak to a therapist and, through the act of speaking, begin to feel better. But while the mirror may be a novel way to approach mental health, it's unclear whether it's a truly effective one. As the cancer community continues to grapple with the challenges of diagnosis, treatment, and recovery, it remains to be seen whether the Smile Mirror will become a valuable tool or a fleeting fad.

The Changing Media Summit returns on 7 March 2018. Our flagship media event brings the industry together to discuss the most important issues facing us today. This year, we'll be focusing on the importance of responsibility across the media industries. As the mainstream media faces increasing accusations of bias and misinformation, we're asking what constitutes balance in news? And as new and independent outlets make headway, how can they work with the mainstream to best serve readers and the public? As news and information consumption changes, social media platforms are finding themselves under more scrutiny than ever before. So what responsibility do these platforms have for the content they host? Should they be judged by the same standards as news providers? and how can they be held accountable for the spread of misinformation? Our expert panel will delve into the complexities of online echo chambers and the role of algorithms in shaping our online experiences. We'll also explore the impact of fake news on the democratic process and the ethical considerations that come with reporting on sensitive topics. With the rise of influencer culture, we'll examine the blurred lines between journalism and celebrity endorsements, and the implications for trust and credibility in the media landscape. Don't miss out on this opportunity to be part of the conversation shaping the future of media. Register now to secure your place at this essential event.

Mark Zuckerberg has been asked to search for evidence that Russia-linked Facebook accounts were used to interfere in the EU referendum and the general election as part of a parliamentary inquiry into "fake news". Damian Collins, the chair of the digital, culture, media and sport committee, has written to the Facebook founder after suspicions that Russian "actors" used the platform to interfere in British politics. Facebook has 32 million users in Britain. Similar evidence on the 2016 US presidential election has already been supplied by Facebook to several US Senate committees, including the Senate intelligence committee, before a hearing with legal representatives from Facebook, Twitter and Google on 1 November in Washington DC. Facebook in the US disclosed last month that an influence operation that appeared to be based in Russia spent $100,000 (£75,000) on adverts to promote divisive political and social messages over a two-year period. In his letter to Zuckerberg, Collins expressed concern that the Russian interference may have had a significant impact on the outcome of the EU referendum and the general election. He requested that Facebook provide any evidence it holds on the use of Russian-linked accounts to spread disinformation and propaganda during the two elections.

Collins also asked Facebook to explain its procedures for detecting and removing fake accounts, as well as its plans to prevent similar interference in future elections. The committee chair noted that Facebook's failure to prevent Russian interference in the US presidential election had led to widespread criticism and calls for greater transparency and accountability.

The inquiry is part of a broader effort by the British government to address the issue of disinformation and propaganda in the run-up to the next general election, which is expected to take place in 2022. The government has already launched a number of initiatives aimed at countering Russian disinformation, including the creation of a new unit dedicated to tackling online propaganda.

Facebook's response to Collins' letter is expected to be closely watched by politicians and the public alike. The company has faced intense scrutiny in recent years over its handling of disinformation and propaganda on its platform, and has faced criticism for failing to do enough to prevent Russian interference in the US presidential election.

In a statement, Facebook said it was committed to protecting the integrity of elections and would provide any information it holds on Russian-linked accounts to the committee. The company added that it had already taken a number of steps to prevent interference in future elections, including the creation of a new team dedicated to countering disinformation.

The news comes as Facebook faces increasing pressure from regulators and politicians around the world to do more to prevent disinformation and propaganda on its platform. The company has faced criticism for failing to do enough to prevent the spread of fake news and propaganda during the US presidential election, and has faced calls for greater transparency and accountability.

In the UK, the government has already launched a number of initiatives aimed at countering Russian disinformation, including the creation of a new unit dedicated to tackling online propaganda. The unit, which is being led by the National Cyber Security Centre, is working with social media companies to identify and remove disinformation and propaganda from their platforms.

The government has also announced plans to introduce new laws aimed at preventing foreign interference in British politics. The laws, which are expected to be introduced in the next parliament, will give the government new powers to regulate social media companies and prevent them from being used to spread disinformation and propaganda.

The news has sparked a heated debate about the role of social media in British politics, with many politicians and experts calling for greater regulation of the platforms. The debate is likely to continue in the coming weeks and months as the government and social media companies work to address the issue of disinformation and propaganda in the run-up to the next general election.

Sir Hector Sants, a former chief City regulator, is due to give evidence to the high court in private in relation to a case brought by Lloyds Banking Group shareholders over the information they were provided at the time of the HBOS takeover in 2008. The former chief executive of the Financial Services Authority made an application in July to allow him to give evidence in private. This can now be reported after an application to the high court made by five media organisations, including the Guardian, to establish what the judge had described as the "special arrangements" that have been put in place for him to give evidence. Mr Justice Norris made his judgment after hearing the application by the Guardian, the Financial Times, Daily Mail publisher Associated Newspapers, the Times and Bloomberg. He made his judgment as the fourth day of the case brought by the shareholders began. About 6,000 Lloyds investors are claiming £600m in compensation on the basis that they were not told about loans being made to HBOS when they voted through the takeover in November 2008. The decision to allow Sir Hector Sants to give evidence in private has raised concerns among some of the shareholders, who are seeking compensation for what they claim is a loss of £600m. The shareholders argue that they were not informed about the significant loans being made to HBOS at the time of the takeover, which they claim would have influenced their decision to approve the deal. The Lloyds Banking Group has denied any wrongdoing and has maintained that the information provided to shareholders was adequate.

Sir Hector Sants, who was the chief executive of the Financial Services Authority at the time of the takeover, has been a key figure in the case. He has previously testified that he did not believe it was necessary to disclose the details of the loans to shareholders, citing a lack of transparency in the banking industry at the time. However, the shareholders claim that this lack of transparency was a deliberate attempt to conceal the true nature of the deal.

The case is being closely watched by the financial industry, as it could set a precedent for future cases involving the disclosure of information to investors. The outcome could also have significant implications for the banking industry as a whole, potentially leading to changes in the way that information is disclosed to investors. The case is expected to continue for several more days, with Sir Hector Sants' private evidence expected to be a key part of the proceedings.

The London Stock Exchange has been forced to set out the rationale for the departure of chief executive, Xavier Rolet, citing his "operating style" and questions from shareholders about how long he intended to stay. The exchange provided the explanation in a 20-page circular setting the date for the shareholders' meeting demanded by an activist investor which wants to oust the company's chairmanover his handling of Rolet's departure. In one of the highest-profile boardroom battles in recent years, Sir Chris Hohn's TCI fund management group has demanded the shareholder vote – which will take place on 19 December – to remove Donald Brydon, the City veteran who has chaired the exchange since 2015. TCI, the Children's Investment Fund Management, had been fighting against Rolet's departure but on Thursday dropped this following the LSE's announcement that the chief executive would leave immediately – a year earlier than planned. The 20-page circular, which was released on Friday, provides a detailed explanation of the reasons behind Rolet's departure, citing his "operating style" as a key factor. The document also addresses concerns from shareholders about the lack of clarity on Rolet's future plans, stating that his decision to leave was "not taken lightly" and was made after careful consideration.

The circular notes that Rolet's departure was not a result of any wrongdoing or breach of his contract, but rather a decision that was made in the best interests of the company. It also acknowledges that Rolet's operating style, which was characterized as "results-driven" and "direct", may not have been universally accepted by all stakeholders.

The document also addresses the controversy surrounding Rolet's severance package, which has been criticized by some as being too generous. The LSE has stated that the package is in line with industry standards and is designed to ensure a smooth transition for the company.

In addition to the explanation for Rolet's departure, the circular also provides details on the company's financial performance and strategy for the future. It notes that the company is well-positioned for growth, with a strong balance sheet and a robust pipeline of new products and services.

The shareholder meeting, which will take place on December 19, is expected to be closely watched by investors and analysts. The outcome of the vote will determine the future of the LSE's board, including the fate of Chairman Donald Brydon, who has been a vocal supporter of Rolet.

In the meantime, the LSE has appointed a new interim CEO, who will take over from Rolet on January 1. The company has also announced plans to conduct a review of its corporate governance practices, in response to the controversy surrounding Rolet's departure.

The vice-chancellor of Bath University has said she is not embarrassed by controversy over her £468,000 pay package, insisting her salary reflects a competitive international jobs market. Dame Glynis Breakwell, the UK's highest paid vice-chancellor, agreed to step down on Tuesday following months of criticism surrounding her remuneration, but has faced more condemnation after it was revealed she will still be paid her full salary after leaving the post. Breakwell announced on Tuesday that she would take a sabbatical at the end of the current academic year before retiring in early 2019, meaning the vice-chancellor will receive around £600,000 from now until her retirement. Speaking to BBC Radio 4's PM programme on Wednesday evening, Breakwell said: "I think the controversy has been something that I would have wished to avoid but I'm not embarrassed by the fact people who have actively determined my salary did so in the way that they did. "I don't actually think that the university's reputation is being damaged by this, I think we recognise the value and significance of the university." However, many have disputed Breakwell's assertion that the university's reputation is not being damaged. Critics have argued that the massive pay package and subsequent backlash have tarnished the institution's image and undermined public trust.

Breakwell's decision to take a sabbatical and receive her full salary until retirement has also been met with outrage. Many have questioned why she is being allowed to leave with such a generous package, while others have expressed disappointment that she is not taking full responsibility for the controversy.

The row has sparked a wider debate about executive pay and accountability in the higher education sector. Many have called for greater transparency and scrutiny of university salaries, as well as stricter guidelines on when and how senior staff can leave their posts.

Breakwell's departure has also raised questions about the future of Bath University, with some speculating that the controversy may have long-term implications for the institution's reputation and ability to attract students and staff. As the university begins the process of finding a new vice-chancellor, many are watching with bated breath to see how the situation will unfold.

Staff at HuffPost Australia fear the axe could fall on the two-year-old arm of the global Huffington Post brand amid a review of its deal with local partner Fairfax Media. Contributors have been told the website is not taking commissions, Guardian Australia understands, and some of the staff of about 30 say the atmosphere is "bleak" as they await developments. The editor-in-chief of Huffpost Australia, Tory Maguire, declined to comment on the future of the website. However, a spokesperson for HuffPost Australia said: "The joint venture partners of HuffPost Australia are having high-level discussions regarding the future of the JV. No definite decisions have been made." Former Nine Today show co-host Lisa Wilkinson, who will join the Ten network next year, is the website's editor at large, a role which has involved filing less than one piece a month for a six-figure pay packet. The last piece she wrote was published in October. Huffpo Australia – which rebranded from the Huffington Post Australia this year – finally started up in 2015, five years after it first talked about setting up an office here and advertised for an Australian editor. The discussions about the future of the site have been sparked by changes at the AOL-owned Huffington Post global empire after the departure of co-founder Arianna Huffington last year. "I thought HuffPost would be my last act. The uncertainty surrounding the future of HuffPost Australia has left staff feeling anxious and uncertain about their jobs. Some contributors have already been told that they will not be receiving commissions for their work, a move that has been seen as a sign that the website is preparing to scale back its operations.

Despite the uncertainty, the website's editor-in-chief, Tory Maguire, has refused to comment on the future of the site. However, a spokesperson for HuffPost Australia has confirmed that the joint venture partners are having high-level discussions about the future of the JV, but no definitive decisions have been made.

The discussions about the future of the site have been sparked by changes at the AOL-owned Huffington Post global empire after the departure of co-founder Arianna Huffington last year. The departure of Arianna Huffington, who was instrumental in setting up the Australian arm of the website, has left many wondering about the future of the site.

The uncertainty has also led to speculation about the role of Lisa Wilkinson, who is the website's editor at large. Wilkinson, who is set to join the Ten network next year, has been a prominent figure at HuffPost Australia, but her involvement with the site has been limited in recent months. The last piece she wrote was published in October, and some have questioned whether she will continue to play a role at the website.

The future of HuffPost Australia remains uncertain, and staff are waiting with bated breath to see what will happen next. Will the website continue to operate, or will it be shut down? Only time will tell.

My colleague and friend Geoffrey Oldham, who has died aged 88, was one of the founders in 1966 of the Science Policy Research Unit (SPRU) at the University of Sussex. He dedicated his life's work to building pioneering institutions that advocated the intelligent and innovative use of science and technology for a sustainable and equitable world. His influence came to span the globe, and his kindness and enthusiasm were felt by a vast network of colleagues and friends. Son of Evelyn (nee Brooke) and Herbert Oldham, Geoff was born in Harden, West Yorkshire, where his father was a manager with the NatWest bank. He went to Bingley grammar and studied geology at the University of Reading. He was accepted for further studies at both Cambridge and Toronto universities; 10 days after his wedding in September 1951 to Brenda Raven, they sailed for Canada. Having obtained a PhD in geophysics from the University of Toronto, Geoff worked in oil company exploration, focusing on South America. Yet, he began to think about achieving something different as a scientist: helping to harness the world's science and technology more effectively to eliminate the depths of poverty he had observed in Latin America. This led to a career change, via a period of research about science and technology in China and other Asian countries. As he delved deeper into the relationship between science, technology, and society, Geoffrey Oldham's fascination with the potential of science to address global challenges only grew stronger. He returned to the UK in the late 1950s, joining the University of Sussex as a lecturer in the Department of Geology. It was during this period that he began to envision a new kind of institution that would bring together scholars from various disciplines to explore the social and environmental implications of scientific and technological advancements.

Geoffrey's vision took shape in 1966 with the establishment of the Science Policy Research Unit (SPRU), which he co-founded with a small group of like-minded colleagues. SPRU's mission was to provide independent, interdisciplinary research and analysis on the social, economic, and environmental impacts of science and technology. The unit quickly gained international recognition for its innovative approach and rigorous research, attracting scholars and policymakers from around the world.

Throughout his career, Geoffrey remained committed to building bridges between academia, government, and civil society. He worked closely with international organizations, such as the United Nations, and advised governments on science and technology policy. His work spanned multiple continents, from the Amazon rainforest to the deserts of Africa, and his research tackled some of the most pressing global challenges of his time, including poverty, inequality, and environmental degradation.

Geoffrey's legacy extends far beyond his own research and achievements. He inspired generations of scholars and policymakers, leaving behind a vast network of colleagues and friends who continue to work towards a more just and sustainable world. His passing is a loss felt deeply by all who knew him, but his life's work will continue to inspire and guide us towards a brighter future.

Being a successful woman seems to attract a disproportionate degree of negative criticism (Vice-chancellor survives no confidence vote, 23 November). Since becoming vice-chancellor of the University of Bath in 2001, Glynis Breakwell has led the university from strength to strength as measured by external assessment. This includes gold status in the teaching excellence framework, one of the top 12 universities in the UK in the research excellence framework, and ranked fifth-best university in the UK by the Guardian University 2018 guide. The university makes an important contribution to the local community and economy. As women academics we are proud to be members of the university and to acknowledge the leadership and support that Glynis Breakwell has provided. Aspects of the governance of the university have been criticised in the recent report from the Higher Education Funding Council. The university urgently needs to address these issues. This involves us all, working together. We think it is time to leave the personalised attacks on the vice-chancellor behind, recognise what we have achieved as a university, and focus on bringing in the necessary governance changes. In light of the recent no-confidence vote, we believe it is essential to shift the focus from personal attacks to constructive dialogue. The university's achievements are a testament to the hard work and dedication of its staff, students, and leadership. It is crucial that we recognize and build upon these strengths rather than tearing each other down.

As women academics, we are acutely aware of the challenges we face in higher education. We know that women are underrepresented in senior leadership positions and that we often have to work harder to prove ourselves. We believe that Glynis Breakwell's leadership has been instrumental in creating a more inclusive and supportive environment for women at the University of Bath.

We understand that the recent report from the Higher Education Funding Council has raised concerns about governance issues at the university. We agree that these concerns need to be addressed, and we are committed to working together to bring about the necessary changes. However, we believe that this can be achieved through constructive dialogue and collaboration rather than through personal attacks and criticism.

We urge our colleagues to join us in recognizing the achievements of the university and to focus on finding solutions to the challenges we face. We believe that by working together, we can create a brighter future for the University of Bath and for higher education as a whole. Let us put aside our differences and focus on what unites us: our passion for education, our commitment to excellence, and our desire to make a positive impact on the world.

We are proud to be part of this university community, and we believe that together, we can achieve great things. Let us work together to build a brighter future for the University of Bath and for all its stakeholders.

A growing proportion of independent faith schools are being failed by Ofsted because of concerns about leadership and the teaching of British values, according to official statistics. The schools watchdog said there had been a sharp decline in inspection outcomes for smaller, fee-paying schools, in particular faith schools. Latest figures show 49% of private faith schools inspected by Ofsted were judged less than good at their most recent inspection and 26% were inadequate. The details were released as part of Ofsted's roundup of inspections of non-association independent schools – smaller, fee-paying schools not part of groups affiliated to the Independent Schools Council. There are just over 1,000 such schools. At the end of August, 68% of those inspected were judged good or outstanding at their most recent inspection, four percentage points down on last year. The alarming decline in inspection outcomes for independent faith schools has sparked concerns about the quality of education and leadership in these institutions. Critics argue that the sharp drop in standards is a result of a lack of accountability and a failure to prioritize the teaching of British values, which are essential for fostering a sense of community and social cohesion.

Ofsted's figures reveal that the majority of private faith schools inspected in the past year were found to be lacking in one or more areas, with 49% judged less than good and 26% deemed inadequate. This represents a significant deterioration in standards compared to previous years, with the proportion of good or outstanding schools declining by four percentage points.

Experts warn that the decline in standards is not limited to individual schools, but rather reflects a broader trend of complacency and a lack of oversight in the independent school sector. "The fact that so many independent faith schools are failing to meet basic standards is a cause for concern," said Dr. Sarah Jones, an education expert at the University of London. "It's not just about the quality of education, but also about the values and principles that these schools are supposed to be instilling in their students."

The teaching of British values, in particular, has been identified as a key area of concern. Ofsted inspectors have found that many independent faith schools are failing to provide adequate instruction on British values, such as respect for the law, tolerance, and democracy. This has raised concerns that students are not being equipped with the skills and knowledge they need to succeed in a rapidly changing world.

The decline in standards has also sparked concerns about the impact on students and parents. "As a parent, I want to know that my child is receiving a high-quality education and being taught the values that are important for their future success," said Sarah Khan, a parent of a child at an independent faith school. "The fact that so many schools are failing to meet basic standards is a cause for concern and I hope that Ofsted will take action to address this issue."

In response to the concerns, Ofsted has announced plans to increase the frequency and intensity of inspections in the independent school sector. The watchdog has also called on schools to prioritize the teaching of British values and to take steps to improve leadership and governance. "We will not tolerate a decline in standards in any sector, and we will take action to ensure that all schools are providing a high-quality education and instilling the values that are essential for success," said Amanda Spielman, Chief Inspector of Ofsted.

In 1973 Heinz Wolff was the specialist judge for my school's team in the first heat of the BBC Young Scientists of the Year competition. Two years previously a consultant at Guy's hospital in London had asked our school if we could assist children with cerebral palsy; they wore out their shoes very quickly due to the manner in which they walked. We researched materials and eventually produced an automated machine that manufactured hard-wearing polypropylene toecaps to fit over their shoes. and our machine was able to produce a customized solution that greatly improved the comfort and mobility of these children. The experience not only taught us about the importance of innovative problem-solving, but also instilled in us a sense of purpose and social responsibility. Little did we know that this project would be the catalyst for a lifelong passion for me to pursue a career in prosthetics and orthotics.

As I grew older, I continued to work on various projects that aimed to improve the lives of individuals with physical disabilities. During my university years, I was part of a team that developed a revolutionary new prosthetic limb that was capable of being controlled by the user's thoughts. The technology was groundbreaking, and it paved the way for further advancements in the field.

Years later, I would go on to establish my own company, dedicated to designing and manufacturing prosthetic and orthotic devices that could make a real difference in people's lives. And it all started with that initial project to create a solution for children with cerebral palsy, thanks to the guidance and encouragement of Heinz Wolff, our specialist judge from the BBC Young Scientists of the Year competition.

The first-ever shipment of Russian gas to the UK looks likely to head straight back out on another ship, disproving Moscow's claims that Britain will be reliant on it for supplies this winter. National Grid confirmed that gas from a Russian field targeted by US sanctions had been delivered by a Russian icebreaker to storage facilities at the Isle of Grain in Kent on Thursday night. Russian media seized on the delivery of liquefied natural gas (LNG) to claim it would "keep Britons from freezing this winter" while the Russian embassy in the UK tweeted: "Feeling cold? Help is on the way." However, industry experts said the most likely scenario was that the UK would simply be a stopping-off point for the gas, which could fetch a much higher price in Asia. Ed Cox, the editor of global LNG at the market intelligence firm ICIS, said: "I would urge some caution [on the idea Russian gas will be supplying the UK]. There's another empty LNG vessel outside the Isle of Grain now, which looks like it's going to come in and pick up that cargo. "The [gas] prices are much more attractive in Asia and India than they are in Europe." Market sources had told ICIS that the LNG was expected to be picked up by the other ship, he added. According to market analysts, the high demand for LNG in Asia, particularly in China and India, has driven up prices to levels that make it more profitable for Russian gas companies to sell to these markets. "The arbitrage is huge," said Cox. "It's like a gold rush for LNG traders." The UK, on the other hand, has a relatively well-stocked gas storage system and a diverse range of suppliers, making it less dependent on Russian gas.

Industry insiders point out that the UK's gas storage capacity is currently around 4 billion cubic meters, with an additional 1 billion cubic meters of storage available in the coming weeks. This, combined with the country's existing supply chain and diverse range of gas sources, means that the UK is well-equipped to meet its gas demands this winter.

Despite Moscow's claims that the Russian gas shipment would "keep Britons from freezing this winter", experts believe that the UK's energy security is not at risk.
