"The UK has a robust energy system, and we are well-prepared to meet our gas demands this winter," said a spokesperson for the UK's Office of Gas and Electricity Markets (Ofgem). "We are not reliant on a single supplier or source of gas, and we have a range of contingency plans in place to ensure that our energy needs are met." With the UK's energy supply looking secure, the Russian gas shipment is unlikely to have a significant impact on the country's energy landscape.

Goldman Sachs has said Donald Trump's radical US tax changes will knock about $5bn (£3.7bn) off its profits this year. The investment bank said most of the cost would come from Trump's "repatriation tax" designed to encourage multinationals to bring back the trillions of dollars they hold overseas to avoid tax. Goldman, which made profits of $7.4bn last year, said: "The enactment of the tax legislation will result in a reduction of approximately $5bn in the firm's earnings for the fourth quarter and year ending 31 December 2017, approximately two-thirds of which is due to the repatriation tax. "The remainder includes the effects of the implementation of the territorial tax system and the remeasurement of US deferred tax assets at lower enacted corporate tax rates," the bank said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Friday. Last week Congress approved the biggest tax overhaul in 30 years, which includes big tax cuts for companies and wealthy people. The reduction in corporation tax – from 35% to 21% – is designed in part to encourage multinational to repatriate cash from overseas. US companies were estimated, by Citigroup, to hold $2.5tn of capital overseas. Companies had previously explained that they had a duty to shareholders to keep the money abroad, rather than bring it back to the US and pay large tax bills. The tax overhaul will allow Apple to bring back its $252.3bn foreign cash mountain without a major tax hit. The news has sent shockwaves through the financial industry, with many experts predicting a similar impact on other multinational companies. The repatriation tax, which is designed to encourage companies to bring back their foreign earnings, is expected to raise billions of dollars in revenue for the US government. However, the cost to companies like Goldman Sachs is significant, and many are already warning of potential job cuts and reduced investment in the US economy.

The tax overhaul has been widely criticized by Democrats and some Republicans, who argue that it will disproportionately benefit the wealthy and large corporations. The legislation also includes a provision that allows companies to deduct the cost of buying back their own shares, which is expected to further increase the wealth gap in the US.

Goldman Sachs' announcement has sparked concerns about the potential impact on the US economy, particularly in industries that are heavily reliant on multinational companies. The bank's CEO, David Solomon, has defended the tax overhaul, saying that it will create jobs and stimulate economic growth. However, many experts are skeptical, and the news has sent the Dow Jones industrial average tumbling. As the global economy continues to navigate uncertain times, the impact of the tax overhaul on multinational companies will be closely watched.

Global temperatures could break through the internationally agreed upper 1.5C limit within the next five years, according to a forecast by British scientists that raises fresh questions about the world's efforts to tackle climate change. The Met Office forecasting service said that in the period from 2018 to 2022, annual global average temperatures are likely to exceed 1C above pre-industrial levels and could top the 1.5C threshold set as an aspiration by the global Paris climate change deal in 2015. "It is now possible that continued warming from greenhouse gases along with natural variability could combine so we temporarily exceed 1.5C in the next five years," said Stephen Belcher, the chief scientist at the Met Office. Global temperatures have been steadily rising over the past 20 years, and in each of the last three years averages have topped the 1C threshold. Last year was the second hottest on record, and the hottest not to have been given an additional boost by the El Niño effect. The 1.5C threshold was set at Paris as an ambitious target because scientists fear that a world warmer than that would be susceptible to ever wilder climactic events that in turn would precipitate greater drought, habitat loss, food insecurity and mass migration. The forecast has sparked concerns among climate experts, who warn that exceeding the 1.5C threshold could have catastrophic consequences for the planet. "We're already seeing the impacts of climate change, from more frequent and severe heatwaves to devastating storms and droughts," said Dr. Belcher. "If we exceed 1.5C, we risk triggering a tipping point that could lead to irreversible damage to our ecosystems and global food systems." The Met Office's warning comes as world leaders prepare to meet at the UN Climate Action Summit in September to discuss their progress towards meeting the Paris Agreement's goals. The forecast has added urgency to the need for immediate and drastic action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and transition to renewable energy sources.

My father, Edgar Young, who has died aged 93, was part of an extraordinary postwar intake at Bognor Regis emergency teacher training college in West Sussex. Created to address the severe teacher shortage following Rab Butler's 1944 Education Act, the college, led by the innovative Roy Macklin, was more concerned with the character and experience of applicants than in formal qualifications. During the second world war, Edgar had worked in a protected occupation as a shipwright in Portsmouth dockyard, but saw a vocation in primary school teaching and shared Macklin's view of education as a guide for living rather than narrowly vocational or academic. The college provided an intensive 50-week course for mature students, mainly former servicemen and women. Possessing practical skills and often widely travelled, they brought to the classroom a wealth of knowledge denied to colleagues whose life had been spent wholly in the education system. Subsequently heads and school inspectors regarded teachers from this course as particularly talented and effective educators. Son of John and Lilian (known as "Cissie"), Edgar was born in Portsmouth into a family of skilled dockyard workers. Edgar's experience in the dockyard had given him a unique perspective on the importance of teamwork and discipline, skills that served him well in the classroom. His fellow students at the college were a diverse and fascinating group, including a former prisoner of war, a pilot, and a nurse. The camaraderie and sense of purpose that developed among them helped to create a supportive and motivating environment, which was reflected in their excellent academic results.

After graduating from the college, Edgar was appointed to a primary school in a small town in East Sussex. He quickly established himself as a popular and respected teacher, known for his creative approach to teaching and his ability to engage even the most reluctant learners. His students loved him, and he was often invited to stay on for extra-curricular activities, such as sports days and school plays.

Edgar's passion for teaching was contagious, and he inspired many of his colleagues to adopt a similar approach. He was a strong advocate for child-centered learning, and his classrooms were always filled with innovative and engaging activities. His commitment to his students and his school was unwavering, and he remained in the same post for over 30 years, earning the respect and admiration of his community.

Edgar's family was always important to him, and he was a devoted husband to his wife, Margaret, and father to their two children. He was also a keen gardener and enjoyed spending time in his garden, where he would often reflect on his teaching career and the many lives he had touched. Despite his many achievements, Edgar remained humble and kind, always willing to lend a helping hand or offer words of wisdom. His legacy continues to inspire future generations of teachers and students, and he will be deeply missed by all who knew him.

There's nothing like picking a primary school for your child to reveal the real you. Friends who could barely recite the Lord's prayer spout Corinthians to get into the local C of E. Closet Tories emerge from beneath socialist hairshirts. Some even move in with their mother-in-law, just to get their tot's tootsies into a catchment area. But where to look? Ofsted reports? Too obsessed with maths and literacy. Year 6 Sats results? Again, too narrowly focused. The Good Schools Guide? The Daily Telegraph's? As if. Here is the continued article:

But what about the school's actual community? Do they have a thriving drama department? Are the kids encouraged to ask questions and think critically? Are the teachers warm and approachable? These are the things that really matter, yet they're rarely considered in the great primary school search.

I remember a friend who was convinced to send her child to a school simply because it had a "good" Ofsted report, only to discover that the teachers were strict and unapproachable, and the kids were more interested in playing video games than learning. Another friend chose a school based on its proximity to their home, only to find that the commute was a nightmare and the school was more focused on preparing kids for tests than on fostering a love of learning.

It's time to rethink the way we choose primary schools. We need to look beyond the statistics and focus on what really matters: creating a nurturing, engaging, and inspiring environment for our children to thrive.

Randolph Quirk was a longstanding family friend. Whenever he and his wife, Jean, came to our house it was full of laughter and fun. He was also exceedingly competitive. On holiday in Northumberland in the 1960s he challenged a Roman Catholic priest, Alec Fraser, who was with us to a motor race on a two-lane, straight but switchback road. Quirk drove with his family in a Morris Minor and Fraser drove an Austin Standard. As they sped down the road, Quirk's competitive streak got the better of him, and he began to weave in and out of the oncoming traffic, much to the horror of his wife and children. Fraser, however, remained calm and steady, his priestly composure unwavering. The two cars hurtled towards the first switchback, and the crowd of onlookers held their breaths as the drivers approached the tight turn. Would Quirk's recklessness pay off, or would Father Fraser's steady hand take the win?

Facebook will roll out a new set of tools aimed at making it easier for users to make informed choices about their privacy in response to sweeping new European privacy laws, according to the company's chief operating officer, Sheryl Sandberg. "We're rolling out a new privacy centre globally that will put the core privacy settings for Facebook in one place and make it much easier for people to manage their data," Sandberg said at a Facebook event in Brussels on Tuesday. She said that the creation of a "privacy centre" was prompted by the requirements of the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), an EU regulation that seeks to give Europeans more control over their information and how companies use it. "Our apps have long been focused on giving people transparency and control and this gives us a very good foundation to meet all the requirements of the GDPR and to spur us on to continue investing in products and in educational tools to protect privacy," Sandberg said. The new privacy centre will be available globally, allowing users to access their core privacy settings in one place, Sandberg explained. She also highlighted that the company has been working on implementing the GDPR requirements for several months, and that the new tools are part of a broader effort to enhance transparency and control for users.

"We want to make sure that people understand how we're using their data, and that they have the ability to make informed choices about how we use it," Sandberg said. "We're committed to protecting the privacy of our users, and we believe that these new tools will help us to do just that."

The new privacy centre will include a range of features, including a "data use" section that will provide users with information about how their data is being used, as well as a "manage your data" section that will allow users to delete or download their data. Sandberg also announced that Facebook will be introducing a new "transparency centre" in Brussels, which will provide information about the company's data use and processing practices.

In addition to the new privacy centre, Sandberg also announced that Facebook will be investing in educational tools to help users understand how to protect their privacy online. The company will be launching a new "Privacy Basics" course, which will provide users with information about how to use Facebook's privacy settings, as well as how to identify and avoid online scams.

Sandberg emphasized that Facebook is committed to protecting the privacy of its users, and that the new tools are just the beginning of the company's efforts to enhance transparency and control. "We're committed to being transparent about how we use our users' data, and to giving them the tools they need to make informed choices about how we use it," she said. "We believe that these new tools will help us to build trust with our users, and to continue to be a responsible and trustworthy partner in the online community."

The Italian restaurant chain Prezzo is to close a third of its 300 UK branches, putting about 1,000 jobs at risk, the latest victim of the casual dining crunch. The chain, owned by the US private equity group TPG Capital, hopes to engineer a turnaround plan echoing steps taken by the burger chain Byron and Jamie's Italian to keep themselves afloat. Prezzo's creditors will be asked to approve proposals under which its restaurants' landlords accept rent reductions. About 100 unprofitable outlets are likely to close altogether, including all branches of its Tex-Mex offshoot, Chimichanga, in an attempt to put the business on a sound long-term financial footing. While landlords have yet to agree to the plan – known as a company voluntary arrangement (CVA) – it is expected to result in about 1,000 of the 4,500-strong UK workforce losing their jobs. Sources close to the company said staff would be transferred to the surviving restaurants where possible. The proposed CVA is expected to be voted on by creditors in the coming weeks, with a decision expected by the end of the month. If approved, the plan would allow Prezzo to restructure its debt and reduce its rent burden, which has been a major contributor to its financial struggles.

The move comes as the casual dining sector continues to face intense competition from fast-casual chains and online food delivery services. Prezzo's sales have been declining in recent years, and the company has been struggling to compete with its rivals.

In a statement, Prezzo said: "We are taking decisive action to address the challenges facing our business and ensure a sustainable future for Prezzo. We are committed to protecting as many jobs as possible and will be working closely with our employees, landlords and creditors to deliver a successful turnaround plan."

The company has already begun informing affected staff of the proposed closures and redundancies, and has set up a support package for those who will be leaving the business.

Industry experts have warned that the casual dining sector is facing a perfect storm of challenges, including rising costs, changing consumer habits and intense competition. "This is a wake-up call for the entire industry," said one analyst. "Prezzo's struggles are a symptom of a much broader problem, and we can expect to see more casualties in the coming months."

The news has sent shockwaves through the industry, with many rival chains and investors expressing concern about the future of the sector. "This is a very worrying development," said one rival chain's CEO. "We're all in the same boat, and we need to work together to find a way to stay afloat."

UK universities top the world rankings in 10 different subject areas, but engineering and technology subjects are falling behind the arts and humanities, according to a prestigious world university league table. The 2018 QS world university rankings, published on 28 February, show that the UK is home to the world's leading universities in 10 subjects – two more than last year. UK universities make up a third of the world's top three positions, but these are concentrated in the arts and humanities. UK universities only topped the world's lists for engineering and technology subjects twice, while they made the top three lists for arts and humanities subjects 10 times. The rankings come as the prime minister, Theresa May, pushes ahead with funding reforms that may see universities cut their fees for social science and humanities courses based on their lower costs of delivery, leaving science and technology courses more expensive. The results show the resilience of the UK's universities in the face of Brexit. The ranking highlights the UK's strengths in arts and humanities, with universities such as Oxford, Cambridge, and Edinburgh performing exceptionally well in subjects like English language and literature, philosophy, and history. In contrast, the country's engineering and technology programs have struggled to keep pace, with only a handful of UK universities making it into the top three in these subjects.

Experts have attributed the decline to a lack of investment in these areas, as well as a shortage of skilled engineering and technology graduates. "The UK's engineering and technology programs have been underfunded for years, and it's no surprise that we're seeing a decline in our global rankings," said Professor Jane Smith, a leading expert in engineering education. "We need to prioritize investment in these areas if we want to remain a global leader in innovation and technology."

The news comes as the UK government prepares to introduce new funding reforms, which could see universities cut their fees for social science and humanities courses based on their lower costs of delivery. The reforms, which are part of a broader effort to reduce student debt, could have significant implications for the country's universities.

While some have argued that the reforms could help make higher education more accessible to a wider range of students, others have expressed concerns that they could have a disproportionate impact on certain subjects. "The government's funding reforms could exacerbate the existing problem of underinvestment in engineering and technology," said Dr. John Taylor, a leading expert in higher education policy. "We need to think carefully about the long-term implications of these reforms and make sure that we're not inadvertently undermining the very subjects that are driving innovation and economic growth."

Despite these challenges, the UK's universities remain a source of national pride and a key driver of the country's economy. As the government moves forward with its funding reforms, it will be important to strike a balance between promoting accessibility and ensuring that the country's universities remain globally competitive in all subjects, not just the arts and humanities.

It's tough for savers: the best-paying easy-access cash Isas – from Virgin Money and Leeds building society – pay just 1.21% interest. Meanwhile, official data earlier this month showed that inflation remained high at 3% in January – meaning savers are losing money in real terms. That may help explain why cash Isas have collapsed in popularity, with government data showing a £20bn fall in the amount invested in the space of 12 months. However, rates do look to be on the move upwards. This week, the Bank of England governor, Mark Carney, told MPs there were likely to be "something more than three rate increases," over the next few years. Lloyds, meanwhile, is predicting the official interest rate will rise only gently, reaching 1.25% by 2020 (it's currently 0.5%). For the best rates, you need to lock your money away. Charter Savings Bank has a table-topping 2.25% (up from 2.11%) – but it is fixed for five years. Rates on its one-year and two-year versions were upped to 1.46% and 1.67% respectively. Virgin Money is offering 1.66% on its two-year fixed-rate Isa. Despite the paltry returns on offer, some savers are willing to lock their money away for longer periods in exchange for slightly higher interest rates. Charter Savings Bank's five-year fixed-rate Isa, for example, now pays a competitive 2.25%, up from 2.11% previously. However, this comes with the caveat that savers will need to keep their money locked away for the full five years to avoid incurring early withdrawal penalties.

Other banks and building societies are also upping their game, with some offering more competitive rates on shorter-term fixed-rate Isas. For instance, Shawbrook Bank's one-year fixed-rate Isa now pays 1.51%, while its two-year version pays 1.71%. Meanwhile, Aldermore's two-year fixed-rate Isa has been boosted to 1.73%.

While these rates may not be enough to make savers rich, they are at least offering a slightly more attractive alternative to the paltry returns on offer from easy-access Isas. And with the Bank of England governor hinting at further rate hikes in the coming years, it's likely that savers will continue to see rates rise as inflation remains high.

Around 20 false emergency calls a day have been made from one of Apple's refurbishment centres since October – and it's not clear how. Emergency dispatchers in California have fielded in the region of 1,600 accidental calls originating from a repair and refurbishment centre in Elk Grove, with no one on the other end. "We've been seeing these calls for the last four months from Apple," police dispatcher Jamie Hudson told CBS, explaining that the instances take up valuable seconds away from real emergencies. "We're able to see quickly where the call is coming from, so when we get one from Apple, the address will come up with their location." The refurbishment centre handles Apple devices, which include its iPhone and Apple Watch. The devices recently gained 4G connectivity in some models and can be used to conduct an emergency call without requiring an iPhone or wifi. Dispatchers describe hearing people talking in the background about Apple devices, maintenance and repairs, but it's not clear how the calls are being triggered. The constant stream of false emergency calls has caused frustration among dispatchers, who are worried about the potential consequences of delays in responding to real emergencies. "It's like a never-ending stream of fake calls," said Hudson. "We're not sure how they're getting triggered, but it's like someone is pressing the panic button repeatedly."

Apple has been notified of the issue and has launched an investigation into the matter. A spokesperson for the company said that they take the situation seriously and are working to identify the cause of the false calls. "We apologize for any inconvenience this may have caused and are committed to resolving the issue as quickly as possible," the spokesperson said.

In the meantime, dispatchers are left to deal with the fallout, scrambling to prioritize real emergency calls over the constant stream of false alarms. "It's a challenge to keep track of everything, especially when we're dealing with multiple calls at once," said Hudson. "We're just hoping that Apple can get to the bottom of this and put a stop to it."

The issue has also raised concerns about the potential for false calls to be triggered by other devices or systems, potentially leading to a wider problem. "We're seeing a lot of new devices coming onto the market with advanced features, and it's possible that this could be a sign of a larger issue," said emergency management expert, Dr. Sarah Johnson. "We need to be vigilant and make sure that our emergency response systems are equipped to handle these types of scenarios."

The Treasury is threatening digital companies such as Facebook and Google with a new tax, as it pushes for global agreement on a fairer system for ensuring digital businesses pay their way. The chancellor, Philip Hammond, is expected to use next month's spring statement to announce the results of a consultation launched by the Treasury in November, on how to update the tax system to reflect the nature of online businesses. The financial secretary to the Treasury, Mel Stride, told the BBC on Thursday that digital companies should pay "fair" levels of tax. He suggested that could mean a system in which tax is levied according to where those companies earn their revenues – rather than simply taxing profits, which are easier to shift from one jurisdiction to another. "At the moment [they] are generating very significant value in the UK, typically through having a digital platform with lots of users interacting with that platform," Stride said. "That is driving a lot of value, so you're looking at social media platforms, online marketplaces, internet search engines – where at the moment the tax regime is not taxing those activities fairly. "We want to move to a situation where we are taxing those activities fairly." The Treasury's move comes as governments around the world grapple with how to tax digital companies, which have traditionally paid low rates of tax due to their ability to shift profits to low-tax jurisdictions. The UK's approach is expected to be part of a broader international effort to address the issue, with the OECD (Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development) leading a global push for a new framework for taxing digital companies.

The Treasury's consultation has sparked debate among experts and businesses, with some arguing that a new tax could stifle innovation and growth in the digital sector. However, others argue that it is essential to ensure that digital companies contribute fairly to the public purse, given the significant value they generate from UK users.

The UK's approach is also expected to be influenced by the European Union's plans to introduce a new digital services tax, which would target companies that provide services such as search engines, social media platforms, and online marketplaces. The EU's tax is expected to come into force in 2021, and the UK is likely to follow suit if it leaves the EU without a deal.

The Treasury's consultation has also raised questions about how a new tax would be implemented and enforced. Stride acknowledged that the Treasury would need to work closely with other governments and international organizations to ensure that a new tax is fair and effective. "We need to work with other countries to make sure that we're all going in the same direction, and that we're not creating a competitive disadvantage for UK businesses," he said.

The Treasury's move is also seen as a response to growing public frustration with the tax practices of digital companies. Many people feel that these companies are not paying their fair share of tax, given the significant profits they generate from UK users. The Treasury's announcement is likely to be welcomed by many, and could put pressure on other governments to follow suit.

The big Tesla battery in South Australia is consistently working to serve the peak energy demand each day, taking the "straw off the camel's back," according to the Australia Institute's latest national energy emissions audit. The report also finds emissions from the National Electricity Market [NEM] continued to drop in January, falling to their lowest levels since 2004, driven by the federal large-scale renewable energy target. Energy expert Hugh Saddler examined the consumption and output of electricity of the Hornsdale Power Reserve, analysing the patterns of charging and discharging of the Tesla battery. He found a consistent pattern of the battery charging overnight when wind generation was abundant and cheap, and discharging into the grid during the late afternoon when demand and spot market prices reached peak levels. Only 30% of the battery's 100MW capacity was devoted to this sort of trading, with the rest spent stabilising the energy system by maintaining the frequency of the grid at the required 50 Hz and240 volts. The Hornsdale Power Reserve, located in South Australia, has been a game-changer for the state's energy landscape. By providing a reliable source of energy storage, the Tesla battery has been able to absorb excess energy generated by wind farms during the night and release it into the grid during peak demand periods. This has not only reduced the strain on the grid but also helped to stabilize the frequency and voltage of the electricity supply.

According to the report, the battery's consistent performance has been a key factor in the decline of emissions from the National Electricity Market. By shifting from fossil fuels to renewable energy sources, Australia is making significant progress in reducing its carbon footprint. The federal government's large-scale renewable energy target has been instrumental in driving this shift, and the success of the Hornsdale Power Reserve is a testament to the effectiveness of this policy.

The report also highlights the importance of energy storage in the transition to a low-carbon economy. As the grid becomes increasingly reliant on intermittent renewable energy sources, energy storage will play a crucial role in smoothing out the fluctuations in supply and demand. The Hornsdale Power Reserve is a prime example of this, as it has been able to stabilize the grid and provide a reliable source of energy even when the wind is not blowing.

The findings of the report have been welcomed by environmental groups and energy experts, who see the Hornsdale Power Reserve as a model for future energy storage projects. As the world continues to transition away from fossil fuels, the role of energy storage will become increasingly important, and projects like the Hornsdale Power Reserve will be crucial in helping to achieve this goal.

Britain's economy grew at a slower rate than first thought in the final three months of 2017, leaving the UK lagging further behind other major economies as it prepares to leave the EU. The Office for National Statistics revised down its estimate for UK growth in the fourth quarter to 0.4%, following an earlier estimate of 0.5% and missing economists' forecasts that the rate would be unchanged. It said UK production was lower than initially estimated, and said consumers were less willing to spend due to the price rises triggered by the sharp fall in the pound following the Brexit vote. The weaker end to the year weighed on the economy's performance in 2017 overall, with growth revised down from 1.8% to 1.7% – the weakest in five years. The revised figures come as a blow to the UK's economic prospects ahead of its departure from the European Union, with many economists warning that the country's growth could be further impacted by the uncertainty surrounding the terms of its exit. The pound fell by 0.5% against the dollar in response to the news, hitting a low of $1.3055.

The UK's manufacturing sector was particularly affected, with production falling by 0.3% in the final quarter of 2017, down from a previous estimate of a 0.1% rise. This was partly due to a decline in the production of pharmaceuticals and chemicals, which was hit by the depreciation of the pound.

The ONS also reported that the UK's trade deficit widened in the fourth quarter, as imports rose faster than exports. This was partly due to a surge in imports of goods such as food and drink, which rose by 3.4% on the quarter.

The news has sparked concerns about the impact of Brexit on the UK's economy, with many economists warning that the country's growth could be further impacted by the uncertainty surrounding the terms of its exit. The Bank of England has already cut interest rates to boost the economy, and there are concerns that it may need to take further action if the economy continues to slow.

The UK's Chancellor, Philip Hammond, has sought to play down the impact of the revised growth figures, saying that the economy was still growing and that the government was taking steps to support businesses and individuals. However, many economists are warning that the UK's economic prospects are increasingly uncertain, and that the country's growth could be further impacted by the terms of its exit from the EU.

Fairfax Media half-year profit has slumped by more than half and the company has announced it will close or sell off 28 of its New Zealand newspapers. The drop in earnings to $38.5m, down from $83m a year ago, comes a day after real estate listings company Domain, which Fairfax spun off into a standalone entity in November, also reported a drop in profits. Greg Hywood, chief executive and managing director, said 35% of the smaller community titles in the NZ company, now known as Stuff, were being offloaded to "bring forward the time when increases in digital revenue outweigh declines in print". Up to 60 staff across titles including NZ Dairy Farmer and Christchurch Mail could be affected, according to reports. But there was good news on the digital front as online subscriptions to the Australian Metro mastheads, the SMH, the Age and the Australian Financial Review, increased by almost 50,000 from August 2017 to more than 283,000. "Metro's next-generation publishing model is delivering a step-change for consumers with the launch of new websites and apps to grow engagement and drive subscriptions and revenue," Hywood said. Earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation were up 1.3% to $146.9m and underlying net profit – which excludes significant writedowns – slipped 9.9% to $76.3m. Hywood pointed out earnings per share of 3.3 cents. "This result reflects the increase in minority interests associated with the separation of Domain from 22 November 2017 and the improved Macquarie Media results. Despite the mixed bag of results, Fairfax's shares fell 4.5% to $1.05 in early trading, with investors likely reacting to the significant decline in profit and the company's decision to offload a large chunk of its New Zealand operations. The move is seen as a bid to refocus the company on its digital assets and reduce its reliance on print advertising, which has been declining in recent years.

Industry analysts have been warning for some time that Fairfax's print business was unsustainable, and the company's decision to divest its New Zealand titles is seen as a pragmatic response to the changing media landscape. However, the impact on staff and local communities is likely to be significant, with many small-town newspapers and publications set to disappear from the scene.

In a statement, the Media, Entertainment and Arts Alliance (MEAA) expressed concern over the potential job losses and the impact on local journalism. "The loss of local newspapers and the jobs that go with them is a blow to the communities they serve," said MEAA national secretary, Paul Murphy. "We urge Fairfax to do everything it can to support its staff and to find alternative arrangements for the affected titles."

Fairfax has promised to provide support to affected staff, including outplacement services and career counseling, but the exact details of the company's plans are still unclear. The company has also pledged to continue to invest in its digital operations, including its online subscriptions and news gathering capabilities. With the media landscape continuing to evolve at a rapid pace, Fairfax's ability to adapt and innovate will be crucial to its long-term success.

"I'd rather pump septic tanks," John Perry Barlow told me in a Chinese restaurant in 1995 to explain how much he hated writing. "You can never tell whether you did any good or not." We were all attending a nearby Computers, Freedom and Privacy conference. As we sipped our wonton soup, Barlow's frustration with the writing process was palpable. He was a pioneer in the field of computer science, having co-authored the influential paper "The Net-Worth of a Nation" in 1973. But despite his technical expertise, he struggled to convey his ideas in a way that resonated with a broader audience. "I'm a terrible writer," he lamented, "I can't seem to get my point across without sounding like a bunch of nerds talking about nerdy things." The conference attendees around us nodded in understanding, knowing that the struggle to communicate complex ideas to the masses was a universal one. Little did they know, Barlow's words would soon become a rallying cry for those seeking to make technology more accessible and user-friendly.

Rupert Murdoch has doubled the length of time he is willing to keep running Sky News to "at least" 10 years, as 21st Century Fox sweetens its offer to protect the news channel to gain clearance for the £11.7bn takeover of Sky. The Competition and Markets Authority said last month that Murdoch's bid raised media plurality concerns because the deal would give his family too much control over UK news media. The Murdoch family trust controls Fox and News Corp, publisher of the Sun and the Times. Last week, Fox strengthened the so-called "firewall" remedies it had tabled but did not increase its original offer of guaranteeing to fund Sky News for a minimum of five years. Ofcom had indicated that extending the funding guarantee might help the Murdochs gain clearance. When the Murdochs tried to buy Sky in 2011 a 10-year funding guarantee was accepted by the then minister in charge, Jeremy Hunt, as part of a package of guarantees to allay media plurality issues. The latest development has been welcomed by Sky's independent directors, who have been working to ensure the channel's editorial independence and impartiality. A spokesperson for the directors said: "We are pleased that 21st Century Fox has taken steps to address the concerns raised by the Competition and Markets Authority. The extended funding guarantee provides greater certainty for Sky News and its employees, and we believe it will help to maintain the channel's high standards of journalism."

The move is also seen as a significant win for the Murdochs, who had been under pressure to sweeten their offer to gain clearance for the takeover. The deal is now expected to be approved by the UK government, pending a final decision from Ofcom. The regulator is set to make a ruling on the deal in the coming weeks, and it is believed that the extended funding guarantee will be a key factor in its decision.

The Murdochs' willingness to commit to funding Sky News for at least 10 years is seen as a significant concession, and it is likely to be welcomed by the UK's media regulator. The deal will also provide a boost to Sky News, which has faced challenges in recent years as the media landscape has become increasingly fragmented. The channel's independent directors will continue to work closely with the Murdochs to ensure that Sky News remains a trusted and impartial source of news and information.

Facebook is launching a range of new tools in an effort to "put people in more control over their privacy" in the buildup to new EU regulations that tighten up data protection. The changes come after a troubling two weeks for the company, which is battling with the fallout of the Cambridge Analytica files. At least one of the new features, a unified privacy dashboard, was previously discussed by Facebook's chief operating officer, Sheryl Sandberg, back in January. "The last week showed how much more work we need to do to enforce our policies, and to help people understand how Facebook works and the choices they have over their data," two Facebook executives wrote in a blogpost announcing the changes. "We've heard loud and clear that privacy settings and other important tools are too hard to find, and that we must do more to keep people informed." Erin Egan, Facebook's chief privacy officer, and Ashlie Beringer, its deputy general counsel, continued: "Most of these updates have been in the works for some time, but the events of the past several days underscore their importance." The features will be available to all users, not just those in countries covered by the EU general data protection regulation (GDPR), which comes into effect on 25 May. On mobile devices, Facebook users will now be able to find all their settings in a single place, rather than spread across "nearly 20 different screens" as they were before. This new unified dashboard will also provide users with a clear and concise overview of their privacy settings, allowing them to easily review and adjust their preferences. Additionally, Facebook is introducing a new "Access Your Information" feature, which will allow users to view and download all the data that the company has collected about them. This includes information such as their name, email address, phone number, and browsing history.

Facebook is also making it easier for users to delete their data, with a new "Delete Your Account" feature that will allow them to quickly and easily remove their profile and all associated data from the platform. The company is also introducing a new "Account Kit" feature, which will allow users to create a new account using only their phone number or email address, without having to provide any additional personal information.

These changes are part of Facebook's efforts to increase transparency and control for its users, and to comply with the upcoming EU GDPR regulations. The company is also working to improve its data collection and retention practices, and to provide users with more clear and concise information about how their data is being used. With these new features, Facebook aims to give users more control over their data and to demonstrate its commitment to protecting user privacy.

Footage of an Asian elephant "smoking" in a forest in southern India has baffled wildlife experts, who say the behaviour has never before been observed. Vinay Kumar, a scientist with the Wildlife Conservation Society's (WCS) India programme, captured the puffing pachyderm while visiting camera traps in the Nagarahole national park in Karnataka state. The 48-second video shows the elephant picking up something with its trunk and putting it in its mouth, then blowing out a gust of smoke. Biologists from the WCS said the footage, shot in April 2016 but only recently posted online, was "the first known video documentation of a wild elephant exhibiting such behaviour, and has scientists and experts puzzled". The video has sparked a flurry of theories among wildlife experts, with some suggesting that the elephant may have inhaled smoke from a nearby forest fire, while others believe it could be a rare instance of the animal mimicking human behavior. Dr. Kumar, who has spent over a decade studying Asian elephants, said that the behavior is "completely unprecedented" and has left him and his team scratching their heads. "We've never seen anything like this before," he said. "Elephants are known for their intelligence and adaptability, but this is something entirely new." The WCS has launched an investigation to determine the cause of the elephant's unusual behavior, and is urging the public to share any information or photos they may have that could shed light on the phenomenon. In the meantime, the video has captured the imagination of wildlife enthusiasts around the world, with many taking to social media to share their theories and speculate about the motivations behind the elephant's curious behavior.

As users continue to delete their Facebook accounts in the wake of the Cambridge Analytica scandal, a number are discovering that the social network holds far more data about them than they expected, including complete logs of incoming and outgoing calls and SMS messages. The #deletefacebook movement took off after the revelations that Facebook had shared with a Cambridge psychologist the personal information of 50 million users, without their explicit consent, which later ended up in the hands of the election consultancy Cambridge Analytica. Facebook makes it hard for users to delete their accounts, instead pushing them towards "deactivation", which leaves all personal data on the company's servers. When users ask to permanently delete their accounts, the company suggests: "You may want to download a copy of your info from Facebook." As users continue to delete their Facebook accounts, they are being met with a surprise: the social network holds far more data about them than they expected. In addition to the usual profile information, Facebook is also storing complete logs of incoming and outgoing calls and SMS messages. This revelation has sparked outrage among those who thought they were deleting their accounts, only to discover that Facebook was still holding onto their personal data.

Facebook's data collection practices have been under scrutiny since the Cambridge Analytica scandal broke, with many users feeling betrayed by the company's handling of their personal information. The company's decision to share user data with a third-party firm without their consent has raised serious concerns about the protection of user privacy.

In response to the backlash, Facebook has announced plans to increase transparency around its data collection practices. The company will now provide users with a clear breakdown of the data it collects and how it is used. Facebook will also be giving users the option to delete their call and text message logs, a feature that was previously only available to users who had been using the company's messaging services for a certain period of time.

However, many users are still feeling frustrated and betrayed by Facebook's handling of their personal data. The company's decision to make it difficult for users to delete their accounts has only added to the controversy. Facebook's data collection practices have been under scrutiny for some time, and the company's failure to provide users with clear information about how their data is being used has only added to the frustration.

As the debate around Facebook's data collection practices continues, it remains to be seen whether the company will be able to regain the trust of its users. For now, many are choosing to delete their accounts and take their business elsewhere, a move that could have significant implications for the company's future.

Elaine Herzberg Was killed last Sunday by an Uber autonomous car that hit the 49-year-old at approximately 40mph as she was crossing the road in Tempe, Arizona. Police confirmed there was an operator in the Volvo SUV at the time of the collision, and stated that it didn't appear the car had slowed down. Robert Williams Cited as the first human killed by a robot, Williams was an assembly worker at Ford's Flat Rock plant in Michigan. He was crushed to death by the arm of a one-tonne robot on the production line on 25 January 1979. His family was awarded $10m in damages. The court concluded that he was struck on the head due to inadequate safety measures. Surgery patients While robot-assisted surgery has allowed surgeons to perform operations remotely with minimal invasiveness, a 2016 US study found that it was linked to the deaths of 144 people between 2008 and 2013. Causes of death included parts falling into patients' bodies, machines turning off/on at the wrong time and loss of video feeds. "Despite widespread adoption of robotic systems… a non-negligible number of technical difficulties and complications are still being experienced during procedures," the study said. The incident in Tempe, Arizona, has raised concerns about the safety of autonomous vehicles and the potential risks of relying on technology to operate without human oversight. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) has launched an investigation into the accident, and Uber has suspended its self-driving car program in the city pending the outcome.

The incident is a stark reminder of the risks associated with automation, and experts warn that it's only a matter of time before another tragedy occurs. "We're seeing a trend of robots and machines being used in various industries, but we're not taking the necessary steps to ensure their safety and reliability," said Dr. Jane Smith, a robotics expert at Stanford University.

As the investigation continues, the family of Elaine Herzberg is left to mourn the loss of their loved one, and the public is left to wonder if the benefits of autonomous technology are worth the risks. "This is a wake-up call for all of us," said Tempe Mayor Mark Mitchell. "We need to make sure that we're doing everything we can to protect the safety of our citizens, and that includes ensuring that these autonomous vehicles are safe and reliable."

Marks & Spencer has ousted the boss of its upmarket food halls and drafted in the supermarket industry veteran Stuart Machin with a brief to cut prices and improve the food ranges. Machin, whose career has included stints at Asda, Sainsbury's and Tesco, worked with the M&S chairman, Archie Norman, in Australia on the turnaround of Coles Supermarkets. Last year Norman warned that M&S had been "drifting" for more than 15 years and pledged to lead a radical shake-up of the business alongside the chief executive, Steve Rowe. As a result of Machin's appointment, the current food boss, Andy Adcock, will leave M&S at the end of April. He joined M&S's food arm in 2009 as commercial director and was promoted to the top job in the summer of 2015. "We face challenges in our food business and we have lots to do to change fast," said Rowe. "Stuart is an excellent addition to our team. He gets food retailing and he has first-class experience of driving change in big food retailers." Until recently M&S's food halls had been its jewel in the crown amid a long-running slump in clothing sales. But over the past year its performance has deteriorated with Rowe warning that its prices were too high at a time when the mainstream grocers had raised the bar in ready meals and other convenience foods. Machin's appointment is seen as a significant coup for M&S, given his extensive experience in the supermarket industry. He is known for his ability to drive change and improve operational efficiency, skills that are expected to be crucial in helping M&S to revamp its food business.

Industry insiders believe that Machin's first priority will be to conduct a thorough review of M&S's food ranges and supply chain, with a view to cutting costs and improving quality. He will also be tasked with reducing prices to make the brand more competitive in the market.

Machin's appointment comes as M&S faces increasing pressure to improve its performance in the food sector. The company's food sales have been declining in recent years, and its market share has been eroded by rivals such as Aldi and Lidl.

In a statement, M&S said that Machin would work closely with Rowe and Norman to develop a new strategy for the food business, which would be focused on improving quality, reducing prices, and increasing convenience for customers.

Machin's appointment is seen as a major boost for M&S, and industry analysts are predicting that he will make a significant impact on the company's fortunes. With his extensive experience and track record of success, Machin is well-placed to help M&S to turn its food business around and regain its position as a leading player in the market.

The chief executive of Sainsbury's has been filmed singing "We're in the Money" on the same day he announced a blockbuster merger with Asda. Waiting to be interviewed by ITV, Mike Coupe started warbling one of the best-known songs from the musical 42nd Street. In the clip released by the broadcaster, he is shown singing: "We're in the money, the sky is sunny. The footage, which was captured outside ITV's London studios, shows Coupe, 54, confidently belting out the tune, seemingly unaware that he was being filmed. According to eyewitnesses, he was "whistling a happy tune" and "looking quite pleased with himself" as he made his way to the interview. The unexpected display of musical talent has left many wondering if Coupe's singing skills will become a new talking point in the wake of the merger announcement. When asked about the incident, a Sainsbury's spokesperson declined to comment, saying only that Coupe was "just getting into the holiday spirit." Meanwhile, Asda's parent company, Walmart, has been quick to poke fun at the situation, tweeting "Who knew our new partner was a secret crooner?" The merger, which is set to create a grocery giant with over 2,000 stores, is expected to be completed by the end of the year.
