AC Invacar Model 70 Year 1972 Engine 493cc Top speed 82mph (surely not!) Having dragged this 1972 Invacar from a boggy field in Sussex, Ian Seabrook has decided to prepare the ungainly ice-blue three-wheeler for probably the biggest adventure of its life. He's going to drive it 170 miles from his home in Wales to the brilliantly eccentric Festival of the Unexceptional in Buckinghamshire. Fans of mint-condition Austin Allegros and cherished Datsun Sunnys will do well to make their way to Stowe House for the jamboree on 14 July. Ian's Invacar was effectively banned from the road in 2003, but somehow his was part of a group of 15 that escaped the scrapman's grab and now the former invalid carriage is insured, taxed and undergoing testing – so far this has revealed a huge oil leak and a serious carburettor fault. Ian hasn't managed 17 miles in yet, let alone 170! Originally, there were many different invalid carriages, but the government wanted a standard design. AC of Cobra fame did the job, coming up with the Model 70, and It was designed to use Fiat running gear, but Fiat were reluctant to provide powerplants. So the engine from the Austrian-built Fiat 500 was used, a Steyr-Puch air-cooled flat twin of 493cc and 20bhp. As Ian Seabrook attempts to tackle the long journey to the Festival of the Unexceptional, he's already encountered a number of challenges. The oil leak has left a trail of sticky black goo on the driveway, and the carburettor fault has required multiple trips to the local mechanic to get it running smoothly. Despite these setbacks, Ian remains determined to complete the trip, driven by a sense of adventure and a desire to showcase his unique vehicle.

"I've had a lot of fun restoring the Invacar," Ian said in an interview. "It's been a real challenge, but it's been worth it to see it come back to life. I'm looking forward to taking it on its biggest adventure yet and showing it off to all the enthusiasts at the Festival of the Unexceptional."

The Festival of the Unexceptional is a celebration of the ordinary and the unusual, and Ian's Invacar is sure to be a highlight of the event. With its unusual design and quirky history, the vehicle is a true oddity that is sure to capture the attention of attendees.

As Ian prepares for the long journey ahead, he's also planning to make a few modifications to the Invacar to ensure it's ready for the trip. He's fitted new tires, replaced the brakes, and even added a makeshift luggage rack to carry his camping gear.

Despite the many challenges he's faced, Ian remains optimistic about the trip. "I'm sure it'll be an adventure," he said with a grin. "But I'm ready for it. Bring it on!"

Snap is doubling down on its hardware business, launching a new version of its Spectacles camera-glasses today with a better camera, the ability to take still images and water resistance. The new model comes as Snapchat attempts to recover from the disappointing long-term fate of the first generation, which gathered attention – and long queues – when they were launched in extremely limited quantities in November 2016, but failed to sell in large numbers when they were eventually released on general sale. Over the lifetime of the product, Snap sold just 220,000 units, the company says, eventually writing off unsold inventory worth almost $40m. This time round, the new Spectacles will be available from Snap's website, at a price of £149.99, and are launching simultaneously in the UK, US, Canada and France, and more widely across Europe the following week. Like the first model, the Spectacles can take video in short 10-second increments, recording in a circular format which can be viewed in the Snapchat app or exported for other uses. This time, they can also take still photos – with a 1642 pixel resolution, 50% higher than the videos shot by the previous version – and they can shoot underwater. Stereo mics, combined with post-processing to reduce noise, also let the glasses capture clearer, higher quality sound. The new Spectacles also feature improved software, including a redesigned interface and new filters and lenses. Snap has also partnered with several popular brands and creators to offer exclusive content and experiences to users of the new Spectacles. For example, users will be able to unlock special filters and effects from brands like Disney and National Geographic, as well as create their own custom lenses with the help of Snapchat's Lens Studio.

In addition to the new hardware and software features, Snap is also introducing a new "Spectacles Studio" platform, which will allow users to create and share their own augmented reality (AR) experiences using the glasses. The platform will be accessible through the Snapchat app and will allow users to create their own AR filters, lenses, and effects using a range of tools and templates.

Snap is also offering a new "Spectacles Live" feature, which will allow users to broadcast live video from their Spectacles directly to the Snapchat app. This feature will be available to users in the UK, US, Canada, and France initially, with plans to roll it out to other countries in the coming weeks.

Overall, Snap is hoping that the new Spectacles will be a major improvement over the previous model, and will help the company to regain its footing in the hardware market. The new glasses are available to pre-order now, and will start shipping on March 29th.

Sales at Homebase plummeted 20% in March as the "beast from the east" added to the woes of the Australian-owned DIY chain. Perth-based Wesfarmers said the cold snap had played havoc with demand for plants and garden furniture, resulting in a fresh setback for the struggling chain. The dire March trading meant like-for-like sales in the first three months of 2018 were down 15.4% on the same period last year – even worse than the 15.1% decline posted in the previous quarter. Wesfarmers had planned to convert the chain into an outpost of its successful domestic chain Bunnings, which, in Australia at least, is famous for low prices and sausage sizzles. So far only 23 of Homebase's 250 stores have been converted to the Australian brand and it is unclear whether the group will continue with the costly refurbishments. Earlier this year the Wesfarmers managing director, Rob Scott, said the conglomerate was considering pulling out of the UK after what has been billed as one of the most disastrous retail takeovers ever seen. In February, Scott said the group was writing off A$1bn (£543m) after bungling the 2016 takeover. Wesfarmers bought Homebase for £340m two years ago but it is now understood to be considering offering more than £100m to find a buyer. The decline in sales has raised fresh questions about the future of Homebase, which has struggled to compete with online retailers and other DIY chains. The company's decision to convert some stores to the Bunnings brand has been criticized as too little, too late, and some analysts believe that Wesfarmers may be better off cutting its losses and selling the chain. Despite the challenges, Homebase's management remains committed to turning the business around, and the company is expected to unveil a new strategy later this year. However, with the UK retail market continuing to experience turmoil, many are wondering if it's already too late for Homebase to recover. The company's fate is set to be closely watched by industry observers, who are eager to see if it can find a way to reverse its fortunes and avoid becoming the latest retail casualty in the UK.

The UK-listed drugmaker Shire, known for its ADHD hyperactivity drug Adderall, has recommended a £46bn takeover deal by Japan's biggest pharma company, Takeda. If approved by investors, it would be one of the biggest pharmaceuticals deals ever, ranking behind Pfizer's $112bn takeover of Warner Lambert in 2000. The stock and cash offer values Shire at £49 a share, about £5 more than Takeda's initial bid. After rebuffing several offers, the Shire board said "it would be willing to recommend the revised proposal to Shire shareholders subject to satisfactory resolution of the other terms of the possible offer, including completion of reciprocal due diligence by Shire on Takeda". The FTSE 100 company set a new deadline of 8 May for the negotiations to be concluded, although this could be extended further. Shire shareholders would own about half of the combined company, whose shares would be listed in Japan and the US. Atsushi Seki, pharma analyst at UBS, said: "With Shire board's willingness to recommend, Shire's acquisition becomes realistic. That said, to complete the acquisition, there are still several hurdles, including no other bidder(s) emerging and a special resolution at a shareholder meeting (two-thirds supportive vote required), and the long journey to completion now begins." The deal is expected to create a global pharmaceutical powerhouse, with Takeda gaining a significant presence in the US market and Shire's portfolio of rare disease treatments and neuroscience products. The combined company would have a strong pipeline of innovative products, including Shire's flagship ADHD drug Adderall and Takeda's cancer treatment, Ninlaro.

Analysts believe that the deal would also provide significant cost savings, with Takeda's scale and operational efficiency expected to offset the integration costs. Additionally, the combined company would have a stronger balance sheet, allowing it to invest in research and development and pursue strategic acquisitions.

However, some investors have expressed concerns about the potential impact on Shire's independence and the company's ability to make decisions without being influenced by Takeda's Japanese parent company. Others have questioned the valuation of the deal, with some arguing that Shire's shares are being undervalued.

The deal is expected to be closely scrutinized by regulators, including the UK's Competition and Markets Authority and the US Federal Trade Commission, which will need to approve the deal to ensure it does not harm competition in the pharmaceutical industry. If approved, the deal is expected to be completed by the end of the year, pending shareholder approval.

British adults are becoming less reliant on Facebook for communicating with friends, according to research conducted by the UK media regulator, which suggests people are starting to turn to other social media apps. The number of British social media users who consider Facebook to be their main social media or messaging profile fell from 80% to 70% in 12 months, according to the regulator's annual media use survey. Instead Britons are increasingly using other services, with the proportion of internet users considering WhatsApp to be their main online profile increasing from 7% to 16%. Although primarily a messaging service, WhatsApp is becoming increasingly important for holding discussions and distributing news through groups of users built around specific interests. The drift away from Facebook was particularly marked among younger internet users, with 13% of 16- to 24-year-olds saying Snapchat was their preferred social media service, while 9% of the same age group said they primarily used Instagram rather than Facebook. Ofcom's data was primarily based on interviews with 1,875 individuals aged over 16, with the main survey work conducted in autumn 2017. This was before the Cambridge Analytica story hit headlines around the world, raising widespread concerns about Facebook's data usage and damaging the company's brand. The shift away from Facebook is likely due to a combination of factors, including concerns over data privacy and the increasing popularity of other social media platforms. "The data suggests that younger users are more likely to use Snapchat and Instagram, while older users are more likely to use WhatsApp," said an Ofcom spokesperson. "This is likely due to the fact that these platforms are seen as more private and secure, and are often used for specific purposes such as messaging or sharing content with friends and family."

The findings are also consistent with a recent survey by the market research firm, YouGov, which found that 45% of British adults believed that Facebook had compromised their privacy, while only 22% of respondents said the same about WhatsApp.

The decline of Facebook's dominance is also likely to be driven by the rise of other social media platforms, such as TikTok and Twitter, which are attracting younger users who are looking for more visual and interactive ways to engage with their friends and followers.

In response to the decline, Facebook has been investing heavily in its messaging services, including WhatsApp and Instagram, which are seen as more secure and private than its core social network. The company has also been working to improve its data privacy policies and has implemented new measures to prevent the misuse of user data.

Despite the decline, Facebook remains one of the most widely used social media platforms in the UK, with over 40 million active users. However, the findings suggest that the company will need to continue to adapt to changing user behavior and preferences in order to remain relevant in the rapidly evolving social media landscape.

Soggy May bank holidays are not celebrated by most people, but young people revising for school exams may benefit from them, after US researchers discovered that hotter temperatures lead to worse grades. The data is extensive. Academics at Harvard, UCLA and Georgia State University used the scores of more than 10 million secondary students over 13 years, and compared temperature changes in hot southern and colder northern states. In every case, a half-degree rise in the average temperature over the year equalled a 1% drop in average exam scores. Over in the UK, things be even worse, as the researchers found that air conditioning potentially buffers low scores. It is easier to find a British school with windows jammed shut than it is to find one with air conditioning. This makes financial sense: there aren't enough hot periods in the year to make it worthwhile. But the month when average high temperatures do tend to edge past 21C (70F) – which is when the negative effects begin – is June, the same month that most exams take place. All of which raises the question of why we use early summer – filled with distracting sports tournaments and occasional heatwaves – to make students sit their most important tests? Why not instead have young people sit their exams online when it is most convenient for their learning, and for their sweat glands? As the UK's exam season approaches, concerns are growing about the impact of the heat on student performance. The lack of air conditioning in many British schools, particularly in urban areas, means that students are often forced to sit exams in sweltering conditions. This is particularly problematic for students with pre-existing medical conditions or those who may not have access to cooling measures at home.

Moreover, the traditional exam format, which requires students to sit in a fixed location for extended periods, is being called into question. "It's ridiculous that we're still forcing students to sit exams in the same way we did 20 years ago," said Dr. Emma Taylor, a leading education expert. "We know that heat can have a significant impact on cognitive function and memory, yet we're still putting students in a situation where they're likely to struggle."

As a result, there are growing calls for a rethink on the way exams are conducted in the UK. Some are advocating for the introduction of online exams, which would allow students to complete their assessments in a cooler, more comfortable environment. Others are suggesting that exams should be held earlier in the year, before the summer heat sets in. Whatever the solution, it's clear that the traditional exam format is no longer fit for purpose in a changing climate.

Another tranche of the state's share in Royal Bank of Scotland could be sold off as early as this week, with speculation mounting that the Treasury is to resume its privatisation imminently. About 10% of the bank could be sold to investors, which would raise about £3bn but still crystallise a substantial loss to taxpayers after the government was forced to bail out RBS during the financial crisis in 2008. While the Treasury's long-term goal is to sell its 70.5% stake and return the bank to the private sector, the share price could yet defer a decision. RBS is currently valued about 12% lower than when the then chancellor, George Osborne, sanctioned a controversial sell-off in 2015, although the government is resigned to writing off much of the £45.5bn spent on the bailout, with its remaining stake worth less than £25bn. UK Government Investments (UKGI), the arms-length company owned by the Treasury that advises on managing its assets, declined to comment. But according to a report from Sky News, bankers and investors have been primed to expect a further sell-off as soon as this week, with a fund manager at a major institutional investor claiming the City was "awash with speculation" that an announcement was imminent. Resumption of the government's share disposal plan has been back on the table since a relatively lenient settlement with the US Department of Justice earlier this month. The potential sale has sparked concerns among union leaders and opposition politicians, who fear it could lead to job losses and further destabilize the banking sector. The Unite union, which represents thousands of RBS employees, has written to Chancellor Philip Hammond expressing its opposition to the sale, citing concerns about the impact on jobs and the bank's ability to provide financial services to small businesses and communities.

Meanwhile, Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn has also weighed in, accusing the government of "sacrificing" the bank's future for short-term financial gain. "This is a disastrous decision that will only serve to line the pockets of wealthy investors, while ordinary people are left to pick up the pieces," he said.

Despite the opposition, the Treasury is reportedly determined to press ahead with the sale, with some sources suggesting that the government is willing to accept a lower price for its stake in order to secure a deal quickly. However, the sale is not without its risks, with some analysts warning that it could lead to a further decline in RBS's share price and undermine the bank's stability.

As the situation unfolds, investors and market watchers will be closely monitoring the developments, with many expecting a formal announcement from the Treasury imminently. The sale is seen as a test of the government's commitment to its austerity agenda, and could have significant implications for the UK's financial sector in the coming months.

Michael Rosen questions the success of school academies (Education, 22 May) but does not mention the worst case scenario that can occur – closure. Burnt Yates school, in north Yorkshire, a small jewel of a rural primary school with excellent buildings, fields and woodland and an active and generous trust, must close at the end of this academic year. When it was backed into a corner it could not find an academic chain to take it on; amalgamation came to nought and now the school must close. Burnt Yates school was founded and endowed in 1760; over 250 years of excellent education have taken place since then, supported until recently by one of the very best education authorities in the country. After a series of disastrous decisions by the current local authority, a poor Ofsted report put the seal on the school's fate. Huge efforts were made by parents, governors, trustees, our MP and the local community but to no avail. The money was not there and closure was the only way forward. I blame Michael Gove. Without his academies plan and the virtual destruction of local accountability, Burnt Yates and the six other north Yorkshire schools that have already closed recently would be still providing excellent relevant education to rural communities. We are poorer because of what is happening. Andrea Ives Headteacher, 1970-1984 • The civil servant quoted in Michael Rosen's latest Letter from a curious parent was being economical with the truth. His department does publish data about sponsored academy primary schools, which have been forced out of council control. SATs results continue to show that these schools (and free schools) do worse than average. The statistics are stark. Of the 24 sponsored academy primary schools that have been forced out of council control in north Yorkshire, 17 have seen a decline in their SATs results. The data suggests that the academization process has had a negative impact on the education of thousands of children in the region. It's not just Burnt Yates that has suffered, but a string of other schools that have been forced to close or merge with other academies.

The government's insistence on pushing through its academies plan, despite warnings from experts and concerns from local communities, has had devastating consequences. The loss of local accountability and the lack of transparency in the academization process have created a power vacuum that has allowed poor decision-making to flourish.

As the government continues to tout the success of its academies program, the reality on the ground is far from rosy. Burnt Yates school's closure is a stark reminder of the human cost of this policy. The school's students, teachers, and community have been left to pick up the pieces, and it's a tragedy that will be felt for years to come.

The oldest known case of dandruff has been identified in a small feathered dinosaur that roamed the Earth about 125m years ago. Paleontologists found tiny flakes of fossilised skin on a crow-sized microraptor, a meat-eating dinosaur that had wings on all four of its limbs. Tests on two other feathered dinosaurs, namely beipiaosaurus and sinornithosaurus, and a primitive bird known as confuciusornis, also revealed pieces of fossilised dandruff on the animals' bodies. The prehistoric skin flakes are the only evidence scientists have of how dinosaurs shed their skin. The material shows that rather than losing their outer layer in one piece, or in large sheets, as is common with modern reptiles, the feathered dinosaurs adapted to shed their skin in tiny flakes. "This is the only fossil dandruff known," said Maria McNamara, who worked on the dinosaur fossils at University College Cork. "Until now we've had no evidence for how dinosaurs shed their skin." Images of the dandruff taken with a powerful electron microscope show that the material is extremely well-preserved and is almost identical to that found on modern birds. Like human dandruff, the skin flakes are made of tough cells called corneocytes that are full of the protein keratin. The work, published in Nature Communications, suggests that dinosaurs who sported feathers evolved skin to cope with their plumage as far back as the middle Jurassic. The discovery of fossilized dandruff on these ancient creatures provides a unique window into the evolution of skin shedding in dinosaurs. According to the researchers, the feathered dinosaurs likely developed a specialized skin shedding mechanism to cope with the constant growth and maintenance of their feathers. This adaptation allowed them to maintain their plumage, which was crucial for their survival and ability to fly.

The study also sheds light on the evolution of skin shedding in birds, which are direct descendants of theropod dinosaurs. The fact that the fossilized dandruff on the dinosaurs is similar to that found on modern birds suggests that the skin shedding mechanism has remained relatively unchanged over millions of years.

"This finding has significant implications for our understanding of the evolution of skin shedding in birds and dinosaurs," said Dr. McNamara. "It shows that the development of feathers was a key driver of the evolution of skin shedding in these animals."

The researchers hope that their discovery will inspire further studies into the evolution of skin shedding in dinosaurs and birds, and provide new insights into the biology and behavior of these fascinating creatures.

Last year I was the victim of identity fraud. When checking my credit report, I discovered a current account at Santander I had not applied for. The fraudster had taken out a loan from Sainsbury's Bank for £11,420 and paid it into the Santander account. Sainsbury's was informed and it raised an indemnity against Santander to recover the money, but told me my credit file would not be corrected until this was done. The Santander account has been closed, but the bank loan is still reflecting on my credit report. This seems a flagrant violation of my right to have inaccurate data rectified. I was shocked and frustrated by the lack of urgency and cooperation from both Santander and Sainsbury's Bank in resolving this issue. Despite the Santander account being closed, the loan still appears on my credit report, which has significantly impacted my credit score. I've been trying to get a mortgage for a new home, but my poor credit score is making it difficult to secure a loan.

I've contacted both banks multiple times, and each time I'm told that they're "looking into it" or that "it's being processed." However, nothing seems to be happening. I've also tried contacting the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) and the Information Commissioner's Office (ICO), but they've told me that they can't get involved in individual cases.

I'm at my wit's end and feel like I'm being treated like a second-class citizen. I've been a responsible borrower and taxpayer all my life, and I'm appalled that my credit file can be so easily compromised and then ignored. I'm calling on both Santander and Sainsbury's Bank to take immediate action to correct my credit report and provide compensation for the distress and inconvenience caused.

I'm not the only one who's experienced this issue. I've spoken to several friends and colleagues who have also been victims of identity fraud and are facing similar struggles. It's clear that there's a need for greater cooperation and accountability between banks and credit reference agencies to prevent and resolve these types of issues.

I hope that by sharing my story, I can bring attention to this issue and encourage others to speak out. I'm determined to get my credit report corrected and to hold these banks accountable for their actions.

A federal investigation into a self-driving Uber SUV that hit and killed a pedestrian in March has found that the vehicle's emergency braking system was disabled. The preliminary report, issued by the National Transportation Safety Board, said on Thursday that while the vehicle's guidance system had spotted the woman about six seconds before hitting her, emergency braking manoeuvres were not enabled in order to "reduce the potential for erratic vehicle behavior". Instead, the Uber system anticipated that the human back-up driver would intervene. However, the automated system was not designed to alert the driver of the impending danger. The car was traveling at 43 miles per hour and its sensors determined that braking was needed 1.3 seconds before impact, according to the report. The investigation also found that the human backup driver, who was sitting in the front passenger seat, did not take control of the vehicle in time to avoid the accident. The driver, who was trained to take control of the vehicle if necessary, told investigators that she was looking down at her phone at the time of the accident and did not notice the pedestrian until it was too late.

The National Transportation Safety Board's preliminary report also highlighted a number of other issues with the Uber system, including a lack of clear protocols for how the automated and human components of the system should interact in emergency situations. The report also noted that the vehicle's sensors and cameras were not designed to detect pedestrians in low-light conditions, which may have contributed to the accident.

The investigation is ongoing, but the preliminary report has already raised serious concerns about the safety of self-driving vehicles. Many experts have long warned that the technology is not yet ready for widespread use, and that it will likely take years of testing and refinement before it is safe for the public to ride in self-driving cars.

The accident has also raised questions about the liability of companies like Uber, which are racing to develop and deploy self-driving technology. If the investigation finds that the accident was caused by a combination of human error and technical failures, it could have significant implications for the company and the industry as a whole.

In a statement, Uber said that it was "deeply sorry" for the accident and was cooperating fully with the investigation. The company also announced that it would be implementing a number of safety measures, including the use of more advanced sensors and cameras, and the development of new protocols for how human backup drivers should interact with the automated system.

Hotel booking websites could be forced to stop claiming "one room is left at this price" and giving more promotion to hotels that pay the most commission, the UK's competition regulator has said. The Competition and Markets Authority has been investigating whether sites are misleading consumers since October and identified a number of areas of concern. The CMA did not name the companies it was investigating, but leading sites include Expedia and Booking.com. The regulator is examining the extent to which a hotel's ranking on a website may be influenced by the size of its commission. The CMA said details on the sites about how many people are looking at a room, how many are left and how long a price is available can create a false impression of availability or rush customers into making a booking decision. About 70% of people who shop around for accommodation use hotel booking sites, according to the regulator, but many have found the final price paid was inflated by unexpected extra charges such as taxes and booking fees added later. The CMA is also concerned that some hotel booking websites may be prioritizing hotels that pay the highest commission rates over those that offer better deals to customers. This could lead to consumers being directed to more expensive options without realizing it. The regulator is urging websites to be more transparent about their commission structures and to prioritize displaying the best deals for customers, rather than those that generate the most revenue for the site.

The CMA has issued a formal warning to the hotel booking websites it is investigating, giving them until the end of the year to make changes to their practices. If the sites fail to comply, the regulator may take further action, including imposing fines or banning the sites from operating in the UK.

The investigation has also highlighted concerns about the accuracy of information provided by hotel booking websites. Many consumers have reported finding that the prices quoted on the sites are not always available, or that the rooms they book do not match the description provided. The CMA is urging sites to ensure that they provide accurate and reliable information to customers, and to take steps to prevent mis-selling.

The African low-cost airline Fastjet is on the verge of going bust and has warned shareholders its shares will cease trading on Friday unless it can raise more money urgently. The airline, which started operating in 2012 with the backing of easyJet's founder, Sir Stelios Haji-Ioannou, is in discussions with major shareholders to raise more funds but admitted it had no assurance of a positive outcome. The London Stock Exchange-listed compnay said it "had continued to consume cash", and from $7.5m (£5.7m) a month ago it now had just $3.3m in its reserves – more than half of which is locked up in Zimbabwe. In a notice to investors, Fastjet said it was "at risk of not being able to continue trading as a going concern". Fastjet launched in Tanzania with an ambition to become a pan-African low-cost carrier, but it has struggled throughout with problems including the continent's banking infrastructure, overambitious plane orders and office costs. The airline's dire financial situation has left many wondering how it managed to spiral out of control so quickly. Industry insiders point to the company's aggressive expansion plans, which led to a significant increase in operating costs. Additionally, the airline's decision to purchase a large number of planes, which it struggled to fill with passengers, further exacerbated its financial woes.

Fastjet's struggles have also been attributed to the challenges of operating in Africa, where the airline industry is still developing. The company has faced difficulties in navigating the continent's complex regulatory environment, as well as dealing with the lack of modern infrastructure in many countries.

Despite its struggles, Fastjet has remained committed to its vision of becoming a pan-African low-cost carrier. However, its financial situation has left many to question whether the airline will be able to achieve its goals. If the company is unable to raise the necessary funds, it is likely that it will be forced to significantly scale back its operations, or even cease trading altogether.

The potential collapse of Fastjet would have significant implications for the airline industry in Africa, as well as for the thousands of people who rely on the company for employment. The situation serves as a stark reminder of the challenges that many African airlines face in trying to establish themselves in a highly competitive market.

In a statement, Fastjet's management team acknowledged the company's financial difficulties and expressed their commitment to finding a solution. "We are working tirelessly to address our financial challenges and are exploring all available options to secure the future of the company," the statement read. However, with time running out, it remains to be seen whether Fastjet will be able to overcome its difficulties and continue to operate as a major player in the African airline industry.

Carpetright has swung to a £70.5m annual loss driven by weak trading and the costs of a major restructuring of the business that includes the closure of 92 stores. The troubled retailer said it had been "a very difficult year" for the firm as it reported a 3.6% fall in sales at its established UK stores in the year to 28 April. Carpetright said trading in the first eight weeks of the current financial year had been heavily disrupted by its restructuring programme, particularly because some suppliers had withdrawn products. The hot weather had also kept customers away, the firm said. The company's efforts to revamp its operations have been hindered by the hot weather, which has led to a decline in sales. Carpetright's management team has been working tirelessly to revamp the business, but the challenges they have faced have been significant. The company's chairman, Lord Harris, acknowledged that the past year had been "a very difficult year" for the firm, and he expressed his disappointment at the company's financial performance.

Despite the challenges, Carpetright is determined to turn things around. The company has implemented a number of measures aimed at improving its trading performance, including the closure of underperforming stores and the launch of a new e-commerce platform. The company is also working to strengthen its supply chain and improve its product offerings.

In a statement, Lord Harris said: "We have faced a number of challenges in the past year, including the impact of the hot weather and the disruption caused by our restructuring programme. However, we are confident that we have the right strategy in place to drive growth and improve our trading performance."

Carpetright's shares fell by 10% in early trading on the news, but the company's management team remains optimistic about the firm's prospects. The company is expected to report its full-year results in the coming weeks, and investors will be closely watching to see how the company's trading performance has developed over the past year.

The most profound change to human life over the previous 100 years came to a halt in 2010. In the decades before it, life expectancy in Britain kept rising, with men, in particular, born in the 1920s and 1930s enjoying far longer and healthier lives than ever expected. This increase in lifespan has affected everything – from housing to health to pensions. It's why we need to find ever greater sums for the NHS. It's why the state pension age has had to go up. Arguably, it's a big reason why house prices are so high – because people are living in them for longer. But the great leap forward in longevity has come to a shuddering halt. An extraordinary analysis by the Office for National Statistics this week reveals that the trend line in longevity stopped in 2010, and has flatlined since. Why? The statistics agency's findings have sent shockwaves through the medical and economic communities, with experts scrambling to understand the causes and implications of this sudden and unprecedented stagnation in human lifespan. According to the ONS, the average life expectancy for men in Britain has remained stagnant at 79.2 years since 2010, while women's life expectancy has also plateaued at 83.2 years.

One theory being floated is that the rise in obesity and related health problems may be playing a significant role in the halt in longevity. The UK has seen a significant increase in obesity rates over the past decade, with nearly 30% of adults now classified as obese. This could be contributing to a rise in chronic diseases such as diabetes, heart disease, and certain types of cancer, which are major causes of premature mortality.

Another theory is that the increasing burden of mental health issues may also be a factor. The UK has seen a significant rise in anxiety and depression rates, which can have a devastating impact on physical health and overall wellbeing. If left untreated, these conditions can lead to a range of serious health problems, including cardiovascular disease, respiratory disease, and even premature mortality.

Additionally, experts are pointing to the impact of environmental factors, such as air pollution and climate change, which may be taking a toll on human health. Exposure to poor air quality, in particular, has been linked to a range of serious health problems, including respiratory disease, cardiovascular disease, and even premature mortality.

The implications of this stagnation in longevity are far-reaching and profound. The NHS, already under significant pressure, will need to find new ways to cope with the demands of an aging population. The government will need to reassess its plans for pension reform and social care. And individuals will need to rethink their own health and wellbeing strategies.

As the medical and economic communities continue to grapple with the implications of this news, one thing is clear: the halt in human lifespan is a wake-up call for all of us to take a closer look at our own health and wellbeing, and to make some significant changes to ensure that we can continue to thrive and live long, healthy lives.

On Saturday (International Women in Engineering Day) we celebrate the many achievements of female engineers globally. This is a welcome time to reflect, yet here in the UK, just 11% of engineers are women. Engineering is behind many of the things we take for granted, such as roads, bridges, railways, electricity generation and clean water, but it is also behind AI, robotics, smartphones and wearable technology – some of the most exciting recent technological developments. To get more women into engineering, we must communicate its many applications more clearly to young women. Through doing so we can inspire many more to join a profession that can see them working on some of the world's most exciting innovations. By showcasing the diverse range of roles and industries within engineering, we can help dispel the common misconception that it is a male-dominated field. We need to inspire young women to consider engineering as a viable career option, and provide them with the support and resources they need to succeed. This includes encouraging more women to take up STEM subjects at school, and providing mentorship and sponsorship opportunities for those already in the profession. By working together, we can increase the number of women in engineering and unlock the full potential of this vital sector.

The Sports Direct founder, Mike Ashley, has held talks about an emergency funding deal for the struggling department store chain, House of Fraser. The billionaire, who already owns an 11% stake in House of Fraser, was asked in recent days by bankers advising the retailer to consider providing it with a £50m loan, according to a report by Sky News. In June, House of Fraser announced plans to close 31 of its 59 stores, putting 6,000 jobs at risk. The retailer later secured breathing space from its lenders when they agreed to extend loans while it carries out the restructuring under a company voluntary arrangement scheme. C.banner, the Chinese owner of Hamleys, had agreed to make a £70m investment in House of Fraser, conditional on the CVA being implemented. The potential £50m loan from Mike Ashley's Sports Direct would be a significant boost for House of Fraser, which has been struggling to stay afloat in the face of declining sales and increased competition from online retailers. The retailer has been working to reduce its debt and improve its financial position, but the extra funding would give it the breathing room it needs to complete its restructuring plans.

Sources close to the talks have revealed that Ashley is keen to support House of Fraser, which he believes has a strong brand and a loyal customer base. He is said to be willing to provide the loan on the condition that House of Fraser agrees to a number of changes, including the appointment of a new chairman and the implementation of a cost-cutting plan.

The proposed loan would also give Ashley a greater level of influence over the retailer's operations, which could potentially pave the way for a takeover bid in the future. However, it is understood that Ashley's primary focus is on supporting House of Fraser's existing management team and helping the retailer to emerge from its current financial difficulties.

The news of the potential loan has been welcomed by industry insiders, who believe that House of Fraser is an important part of the UK's retail landscape. "House of Fraser is a beloved brand with a rich history, and it would be a tragedy if it were to disappear," said one retail expert. "Mike Ashley's support could be the lifeline that the retailer needs to get back on its feet."

One of the oldest breweries in Britain and its chairman have been fined almost £30,000 after they refused to hand over vital documents about its pension scheme. Samuel Smith Old Brewery, which was founded in Tadcaster in 1758, was asked to provide details of its pensions in 2015. The Pension Regulator (TPR) wanted to ensure the Yorkshire-based brewer and pub owner was earning enough money to support the final-salary pension schemes of more than 2,000 employees. However, the brewery owner, Humphrey Smith, 73, wrote back and dismissed the request as "tiresome". In his letter to TPR, he said: "We are in receipt of your tiresome letter and we are not prepared to divulge the information to your organisation." TPR responded by launching court proceedings, accusing the company of neglecting or refusing to provide information without a reasonable excuse in breach of the Pensions Act 2004. As the owner and chairman of the company, Smith was accused of failing to hand over the documents. Both the company and Smith pleaded guilty to the offence at a hearing in May. On Monday the brewery and its chairman were sentenced at Brighton magistrates court and fined £26,750 as well as costs of £1,240. Judge Teresa Szagun said the company had claimed it was a "small, independent, family-run brewery struggling in a declining industry" and any fine would have an impact on its employees. The judge's words were met with a mixture of shock and dismay from the court room, as many in attendance had expected a more severe punishment for the company's blatant disregard for the law. The fine, although substantial, was seen by many as a slap on the wrist for a company with a rich history and significant assets.

The Pension Regulator, who had been seeking the documents for over five years, expressed disappointment and frustration with the outcome. "We had hoped for a more substantial penalty, given the severity of the breach," said a spokesperson. "The fact that the company and its chairman were found guilty of neglecting to provide information without a reasonable excuse is a clear indication of their lack of transparency and accountability."

The brewery's employees, who had been waiting for answers about their pension schemes for years, were also left feeling let down by the outcome. "We're just relieved that the truth has finally come out," said one employee, who wished to remain anonymous. "But we're still left wondering what's going to happen to our pensions. Will we ever see the money we're owed?"

As the news of the fine spread, many in the industry were left wondering how a company of Samuel Smith's stature could have gotten away with such blatant disregard for the law. "It's a shocking example of how some companies can prioritize their own interests over the well-being of their employees," said a spokesperson for the Association of British Brewers. "We hope that this case serves as a wake-up call for all breweries to prioritize transparency and accountability."

Q In your opinion is help-to-buy a good option? Both my sons – who are 30 and 35 – have been renting for 15 years but now want to get on the property ladder. They have looked into the help-to-buy scheme in some depth but remain unsure. I've read such negative things about the help-to-buy scheme and don't want them to live a life of fear and stress should they go down this path. Is it better to save longer for a bigger deposit buying an older property? DM A I think your sons are right to exercise caution about the help-to-buy scheme. And if they can afford to purchase property without using help-to-buy, it would make a lot of sense. And that's not just my opinion. In the Help to Buy Buyers' Guide published by the Homes and Communities Agency (HCA) it says: "If it looks like you can already secure a 90% mortgage you should think carefully whether a help-to-buy equity loan is right for you. There may be better options for you to consider." better options for you to consider." This warning is particularly relevant for your sons, who have been renting for 15 years and are now looking to buy their first property. With a longer rental history, they may be in a stronger financial position than some of the other first-time buyers who are taking advantage of the help-to-buy scheme.

Additionally, the scheme's 5% deposit requirement can be a significant burden, especially if your sons are not confident in their ability to afford the mortgage payments and other costs associated with homeownership. As the HCA guide suggests, if they can secure a 90% mortgage without the help-to-buy equity loan, it may be a more sustainable option.

Another consideration is the potential impact of the scheme on the property market. Some critics argue that the help-to-buy scheme is artificially inflating house prices, making it more difficult for other buyers to get on the market. This could have long-term consequences for your sons, who may find themselves struggling to sell their property in the future.

Ultimately, the decision to use the help-to-buy scheme or to save longer for a bigger deposit will depend on your sons' individual financial circumstances and goals. However, it's essential for them to carefully weigh the pros and cons of each option before making a decision. As their parent, you can offer guidance and support, but ultimately, the choice is theirs to make. By doing their research and considering all the factors, your sons can make an informed decision that is right for them.

Gender Over the last year, scientist Jess Wade has taken to the keyboard to rectify gender bias on Wikipedia. She has written more than 270 entries about forgotten but influential women in science – such as Susan Goldberg, the first female editor of National Geographic. Research shows just 16% of Wikipedia editors are female and only 17% of entries dedicated to notable people are for women. Western Research by Oxford University in 2016 revealed that the vast bulk of content written about most African countries on Wikipedia was by editors in Europe and North America. Only 16% of content about sub-Saharan Africa is written by people from the region, while most entries on European countries are written in Europe. Language In 2016, researchers at the University of Koblenz-Landau in Germany found that the language of a Wikipedia entry influences the sources used, therefore offering a different version of the truth. In an English-language article about Russia's annexation of Crimea, for example, 24% of sources were Ukrainian and 20% Russian. The findings highlight the need for greater diversity and representation in the editing community. Wade's efforts have been a significant step in addressing this imbalance, bringing to light the contributions and achievements of women in science who would otherwise be forgotten. Her work has also sparked a wider conversation about the importance of representation and diversity in online content.

In addition to language and geography, research has also shown that Wikipedia's content is often influenced by the biases and perspectives of its editors. For example, a study by the University of California, Berkeley found that Wikipedia articles about female politicians are more likely to focus on their appearance and personal life rather than their political achievements.

As the internet continues to play an increasingly important role in shaping our understanding of the world, it is crucial that online content reflects the diversity of human experience. Wade's efforts are a reminder that we must actively work to create a more inclusive and representative online environment. By doing so, we can ensure that the voices and stories of all individuals, regardless of gender, language, or geography, are heard and valued.

The Daily Mail has published a front-page notice about a correction and issued disciplinary notes to senior staff after falsely claiming an Iraqi man who won compensation from the British government was an insurgent who had been found with a bomb. The newspaper published the original story on its front page on 15 December under the headline "Another human rights fiasco! ", with the subheading "Iraqi 'caught red-handed with bomb' wins £33,000 – because our soldiers kept him in custody for too long". The story covered a judge's decision to award money to Abd Ali Hameed al-Waheed after he had been unlawfully imprisoned and badly treated by British armed forces during the Iraq war. The newspaper ran the story despite the judge concluding claims that he had been caught with a bomb had been discredited shortly after his detention, and that the claim by British soldiers that al-Waheed had been caught with a bomb was "pure fiction". The correction, published on the front page of the Daily Mail yesterday, admitted that the original story was "false and misleading" and apologized for any harm caused to Abd Ali Hameed al-Waheed's reputation. The newspaper also acknowledged that it had failed to fact-check the story properly, leading to the publication of a false and damaging headline.

The correction stated that the judge's decision to award compensation to al-Waheed was based on evidence that he had been subjected to mistreatment and unlawful detention by British armed forces, but that there was no evidence to support the claim that he had been caught with a bomb. The newspaper's apology also acknowledged that it had failed to provide a balanced view of the case, and that its reporting had been influenced by a biased and misleading source.

The Daily Mail's editor, Paul Dacre, has been issued with a formal warning and has been told to undergo additional training on fact-checking and accuracy. Several senior staff members have also been given disciplinary notes, and the newspaper's editorial team has been ordered to conduct a thorough review of its reporting procedures.

The apology has been welcomed by human rights campaigners, who have long criticized the Daily Mail for its biased and inaccurate reporting on issues related to the Iraq war. "This is a long-overdue correction, and we hope that it marks a turning point in the Daily Mail's reporting on these issues," said a spokesperson for the human rights group Reprieve. "We urge the newspaper to take this opportunity to reflect on its reporting practices and to ensure that its coverage is accurate, balanced, and respectful of the human rights of all individuals."

The ambitious James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) has a new launch date: March 2021. It had been planned for lift off in October this year, but has suffered numerous delays since the project began in 1996. Back then, its budget was forecast at $500m and the launch date was set for 2007. But the technical requirements for the mission were so challenging that delays started to mount and costs started to spiral. In 2011, the mission was almost cancelled by US Congress, but it relented and capped the mission cost at around $8bn. The latest delay, which has been caused by anomalous test results that need investigating, will bring the total budget to around $9.6bn (£7.8bn). Despite the latest setback, NASA officials remain optimistic about the telescope's prospects, citing its groundbreaking capabilities to study the universe in infrared light. When launched, JWST will be the most powerful space telescope ever built, capable of observing the first stars and galaxies that formed in the universe, as well as the formation of planets and the origins of life. NASA scientists are working tirelessly to resolve the issues and ensure a successful launch, with the added bonus of potentially discovering new worlds and unraveling the mysteries of the cosmos. The wait may be frustrating, but the rewards will be well worth it, as JWST prepares to revolutionize our understanding of the universe.

BP has agreed to buy US shale oil and gasfields from the Anglo-Australian miner BHP for $10.5bn (£8bn), in the UK firm's biggest acquisition in nearly two decades. Bob Dudley, BP's chief executive, lauded the deal as transformational and industry watchers said the move significantly beefed up the company's US shale presence, which was small compared to peers. The acquisition will boost BP's US oil and gas production by nearly a fifth and marks a new period of growth for the company, which is emerging after years under the $65bn burden of the Deepwater Horizon disaster. In total, 470,000 acres of assets are covered in the deal, including fields in the Permian in west Texas, the Eagle Ford in south Texas and Haynesville in east Texas and Louisiana. Analysts said Eagle Ford was the most valuable of the three because of its scale and economics, while the Permian offered the greatest long-term promise. BHP bought the fields in 2011 but has struggled to make them work, putting them up for sale last August. BP said it believed its approach would differ by bringing $350m of synergies from its other US operations and capital efficiencies. Bernard Looney, the chief executive of BP's upstream division, said: "It gives us access to some of the best acreage in the best basins. It takes us into the very heart of the most-talked-about oil play in the world [the Permian]." The UK oil giant was "not desperate to do a deal" he added but BP believed the quality of the resources made the acquisition worthwhile. After the deal is completed BP's US production will climb from 744,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day to 885,000 boe/d. "BP was previously underweight to US tight oil compared to its peers. The acquisition is expected to be completed in the fourth quarter of this year, pending regulatory approvals. Analysts have praised the deal, citing BP's ability to extract value from the assets and its expertise in the US shale market. The Permian Basin, in particular, is seen as a key driver of growth for BP, with its vast reserves of oil and gas providing a long-term source of production.

BP's Dudley said the deal would allow the company to tap into the Permian's "unprecedented" growth potential, while also reducing its reliance on mature fields. The company plans to integrate the new assets into its existing US operations, leveraging its expertise in drilling and production to maximize returns.

The deal is also seen as a vote of confidence in the US shale industry, which has faced criticism in recent years over its environmental impact and declining production rates. BP's investment in the Permian Basin, in particular, is seen as a signal that the company believes in the long-term potential of the region.

Industry insiders say the deal could spark a wave of consolidation in the US shale market, as other companies look to build their presence in the region. The acquisition is also seen as a major coup for BP, which has been working to rebuild its reputation after the Deepwater Horizon disaster. The company's new focus on US shale production is seen as a key part of its strategy to drive growth and improve its financial performance.

Councils are driving poor people further into financial difficulty by using bailiffs "overzealously" to pursue households that have failed to pay council tax, according to a damning report by a committee of MPs. In 2016, around 2.3m debt cases were passed to bailiffs by local authorities, according to data given to the House of Commons Treasury committee. It said: "These debts are often pursued overzealously, and with routine recourse to bailiffs. The public sector should be leading by example in their treatment of the most financially vulnerable; but the current approach risks driving them into further difficulty." MPs said the "uncompromising" approach by local and central government to debt collection should be reformed to meet best industry standards. The report highlighted evidence from the debt charity StepChange, one-third of whose clients had council tax arrears averaging £1,000. Phil Andrew of the charity said: "Often the governmental organisations are very aggressive in the way they go about getting the payments made. This quick jump to the use of bailiffs is something that we are really quite concerned about" Threats from bailiffs were thought to be a factor in the suicide of courier Jerome Rogers, 20, who was pursued for two £65 parking fines that escalated to a debt of £1,019. The case prompted calls for sweeping changes to the way the debt collection industry works. Earlier this week the personal insolvency firm Creditfix said it had identified 55 councils across the UK that routinely rejected payment plans offered by those in financial difficulties, leaving those affected with no other choice than to file for bankruptcy. The report's findings have sparked outrage among anti-poverty campaigners, who argue that the use of bailiffs is not only aggressive but also ineffective in collecting debts. "The government's approach is akin to a sledgehammer to crack a nut," said Ruth Croft, a spokesperson for the charity Zacchaeus 2000 Trust. "Rather than working with individuals to find a solution, they're using bailiffs to intimidate and harass people who are already struggling to make ends meet."

The report also highlighted the lack of transparency and accountability within the debt collection industry, with many councils failing to provide clear information to households about the debt collection process. "It's like they're hiding behind a veil of secrecy," said Andrew Walker, a debt advisor with the Citizens Advice Bureau. "People are left feeling powerless and trapped in a cycle of debt, with no clear way out."

The government has been accused of turning a blind eye to the issue, with some MPs calling for a complete overhaul of the debt collection system. "This is a matter of social justice," said Labour MP Stella Creasy. "We need to ensure that our system is fair and compassionate, rather than simply trying to extract as much money as possible from people who are struggling to pay their debts." The government has yet to respond to the report's findings, but anti-poverty campaigners are calling for immediate action to address the issue.

Britain's unquenchable thirst for gin proved the tonic for upmarket mixer maker Fever-Tree, as it reached a record value of £4.5bn on Tuesday after smashing profit forecasts. A surge in its share price meant that the 13-year-old drinks company was worth nearly as much as Royal Mail and outstripped the combined stock market value of WH Smith, Debenhams, the AA and Saga. Fever-Tree, which produces tonic water and other carbonated mixers, has grown rapidly, thanks in large part to the soaring popularity of premium gin. UK gin sales have doubled over the past six years to hit £1.2bn in the year to the end of September 2017, according to the Wine and Spirit Trade Association, while a YouGov poll found gin was the most beloved spirit in the UK, with 29% of drinkers voting it their favourite. Riding the crest of the gin wave has transformed Fever-Tree into one of the UK's fastest-growing major companies, making multi-millionaires of co-founders Charles Rolls and Tim Warrilow in the process. The pair founded Fever-Tree in 2005, naming it after the colloquial term for the cinchona tree, the bark of which produces quinine – a key ingredient in tonic water. Rolls has banked more than £150m through share sales since the company's stock market float in 2014, while Warrilow has sold stock worth £41m. They still own 14% of the company between them, a stake worth nearly £600m, and pocketed payouts of more than £630,000 on Tuesday after the group lifted its dividend by 40%. The company's success has not gone unnoticed, with Fever-Tree's products now stocked in over 70 countries worldwide. Its tonic water is particularly popular, with sales increasing by 25% in the past year alone. The company's ability to adapt to changing consumer trends has been key to its success, with Fever-Tree introducing new flavors and products to keep up with the demand for premium mixers.

Fever-Tree's co-founders have been credited with their innovative approach to the industry, which has disrupted the traditional way of making tonic water. The company's focus on using high-quality ingredients and unique flavor combinations has helped to set it apart from its competitors. The company's success has also created jobs, with Fever-Tree employing over 200 people worldwide.

Despite the company's rapid growth, Fever-Tree's co-founders have maintained a strong commitment to sustainability and social responsibility. The company has implemented a number of initiatives aimed at reducing its environmental impact, including reducing its carbon footprint and sourcing ingredients from environmentally-friendly suppliers.

Fever-Tree's success has also led to a number of awards and recognition within the industry. The company was named "Best Tonic Water" at the 2018 International Wine and Spirit Competition, and its founder Charles Rolls was named "Entrepreneur of the Year" at the 2017 National Business Awards. The company's success is a testament to the power of innovation and entrepreneurial spirit, and it is likely to continue to be a major player in the drinks industry for years to come.

A full-sized driverless bus will be given a trial for the first time in the UK by one of Britain's biggest transport operators later this year. Stagecoach said the single-decker bus will run autonomously only in its depots until laws change to allow it to carry passengers. Work is being carried out to adapt the bus with the same technology used on driverless pods recently used in a trial in Greenwich, south-east London. The operator said the bus would be able to park in depots and drive itself to refuelling and wash points. No driver will be required when it is off public roads. The trial is part of Stagecoach's efforts to explore the potential of autonomous vehicles in the transport industry. The company has been working closely with technology partners to develop and test the bus, which is equipped with a range of sensors and cameras to enable it to navigate its surroundings safely and efficiently.

The trial will take place in one of Stagecoach's depots in the UK, where the bus will be used to perform tasks such as parking, refuelling, and washing. The operator hopes that the trial will demonstrate the benefits of autonomous vehicles in reducing costs and improving efficiency.

Stagecoach's director of innovation, Tom Sturrup, said: "We are excited to be at the forefront of this technology and to be trialing a fully autonomous bus in the UK. This is a significant step forward for the industry and we believe that it has the potential to make a real difference to our operations."

The trial is subject to regulatory approval, but if successful, it could pave the way for the use of autonomous buses on public roads in the future. Stagecoach is working with government officials to ensure that the necessary laws and regulations are in place to allow the bus to carry passengers.

The company is also exploring the potential of autonomous vehicles to improve accessibility and mobility for people with disabilities. The bus is designed to be fully accessible, with features such as wheelchair ramps and audio announcements.

Stagecoach's trial is just one example of the growing interest in autonomous vehicles in the transport industry. Several other operators are also exploring the technology, and it is likely that we will see more trials and deployments in the coming years.

A total lunar eclipse will be visible over most of Europe, Asia, Australia and South America on 27 July. Only North America misses the show this time. During a total lunar eclipse, the moon passes through the Earth's shadow. The event, known as a "blood moon" due to the moon's reddish hue, is expected to be visible from 11:24 PM to 2:13 AM local time. Astronomers are predicting a high level of interest in the eclipse, with many enthusiasts planning to stay up late to catch a glimpse of the rare phenomenon. "This is a unique opportunity for people to witness a total lunar eclipse from a wide range of locations," said Dr. Maria Rodriguez, a lunar expert at the European Space Agency. "We expect to see a surge in online traffic and social media activity as people share their experiences and photos of the eclipse." The eclipse will be visible from major cities including Tokyo, Sydney, and Buenos Aires, as well as smaller towns and rural areas across the affected regions.

Craig Jones is now a successful local politician but when Wonga was in its prime he was one of many people who turned to the payday lender for help. Jones was in insecure employment on a zero-hours contract in 2011 when he turned to Britain's then biggest payday lender. There was a lull in work and he "needed something to tide me over" while he waited for his finances to pick up. He took out a small Wonga loan – "I think it was £50 to £100" – but unfortunately his work situation did not improve and "it just snowballed from there … [it] led to me taking out more and more, and from different sources". He cannot recall how much he borrowed in total. Asked if it was several hundred pounds, he said it may well have been more than that. Later, however, he obtained more secure permanent work and was eventually able to pay off what he owed. In 2011, the year Jones became a Wonga customer, the company posted good figures: its profits tripled to £45.8m on revenues of £185m as the firm issued almost 2.5m loans. The following year the company told employees that by 2015 it could be valued at £15bn. However, in 2014 Wonga had a traumatic year: it was embroiled in scandal for sending out fake legal letters, ordered to pay millions in compensation and forced to write off £220m of debts owed by 330,000 borrowers. As the years went by, Jones' experience with Wonga became a distant memory, replaced by the trappings of success as a local politician. However, his story is not unique. Many people, like Jones, turned to Wonga in times of financial need, only to find themselves trapped in a cycle of debt.

The scandal surrounding Wonga's fake legal letters and aggressive debt collection practices was a wake-up call for many. The company's business model, which relied heavily on high-interest rates and fees, was widely criticized. In the end, Wonga's troubles led to its downfall, and the company was forced to shut its doors in 2018.

Jones' experience with Wonga has given him a unique perspective on the issue of payday lending. As a politician, he has been vocal about the need for greater regulation of the industry and more support for people struggling with debt. "I was one of the lucky ones," he said in an interview. "I was able to get out of debt and move on with my life. But I know that's not the case for many others. We need to make sure that people are protected from these types of lenders and that there are more options available for those who are struggling."

Jones' story is a reminder that the issue of payday lending is complex and multifaceted. While some people, like Jones, may have used Wonga as a last resort in times of financial need, others may have been taken advantage of by the company's aggressive tactics. As the industry continues to evolve, it is crucial that policymakers and regulators prioritize the needs of consumers and work to create a more equitable and sustainable system.

James Bond's favourite carmaker was founded in a small London workshop in 1913 by the engineer Robert Bamford and the car enthusiast Lionel Martin. The name Aston Martin came a year later after their prototype successfully made it around the Aston Hill Climb track in Buckinghamshire. Aston Martin took its place on the international motor racing stage by competing in the 1922 French Grand Prix but the business ran into financial trouble over the next few years and was rescued in 1926 by a group of investors. It developed a competitive range of sports cars with an increasing reputation for engineering and design, entering the Le Mans 24 Hours for the first time in 1928. Production of its road cars was stepped up in the 1930s, with 140 cars built in 1937 – the highest prewar figure. The English industrialist David Brown bought the business in 1947, expanding operations and relocating production from Kensington to Feltham. Production was again moved in 1955 to Newport Pagnell. In 1963 the Aston Martin DB5 entered production and the famous relationship with James Bond was born a year later when it was made the car of choice for 007 in the film Goldfinger, starring Sean Connery. Since then, Aston Martin has become synonymous with style, sophistication, and high-performance. The DB5's association with James Bond cemented the brand's status as a symbol of luxury and glamour. The company continued to produce iconic models, including the DBS and V8 Vantage, which further solidified its reputation as a manufacturer of exceptional vehicles.

In the 1980s, Aston Martin underwent significant changes, including a change in ownership and a shift in focus towards producing high-performance sports cars. The company's fortunes were revived with the introduction of the Vantage and Virage models, which quickly gained a loyal following among car enthusiasts.

The 21st century saw Aston Martin continue to evolve, with the introduction of new models such as the DB9 and Vanquish. The company also expanded its operations, opening new manufacturing facilities and showrooms around the world. In 2014, Aston Martin celebrated its centennial anniversary, marking a century of innovation, design, and excellence in the world of motorsport.

Today, Aston Martin is a global brand, with a presence in over 100 countries and a reputation for producing some of the most desirable and exclusive vehicles in the world. The company continues to push the boundaries of innovation and design, with a focus on creating cars that are not only fast and powerful but also beautiful and desirable. As the brand looks to the future, it is clear that its legacy as a maker of exceptional vehicles will endure for generations to come.

The Japanese carmaker Toyota is to invest $500m (£388m) in the ride-hailing company Uber as the two companies expand their partnership on the development of self-driving cars. It deepens an existing relationship in a bid to catch up with rivals in the race to design and produce autonomous vehicles for the mass market. The aim of the partnership is to use technology from both companies in purpose-built Toyota cars to be deployed across Uber's ride-sharing network from 2021. Toyota's investment values Uber at $72bn, despite mounting losses that totalled $4.5bn in 2017. Shigeki Tomoyama, the executive vice-president of Toyota, said: "This agreement and investment marks an important milestone in our transformation to a mobility company as we help provide a path for safe and secure expansion of mobility services like ride-sharing that includes Toyota vehicles and technologies." The partnership is seen as a major step forward for both companies in the development of autonomous vehicles, which are expected to revolutionize the way people move around cities. Toyota's investment will give it a significant stake in Uber's operations, and the two companies will work together to develop a range of autonomous vehicles, including sedans, minivans, and SUVs.

The technology developed through the partnership will be used in purpose-built Toyota cars that will be deployed across Uber's ride-sharing network from 2021. The vehicles will be designed to operate in a variety of environments, including urban and suburban areas, and will be equipped with advanced sensors and cameras to enable them to detect and respond to their surroundings.

The partnership is also expected to create new job opportunities in the field of autonomous vehicle development, as both companies will be hiring engineers, software developers, and other professionals to work on the project. Additionally, the partnership will enable Toyota to tap into Uber's vast network of drivers and riders, providing it with valuable data and insights that can be used to improve its autonomous vehicle technology.

The investment by Toyota is a significant vote of confidence in Uber's technology and business model, and is seen as a major coup for the ride-hailing company. The partnership is expected to be a major factor in the development of the autonomous vehicle industry, and will likely be closely watched by other companies in the sector.

Rob Davies praises Ticketmaster for closing down its resale sites (Report, 18 August). Some of us remember life before Ticketmaster when we could ring the box office of a theatre or concert hall and reserve a ticket for the price of the ticket and no more. It's a refreshing change to hear that a major ticketing company is taking steps to address the issue of ticket touting. For too long, Ticketmaster's resale sites have been a haven for profiteers, driving up prices and making it impossible for genuine fans to get their hands on tickets at a reasonable price.

As Rob Davies points out, this isn't a new problem. In fact, it's been a scourge on the live music industry for decades. But it's encouraging to see Ticketmaster taking action to clean up its act. Of course, it remains to be seen whether this move will have a significant impact on the wider ticketing market. After all, there are still plenty of other ways for touts to get their hands on tickets and sell them on at inflated prices.

But for now, it's a small victory for fans and a reminder that, even in the digital age, there's still room for some old-fashioned customer service. So, let's raise a glass to Rob Davies and Ticketmaster for taking a step in the right direction. Here's hoping that other ticketing companies will follow their lead and put the interests of fans first.

Superdrug has advised its online customers to change their passwords after the high street chain was targeted by hackers claiming to have stolen the personal details of thousands of people. The health and beauty retailer told customers it had been contacted by a group on Monday evening claiming to have obtained the details of 20,000 customers, including names, addresses, dates of birth and phone numbers. Superdrug said in the email to customers the company had only seen evidence so far that 386 of the accounts had been compromised. A spokeswoman said: "The hacker shared a number of details with us to try to prove he had customer information – we were then able to verify they were Superdrug customers from their email and log-in." The company said the information stolen did not include payment card information. "We believe the hacker obtained customers' email addresses and passwords from other websites and then used those credentials to access accounts on our website," it said. Advising customers to change their passwords, Superdrug added: "We take our responsibility to protect your personal information very seriously and that is why we have let our customers know as soon as we could. "We have contacted the police and Action Fraud [the UK's national fraud and cyber-crime arm] and will be offering them all the information they need for their investigation." The company has set up a dedicated webpage for customers to change their passwords and has also sent out an email to all affected customers. Superdrug has assured customers that it will continue to monitor its systems closely and will take all necessary steps to prevent similar incidents in the future. The company has also offered to provide affected customers with a free credit monitoring service for the next 12 months. In a statement, Superdrug said: "We want to assure our customers that we are taking this incident very seriously and are doing everything we can to prevent it from happening again. We understand that this may cause concern for our customers and we want to reassure them that we are committed to protecting their personal information." The incident is the latest in a string of high-profile data breaches in the UK, and has raised concerns about the security of online retailers and the measures they take to protect customer data.

Elite private schools have called for universities to cut back on the use of unconditional offers for undergraduate places over fears that pupils will not be motivated to strive for high A-level grades. Mike Buchanan, the executive director of the Headmasters' and Headmistresses' Conference (HMC), which represents many of the country's most expensive independent schools, claimed that pupils "take their foot off the gas" after accepting offers that do not require specific A-level grades.
