"These youngsters have to carry their results with them for their whole careers," Buchanan, the former headteacher of Ashford School in Kent, told the Times newspaper. "I am asking universities to stop using them unless they have interviewed the pupil and got some sense that it would be good for this pupil, or have consulted the school, which has given you the same information." Until recently only a small number of school-leavers were given unconditional offers. Buchanan's comments have sparked a debate among educators and policymakers, with some arguing that unconditional offers can be beneficial for students who may be struggling with anxiety or pressure to achieve high grades. Dr. Sarah Jones, a lecturer in education at the University of Cambridge, pointed out that "for some students, the weight of expectation can be overwhelming, and an unconditional offer can be a welcome relief."

However, others have criticized the move, suggesting that it could undermine the value of hard work and academic achievement. "If universities are offering unconditional places, it sends a message that it doesn't matter how well you do in your exams," said James Parker, a former student at a state school in London. "It's like saying, 'Just turn up and you'll get in, regardless of your grades.'"

The debate has also raised questions about the impact on students from disadvantaged backgrounds, who may face additional barriers in accessing higher education. "Unconditional offers can be a lifeline for students who may not have the same access to resources and support as their more affluent peers," said Dr. Maria Rodriguez, a researcher at the University of Manchester.

The HMC's call for universities to reconsider their use of unconditional offers comes as the number of school-leavers receiving such offers has increased significantly in recent years. According to data from the University and Colleges Admissions Service (UCAS), the number of unconditional offers rose by 15% between 2018 and 2019, with some universities offering as many as 50% of their places on an unconditional basis.

As the debate continues, it remains to be seen whether universities will heed the HMC's call and revise their admissions policies. In the meantime, students and parents are left to navigate the complex and often confusing world of university admissions, where the lines between reward and entitlement are increasingly blurred.

White boys from disadvantaged family backgrounds are significantly underachieving even at the earliest stage of their education, results of this year's phonics screening check for six-year-olds have revealed. When results are broken down by ethnic group, gender and free school meal (FSM) eligibility, white boys on FSM are the lowest attaining group, with only six out of 10 pupils (62%) meeting the required standard. Although official figures published by the government on Thursday show a two percentage point improvement on last year's results among this group, disadvantaged white boys still lag way behind their peers. Overall more than four in five pupils (82%) met the expected standard in the phonics screening check this year, a one percentage point increase on 2017 results. Chinese girls (not eligible for FSM) were the highest performing group. The screening check involves pupils reading a list of 40 words aloud, of which half are nonsense. The pass mark this year was 32. Pupils who fall short take the check again at the end of year 2, by which time 92% met the required standard. The findings have raised concerns about the persistent achievement gap between disadvantaged white boys and their peers. Experts argue that the issue is not just about individual pupil performance, but also about the broader societal and environmental factors that contribute to their underachievement.

"We need to acknowledge that poverty, lack of access to resources, and negative stereotypes can all impact a child's ability to learn," said Dr. Emma Taylor, a leading education researcher. "It's not just about the child's ability, but also about the environment they're growing up in. We need to address these underlying issues to give all children an equal chance to succeed."

The government has announced plans to increase funding for schools in disadvantaged areas, as well as provide additional support for teachers and pupils. However, some critics argue that more needs to be done to address the root causes of the problem.

"This is a complex issue that requires a multi-faceted approach," said Sarah Jones, a parent and education activist. "We need to work with communities, schools, and policymakers to create a system that supports all children, regardless of their background. We can't just keep patching up the symptoms, we need to address the underlying causes."

The phonics screening check results have also highlighted the importance of early intervention and targeted support for disadvantaged pupils. Experts are calling for more resources to be invested in early years education, as well as targeted support for pupils who are struggling to catch up.

"This is a wake-up call for all of us," said Education Secretary, Damian Hinds. "We need to work together to ensure that every child has the opportunity to succeed, regardless of their background. We will be working closely with schools, teachers, and parents to address this issue and ensure that all children are given the support they need to thrive."

The tech billionaire Mike Cannon-Brookes and his wife, Annie, have bought Australia's most expensive home, Lady Fairfax's sprawling Point Piper mansion Fairwater. Cannon-Brookes, the co-founder of software company Atlassian, has reportedly paid $100m for the historic 1.12 hectare estate on Sydney harbour after more than a century in the hands of the Fairfax family. "We are delighted with the purchase of Fairwater for our young family and look forward to continuing the legacy of this beautiful Sydney home," Cannon-Brookes said in a statement. "We love the idea of raising our four young children in this historic property." Fairwater is the largest privately held property on Sydney harbour, and one of the most significant heritage homes in Australia. Built in 1882, the waterfront estate in leafy Point Piper stretches from New South Head Road to Seven Shillings Beach. The purchase marks a significant milestone in the history of Fairwater, which has been owned by the Fairfax family since its construction in 1882. The estate's grandeur and picturesque setting have made it a sought-after property for generations, with many notable Australians having lived there over the years.

Cannon-Brookes and his wife, Annie, are expected to renovate the property to suit their growing family's needs. The couple has four young children, and they have stated that they plan to raise them in the historic home. While the exact extent of the renovations is unclear, it is likely that the couple will modernize the property while still preserving its original charm and character.

The sale of Fairwater is a significant departure from the Fairfax family's traditional ownership of the property. The family has been the custodians of the estate for over 130 years, and its sale marks the end of an era for the Fairfaxes. The family has made significant contributions to Australian society, with Sir Warwick Fairfax, a former chairman of the Fairfax Media company, being a notable figure in the country's business and media circles.

The purchase of Fairwater is also a significant investment for Cannon-Brookes, who has made his fortune through his co-founding of Atlassian. The software company has experienced rapid growth in recent years, and Cannon-Brookes' net worth is estimated to be over $1 billion. The purchase of Fairwater is likely to be just one of many investments for the tech mogul, who is known for his shrewd business acumen and his commitment to philanthropy.

Overall, the sale of Fairwater marks a significant moment in the history of Australia's most expensive home. The property's new owners, Mike and Annie Cannon-Brookes, are expected to bring a new level of energy and enthusiasm to the estate, while also preserving its rich history and heritage.

Bentley has become the latest carmaker to warn that failure to reach a Brexit deal would hurt its sales and ability to invest, and would lead to a temporary shutdown of its factory in Crewe, Cheshire. Adrian Hallmark, the chief executive of the luxury carmaker, told Reuters it was stockpiling some components ahead of Brexit and switching from the port of Dover to Immingham to bring in certain parts. The Volkswagen-owned marque makes about 11,000 cars a year in Crewe. If London and Brussels fail to reach an agreement by the end of the year, Bentley may stockpile more car parts and close its factory for a few extra days, said Hallmark, who joined Bentley from Jaguar Land Rover in February. The majority of key parts including engines and body come from the European Union, mainly Germany. "We may work for four days, or we may have a longer Christmas break and a longer Easter break if there is no deal so that we can smooth the period between now and the middle of next year," Hallmark said. BMW plans to shut its Mini plant for a month after the UK's departure from the EU on 29 March, to minimise the impact of a no-deal Brexit that it fears would cause a shortage of parts. As the Brexit deadline looms, concerns are growing among car manufacturers about the potential disruption to their supply chains and production. Bentley's warning comes as other major carmakers, including BMW and Jaguar Land Rover, have already announced plans to stockpile parts and adjust their operations in anticipation of a no-deal Brexit.

The uncertainty surrounding Brexit has led to a surge in demand for luxury cars, as some buyers seek to import vehicles before the UK's departure from the EU. However, Bentley's Hallmark warned that this surge in demand would not be enough to offset the potential impact of a no-deal Brexit on the company's sales and production.

"We're not just talking about a few days of disruption, we're talking about a significant impact on our business," Hallmark said. "We're working closely with our suppliers to ensure that we have the necessary parts to continue production, but it's not just about having the parts, it's about having the right parts at the right time."

Bentley's warning comes as the UK's automotive industry faces significant challenges, including a decline in demand for diesel cars and increased competition from electric vehicles. The industry has been calling for a Brexit deal that would allow for a smooth transition and minimize disruption to trade and supply chains.

The UK government has been working to reassure the automotive industry that it is doing everything it can to secure a Brexit deal that works for all parties. However, the lack of progress in negotiations between the UK and EU has left many carmakers feeling uncertain about the future.

As the Brexit deadline approaches, Bentley and other carmakers will be closely watching the negotiations and preparing for all eventualities. While some carmakers may be able to adapt quickly to a no-deal Brexit, others may struggle to maintain production and sales. The uncertainty surrounding Brexit has already led to a decline in consumer confidence and a slowdown in economic growth, and the impact on the automotive industry could be significant.

Every week a Guardian Money reader submits a question, and it's up to you to help him or her out – a selection of the best answers will appear in next Saturday's paper. I'm a 26-year-old male who has landed his first proper job, but my heart sank at the dress code: smart casual. What does that actually mean? Blazers and chinos from Marks & Spencer? I don't have a large budget and I don't know what is expected of me. Are jeans allowed? Don't worry, you're not alone in your confusion! Smart casual is a dress code that can be tricky to navigate, especially on a budget. While blazers and chinos from Marks & Spencer are a safe bet, you don't need to break the bank. A pair of dark-washed jeans, paired with a crisp white shirt and a cardigan or a lightweight jacket, can create a stylish and professional look. Consider thrift stores or second-hand shops for affordable options. For shoes, opt for loafers or dress boots in a neutral color. And remember, it's not about the price tag, but about presenting yourself with confidence and a sense of style.

A students' union has been forced to introduce fancy dress guidelines after a student society held a homelessness-themed party. The trampolining society at Liverpool John Moores University was criticised after photographs of its annual "tramps' night out" event were published in the student paper the Liverpool Tab. The pictures showed the students wearing ripped clothes, with their faces painted to appear dirty. Some wore signs reading "Spare change? Meet me at the bar" and "give me your change and I'll change your night". The backlash was swift and severe, with many students and staff members expressing outrage and disgust at the event. The university's student union was forced to issue a statement apologizing for the "insensitive and thoughtless" party, and announced that it would be introducing new guidelines for future events to ensure that they do not cause offense.

The guidelines, which will come into effect next semester, will require all student societies to submit a detailed plan for their events, including a risk assessment and a plan for managing any potential controversy. Societies will also be required to include a statement on their event invitations explaining the theme and context of the event, and to provide a contact point for any students who may be offended or upset by the event.

The university's vice-chancellor, Professor Jane Smith, said that the event had "fallen short of the standards expected of our students and staff", and that the new guidelines were necessary to ensure that such a situation did not happen again. She added that the university was committed to promoting a culture of respect and inclusivity, and that it would work with students and staff to ensure that all events were respectful and considerate of all members of the university community.

The trampolining society has also issued an apology for the event, and has promised to work with the student union to implement the new guidelines. The society's president, Tom Johnson, said that the event had been intended as a lighthearted and humorous way to raise awareness about homelessness, but that it had clearly fallen flat. He added that the society was committed to learning from the experience and to ensuring that its future events were more thoughtful and considerate.

Nearly 600 jobs have been saved at landmark Manchester department store Kendals after the local council intervened to prevent its closure. The 182-year old House of Fraser store, in Deansgate, was set to close down in January after Mike Ashley's Sports Direct – which bought House of Fraser out of administration in August – failed to agree new rental terms with the building's landlords. However, the billionaire retailer said on Friday night that a deal had been reached, with Manchester city council playing an "instrumental" role. The council leader, Sir Richard Leese, said: "Today's announcement is fantastic news for the city, and I am proud that the council has been able to play a constructive role in saving a real Manchester icon and hundreds of jobs. The news of the deal being reached was met with relief and joy from the employees and customers of Kendals, who had been left in uncertainty about the store's future. The store's manager, Sarah Jones, said: "We are absolutely thrilled that a deal has been reached and that Kendals will be staying open. The team has worked tirelessly to keep the store running, and this news is a huge weight off our shoulders. We can't thank the council enough for their support and help in saving our jobs."

The deal is believed to have been reached after intense negotiations between Sports Direct, the building's landlords, and Manchester city council. The council had been working closely with the parties to find a solution that would save the store and its jobs. Sir Richard Leese added: "The council has been working closely with the parties involved to find a solution that works for everyone. We are delighted that we have been able to achieve this outcome, and we look forward to seeing Kendals continue to thrive in the heart of Manchester."

The news has also been welcomed by local businesses and residents, who had been concerned about the potential impact of the store's closure on the area. Councillor Pat Karney, who represents the Deansgate ward, said: "This is fantastic news for the area. Kendals is a beloved institution in Manchester, and its closure would have been a huge loss for the city. We are thrilled that the council has been able to play a role in saving the store and its jobs."

The deal is expected to be finalised in the coming weeks, and Kendals is set to remain open for business as usual. The store's employees are expected to receive their usual pay and benefits, and the store's management is planning to invest in the store's future, including upgrading its facilities and improving its customer offer. The news is a major boost for the city's retail sector, and is expected to have a positive impact on the local economy.

The Bank of England has defended spending £100,000 on its summer party, saying it "carefully budgeted" for the lavish event. The governor, Mark Carney, joined over 2,500 staff and their families at the Bank's sports ground in Roehampton, south-west London, in July, which featured a bake-off competition, a treasure hunt, fun run and bouncy castle. Employees were also treated to performances by the Bank of England's choir and band. Party planners racked up a bill of more than £58,000 for food and drink alone, according to a Freedom of Information request lodged by the Press Association. More than £27,000 was spent on entertainment, and £10,400 on "additional expenses", with the total being £95,674, excluding VAT. A spokesman for the Bank, which is partly funded by taxpayers, said: "Governors' Day is a long-held tradition that is open to all employees, including their families, with the aim of recognising their hard work and dedication. The Bank of England's lavish summer party has sparked outrage among critics, who argue that the £100,000 spend is a "waste of taxpayers' money" during a time of economic uncertainty. The event, which was attended by Mark Carney and over 2,500 staff and their families, has been criticized for its extravagance, particularly in light of the Bank's role in regulating the financial sector. The total cost of the party, excluding VAT, was £95,674, with £58,000 spent on food and drink alone. The Bank's spokesman claimed that the event was a "long-held tradition" aimed at recognizing employees' hard work and dedication, but many have questioned the need for such an extravagant celebration. The news comes as the Bank is facing scrutiny over its handling of the economy and its role in the 2008 financial crisis. The Bank's governor, Mark Carney, has been under fire for his handling of the economy, and the party has been seen as a symbol of the Bank's perceived detachment from the financial struggles of ordinary people.

Nine in 10 businesses say Brexit has affected their ability to recruit and train staff this year, the Confederation of British Industry has said. The Recruitment and Employment Confederation, the professional body for the recruitment industry, says the public sector, including the NHS and schools, face up to seven more years of skills shortages, based on current demand. On Thursday the Office for National Statistics said the number of EU citizens coming to the UK for work had fallen to a six-year low. Matthew Fell, the CBI's chief UK policy director, said: "These latest statistics highlight the continuing trend of falling net EU migration amid growing shortages across all skills levels in the UK. Ninety-two per cent of businesses cited Brexit as impacting their ability to recruit and train staff in 2018. "This is a critical issue that needs to be addressed urgently," Fell added. "The government must take immediate action to fix the skills shortage crisis, which is having a devastating impact on businesses of all sizes and sectors." The CBI is calling for a comprehensive review of the UK's immigration system, including a new points-based system that prioritizes skills and talent. The organization is also urging the government to increase investment in vocational training and apprenticeships to help address the skills gap.

The REC's chief executive, Neil Carberry, warned that the skills shortage crisis will only worsen unless action is taken. "We're facing a perfect storm of a shrinking workforce and a growing demand for skills," he said. "If we don't address this issue, we risk seeing a decline in productivity and economic growth." The REC is urging the government to take a more proactive approach to addressing the skills shortage, including increasing funding for vocational training and apprenticeships, and introducing a new visa system that allows businesses to bring in the skills they need.

Renault, Nissan and Mitsubishi Motors are not planning to appoint a new interim chairman to replace Carlos Ghosn as head of their carmaking alliance, following his shock arrest in Japan. Osamu Masuko, chief executive of Mitsubishi Motors, said on Thursday that the alliance would shift to a system where the group would be led by the heads of the three companies, rather than a single figurehead like Ghosn. Masuko, speaking to reporters in Tokyo, said changes to the alliance's capital structure were not discussed by company leaders at a meeting in Amsterdam. A change in the governance structure of the alliance was seen as likely by some analysts. Ghosn, who was the architect of the alliance and chaired the boards of all three manufacturers, was arrested 10 days ago after Nissan alleged he underreported income to regulators. Tokyo prosecutors are reportedly planning to extend the detention of Ghosn for a further 10 days, after which they must decide whether or not to charge him with a crime, Japan's Kyodo news agency reported on Thursday. The arrest has cast doubt on the future of the alliance. The move to a more decentralized leadership structure is seen as a response to the uncertainty surrounding Ghosn's fate and the potential impact on the alliance. Under the new system, the CEOs of Renault, Nissan, and Mitsubishi Motors will work together to make key decisions, with no single individual holding the reins.

While the change may seem radical, analysts believe it could be a pragmatic solution to the crisis. "The alliance needs to be flexible and adaptable to navigate this challenging period," said Noriaki Yoshida, an analyst at SMBC Nikko Securities. "By having the CEOs lead the alliance, they can respond quickly to changing circumstances and make decisions without needing to consult with a chairman."

The shift in leadership structure is also seen as a way to reduce the influence of Ghosn, who had been accused of wielding too much power within the alliance. "Ghosn's arrest has exposed the weaknesses in the alliance's governance structure," said Kenji Kawabata, a professor at Waseda University. "By decentralizing decision-making, the companies can reduce their dependence on any one individual and create a more balanced leadership."

Despite the changes, the alliance's future remains uncertain. The arrest of Ghosn has sent shockwaves through the industry, and many are wondering whether the alliance can survive without its charismatic leader. The companies are expected to hold further discussions in the coming weeks to address the crisis and determine the best course forward.

Journalists at the Financial Times have passed a vote of no confidence in the newspaper's chief executive, John Ridding, after a live webcast of a speech he was making to staff was stopped ahead of a debate about issues including his multimillion-pound pay package. Relations between the National Union of Journalists chapel at the Financial Times and management hit rock bottom in the summer when it emerged that Ridding had been paid £2.6m while the newspaper made an operating profit of £5.2m, prompting a backlash that saw him hand back about £500,000. The FT Group, the parent company of the newspaper, made more than £20m in profits. The NUJ chapel has now passed a vote of no confidence in Ridding after a fractious "town hall" meeting on Monday that was streamed live to all staff. In a statement the chapel said Ridding had not acknowledged or addressed serious concerns at the Financial Times in the speech broadcast to staff. The live broadcast was stopped at the end of formal speeches, meaning staff not in attendance were not able to watch the following debate about the issues. "In the middle of a dispute over transparency, better governance and high executive pay at the FT, John Ridding failed to acknowledge or even address serious staff concerns over these matters in his speech to staff," said the chapel in a motion. "Demonstrating a complete disregard for transparency, the live broadcast of the town hall meeting was stopped at the end of the formal speeches, preventing all staff not in the room from hearing the questions and responses." The motion also criticized Ridding for not providing a "clear plan" to address the concerns raised by staff, and for failing to engage with the union's proposals for improving transparency and governance at the Financial Times. The chapel called on Ridding to "take immediate action" to address the concerns and to work with the union to find a solution. The vote of no confidence is a significant blow to Ridding's leadership, and it is unclear what the next steps will be. The Financial Times has been a leading voice in the business and financial world for over 130 years, and the controversy surrounding Ridding's pay package has raised questions about the newspaper's commitment to transparency and accountability. The union has vowed to continue its campaign for change, and it is likely that the controversy will continue to dominate the headlines in the coming days.

Three online casino firms will pay out £14m after the largest enforcement action by the Gambling Commission uncovered failings in systems designed to prevent money-laundering and protect problem gamblers. The industry regulator ordered Casumo to pay a penalty package of £5.85m, while Videoslots will pay £1m in lieu of a financial penalty. Daub Alderney was hit with a fine of £7.1m, previously announced. A fourth company, CZ Holdings, surrendered its right to provide gambling services in the UK after the regulator opened a review of its licence. A further six firms remain under investigation. The Gambling Commission's investigation, which began in 2020, uncovered widespread failures in the systems designed to prevent money-laundering and protect problem gamblers at the three online casino firms. The regulator found that Casumo, Videoslots, and Daub Alderney had all failed to properly implement anti-money laundering and counter-terrorism financing measures, putting them at risk of being used for illegal activities.

The Commission also found that the companies had not done enough to identify and prevent problem gambling, despite being required to do so under their licences. This included failing to implement adequate age verification checks, to identify and restrict players who were at risk of developing gambling addiction, and to provide adequate support to those who were struggling with gambling problems.

The penalty package imposed on Casumo is the largest ever issued by the Gambling Commission, and is intended to reflect the seriousness of the company's failures. The £5.85m fine is made up of a £4.5m financial penalty, plus £1.35m to be spent on improving the company's systems and processes.

Videoslots, which was also found to have failed to properly implement anti-money laundering measures, will pay a £1m financial penalty. The company has also agreed to implement a range of measures to improve its systems and processes, including the appointment of an independent auditor to monitor its compliance with the Commission's requirements.

Daub Alderney, which was previously announced as being hit with a £7.1m fine, has been ordered to pay the full amount. The company has also been ordered to implement a range of measures to improve its systems and processes, including the appointment of an independent auditor to monitor its compliance with the Commission's requirements.

The Gambling Commission's Chief Executive, Neil McArthur, said that the regulator was "committed to ensuring that gambling operators are held to the highest standards of social responsibility and anti-money laundering compliance". He added that the Commission would "continue to take tough action against operators who fail to meet these standards".

The investigation is ongoing, and the Commission has warned that further penalties and fines may be imposed on the six firms still under investigation. The regulator has also announced that it will be launching a review of the gambling industry's approach to anti-money laundering and counter-terrorism financing, in order to identify areas for improvement and to ensure that the industry is doing enough to prevent illegal activities.

Cashless businesses would be banished from New York City under new legislation introduced on Wednesday that is aimed at protecting the poor. A growing number of businesses in New York and cities around the country have adopted cashless policies, refusing to accept paper currency and requiring customers to pay with debit or credit cards. The trend has spread from hipster coffee shops to popular burrito and salad chains, with business owners saying it's quicker and easier to dispense with cash. But city councilman Ritchie Torres, who introduced the legislation to prohibit the practice, said it freezes out people who don't have access to bank accounts and credit cards, who are more likely to be low-income and people of color. The same concerns have prompted proposed bans in Philadelphia and Washington DC. Torres called the proposals a "new frontier" of anti-discrimination law, needed to prevent a "gentrification of the marketplace" by businesses unwilling to accept cash. "A cashless business model has an exclusionary effect on the impoverished, the homeless, the underbanked, the undocumented," he told the Guardian. The proposed legislation would require businesses to accept cash payments, with some exceptions for certain types of transactions, such as online purchases. Torres argued that the ban would help level the playing field for low-income and marginalized communities, who are disproportionately affected by cashless policies. "We can't let the market dictate who can and can't participate in the economy," he said. "Everyone deserves access to goods and services, regardless of their financial situation." The proposal has gained support from community organizations and advocacy groups, who see it as a crucial step towards promoting economic equality and combating systemic racism. Opponents, however, argue that the ban would increase costs for businesses and make it harder for them to operate efficiently. The legislation is set to be voted on by the city council in the coming weeks, with a decision expected by the end of the year.

Donald Trump has raised the stakes in the escalating global trade dispute between the US, China and some of America's traditional allies ahead of a major gathering of world leaders this week. Ahead of the G20 meeting in Argentina, which begins on Friday, the US president used a newspaper interview to warn China that he expects to move ahead on the imposition of higher import tariffs on Chinese goods. The news sent shares lower in London and New York on Tuesday, after Trump told the Wall Street Journal it was "highly unlikely" that he would heed a call by Beijing to refrain from increasing the tariffs from the start of next year. It paves the way for the existing 10% US import tariff on $200bn (£158bn) of Chinese goods to increase to 25% from 1 January. Economists at the Dutch lender Rabobank said the world economy could suffer badly over the next decade if the US-China trade war escalates further, with as much as 2% of GDP growth lost by 2030. Hugo Erken, senior economist at the bank, said: "An ongoing trade war between the world's two largest economies has much broader ramifications that transcend their own borders … in a globalised economy, there are no real winners from such policies." The escalating trade tensions have also sparked concerns about the potential impact on global supply chains and the broader economy. "If the trade war escalates, it could lead to a significant disruption in global supply chains, which could have far-reaching consequences for businesses and consumers alike," said Mark Zandi, chief economist at Moody's Analytics. The US-China trade war has already led to retaliatory measures from both sides, with China imposing tariffs on $110 billion worth of US goods, including soybeans and aircraft. The ongoing dispute has also raised concerns about the potential for a global recession. "The risk of a global recession is higher than it was a year ago, mainly due to the trade tensions," said Jan Szymanski, chief economist at Pictet Wealth Management. The G20 meeting in Argentina is expected to be a crucial moment in the ongoing trade dispute, with leaders from around the world gathering to discuss the issue. However, with no clear resolution in sight, many are bracing for a prolonged and potentially damaging trade war. "The world is facing a very uncertain and potentially very difficult period," said Robert Alan Feldman, chief economist at Societe Generale. "We are entering a new era of protectionism and nationalism, and it's hard to predict what the outcome will be."

Uber's European operation has been fined £385,000 for a data breach that affected almost 3 million British users, the Information Commissioner's Office has announced. In November 2016, attackers obtained credentials to access Uber's cloud servers and downloaded 16 large files, including the records of 35 million users worldwide. The records included passengers' full names, phone numbers, email addresses, and the location where they had signed up. Drivers were also affected, with 3.7 million, including 82,000 from the UK, having their weekly pay, trip summaries and, in a small number of cases, driver's licence numbers accessed. The ICO said the breach was caused by inadequate information security, and was compounded by Uber US's decision to not disclose the attack, instead complying with the hackers' demands to pay $100,000 as a "bug bounty". Such bounties are common in the security world, with companies offering rewards to researchers who find and notify them of system weaknesses before they can be attacked. However, the ICO wrote: "Uber US did not follow the normal operation of its bug bounty programme. In this incident Uber US paid outside attackers who were fundamentally different from legitimate bug bounty recipients: instead of merely identifying a vulnerability and disclosing it responsibly, they maliciously exploited the vulnerability and intentionally acquired personal information relating to Uber users." The ICO's investigation found that Uber's European operation had failed to implement adequate security measures to prevent the breach, and that the company had also failed to notify the affected users in a timely manner. The regulator said that Uber's handling of the breach was "completely unacceptable" and that the company's decision to pay the hackers to delete the stolen data was "not a sufficient response".

The ICO's fine is the largest ever imposed on a technology company in the UK, and it serves as a warning to other companies that they must take their data protection responsibilities seriously. "The failure to protect personal data is not a trivial matter," said Information Commissioner Elizabeth Denham. "It's a serious breach of trust and a serious breach of the law. We are determined to take enforcement action where necessary to ensure that organisations comply with the law and respect the privacy of individuals."

Uber has apologized for the breach and has taken steps to improve its data security measures. The company has also established a new data protection team and has implemented additional security measures to prevent similar breaches in the future. However, the incident has left many users concerned about the security of their personal data and the company's ability to protect it.

The ICO's investigation also found that Uber's handling of the breach was not isolated to the UK. The company's US operation had also been affected by the breach, and the ICO said that it had received reports of similar breaches in other countries. The incident highlights the need for companies to take a global approach to data protection and to ensure that their data security measures are robust and effective.

In a statement, Uber said that it was "sorry" for the breach and that it was "taking steps to make sure it doesn't happen again". The company said that it had learned a lot from the incident and was committed to protecting the personal data of its users. However, the incident has left many users wondering whether they can trust the company with their personal data. Only time will tell if Uber's efforts to improve its data security measures will be enough to restore trust in the company.

I am a keen gardener and was fortunate to receive more than £150-worth of Wyevale garden centres gift cards for my recent summer birthday. I had specified that retailer as there has been a large one near my home for many years. However, when I visited last weekend I was shocked to see that it is now a Dobbies garden centre. I was finally told that I could not use the cards there but that I could do so at other centres. However, the three "relatively" near me are a considerable drive away. This all seems unfair as it is hardly my fault that the company has changed hands. I was taken aback by the news, to say the least. I had been looking forward to using the gift cards to stock up on some new plants and gardening tools for my garden. But now, it seemed that I was out of luck. The staff at the new Dobbies centre were polite, but firm, in their refusal to accept the Wyevale cards.

I asked if there was any way to transfer the balance to a different centre, but was told that it was not possible. The only option was to use the cards at one of the other Wyevale centres, which, as I mentioned, are a significant drive away. I was disappointed, to say the least.

As I left the centre, I couldn't help but feel a sense of frustration. It seemed unfair that I was being penalized for the company's decision to change hands. I had chosen Wyevale specifically because of its location, and now it seemed that I was being forced to drive further afield just to use the gift cards.

I am not the only one who has been affected by this change, I'm sure. Many people must have received Wyevale gift cards as presents, only to find that they are no longer valid at the centre they had chosen. It's a shame, really, as Wyevale was a well-respected and popular garden centre. I hope that Dobbies will find a way to make things right for customers like me who are left feeling disappointed and frustrated by this change.

The Observer and Guardian journalist, Carole Cadwalladr, has won the Foreign Press Association media award for print and web story of the year for her reporting on the links between Cambridge Analytica, the UK's pro-Brexit campaigners and Donald Trump presidential election team. Also among the nominees was Cadwalladr's Guardian colleague, Amelia Gentleman, for an article on the Windrush scandal, as well as Stephen Bleach of the Sunday Times, who revealed the abuse he suffered at the hands of the Catholic church, and Reuters' Wa Lone and Kyaw Soe Oo, who were jailed for their reporting on the massacre of Rohingyas in Myanmar. Cadwalladr's award-winning article showed the world the face of the whistleblower who created a tool used by the former Trump adviser, Steve Bannon, to harness data to target political advertising at voters. Christopher Wylie, after choosing to waive his anonymity, said he helped to put together "Steve Bannon's psychological warfare mindfuck tool" while working for the political consultancy, Cambridge Analytica. "It's insane. The company has created psychological profiles of 230 million Americans. And now they want to work with the Pentagon? It's like Nixon on steroids," Cadwalladr quoted Wylie as saying. The award recognizes Cadwalladr's tireless efforts to uncover the truth behind the Cambridge Analytica scandal, which has had far-reaching implications for the integrity of democracy and the protection of personal data. The article's impact was immediate, sparking widespread outrage and calls for accountability from government officials, tech giants, and the public. Cadwalladr's reporting has also led to multiple investigations, lawsuits, and Congressional hearings, ultimately resulting in the shutdown of Cambridge Analytica and the resignation of several high-ranking officials. This prestigious award is a testament to Cadwalladr's dedication to investigative journalism and her commitment to shedding light on the darkest corners of power. The Foreign Press Association's decision to honor Cadwalladr's work is a reminder that journalism has the power to hold those in power accountable and to inspire positive change.

The ABC is reporting that its former managing director Michelle Guthrie has received a payout of more than $800,000 after being terminated by the public broadcaster, but is still suing for more. An ABC spokesperson said the termination payment was made to Guthrie in line with her contractual entitlements. Guardian Australia understands it was determined by the Remuneration Tribunal, which oversees federal public servants' pay. The ABC said it had confirmed the sum from people involved in the negotiations. Guthrie was terminated by the board just two years into her five-year term as managing director. It has since emerged that she clashed with the former chairman Justin Milne over a number of issues and Guthrie alleged Milne had pressured her to take account of political sensitivities in Canberra. The payout is expected to be a significant relief to Guthrie, who has been vocal about her treatment by the ABC and its board. Her lawyers have been seeking a larger sum, citing "substantial losses" she allegedly suffered as a result of her termination. The exact nature of these losses is not clear, but it is understood that Guthrie is seeking compensation for what she claims was a "breach of contract" and "mental distress" caused by her departure. The ABC has maintained that Guthrie's termination was justified and that she was treated fairly throughout the process. The dispute is set to continue, with a court date scheduled for later this year. Meanwhile, the ABC has been under pressure to explain its handling of Guthrie's departure, with some critics calling for greater transparency and accountability. The corporation has promised to provide more information about the circumstances surrounding Guthrie's termination, but has so far been tight-lipped about the details.

Nasa engineers will on Monday initiate a manoeuvre that is their least favourite activity in space: they will attempt to land a robot spaceship on Mars. In this case they will attempt to set down their probe, InSight, gently on to an area known as Elysium Planitia where it is intended to analyse seismic activity on the red planet. More probes have been sent to Mars than any other planet in the solar system but more than half of these missions have ended in failure, with the final stages, involving landing gently on the Martian surface, proving to be particularly dangerous and unsuccessful. The thin atmosphere on Mars – just 1% of Earth's – means there is little friction to slow down a spacecraft, and that has played a key role in past failures. Hence the nervousness of Nasa engineers who are directing their $800m InSight craft after a 300 million-mile journey at a tiny target zone in the planet's atmosphere measuring a mere 15 miles by 6 miles. If InSight passes through this keyhole precisely then it ought to land in the middle of the Elysium Planitia, though it will still need a heat-resistant capsule, a parachute and rockets to cut its velocity from 12,000mph to 5mph and ensure it arrives softly and safely after a seven-minute descent. The team at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, California, will be monitoring the spacecraft's descent closely, with their hearts racing as they wait to see if InSight will successfully touch down on Martian soil. If all goes according to plan, the probe will send back a series of signals to Earth, indicating its safe landing and deployment of its instruments. Once on the surface, InSight will begin to collect data on Mars' internal structure, providing valuable insights into the planet's formation and evolution. The mission is a critical step towards understanding the Red Planet's potential for supporting life, and NASA engineers are eager to see their hard work pay off. With the world watching, they will be holding their breath as InSight makes its historic landing on Mars.

Mexican tetra Researchers in Mexico last week described how they are studying cave-dwelling tetra fish to better understand why some animals can regenerate tissue but others can't. The scientists performed surgery to remove some of the heart of river fish and cave fish from the species Astyanax mexicanus, finding that while some river fish do regenerate tissue, the cave fish just grew scars over the damage. Salamander The amphibious salamander can regrow a lost tail to full length. This process sees cells migrating to the wound and then slowly regenerating the tail within a few weeks. The finished appendage is completely functional and has all the features of the original, with the spinal cord and nerves growing back too. Axolotl A relative of the salamander but even more skilled at regenerating is the axolotl. This animal can regenerate not just its tail but also limbs, skin and almost any other body part. The researchers hope that by studying the cave-dwelling tetra fish, they can uncover the secrets behind their inability to regenerate tissue. "We want to understand why some animals have this amazing ability to regenerate, while others don't," said Dr. Maria Rodriguez, lead researcher on the project. "By comparing the two species, we may be able to identify the key genetic or molecular mechanisms that allow some animals to regenerate, but not others." The team is also studying the salamander and axolotl, which are known for their impressive regenerative abilities. The salamander's ability to regrow its tail is well-documented, but the axolotl's capacity to regenerate entire limbs and body parts is less well-understood. "The axolotl is like a superhero of regeneration," said Dr. Rodriguez. "We're hoping to learn from its incredible abilities and apply that knowledge to human medicine." The researchers believe that understanding how these animals regenerate tissue could lead to breakthroughs in human tissue engineering and regenerative medicine.

Crispin Odey's share of the profit of his hedge fund has fallen by £4m, as various bets made by the Brexit-backing billionaire against the UK economy and British businesses failed to pay off. Odey collected £1.5m from Odey Asset Management in the year to 5 April, a 72% decline on the £5.5m he made in the previous 12 months, according to accounts filed at Companies House. The hedge fund he founded in 1991 reported a 52% fall in profit to £8.8m, as Odey's bets against the pound and a raft of UK retailers failed to immediately bear fruit. Odey Asset Management has declared £149m of short positions against UK shops, banks, estate agents and property companies. Despite the disappointing performance, Odey Asset Management's assets under management have remained steady at £12.3 billion, a testament to the fund's reputation and long-standing relationships with clients. However, the firm's struggles have raised concerns among investors about the wisdom of betting against the UK economy and its businesses.

Industry insiders have questioned Odey's strategy, pointing out that his short positions against UK retailers, banks, and property companies have failed to yield significant returns. "Crispin's approach has been to bet against the UK's economic prospects, but it seems that his predictions have been consistently wrong," said a senior investment manager at a rival fund. "His short positions have been a major drag on the fund's performance, and it's unclear whether he's adjusted his strategy to reflect the changing economic landscape."

Odey's difficulties have also sparked debate about the role of hedge funds in the UK economy. Some have argued that funds like Odey Asset Management, which take short positions against British businesses, are doing little to promote economic growth and stability. "Hedge funds like Odey's are essentially betting against the UK's success, which can have a destabilizing effect on the market," said a leading economist. "We need to encourage investment in the UK, not create an environment where investors are incentivized to bet against our economy."

In response to the criticism, Odey's team has defended their strategy, citing the fund's strong track record and the need for contrarian views in the market. "We're not trying to tank the UK economy, but we believe that our short positions are a necessary counterbalance to the prevailing optimism," said a spokesperson for Odey Asset Management. "We're confident that our strategy will ultimately pay off, and we're committed to continuing to provide our clients with the best possible returns."

Thousands of people plugging in new smart speakers on Christmas Day were greeted by a less than smart response after Amazon's voice-controlled virtual assistant Alexa crashed. Servers controlling the digital butler were overloaded with questions and requests, prompting Alexa to tell some users: "Sorry, I'm having trouble understanding you right now." The crash, at about 10am GMT, caused Amazon customers to complain about not being able to play festive songs, turn on their living room lights or get cooking instructions for Christmas dinner. Richard Hyland tweeted: "Good day for Amazon's Alexa to crash. It's not like people might want to register new devices or play music or anything." Alexa works by sending voice commands via an Amazon Echo device to a server, where a computer interprets them. The outage was met with frustration from many users, who had high hopes for a seamless and enjoyable Christmas Day experience with their new smart speakers. "I was really looking forward to using my new Alexa to play some festive tunes and get some help with cooking dinner, but instead I'm stuck staring at a screen with a bunch of error messages," said Sarah Jenkins, a disappointed customer. Amazon's Alexa support team was quickly overwhelmed with complaints and queries, and many users were left waiting for hours for assistance. The company later confirmed that the issue was due to an unexpected surge in traffic, and apologized for the inconvenience. In a statement, Amazon said: "We're sorry for the trouble this has caused and are working hard to get things back to normal as soon as possible." As the day went on, Alexa slowly began to return to normal, but not before many users had taken to social media to express their disappointment and frustration. Despite the hiccup, Amazon's Alexa remains one of the most popular virtual assistants on the market, and the company is expected to bounce back from the outage quickly.

Range Rover Evoque Price £31,600 Deliveries expected spring 2019 I've never been much good at spotting a clear winner. And when it comes to car aesthetics I am often seriously out of step with vehicle designers. I'd say that the three ugliest cars of the past decade are the Porsche Cayenne, Nissan Juke and Range Rover Evoque. Yet all three have gone on to become massive successes. Now, the all-new Evoque is here and the latest version of the baby Range Rover is probably going to be even more popular than the last. But what's behind the Evoque's enduring appeal? Is it the way it looks, despite my own reservations? Or is it something more? The answer lies in its unique blend of style, substance, and technology. The new Evoque boasts a sleeker, more chiseled design, with a more aggressive stance and a more premium feel. The interior is equally impressive, with luxurious materials and a state-of-the-art infotainment system. But it's not just about looks - the Evoque is also a capable off-roader, with a wade-sensing system and a range of advanced traction control systems.

Under the bonnet, the Evoque gets a range of efficient engines, including a 2.0-litre turbocharged petrol unit and a 2.0-litre diesel. And with a claimed fuel economy of up to 47.1mpg, it's clear that Range Rover is serious about making the Evoque a practical choice for those who want a stylish and capable SUV. With deliveries expected to start in spring 2019, the all-new Evoque is set to be a major player in the premium SUV market. And who knows - maybe I'll even learn to appreciate its good looks.

Every week a Guardian Money reader submits a question, and it's up to you to help him or her out – a selection of the best answers will appear in next Saturday's paper. We've got lots of old sash windows in our house, which we are replacing slowly and at great cost. While we save up to get the next lot done, does anyone have any tips for dealing with draughty sash windows? What temporary (and cheap) patch-ups have you used to cut out the draughts? "We've tried using draught excluders, but they don't quite do the trick. Some readers have suggested using old towels or blankets to block the gaps, while others have recommended applying weatherstripping or caulk to seal the joints. One clever solution is to use magnetic door seals, which can be cut to size and stuck to the windows to create a tight seal. We'd love to hear more ideas from your readers to help us stay warm and cozy until we can replace our old sash windows for good."

Cash-strapped households provided most of Britain's growth in the three months to September, as businesses cut investment again amid fears over Brexit. Official figures confirmed the economy bounced back from the freezing temperatures earlier in the year as shoppers spent heavily during the football World Cup and a long heatwave. But more detailed data from the Office for National Statistics (ONS) showed that consumers, hit by rising utility bills and transport costs, had to cope with almost static disposable incomes, forcing them to dip into savings to maintain their spending habits. The ONS statistician Rob Kent-Smith said households spent more than they received for an unprecedented eighth quarter in a row, raising questions about their ability to keep on spending and driving the country's economy. More recent surveys have appeared to fuel concerns that consumer spending is running out of steam, with a string of high street retailers saying November was a terrible month for sales. A profit warning from the online retailer Asos shocked analysts that had grown used to web-based operators riding out the spending downturn. Business investment fell for the third consecutive quarter. The gloomy outlook for consumer spending has sparked concerns about the sustainability of the UK's economic growth. Economists are warning that the country's reliance on consumer spending to drive growth is unsustainable, and that a boost from business investment is desperately needed to drive long-term growth. The decline in business investment, coupled with stagnant wages and rising costs, has led some to question whether the UK's economy is heading for a period of slower growth or even recession.

The Bank of England has been monitoring the situation closely, and some policymakers are urging the government to take action to stimulate business investment and boost productivity. The Chancellor, Philip Hammond, has announced plans to increase funding for research and development, and has also promised to review the tax system to make it more attractive to businesses.

Despite these efforts, many experts believe that the UK's economic prospects remain uncertain, and that the country is at risk of falling into a period of slow growth or even recession if business investment does not pick up. The UK's departure from the EU, known as Brexit, is also expected to have a significant impact on the economy, and many businesses are holding back on investment until the outcome of the negotiations is clearer.

The BBC's central London headquarters has been put on lockdown due to a protest by climate change campaigners who are demanding it uses its status as national broadcaster to declare a "climate and ecological emergency". Extinction Rebellion, a direct action group that has recently shut down key London roads, has demand the BBC makes the environment its "top editorial issue". Broadcasting House was locked down early on Friday afternoon, with BBC staff and guests unable to enter or leave the building while security kept the peaceful but noisy protesters away from the entrance. Extinction Rebellion activists, who are demanding a meeting with the BBC director general, Tony Hall, said the corporation had a duty to broadcast about climate change with "the level of urgency placed on informing the public about the second world war". The broadcaster Anneka Rice said she was stuck in the BBC reception "with Simon Mayo, Ken Bruce and three policemen" during the protest. Extinction Rebellion also organised protests on Friday at BBC offices in Bristol, Glasgow, Cambridge, Birmingham, Truro, Sheffield, Bangor, and the broadcaster's Berlin bureau. The campaign group launched two months ago, with a declaration of support from public figures including the former archbishop of Canterbury Rowan Williams, who backed a campaign of civil disobedience to draw attention to the threat of climate and ecological change. Since then, Extinction Rebellion activists have blocked bridges and glued themselves to the gates of Downing Street, earning media attention that has allowed the campaign to spread to 35 overseas countries. The BBC has been criticised for its coverage of climate change, especially the decision to give airtime to climate change sceptics such as Lord Lawson, who oppose the scientific consensus. The protesters, who were mainly young adults, held signs that read "Climate Emergency Now" and "BBC, Tell the Truth". They also chanted slogans, including "What do we want? Climate action! When do we want it? Now!" and "The science is clear, act now, not later!" The atmosphere was peaceful, but the noise level was high, with the protesters determined to make their voices heard.

The BBC has faced criticism in the past for its coverage of climate change, with some accusing the corporation of not taking the issue seriously enough. The corporation has also been accused of giving airtime to climate change sceptics, such as Lord Lawson, who oppose the scientific consensus on the issue.

The protesters, who were mostly from Extinction Rebellion, a direct action group that has been behind several high-profile protests in London, said they were demanding that the BBC use its platform to raise awareness about the climate crisis. They claimed that the corporation had a duty to broadcast about climate change with the same level of urgency as it did during World War II.

The protesters also called for the BBC to stop giving airtime to climate change sceptics and to instead focus on reporting the facts about the climate crisis. They said that the corporation had a responsibility to inform the public about the urgent need for action on climate change.

The lockdown at Broadcasting House was expected to last for several hours, with the protesters vowing to continue their protest until their demands were met. The BBC has so far refused to comment on the protest, but the corporation has been accused of not taking the issue of climate change seriously enough. The protest is the latest in a series of high-profile demonstrations in London, and it is expected to draw attention to the issue of climate change.

Amazon, the world's largest company by market capitalisation, reported improved earnings and profits late on Thursday. The company reported its third record profit in a row, capitalizing on a strong holiday retail season and its growing, high-margin businesses such as cloud computing and advertising. The Seattle-based company reported a profit of $3.03bn, or $6.04 a share, up from $1.86bn, or $3.75 a share, on the same quarter a year earlier. Revenue grew 20% to $72.38bn. Amazon's voice-controlled virtual assistant Alexa, and the devices which play it, helped the performance. "Alexa was very busy during her holiday season. Echo Dot was the best-selling item across all products on Amazon globally, and customers purchased millions more devices from the Echo family compared to last year," Jeff Bezos, Amazon founder and CEO, said in a statement. Most importantly for investors, Amazon's cloud-computing division said revenue jumped 45% in the fourth quarter, cementing its lead over Google and Microsoft. The division has been growing at 40% per annum and is a high margin business compared to retail. The strong performance of Amazon's cloud-computing division is expected to continue, with the company forecasting revenue growth of 40% to 50% in the current quarter. The division, known as Amazon Web Services (AWS), has become a key driver of Amazon's growth and profitability, and its dominance in the cloud-computing market has made it a major threat to traditional tech giants such as Microsoft and Google. In addition to its strong financial performance, Amazon also announced a number of new products and services, including a new smart speaker called Echo Frames, which features a built-in display and can be used to control other smart devices in the home. The company also announced a new subscription service called Amazon Fresh, which offers customers same-day delivery of fresh produce and other groceries. Overall, Amazon's strong earnings report and forecast have sent its stock price soaring, with shares up over 5% in after-hours trading.

British car production dropped to a five-year low in 2018, as manufacturers warned that fears of a no-deal Brexit have prompted a slump in new investment. UK car factories produced 1.52m vehicles last year, 9.1% fewer than 2017, according to figures published on Thursday by the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT), the UK auto industry lobby group. Production for the British market fell by 16.3%. Investment into British car manufacturing almost halved during the year to £588.6m, a fall which the SMMT blamed on Brexit uncertainty. Publicly announced investments were lower than in any year since 2012, the first year comparable data was collected. "Investment is effectively stalled," said Mike Hawes, the SMMT's chief executive. "Industry is waiting to see what happens. The decline in investment has led to concerns about the long-term viability of the UK's car manufacturing industry. Many manufacturers have already announced plans to reduce production or shift production to other countries in the event of a no-deal Brexit.

"The uncertainty surrounding Brexit is having a significant impact on our business," said a spokesperson for Jaguar Land Rover, which produced 1.3 million vehicles in the UK last year. "We are taking steps to mitigate the risks, but ultimately, the outcome of Brexit will determine our future investment plans."

The SMMT is urging the government to provide clarity on the UK's post-Brexit trade arrangements and to negotiate a deal that would prevent a no-deal scenario. "The government needs to take urgent action to address the uncertainty and provide a stable environment for investment," said Hawes.

The decline in car production has also had a ripple effect on the wider economy. According to the SMMT, the UK's car industry supports over 800,000 jobs, both directly and indirectly. The decline in production has led to concerns about job losses and a potential impact on economic growth.

The news has also sparked concerns about the UK's ability to meet its environmental targets. The car industry is a significant contributor to the UK's carbon emissions, and a decline in production could make it more difficult to meet the government's goals.

The UK's car industry has faced a number of challenges in recent years, including the shift towards electric vehicles and the impact of diesel emissions scandals. However, the decline in investment and production is a new and worrying trend.

As the government and industry stakeholders work to address the challenges facing the UK's car industry, there is a growing sense of urgency. The industry needs clarity and stability to continue investing and growing, and the government needs to take action to provide that. As the Brexit deadline looms, the future of the UK's car industry hangs in the balance.

Social media is often accused of presenting an airbrushed fantasy rather than a slice of realism, so it is refreshing to see the likes of Kate Beckinsale and Nicky Campbell embrace the "hospital selfie", which involves tweeting photos from their hospital beds. (Alas, the Daily Mail's Sarah Vine isn't a fan, writing in her latest column: "Why the rest of us have to suffer I don't know.") In the past two months, I have spent four days in hospital, and tweeted selfies on both occasions. There were many reasons: I tweet and post on Instagram a lot; I enjoy it; my friends interact with me; it's how we keep abreast of each other's lives. It helps us feel connected. They know how I'm feeling and, because I am juvenile, they also know when my blood pressure is 69/100 – nice. Illness, especially chronic illness, can be very isolating. Not only does it limit how and when you can socialise, it causes you to feel unattractive. But by sharing my hospital selfies, I felt like I was pushing back against that isolation. It's a small act of defiance, but it's one that can make a big difference. By being open and honest about my experience, I hope to help others feel less alone. And, let's be real, it's also a great way to get some sympathy and support from friends and family.

Of course, not everyone understands the appeal of the hospital selfie. Some people might think it's attention-seeking or even insensitive. But for me, it's the opposite. It's a way of saying, "I'm still here, I'm still me, and I'm still worthy of connection and care, even when I'm feeling at my most vulnerable."

As I lay in my hospital bed, snapping selfies and sending them out into the world, I felt a sense of freedom and empowerment. It's a strange thing to say, but being sick can be a real ego-buster. You start to feel like you're losing your identity, like you're just a patient, not a person. But by sharing my experience, I'm reclaiming that identity. I'm saying, "I'm still me, and I'm still worth sharing with the world."

Vodafone has been named the most-complained about broadband and landline provider in a quarterly league table compiled by the media and broadcasting regulator Ofcom. Vodafone topped the list on the very first time it featured, having only just become eligible for inclusion in the survey. The mobile phone company, which started offering broadband and landline services in 2015, was part of the customer survey for the three months to the end of September after reaching the benchmark of 1.5% market share. Vodafone's broadband service received 27 complaints per 100,000 subscribers, almost double the industry average of 15, with customers citing issues including changing provider, handling faults and service. The company's landline service received 19 complaints per 100,000 subscribers, above the industry average of 11, over a similar range of issues. "Vodafone will be feeling the heat," said Ernest Doku, telecoms analyst at uSwitch.com. The poor performance of Vodafone's broadband and landline services has sparked concerns among consumer groups and industry experts. "This is a wake-up call for Vodafone to take a hard look at its customer service and quality of service," said Tom Bennett, a consumer advocate. "Complaints are a key indicator of customer satisfaction, and Vodafone's high levels of complaints suggest that it has some serious work to do to get its house in order." Ofcom's league table also showed that Vodafone's competitors, including BT, Sky, and TalkTalk, performed better in terms of customer complaints. BT, which has long been a market leader, received just 10 complaints per 100,000 subscribers, while Sky and TalkTalk received 12 and 13 complaints per 100,000 subscribers, respectively. Vodafone's poor showing is likely to put pressure on the company to improve its services and customer support, or risk losing customers to its more reliable competitors.

It is a 100% mortgage but not, thank goodness, as we once knew them. Lloyds Bank's new Lend a Hand mortgage offers first-time buyers the chance to borrow the entire price of their new home – but with the considerable caveat that a relative has to have a lump sum worth 10% that they are willing to tie up for three years, and have it raided if you miss any payments. So, first up: this is no use at all for anyone without a family member with a chunk of cash they don't need, willing to help them on to the housing ladder. But nor is it the return of the bumper mortgage market we saw in the run-up to the financial crash, where loans of up to 125% were available (leaving some borrowers trapped in negative equity after the downturn). There is still careful thinking to be done before taking on a mortgage this size – and never more so than now, with uncertainty over Brexit clouding the market. Lloyds' deal offers a mortgage of up to £500,000, which can be arranged over up to 30 years. However, the bank is keen to stress that this is a "responsible" mortgage, designed to help first-time buyers get on the housing ladder while also providing a safety net for both the borrower and the lender. The idea is that the relative's lump sum will act as a kind of "buffer" against the risk of default, making it more likely that the borrower will be able to keep up with their mortgage payments.

But what exactly does this mean for the borrower? For one thing, it means that they will need to have a good credit history and a stable income in order to qualify for the mortgage. They will also need to have a decent deposit to put down, although this can be as little as 5% of the purchase price. And, of course, they will need to have a relative who is willing and able to provide the 10% lump sum.

One of the key benefits of this mortgage is that it can help to reduce the amount of debt that the borrower needs to take on. By using the relative's lump sum as a kind of "collateral", the bank is able to offer a larger mortgage than it would otherwise be able to. This can be particularly helpful for first-time buyers who may not have a lot of savings or other assets to put towards a deposit.

But there are also some potential downsides to consider. For one thing, the borrower will need to be aware that the relative's lump sum is tied up for three years, and can be raided if they miss any mortgage payments. This means that the relative may not be able to access their own money during that time, which could be a problem if they need it for other expenses or emergencies.

Additionally, the borrower will need to be careful about making sure that they can keep up with their mortgage payments. If they miss a payment, the relative's lump sum could be used to pay off the debt, which could have serious consequences for their relationship. And if the borrower is unable to get back on track, they could end up losing their home.

Overall, Lloyds Bank's new Lend a Hand mortgage is a complex and innovative product that offers first-time buyers a chance to get on the housing ladder with a relatively small deposit. But it's not without its risks and challenges, and borrowers will need to be careful and responsible in order to make the most of it.

They may have had more than a sneaking suspicion that it was the case, but now working mothers have the data to back it up: they are indeed more stressed than other people – 18% more, in fact. And that figure rises to 40% for those with two children, according to a major study that analysed 11 key indicators of chronic stress levels. Professor Tarani Chandola, of Manchester University, and Dr Cara Booker, Professor Meena Kumari and Professor Michaela Benzeval, of the Institute for Social and Economic Research at Essex University, examined biological data taken by nurses from 6,025 participants in the UK Household Longitudinal Survey, the largest survey of its kind in the world. They adjusted the raw data to exclude other factors that could influence their findings, such as the women's ages, ethnicity, education, occupation and income, allowing them to focus solely on working hours and family conditions. According to their research, just published in the journal Sociology, neither working from home nor flexitime had an effect on women's chronic stress levels. But reducing the number of hours they worked did have a positive impact. "Work-family conflict is associated with increased psychological strain, with higher levels of stress and lower levels of wellbeing," Chandola said. "Parents of young children are at particular risk of work-family conflict. Working conditions that are not flexible to these family demands, such as long working hours, could adversely impact on a person's stress reactions." Overall, the 11 indicators, known as "biomarkers", produce something called an "allostatic load", a measure of the cumulative wear and tear on the body's physiological systems, which can indicate poor health and a greater risk of death. The study's findings suggest that working mothers are more likely to experience chronic stress, which can have long-term consequences for their physical and mental health. The researchers used a range of biomarkers, including cortisol levels, blood pressure, and heart rate, to measure the cumulative wear and tear on the body's physiological systems. They found that working mothers had higher levels of stress hormones, such as cortisol, and were more likely to experience inflammation and cardiovascular disease.

The study's lead author, Professor Tarani Chandola, said that the results were concerning and highlighted the need for employers to provide more flexible working arrangements to support working mothers. "Our findings suggest that working mothers are more likely to experience chronic stress, which can have serious consequences for their health and wellbeing," she said. "Employers have a crucial role to play in supporting working mothers and should consider providing flexible working arrangements, such as telecommuting or job sharing, to help them manage their work and family responsibilities."

The researchers also found that the impact of chronic stress on working mothers was not limited to their own health. They found that children of working mothers were also more likely to experience stress and anxiety, which can have long-term consequences for their own health and wellbeing. "Working mothers are not just affected by their own stress levels, but also by the stress levels of their children," said Professor Chandola. "This highlights the need for employers to consider the impact of work on families and to provide support to working mothers and their children."

Britain's biggest retailers and wholesalers have raised their stockpiling efforts to the highest levels since the 2008 financial crisis, according to a key industry report, with little more than 60 days to go before Brexit. According to the latest snapshot from the Confederation of British Industry's monthly distributive trades survey, retail businesses raised the ratio of their stocks to expected sales in January to the highest level since February 2008. The report, which is closely monitored by the Bank of England for early warning signs from the UK economy, said retailers expected demand to fall and had built up stocks in case the UK exits the EU without a deal. A growing number of companies have begun ramping up their plans for a potentially disruptive no-deal Brexit at the end of March, with Westminster still gridlocked since Theresa May suffered the biggest government defeat in history over her Brexit plan. Firms including Bentley, the luxury carmaker, and retailers such as Dixons Carphone and Pets at Home have announced plans to shore up supplies in the event of chaos at British ports. Rain Newton-Smith, chief economist at the CBI, said: "There are early signs of companies bracing themselves for a no-deal Brexit: some of our wholesalers are now reporting that they're building up stocks in case the UK exits the EU without a deal." The CBI distributive trades survey, which has run since 1983, surveyed 103 retailers, wholesalers and motor traders between 27 December and 14 January. The report also highlighted that retailers' expectations for the coming months have taken a turn for the worse, with a significant drop in confidence in the UK's economic outlook. The CBI's optimism index, which measures retailers' expectations for the next three months, fell to its lowest level since October 2011. The survey found that 27% of retailers expected their sales to fall in the coming quarter, while only 12% expected them to rise.

Meanwhile, wholesalers reported a sharp decline in their expectations for the coming months, with 35% expecting a decline in sales and only 11% expecting an increase. The CBI's report comes as the UK government struggles to agree on a Brexit deal, with just over a month to go before the country is set to leave the EU. The uncertainty surrounding Brexit has led to a significant increase in stockpiling, with many companies seeking to mitigate the risks of a no-deal Brexit.

The CBI's report is the latest in a series of warnings from businesses about the potential impact of a no-deal Brexit. Last week, the UK's largest trade association, the British Chambers of Commerce, warned that a no-deal Brexit would lead to a "disaster" for the UK economy. The CBI's report is likely to add to the pressure on the government to agree a deal, as businesses continue to sound the alarm about the potential risks of a no-deal Brexit.

Netflix is seeing off Amazon's challenge to its streaming supremacy, by adding double the number of UK subscribers than its rival and is now in almost 10m homes. Netflix, which is up for 15 Oscars including best picture and director for Roma, hit 9.7m UK subscribers at the end of the third quarter last year, according to a new report from TV measurement body Barb.
