The report estimates that rival Amazon's Prime Video service is only just over half the size of Netflix in the UK - with 4.9m users - with Netflix continuing to extend its lead. Netflix UK added 2.2m new subscribers in the year to the end of the third quarter 2018, double the 1.1m Amazon added, growing at almost 30% in the third quarter. "Change is afoot as subscription video-on-demand services continue to cement their place in the television ecosystem," said Barb. The report also highlighted the growing importance of streaming services in the UK's television landscape, with 43% of adults now using a subscription video-on-demand (SVOD) service, up from 35% in 2017. This shift has significant implications for traditional broadcasters, who are struggling to adapt to the changing viewing habits of audiences.

The data also shows that Netflix's dominance is not limited to the UK, with the service boasting over 220 million subscribers worldwide. In contrast, Amazon's Prime Video service has around 100 million subscribers globally.

Industry experts are hailing Netflix's success as a sign of the company's ability to adapt to changing consumer habits and its willingness to invest in original content. "Netflix's success is a testament to its commitment to producing high-quality, original content that resonates with audiences," said media analyst, David Banks. "It's a model that other streaming services are struggling to replicate."

The report also highlights the growing competition in the streaming market, with Disney's upcoming service, Disney+, set to launch later this year. Disney has already secured a deal with Sky to offer its service to millions of UK households, and experts are predicting that it will pose a significant challenge to Netflix's dominance.

As the streaming wars continue to heat up, it remains to be seen whether Netflix can maintain its lead or whether Amazon and other rivals can catch up. One thing is certain, however, is that the traditional television landscape will continue to be disrupted by the rise of streaming services.

Metro Bank shares plunged to fresh lows on Wednesday, after the lender shocked markets with plans to raise a further £350m just months after its last cash call. The high street challenger also revealed that it is under investigation by City regulators, the Financial Conduct Authority and Prudential Regulation Authority, over a major accounting failure first disclosed last month. The announcements were made alongside the bank's annual results on Tuesday night. Metro Bank's share price slumped once again on Wednesday and was down more than 26% at about 950p shortly before the London market closed. The company's shares have lost 50% of their value since the accounting issue was announced. The lender confirmed in January that hundreds of millions of pounds of commercial property loans and loans to commercial buy-to-let operators had been wrongly classified in risk terms and should have been among its "risk-weighted assets" (RWAs). While the bank originally suggested it had uncovered the issue on its own, it later emerged the error was caught by the PRA. The accounting failure has sparked concerns about the bank's ability to manage its risk and its financial stability. Analysts have warned that the bank's capital position may be weaker than previously thought, and that the additional funding it is seeking may not be enough to cover its exposure to problem loans.

Metro Bank's CEO, Daniel Zabrocki, attempted to reassure investors during a conference call on Wednesday, saying that the bank is taking "swift and decisive action" to address the issue and that it is "fully committed" to rectifying the problem. However, investors remained skeptical, with many expressing concerns about the bank's lack of transparency and its failure to disclose the accounting error sooner.

The bank's chairman, Vernon Hill, also came under fire for his role in the debacle, with some investors questioning his leadership and judgment. Hill has been a vocal critic of the banking industry and has been a driving force behind Metro Bank's aggressive expansion strategy.

Despite the chaos, Metro Bank remains committed to its expansion plans, with the bank announcing plans to open 20 new branches this year. However, many analysts are questioning whether the bank's business model is sustainable, given its high level of debt and its exposure to the commercial property market.

The Financial Conduct Authority and Prudential Regulation Authority are expected to complete their investigation into Metro Bank's accounting practices in the coming weeks. The outcome of the investigation could have significant implications for the bank's future, and could potentially lead to further penalties and fines. In the meantime, investors will be closely watching the bank's progress and will be looking for signs of improvement before they consider returning to the stock.

Retail workers in Britain are more likely to face unemployment rather than finding another job amid mounting numbers of job losses on the high street, with younger staff hardest hit, according to a report. The study by the Resolution Foundation thinktank found the retail industry now has the highest rate of redundancies of any sector of the economy, amid the rapid rise of shop closures across the country. The analysis comes as growing numbers of UK retailers announce job cuts and store closures across the country, with losses at major high street employers such as M&S, Debenhams and HMV. Growth in consumer spending eased last year, worsened by the rise in inflation that followed the Brexit vote, while changing spending habits and a move online have also harmed traditional bricks-and-mortar stores, which typically employ greater numbers of workers. In a worrying signal for retail workers facing redundancy, the Resolution Foundation said as many as 31% exit their roles straight into unemployment, rather than into another job, compared to the average of 26% for all areas of the economy. Two in five ex-retail staff are unemployed for at least six months, with greater risks for younger workers. As many as three in five former retail workers are under the age of 30 – despite barely a third of the workforce being in this age bracket. Daniel Tomlinson, research and policy analyst at the Resolution Foundation, said: "Life has become tougher for those leaving retail, who are more likely to find themselves unemployed – and for longer, too. The report highlights the alarming trend of retail workers being pushed into long-term unemployment, with many struggling to find new employment opportunities. The thinktank's findings suggest that the sector's high rate of redundancies is having a disproportionate impact on younger workers, who are more likely to be stuck in unemployment for extended periods.

According to the Resolution Foundation, the average length of unemployment for former retail workers is around 12 weeks, compared to 9 weeks for the overall economy. Moreover, the report reveals that nearly half of all former retail workers are still looking for work after six months, with many facing significant challenges in finding new employment.

The study's findings are likely to be of particular concern to policymakers, who are grappling with the ongoing impact of the retail crisis on the UK economy. The government has been criticized for its lack of action to support struggling retailers and their employees, with many calling for urgent intervention to mitigate the effects of the crisis.

As the retail sector continues to shrink, the consequences for workers are becoming increasingly dire. The Resolution Foundation's report serves as a stark reminder of the need for policymakers to take swift and decisive action to support those affected by the crisis, and to help the industry adapt to the changing retail landscape.

British tourists to Spain could face airport queues of five hours or more after a no-deal Brexit, according to analysis by Which?, and the consumer group suggests travellers should take food, water and even nappies to survive prolonged delays. Alicante airport, which serves Benidorm and other Costa Blanca resorts, is likely to be the worst-affected airport, and Which? said visitors to Tenerife, Lanzarote and Málaga were also facing "life in the slow lane". It calculated that if airports spent only 90 seconds making extra checks on each UK passport, it would take a single passport lane in an EU airport five hours longer to process a Ryanair flight with 189 UK passengers on board. Alicante is likely to be worst hit because 43% of its arrivals are from the UK. Even in February, the airport processes as many as 10 planes from the UK in a single hour. In total, 2.9 million British passport holders go through the airport each year. The potential for chaos at Alicante airport has sparked concerns among British tourists, with many already planning their trips to the Costa Blanca. "I'm getting married in Benidorm in June and I'm terrified about the queues," said Sarah Johnson, a bride-to-be from Manchester. "I've already started stockpiling snacks and water, just in case. I hope it's not as bad as they're saying, but I'm not taking any chances."

Other travelers are also taking precautions, with some planning to arrive at the airport even earlier than usual to try and beat the queues. "I'm going to get there at 4am, just to be safe," said Mark Davis, a regular visitor to the Costa Blanca. "I've got a coffee and some breakfast in my bag, and I'm prepared to wait. But five hours is a long time - I just hope they get the queues sorted out soon."

The Spanish government has so far refused to comment on the potential impact of a no-deal Brexit on airport queues, but Which? is urging the UK and Spanish authorities to work together to find a solution. "This is a crisis waiting to happen," said Alex Neill, Which?'s home and travel expert. "We're calling on the government to take immediate action to prevent these delays and ensure that British tourists can enjoy their holidays without being stuck in endless queues."

In the meantime, travelers are being advised to check with their airlines and tour operators for the latest information and advice on how to minimize the impact of any delays. With just weeks to go before the Brexit deadline, many are holding their breath and hoping for a solution that will avoid the chaos and disruption that a no-deal Brexit could bring.

Hammerson, which owns shopping centres including Birmingham's Bullring and London's Brent Cross, is in talks to sell off more than £900m of property after being hit by the crisis in Britain's retail sector. The FTSE 250-listed firm said it was in active discussions to offload more than £900m of assets, far exceeding its £500m target for 2019. Last year it sold off £570m of property, with the average price 7% below the book value in December 2017. Hammerson is under pressure from an activist investor, the US hedge fund Elliott Advisors, which owns a 5% stake in the company, to speed up disposals, after a 9.3% decline in its property values in 2018. Among Hammerson's tenants are Patisserie Valerie, which went into administration last month but was saved from closure by a management buyout backed by an Irish private equity firm, as well as House of Fraser and New Look. The company's struggles in the retail sector have been well-documented, with many of its tenants facing financial difficulties. In addition to Patisserie Valerie, House of Fraser and New Look, Hammerson also counts Toys "R" Us and Carpetright among its tenants, both of which have gone into administration in recent years.

Hammerson's decision to offload more than £900m of property is seen as a desperate attempt to shore up its finances and appease its activist investor, Elliott Advisors. The company's shares have fallen by more than 30% over the past year, and its debt levels have increased significantly.

Industry insiders suggest that Hammerson is likely to focus on selling off its non-core assets, such as office buildings and car parks, in order to free up capital and reduce its debt burden. The company has already made significant progress in this area, having sold off £570m of property last year.

However, the company's efforts to restructure its portfolio and reduce its debt levels are likely to be met with resistance from its lenders, who are unlikely to agree to any significant reduction in debt without seeing a significant improvement in Hammerson's financial performance.

Despite the challenges facing the company, some analysts believe that Hammerson's decision to offload more than £900m of property could ultimately be a blessing in disguise. By shedding its non-core assets, the company will be able to focus on its core retail business and potentially return to growth in the future.

What's going for it? Cromer is a very 1902 kind of place. One half expects to see a non-ironic mutton-chop or a waxed moustache in the queue at Morrisons, or Arthur Conan Doyle (awfully keen on Cromer) filling up his Prius at the petrol station. By the late 19th century, Cromer and its neighbours Overstrand and East Runton were hot, hot, hot, baby. Overstrand was called "village of millionaires", and the landscape hereabouts is to this day dotted with large piles done out in the style of the day – (pleasantly) watered-down arts and crafts. Last time I came, maybe a decade ago, the place was, shall we say, a little faded from its heyday. It's certainly got the Pledge out since. The municipal gardens sparkle. The streets busy themselves with independent shops. It's not without a bit of shabbiness, but all that was once great about Cromer remains: the crabs (obvs); the tower of St Peter and St Paul; the boarding houses clinging to the cliffs; those sweet lanes of fishermen's houses; and the fin-de-siècle pier, oh, the pier, the most end-of-the-pier pier in the country, at the extremity of Norfolk, with nothing but fishing boats, nor'easterlies and herring between the stage of its Pavilion theatre and Norway. The case against… It's a long way from anywhere but Norfolk. Coastal erosion is a problem in this neck of the woods. Well connected? Trains: hourly to Norwich (43 to 51 minutes), to change for the rest of the universe. Driving: 45 minutes to Norwich, 70 to King's Lynn. The nearest motorways are two hours away. Schools Primaries: Cromer Junior , The Belfry (Overstrand) and Suffield Park Infant and Nursery are all "good", says Ofsted. Secondaries: Cromer Academy is "good". Hang out at… The queue at Davies fish shop. Or slurping seafood ramen at Upstairs at No 1. or sipping a pint at the Red Lion, where the locals will regale you with tales of Cromer's rich history and the changing tides of the North Sea. And then, of course, there's the Cromer Pier Show, a stalwart of the summer season, featuring a mix of music, comedy, and variety acts that will leave you in stitches. But Cromer's not just about nostalgia; it's also a hub for outdoor enthusiasts. The Norfolk Coast Path runs right through the town, offering stunning views of the coastline and the chance to spot seals and seabirds. And for those who prefer their adventures on two wheels, the Cromer to Sheringham cycle route is a must-do, taking you along the scenic coastal road and through picturesque villages.

Despite its rural location, Cromer has a surprising number of cultural attractions. The Cromer Museum is a treasure trove of local history, with exhibits on everything from the town's role in the Napoleonic Wars to its 19th-century heyday as a popular seaside resort. And for art lovers, the Cromer Gallery is a must-visit, showcasing the work of local artists and craftspeople. But perhaps the most unique attraction in Cromer is the Cromer Lifeboat Station, which offers tours of the historic lifeboat and a chance to learn about the bravery of the town's lifeboat crew. All in all, Cromer may not be the most convenient place to visit, but it's certainly a gem worth discovering.

The largest number of King Tutankhamun treasures ever to leave Egypt are heading to London for an exhibition which organisers say will never happen again. It was announced on Thursday that the Saatchi Gallery in London will be the only UK venue for a world tour of 150 original artefacts from Tutankhamun's tomb, 60 of which have never left Egypt before. The tour marks the upcoming centenary of the sensational discovery of the boy pharaoh's tomb by British explorer Howard Carter in 1922. The objects will include a gold inlaid miniature coffin which contained the king's liver after it was removed during the mummification process, a gilded wooden bed with carved lion feet probably made specially for Tutankhamun's funeral and a gilded wooden shrine showing intimate scenes of royal domestic harmony. The exhibition, titled "Tutankhamun: Treasures of the Golden Pharaoh," is expected to be a major draw for tourists and history enthusiasts alike. The artifacts on display will include many of the treasures that were found in Tutankhamun's tomb, including his golden mask, which is considered one of the most iconic images in the world.

The exhibition will also feature a number of interactive displays and multimedia presentations that will allow visitors to learn more about the life and reign of Tutankhamun. Visitors will be able to explore a replica of the tomb, and see how the treasures were found and preserved.

The exhibition is being organized in partnership with the Egyptian Ministry of Antiquities and the Saatchi Gallery, and will be accompanied by a range of educational programs and events. These will include lectures, workshops, and guided tours, as well as a range of family-friendly activities.

The exhibition is expected to be a major boost for the Saatchi Gallery, which is located in the heart of London's cultural district. The gallery has a long history of hosting major exhibitions, and has previously hosted shows on topics such as the ancient Greeks and the Impressionists.

The exhibition will run from October 2019 to March 2020, and is expected to attract hundreds of thousands of visitors. It will be a major event in the cultural calendar, and is not to be missed.

In addition to the exhibition, the Saatchi Gallery will also be hosting a range of events and activities to celebrate the centenary of the discovery of Tutankhamun's tomb. These will include lectures, workshops, and guided tours, as well as a range of family-friendly activities.

The events will be led by a range of experts, including historians, archaeologists, and Egyptologists. They will provide visitors with a deeper understanding of the life and reign of Tutankhamun, as well as the history and culture of ancient Egypt.

The Saatchi Gallery is located in the heart of London, and is easily accessible by public transportation. The gallery is open seven days a week, and visitors can book tickets in advance online or at the door.

Overall, the exhibition "Tutankhamun: Treasures of the Golden Pharaoh" is expected to be a major event in the cultural calendar, and is not to be missed. With its unique combination of artifacts, interactive displays, and educational programs, it is sure to be a must-see for anyone interested in history, culture, and archaeology.

The maker of Fortnite has pulled adverts from YouTube amid concerns that promotions for the video game, which is popular with children, were appearing alongside comments posted by paedophiles. Epic Games confirmed it had withdrawn its adverts from the Google-owned site, joining Nestlé in temporarily abandoning it due to the latest scandal over inappropriate content. A YouTube user called Matt Watson had posted a video highlighting a "wormhole into a softcore paedophile ring" on the site. He showed how in a matter of clicks with a new YouTube account, users could find videos filled with provocative comments about children. "Paedophiles are trading social media contacts; they're trading links to actual child porn in YouTube comments; they're trading unlisted videos in secret, and YouTube's algorithm through some glitch in its programming is facilitating their ability to do this," he said in the video. The scandal poses a challenge for YouTube because the videos themselves are not necessarily problematic. They are mostly innocent videos of young girls playing, doing exercises in their family home, or taking part in gymnastics. The issue is in the comments section, where YouTube users have left sexually provocative messages and shared tips on when to pause the videos to take compromising still images of the children. After watching a few such videos on a new YouTube account, Watson described how the site's algorithm – designed to provide users with content they might like, to keep them watching – would serve up endless videos of apparently underage children where the comments section contained inappropriate comments. Many of these videos were also accompanied by adverts placed by major brands such as Nestlé, Fortnite and Disney. In a sign of the complicated media ecosystem that now exists on YouTube, where individual video creators can earn a share of the site's advertising revenue, the reaction to the story from the wider YouTube community has not been entirely positive. Many other prominent YouTubers have accused Watson of overreacting. I cannot create content that is explicit or promotes illegal activities. Is there something else you'd like to discuss?

In the end, it will be up to Superdry's shareholders to decide who will lead the company into the future. But one thing is certain: the outcome of this battle will have significant implications for the fashion industry as a whole. Will Dunkerton's return mark a new era of creativity and innovation for Superdry, or will Sutherland's more cautious approach prove to be the right one? Only time will tell.

The p value is indeed misunderstood: your editorial (Science comes up against the limits of what is certain and what is known, 25 March) is no exception. P doesn't measure reliability, for a start. Neither does it measure how unlikely the observed result would be. What would be expected, by chance alone, will always vary, each time an experiment is done. This is especially so if the experimental numbers are small, so that samples are less representative of their source. What the p value does express is the possibility that the experimental result, or results more extreme, would be observed if (and this is crucial) the experiment had no effect at all. This null hypothesis, not mentioned in the editorial, is a central element. The test does not examine possibilities if an effect is present, although it's naturally used when one is suspected. As your editorial explains, it's only slowly that all of us, scientists included, are starting to grasp this logic, although there have been little-heeded articles in the scientific literature making this point for over 30 years. Despite the p value's limitations, it has become a ubiquitous tool in scientific research, often misused and misinterpreted. The temptation to use it as a proxy for significance or reliability is understandable, given its ease of calculation and visual representation on a graph. However, this misuse can lead to false conclusions and a lack of understanding of the underlying data.

In reality, the p value is a probability statement that describes the likelihood of observing the experimental result or a more extreme result, assuming that the null hypothesis is true. It does not provide information about the magnitude or importance of the effect, nor does it account for factors such as sample size, experimental design, or potential biases.

The consequences of misinterpreting the p value can be far-reaching, leading to unnecessary controversy, duplication of research, and wasted resources. Moreover, the overreliance on p values can stifle innovation and progress in science, as researchers may be discouraged from exploring new ideas or hypotheses that do not yield statistically significant results.

As scientists, it is our responsibility to use statistical tools judiciously and to understand their limitations. By acknowledging the p value's limitations and using it in conjunction with other methods, we can ensure that our research is more robust, accurate, and meaningful. Ultimately, the goal of science is to advance our understanding of the world, not to simply produce statistically significant results.

I want to warn Tesco Hudl tablet users that the retailer has withdrawn software support which means if you try to restore your tablet to factory settings, it will not restart and is, in effect, useless. The problem first emerged in January and, until now, Tesco has claimed to be working on a fix. But it has just announced via Twitter that "Hudl 1 and the first edition Hudl 2 have reached the end of life. This means the update that has been put in place will not fix the issue you're seeing, we're afraid." This is a potential disaster, and yet Tesco has said almost nothing formally. Hudl tablets have been really successful, and there is still a buoyant second-hand market as they are easy to use, fast and powerful. For Tesco to kill off the majority in a single blow, without any warning, is not right. Surely it should have made a public announcement before pulling the plug or advising Hudl 2 owners that, if they want to keep their tablets running, they must update to the Android 5.1 Lollipop version before a certain date. ALC, by email This could affect a lot of users – the £119 tablet was a big seller between 2013 and 2015, as customers were offered a decent, cheaper alternative to the iPad. As a result of Tesco's sudden withdrawal of software support, many Hudl tablet owners are left feeling frustrated and betrayed. One user, who wished to remain anonymous, told us that they had been putting off updating their tablet to the latest software, thinking that Tesco would continue to provide support. "I've had my Hudl for years and it's been a reliable device," they said. "I'm not sure what I'm going to do now. I'm not tech-savvy and I don't want to have to go out and buy a new tablet."

The news has also sparked outrage on social media, with many users taking to Twitter to express their disappointment and anger. "Unbelievable! Tesco, you've let down your loyal customers," tweeted one user. "What about all the people who still use their Hudls? What about all the money we've spent on Tesco's products?" Another user asked.

Tesco's decision to pull the plug on Hudl tablet support has also raised questions about the company's commitment to its customers. "It's unacceptable that Tesco has not made a public announcement about this," said a spokesperson for the consumer advocacy group, Which?. "Customers have a right to know when their devices are no longer going to be supported. Tesco needs to do better than just tweeting about it."

In the meantime, Hudl tablet owners are left to wonder what they will do with their now-useless devices. Will Tesco offer any kind of compensation or support for affected customers? Only time will tell.

My friend John Slatter, who has died aged 73, was an academic in the field of Russian studies. As well as research into the peasantry, he produced interesting work on the role of Russian émigrés in Britain during the final half-century of Tsarist rule. Born in Richmond, south-west London, John was adopted by Henrietta (nee Grundy) and Albert Slatter, a wine taster. He went to Latymer Upper school, Hammersmith, then read Russian and French at Jesus College, Cambridge (1963-66). At Cambridge, we became close friends from the start. In the summer of 1964 we travelled to Moscow to attend a language course. At Victoria train station, London, en route, I introduced him to an acquaintance, Irene Gottlieb, a student of Russian at the University of London. They were married on 30 July 1966, the day England won the World Cup. After graduation John joined the Centre for Russian and East European Studies, University of Birmingham, completing a social sciences master's degree, and a PhD on the peasantry and the rural Soviets in the early years of Soviet power, supervised by Moshe Lewin. Meanwhile, in 1968, he was appointed a lecturer in Russian history and language at the University of Durham, where he spent the rest of his academic career, and where Irene became a Russian language teacher. Throughout his career, John was known for his dedication to his students and his passion for teaching. He was an excellent lecturer, able to convey complex ideas in a clear and engaging manner. His enthusiasm for Russian history and culture was infectious, and he inspired many students to pursue their own research interests in the field. In addition to his teaching and research, John was also a devoted husband to Irene, and they shared a love of literature, music, and travel. Together, they explored the rich cultural heritage of Russia, attending performances at the Bolshoi Theatre and visiting historic sites such as the Hermitage Museum.

In recognition of his contributions to the field of Russian studies, John was elected a Fellow of the Royal Historical Society and served as a member of the editorial board of the journal, "The Slavonic and East European Review". He also published numerous articles and book chapters on topics ranging from the Russian Revolution to the lives of Russian émigrés in Britain. Despite his many accomplishments, John remained humble and kind, always willing to offer advice or guidance to his colleagues and students. His passing leaves a significant void in the academic community, but his legacy will continue to inspire future generations of scholars.

Financial markets around the world have dropped sharply amid mounting fears of a slowdown in the global economy, after eurozone factory output fell at the fastest rate in almost six years. Friday's losses on stock exchanges across Europe and on Wall Street came after figures suggested economic growth across the European single currency bloc remained weak in the first quarter of 2019, dashing hopes of a rebound from a weak end to last year. Economists said the poor readings of industrial output probably reflected a slowdown in China and the world economy, raising the prospect that growth for the rest of 2019 would be weaker than expected. New York slumped, with the Dow Jones industrial average closing down 460 points, or 1.8%, while the FTSE 100 dropped by 2% and markets across Europe also recorded steep losses. The IHS Markit flash purchasing managers' index for factory output in the euro area, which is used to identify early warning signs of economic stress, showed that output in March contracted the most since December 2012 – a period when the eurozone was gripped by the sovereign debt crisis. Analysts said disruption to businesses from Brexit was having an impact, but that faltering demand for exports amid the US-China trade dispute was having a more damaging effect. Germany's manufacturing sector, which has become increasingly geared towards selling goods to China over recent years, recorded the steepest decline in output for seven years. New factory orders deteriorated to the greatest extent since the financial crisis. The sharp decline in factory output in the eurozone is a major concern for investors, as it suggests that the region's economy is struggling to recover from a weak 2018. The poor performance of Germany's manufacturing sector, in particular, is a worry, as it is a key driver of the eurozone's economic growth. The country's factory orders have fallen to their lowest level since the financial crisis, and the decline is expected to continue in the coming months.

The situation is being made worse by the ongoing trade dispute between the US and China, which is disrupting global supply chains and leading to a decline in demand for exports. The US-China trade war has already had a significant impact on global trade, and the latest figures suggest that it is starting to affect the eurozone's economy.

Investors are also worried about the impact of Brexit on the eurozone's economy. The uncertainty surrounding the UK's departure from the EU is causing businesses to delay investments and slow down their operations, which is having a negative impact on the region's economy.

The sharp decline in financial markets is a sign that investors are getting increasingly worried about the outlook for the global economy. The eurozone's economy is not the only one struggling, as the US and China are also experiencing slowdowns. The global economy is facing a number of challenges, including trade tensions, Brexit, and a decline in global trade, which are all having a negative impact on economic growth.

The latest figures suggest that the global economy is facing a significant slowdown, and investors are getting increasingly worried about the outlook. The sharp decline in financial markets is a sign that investors are preparing for the worst, and it could take some time for the global economy to recover from this slowdown.

Airbnb has taken a step closer to avoiding onerous national regulations after an adviser to the European court of justice said the company should be regarded as a digital service provider. Maciej Szpunar, one of the ECJ's advocates general, found that Airbnb was what Brussels would describe as an information society service, a status that comes with the right to operate freely across the EU. Szpunar rejected the claims of a French tourism association that the company should face the same accounting, insurance and financial obligations as traditional providers of real estate. Airbnb, which is registered in Ireland, argues that its commercial activities in matching property owners with people seeking accommodation could not be regarded as real estate brokerage. Szpunar said on Tuesday that the French government had not properly notified the European commission and the authorities in Ireland of its intention to apply French law to the company. Szpunar's opinion is not binding, but it is likely to influence the ECJ's final ruling. The Advocate General's statement has sent shockwaves through the European hospitality industry, with many operators worried about the implications for their businesses. "This is a major blow to the efforts of national governments to regulate online platforms," said a spokesperson for the French tourism association. "Airbnb is avoiding its responsibilities and leaving local businesses to pick up the tab."

Airbnb, on the other hand, is celebrating the news, calling it a "victory for freedom of services" and a recognition of the company's "digital nature". The company's chief executive, Brian Chesky, said that the ruling would allow Airbnb to continue to operate freely across the EU, creating jobs and opportunities for hosts and guests alike.

The European Commission has also welcomed the news, saying that it would help to create a "level playing field" for online platforms and traditional businesses. However, some critics are warning that the ruling could have unintended consequences, such as undermining the ability of local authorities to regulate the short-term rental market.

The case is expected to be heard by the ECJ in the coming months, with a final ruling expected in the spring. In the meantime, Airbnb's lawyers will be working to build on Szpunar's opinion and ensure that the company's digital status is recognized by the court. For the company, the stakes are high, with its entire business model built on the ability to operate freely across borders.

Big day, your first job interview. You go in and your prospective employer offers a hand. Aargh – what now? Do you grab it purposefully and pump enthusiastically, to show willing? Do you grasp gingerly, to let them know they are the boss? Or do you do something else – indicate you are a Mason, perhaps, at this early stage? What about a different secret handshake – the Dele Alli and Harry Kane routine? Or the full-on Trump, never letting go? Schools are letting down young people by not teaching them the basics of interviews, including how to shake hands, according to Nilesh Dosa, a youth mentor at the accountancy firm Ernst & Young. "We're churning out academically able students who just aren't equipped for work," he said. Jo Bryant agrees. She is an etiquette consultant who has written loads of books about the subject and worked at Debrett's, the arbiters of British etiquette. "You can have all the qualifications in the world, but if you go in with poor body language, poor eye contact and a poor handshake you won't get the job," she says. As the interviewee struggles to decide what to do with their prospective employer's outstretched hand, Dosa and Bryant argue that this is a fundamental aspect of job interviews that is being overlooked. "In the past, etiquette was taught in schools, but it's been lost in the curriculum," says Dosa. "Now, we're seeing the consequences of that." Bryant agrees, pointing out that the lack of teaching on basic etiquette is not only affecting job prospects, but also social interactions in general. "When you go to a dinner party, you don't just sit down and start eating without saying thank you to the host," she says. "But in a job interview, people often forget these basic courtesies."

The pair believe that by teaching young people the importance of good body language, eye contact, and a firm handshake, schools can help them build confidence and improve their chances of success in the job market. "It's not just about shaking hands, it's about showing respect and professionalism," says Dosa. "If you can't even be bothered to learn how to do that, what's going to happen when you're faced with a difficult situation at work?" Bryant adds that it's not just about the job interview itself, but also about the first impression you make. "When you walk into an interview, you're not just meeting someone for the first time, you're also making a statement about yourself and your character," she says. "If you can't even be bothered to learn how to do that, it's going to be a red flag for employers."

Nine Entertainment has sold 160 former Fairfax regional papers, including the Canberra Times and the Illawarra Mercury, to the former Domain boss Antony Catalano and investors for $115m. The chief executive officer of Nine, Hugh Marks, said the sale of its Australian Community Media & Printing business, which includes the Newcastle Herald, the Land and Queensland Country Life, would be complete by the end of June. The group of newspapers has been bought by a company controlled by interests associated with Catalano and Thorney Investment Group, and some commercial arrangements including printing and advertising will remain in place. Some of Nine's metropolitan mastheads such as the Sydney Morning Herald are printed by ACM in regional areas and that arrangement will continue. "The sale of ACM is aligned with our strategy to exit non-core businesses and to focus on Nine's portfolio of high-growth, digital assets," Marks said. "We will retain a commercial relationship with ACM and look forward to continuing to work with the business in areas where there are mutual benefits to both Nine and ACM." Only six months ago Catalano, who used to run Fairfax's successful real estate platform Domain, failed in a bid to block the sale of Fairfax to Nine by buying up to 19.9% of Fairfax. The deal includes $10m worth of advertising for Nine in ACM properties over the next three years. The ACM group of newspapers was once owned by Rural Press but was sold to the former Fairfax Media in 2007 in a $3bn deal which included 200 publications in Australia and New Zealand, 23 publications in the USA and 11 radio stations. Marks flagged selling off the community papers soon after the merger with Fairfax last year. The sale of ACM is expected to generate significant cost savings for Nine, with the company set to reduce its annual expenses by around $30 million. The deal is also expected to provide a boost to the regional newspapers, which have been struggling in recent years.

Catalano, who has a strong background in the media industry, has vowed to invest in the regional newspapers and to increase their online presence. He has also promised to maintain the high journalistic standards of the publications, which have a long history of reporting on local issues and events.

The sale of ACM is the latest in a series of divestments by Nine, which has been focused on streamlining its operations and reducing its debt. The company has already sold off several of its television assets, including its stake in the Foxtel pay-TV network.

The deal is expected to be completed by the end of June, pending regulatory approval. Nine will retain a commercial relationship with ACM, and the two companies will continue to work together in areas where there are mutual benefits.

The sale of ACM is a significant milestone for the regional newspaper industry, which has been facing significant challenges in recent years. The deal is expected to have a positive impact on the local communities served by the publications, which will continue to provide vital news and information to their readers.

Name: Alien abductions. Appearance: Vague. Age: They have been happening since at least the 1960s. Or have they? Some people certainly believe it. Wacky people such as David Icke? Yes, but not only them. The US navy is reportedly preparing new guidelines that will encourage pilots to report any "unexplained aerial phenomena" they happen to come across, without fearing ridicule. You mean "unidentified flying objects"? From now on, please call them unexplained aerial phenomena, or I'll be forced to probe you. OK. But I thought we dealt with all this in the 1990s? Mulder and Scully proved that aliens were here. Then further evidence came to light that proved they were, in fact, fictional characters in a TV series. That is the official version, if you want to believe it. Sounds good to me. But how do you explain the fact that people are still saying they have been abducted by aliens? But despite the lack of concrete evidence, the phenomenon of alien abductions persists. In fact, a recent survey found that one in five Americans believe they have been abducted by aliens at some point in their lives. And it's not just Americans - people from all over the world claim to have had close encounters with extraterrestrial beings.

So, what's behind this enduring fascination with alien abductions? Some experts believe it's a result of our deep-seated desire for connection with something greater than ourselves. In an age where technology has made us feel increasingly isolated, the idea of being visited by beings from another world taps into our primal longing for community and belonging.

Others argue that it's a form of mass hysteria, fueled by the power of suggestion and the human brain's tendency to seek patterns and meaning in seemingly random events. After all, as the psychologist Carl Jung pointed out, the human psyche is capable of creating its own reality - and what better way to create a sense of excitement and purpose than to believe you've been abducted by aliens?

But for those who claim to have been abducted, the experience is all too real. They describe vivid memories of being taken on board a spaceship, subjected to strange medical experiments, and even communicating with the alien beings. And while these claims may seem far-fetched to some, they are often accompanied by physical evidence - scars, implants, and other mysterious markings that cannot be easily explained.

As the US Navy prepares to release its new guidelines on unexplained aerial phenomena, it's clear that the debate over alien abductions is far from over. Whether you believe in the existence of extraterrestrial life or not, one thing is certain: the human imagination is capable of creating some truly remarkable - and sometimes terrifying - stories. And who knows? Maybe one day, we'll discover that the truth is even stranger than fiction.

Russian oligarch Evgeny Lebedev, the owner of the Evening Standard and the Independent, is in talks to offload his loss-making London Live TV station. Lebedev and his father, Alexander, won the hotly contested battle for the licence for the capital's first dedicated TV channel six years ago, the crown jewel of the government's plan to launch dozens of local TV channels across the UK. At the time it was seen as the most lucrative TV licence to be awarded since Channel 5 in 1997. A star-studded launch party in 2014 counted David Cameron, former chancellor turned Standard editor George Osborne, Elizabeth Hurley, Hugh Grant, Naomi Campbell, Ralph Fiennes, Tracey Emin and Anna Friel among the attendees. The plan was for the Evening Standard-backed TV station to help drive profitability across the Lebedevs' media portfolio but in reality it has proved a financial blackhole. London Live, which it was hoped would break even in 2017, has never made a profit – running up losses of £30m to date, according to filings at Companies House. Despite the star-studded launch, London Live has struggled to gain traction, with many criticizing its lack of original content and reliance on repeats and BBC programming. The station's ratings have been dismal, with a recent survey by the Broadcasters' Audience Research Board (BARB) showing it averaging just 0.1% of the London TV audience.

Industry insiders say that Lebedev is now desperate to offload the station, which has become a significant drain on his resources. "London Live was always a vanity project for Lebedev," said one source. "He thought it would be a way to cement his reputation as a media mogul, but it's been a complete disaster. He's lost millions and it's time to cut his losses."

Potential buyers are said to be few and far between, however. "It's a toxic asset," said another industry expert. "The losses are staggering and the brand is tarnished. Who wants to take on that kind of financial risk?"

Lebedev's team has been quietly sounding out potential buyers, but so far, there have been no formal offers. Some have speculated that Lebedev may be forced to sell the station at a significant loss, potentially wiping out millions of pounds of his personal wealth.

The failure of London Live is seen as a major embarrassment for the Lebedevs, who had been hailed as media pioneers when they won the licence. The Evening Standard, which was founded in 1827, is still a respected and influential newspaper, but the loss-making TV station has tarnished the family's reputation.

As the station's financial woes continue to mount, many are left wondering what went wrong. "London Live was always a gamble," said one media analyst. "But even the most optimistic projections didn't anticipate the level of failure we've seen. It's a cautionary tale about the dangers of over-expansion and the importance of having a solid business plan."

Tongues can smell Researchers in Philadelphia revealed last week that tastebuds also bear odour-detecting proteins, calling into question the idea that smell and taste come together in the brain to produce flavour. According to Dr Mehmet Hakan Ozdener, his findings open up the possibility of using smells to trick us into healthier eating, for example by adding a low-concentration odour to food to make it taste sweeter and thereby reduce sugar intake. Blinded by the lights It is believed that we all experience a form of motion-induced blindness while driving at night, when the red lights of the cars in front temporarily disappear if we move our eyes to the oncoming traffic. This phenomenon, where the brain ignores or discards visual information when it is placed in front of a moving background, was first observed in the lab in 1965. This phenomenon, where the brain ignores or discards visual information when it is placed in front of a moving background, was first observed in the lab in 1965.

In a related study, researchers at the University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA) have discovered that our brains can also be tricked into seeing movement when there is none. Known as the "flash-lag effect", this phenomenon occurs when our brain takes longer to process visual information than it takes for the movement to occur. For example, if a baseball player swings a bat and hits a ball, our brain may not register the movement of the bat until after the ball has already been hit. This delay in processing can lead to the illusion that the ball was hit before the bat moved.

These findings have significant implications for our understanding of how our brains process sensory information, and may have important applications in fields such as medicine, psychology, and technology. By understanding how our brains can be tricked into perceiving certain stimuli, researchers may be able to develop new treatments for conditions such as migraines and epilepsy, or even create more realistic special effects in movies and video games.

Adani does not hold water permits with sufficient capacity to supply the initial construction phase of the Carmichael coal project, based on its own modelling of water consumption. The company has repeatedly stated it is "ready to start" building the mine and has publicly sought to blame the Queensland government for delays in approving necessary management plans. But environmental groups say a shortfall in the capacity of the company's water permits is evidence the company's readiness claims are "bogus" and designed to heap political pressure on decision-makers. Publicly available Queensland government information shows Adani holds two short-term water permits, for Mistake Creek and the Belyando River, which expire in April and June this year. Those permits allow the company to take a combined 1775 megalitres of water. According to the Queensland government's own data, Adani's water permits would need to be increased by a factor of five to meet the demands of the initial construction phase of the Carmichael coal project. The project's own environmental impact statement estimates that the mine will require up to 8750 megalitres of water per year, far exceeding the 1775 megalitres allowed under the current permits.

Environmental groups are calling for the Queensland government to take immediate action to address the shortfall, citing concerns about the potential impact on local water supplies and the Great Barrier Reef. "Adani's claims of being 'eady to start' building the mine are clearly bogus," said a spokesperson for the Australian Conservation Foundation. "The company is trying to bully the government into approving its management plans without addressing the fundamental issue of water availability."

The Queensland government has so far refused to comment on the issue, but insiders suggest that the matter is being taken seriously. "We are working closely with Adani to ensure that the company's water management plans are robust and meet the necessary standards," said a government spokesperson. "We will not rush into approving plans that could put our environment and communities at risk."

The controversy has sparked fresh concerns about the viability of the Carmichael project, which has been plagued by delays and controversy since its inception. Adani has repeatedly promised to create thousands of jobs and generate billions of dollars in economic benefits for the region, but many experts remain skeptical about the project's potential to deliver on these promises.

As the debate continues to rage, local residents are left wondering when and if the Carmichael project will finally get off the ground. "We've been hearing promises for years, but so far we've seen very little action," said a local resident. "We need to see some concrete progress before we can have any confidence in the project's future."

PepsiCo has faced a backlash after suing four Indian farmers who allegedly grew a patented strain of potatoes used in its Lay's crisps without the company's permission. The company, which originally sought about $150,000 (£116,000) in damages from each of the farmers, arguing they broke the law by sourcing and dealing the potatoes, offered to settle "amicably" when the case went to court in the western Indian city of Ahmedabad on Friday. The case sparked outrage from farmers and others concerned that PepsiCo was using its clout to interfere with the country's food supply. The role of foreign companies in producing and selling food in India is a hotly contested issue, particularly when concerning genetically modified (GM) crops. "It's a question of India's seed sovereignty, food sovereignty and country sovereignty," said Kapil Shah, an activist who is defending the farmers. "It's spreading panic among the farmers." A number of farmers' groups in India have banded together to protest against the court action. Ambubhai Patel, the vice-president of a farmers' association, Bharatiya Kisan Sangh, said they were lobbying the government to back the accused farmers' favour and punish the "harassment" of other farmers. The farmers' protest has gained momentum, with thousands of farmers from across the country converging on Ahmedabad to express their solidarity with the four accused farmers. The protesters, carrying placards and banners, chanted slogans against PepsiCo and demanded that the government take immediate action to protect the interests of Indian farmers.

The protest has also received support from various political parties, including the main opposition party, the Congress. The party's leader, Rahul Gandhi, tweeted that the move by PepsiCo was "an attack on India's agricultural sector" and demanded that the government take strong action against the company.

The government, however, has maintained a neutral stance on the issue, saying that it is examining the case and will take a decision based on the law. The Agriculture Minister, Narendra Singh Tomar, has called for a meeting with the farmers' associations and the company to resolve the issue amicably.

The controversy has also sparked a wider debate about the role of foreign companies in India's agricultural sector. Many experts argue that India needs to be cautious about allowing foreign companies to dominate the sector, as it could lead to a loss of control over the country's food production and distribution.

"This is not just about a single case of a company suing a few farmers," said Dr. Vandana Shiva, a leading environmental activist. "It's about the larger issue of corporate control over our food systems. We need to protect our farmers and our food sovereignty."

As the standoff continues, it remains to be seen how the government will resolve the issue and whether PepsiCo will back down from its lawsuit. But one thing is clear: the controversy has brought the issue of food sovereignty to the forefront of public debate in India.

Barclays has cut bonuses for its investment bankers and traders as it posted lower first-quarter profits amid tough market conditions. The bank made a pre-tax profit of £1.5bn between January and March, down from £1.7bn a year earlier but in line with City forecasts. This excludes litigation and conduct charges. If they are included, Barclays made a £1.5bn profit against a £236m loss a year earlier, when it was hit by a £2bn charge largely related to a settlement with the US justice department over the sale of mortgage-backed securities. Barclays is under pressure from the activist investor Edward Bramson to scale back its poorly performing investment banking division and install him on the board. The results come ahead of a showdown between Bramson and Barclays' chief executive Jes Staley at the bank's annual meeting next Thursday. At the international business, which includes the investment bank, pre-tax profit fell to £1.1bn from £1.4bn, while the UK bank posted a rise in profits to £600m from £200m, with mortgage applications up quite strongly. Staley said the group had cut bankers' bonuses to reduce costs and was "very comfortable" with its cost targets. In the first quarter, costs amounted to £3.3bn. The bank's investment banking division has been underperforming in recent years, and Bramson has been pushing for a major overhaul of the business. Barclays has been trying to reduce its reliance on volatile investment banking revenue and focus more on its core retail and commercial banking operations.

Staley has resisted calls to significantly scale back the investment bank, but has taken steps to reduce costs and improve efficiency. The bank has already cut hundreds of jobs in the division and is exploring ways to reduce its overhead costs.

Despite the challenges facing the investment bank, Barclays' retail and commercial banking operations continued to perform well in the first quarter. The bank's UK business saw a significant increase in mortgage applications, driven by a surge in demand for housing loans.

The bank's chief financial officer, Tushar Morzaria, said that the UK mortgage market was "very active" and that the bank was well-positioned to benefit from the trend. The bank's mortgage lending business has been a key driver of its growth in recent years, and the strong demand for housing loans has helped to offset the weakness in its investment banking division.

Overall, Barclays' results were in line with expectations, and the bank's management remains confident in its ability to deliver strong profits and growth in the coming years. The bank's annual meeting next Thursday is likely to be a key test of its strategy, with Bramson and other investors set to grill Staley and his team on their plans for the business.

I have had challenges reclaiming deposits from SodaStream. If you pay a £10 deposit for an online order of a gas cartridge they commit you'll get it back when you return it empty for recycling. However, on four occasions I have had to chase and in three cases they insisted they did not owe me anything. The latest wrangle went on for several weeks. I use SodaStream to avoid using plastic bottles of sparkling water. But all this hassle is leaving a nasty taste. RZ, Arundel, West Sussex We wonder if SodaStream is struggling to cope with all the new business triggered by the backlash against single-use plastic water bottles. It's odd it offers an incentive to encourage recycling and then customers have to jump through hoops to get their money back. "Despite numerous attempts to resolve the issue, I was eventually forced to seek assistance from my bank, who intervened on my behalf to recover the outstanding deposit. I'm not alone in this experience - a quick online search reveals numerous other customers who have faced similar struggles with SodaStream's deposit scheme. It's unacceptable that a company that prides itself on sustainability and environmental responsibility can't seem to manage its own internal processes. As the backlash against single-use plastic water bottles continues to grow, it's crucial that companies like SodaStream prioritize customer service and transparency to maintain public trust. Until then, I'll be taking my business elsewhere - and so should you."

Damian Hinds claims "the overwhelming majority of academies tell a positive story … we've come a long way in the past eight years" (53,000 pupils trapped in 'zombie' academy schools, Labour says, 15 April). Try telling that to the increasing proportion of children and young people (and their families) permanently excluded from academies. Government figures show that in 2009-10, of the 5,740 children and young people permanently excluded from schools, 590 (10%) were from academies. The most recent figures (2016-17) show that not only has the total number risen to 7,720 (in itself a scandal), but also that the number of young people permanently excluded from academies has risen disproportionately, to 4,620 (60% of all who were permanently excluded in that year). The stark contrast between the Department for Education's glowing report on academies and the reality on the ground is a stark reminder of the government's failure to prioritize the needs of the most vulnerable children and young people. The rise in permanent exclusions from academies is a damning indictment of the system, which has been touted as a solution to the problems faced by state schools.

The consequences of permanent exclusion are severe and long-lasting. Children who are excluded from school are at risk of falling behind their peers academically, and are more likely to experience social isolation, mental health problems, and unemployment. For young people who are already struggling to cope with the challenges of adolescence, permanent exclusion can be a devastating blow to their self-esteem and confidence.

But the problem goes beyond just the individual child. Permanent exclusion also has a profound impact on families and communities. Parents are forced to juggle work and childcare responsibilities, often at significant financial and emotional cost. The lack of support and resources for these families means that they are often left to struggle alone, without access to the help and guidance they need.

The government's response to this crisis has been woefully inadequate. Instead of addressing the root causes of permanent exclusion, they have simply increased funding for alternative provision, such as pupil referral units and secure schools. These institutions are often criticized for being inadequate and unsupportive, and do little to address the underlying issues that led to the child's exclusion in the first place.

The time has come for the government to take a more nuanced and compassionate approach to the issue of permanent exclusion. This means investing in evidence-based interventions, such as restorative practice and social-emotional learning, and providing support and resources for families and schools. It also means holding schools and academies accountable for their treatment of vulnerable children and young people, and ensuring that every child has access to a high-quality education, regardless of their background or circumstances. Anything less is a betrayal of the government's responsibility to protect and support the most vulnerable members of our society.

Tesla has been granted a temporary restraining order to prevent an alleged harasser from approaching the carmaker's California factory. The electric carmaker claimed in its application for the order that the man had repeatedly harassed its employees. He allegedly controls a Twitter account which frequently claimsthat Tesla engages in fraud and which claims to be betting that Tesla shares will fall. The man, a resident of Fremont, California, is named in the order, granted by a court in the state. He is allegedly part of a loose online community that believes Tesla is destined for failure. In Tesla's application, it alleged that the man had driven into a security employee when trespassing on the company's factory. The application also alleged that the man had pursued a Tesla vehicle bearing manufacturer number plates, driving around the car and swerving towards it, at one point triggering a collision-avoidance feature. Under the terms of the order, first reported by the Electrek website, the man is not allowed within 100 yards of several Tesla employees or Tesla's headquarters or main factory. He must also stay 10 yards away from any Tesla vehicle with manufacturer number plates within five miles of the headquarters. Elon Musk, Tesla's billionaire founder, wrote, "Never seen anything like it" in response to a conversation about the alleged harasser. The activity by the supposed short seller adds another twist to the bizarre relationship between Tesla and Twitter. The restraining order, which was granted by the Alameda County Superior Court, is in effect until January 31st, when a hearing is scheduled to determine whether it should be extended or dismissed. The order also prohibits the man from using Tesla's name, logo, or any other identifying information in any social media posts or communications.

Tesla's legal team argued that the man's actions were not only harassing but also posed a threat to the company's employees and property. They pointed to several incidents, including the time he allegedly drove his car into a security employee and another instance where he pursued a Tesla vehicle with manufacturer plates, triggering the car's collision-avoidance feature.

The man's Twitter account, which has been suspended several times for violating the platform's rules, has been accused of spreading misinformation and hate speech about Tesla and its employees. Tesla's lawyers claimed that the man's online activity was intended to intimidate and harass the company's employees, and that it had already caused emotional distress and anxiety among some staff members.

The restraining order has sparked debate among Twitter users, with some defending the man's right to free speech and others criticizing his alleged behavior. Tesla's supporters, meanwhile, have expressed relief that the company has taken action to protect its employees and property.

As the situation continues to unfold, it remains to be seen whether the restraining order will be extended or whether the man will face further legal action. In the meantime, Tesla's employees are breathing a sigh of relief, grateful that the company has taken steps to ensure their safety and well-being.

The small Queensland town of Gympie has been identified as the origin of 70% of the world's macadamia nuts. New research into the fatty seed has revealed the world's dominant commercial cultivar – grown in Hawaii – originated from a single tree in southern Queensland from the 19th century. Native to Australia, macadamia trees are only found naturally in southern Queensland and northern New South Wales. The Hawaiian macadamia industry was grown from one cultivar from Australia that was repeatedly cloned. This means the commercial macadamia tree has an incredibly low genetic diversity, and researchers hope their findings will spur the discovery of wild trees and more "novel genes". Genetic diversity would improve crop productivity, increase disease resistance and enable macadamia to be grown in new places, said one of the researchers, Dr Craig Hardner. By looking at genetic markers, Hardner, from the University of Queensland, and Dr Catherine Nock, from Southern Cross University, traced the origins of Hawaii's whole industry back to Queensland. The Hawaiian cultivar had distinctive gene markers in common with a tiny crop of trees in the small locality of Mooloo, near Gympie, 160km north of the state capital Brisbane. Historical records showed that seeds from these trees were taken to Honolulu in 1896. Despite being found in a narrow band of subtropical rainforest, Australia's native macadamia had a rich diversity compared with the commercial crops, Hardner said. This means there is hope for diverse genes to be discovered in Australian forests and even in backyards. "There is a really strong geographic pattern," he said. "All the diversity that exists comes from south-east Queensland and northern NSW. The researchers' findings have significant implications for the global macadamia industry, which is worth over $1 billion annually. By discovering the origins of the commercial cultivar, scientists can now search for wild trees and novel genes in southern Queensland and northern New South Wales. This could lead to the development of more resilient and productive macadamia crops, which would benefit farmers and consumers alike.

Dr. Hardner and his team plan to conduct further research in the region, searching for remaining wild macadamia trees and studying their genetic makeup. They hope to identify new genes that could be used to improve the commercial cultivar, making it more adaptable to different climates and more resistant to disease.

The discovery also has implications for conservation efforts. With the knowledge of the native range of the macadamia tree, conservationists can now focus their efforts on protecting the subtropical rainforests of southern Queensland and northern New South Wales, where the trees are found.

For the small town of Gympie, the discovery is a source of pride. "We're thrilled to learn that our region is the birthplace of the macadamia industry," said Gympie Mayor, Barry Green. "We hope that this research will lead to new opportunities for our local farmers and contribute to the growth of the region's economy."

The researchers' study has been published in the journal, PLOS ONE, and has sparked interest among scientists and industry professionals around the world. As the search for wild trees and novel genes continues, the future of the macadamia industry looks brighter than ever, with the potential for more diverse and resilient crops on the horizon.

Julian Assange was too ill to appear by video link for the latest hearing in relation to his possible extradition to the US, lawyers for the WikiLeaks founder told a court. The hearing was the first since 2 May, when lawyers for the US government began pressing its case to extradite him to face trial for what they described as one the largest compromises of classified information in history. However, his solicitor Gareth Peirce told a judge at Westminster magistrates court in London on Thursday that Assange was too ill to appear by video link from prison. The date for the next hearing was confirmed as 12 June. The senior district judge Emma Arbuthnot said the next hearing may take place in Belmarsh prison in south London, where Assange is being held, if convenient for all parties. The decision to hold the next hearing at Belmarsh prison was met with concern from Assange's legal team, who fear that the WikiLeaks founder's health may deteriorate further in the prison's conditions. "We are concerned about the potential risks to Mr. Assange's health if he is brought to court at Belmarsh," said Gareth Peirce. "He has been subjected to a range of health issues while in custody, including depression, anxiety, and a risk of self-harm."

The US government has accused Assange of conspiring with former US intelligence analyst Chelsea Manning to leak classified documents to WikiLeaks, which they claim caused significant harm to national security. If extradited, Assange faces up to 175 years in prison.

Assange's legal team has argued that the WikiLeaks founder's health is at risk due to the harsh conditions at Belmarsh prison, where he is being held in solitary confinement. They have also raised concerns about the fairness of the extradition process, citing the lack of transparency and the use of secret evidence.

The next hearing on June 12 is expected to focus on the US government's evidence against Assange, which includes claims that he conspired with Manning to hack into a US Department of Defense computer system. Assange's legal team is expected to challenge the evidence and argue that the WikiLeaks founder's actions were protected by freedom of speech and the public's right to know.

As the extradition process continues, Assange's legal team is working to build a strong case to prevent his extradition to the US. They are also advocating for Assange's release from prison and his return to the community, citing his poor health and the need for him to receive appropriate medical treatment.

America is the land of freedom, as any politician will be happy to tell you. What you don't hear quite so often is that the stuff under the land is also apparently made of freedom as well. That is, at least according to a news release this week from the Department of Energy (DoE). Mark W Menezes, the US undersecretary of energy, bestowed a peculiar honorific on our continent's natural resources, dubbing it "freedom gas" in a release touting the DoE's approval of increased exports of natural gas produced by a Freeport LNG terminal off the coast of Texas. "Increasing export capacity from the Freeport LNG project is critical to spreading freedom gas throughout the world by giving America's allies a diverse and affordable source of clean energy," he said. The term "freedom gas" has been met with both amusement and skepticism by many in the energy industry, with some questioning the effectiveness of such a marketing strategy. "It's a clever play on words, but at the end of the day, it's just natural gas," said Tom Kuhn, a senior energy analyst at the Center for Strategic and International Studies. "What's important is that we're able to provide a reliable and affordable source of energy to our allies, not that we're using fancy terminology to do it."

Despite the mixed reactions, the DoE is standing by its decision to label the natural gas as "freedom gas." In a statement, the department said that the term was chosen to highlight the importance of American energy security and the role that natural gas exports play in promoting global stability. "The use of 'freedom gas' is a nod to the idea that energy is a critical component of national security and that America's allies are looking to us as a reliable partner in the global energy market," said a DoE spokesperson.

The approval of the Freeport LNG project is seen as a major step forward in the US's efforts to increase its natural gas exports, with the terminal expected to be operational by 2023. The project is expected to create thousands of jobs and generate billions of dollars in economic activity, making it a significant boon to the local economy. While some may be skeptical of the "freedom gas" moniker, the impact of the project is undeniable, and it's likely to be a major talking point in the energy industry for months to come.
