Airlines including British Airways and Virgin Atlantic have resisted calls to remove "no-show" clauses, which bump passengers off the second half of a return trip, despite heavy criticism from regulators and calls for a ban. Consumer body Which? wrote to nine airlines in December, warning they may be breaking consumer laws by keeping clauses that cancel the second leg of a return flight if a passenger misses the first leg of the same booking, forcing some customers to pay hundreds of pounds for replacement flights. In many cases airlines can sell on the same tickets, doubling their earnings for one seat. Of the nine airlines, only Flybe told Which? it would change the clauses, although it has not removed them completely. The airlines' stance has been met with widespread criticism from consumer advocates and regulatory bodies. The UK's Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) has warned that such clauses can be "unfair and misleading" and may be in breach of consumer protection laws. "No-show" clauses are typically buried in the fine print of airline contracts, leaving passengers unaware that they may be at risk of being bumped off the second leg of their return journey if they miss the first leg.

The CAA has called on airlines to review their policies and consider removing such clauses, which it says can cause "significant inconvenience and financial loss" for passengers. The regulator has also launched an investigation into the use of "no-show" clauses by airlines, with a view to determining whether they are in breach of consumer protection laws.

Meanwhile, the UK's Office of Fair Trading (OFT) has written to the airlines urging them to take a closer look at their policies. "We are concerned that some airlines may be using 'no-show' clauses to unfairly penalize passengers who miss the first leg of their return journey," said an OFT spokesperson. "We will be monitoring the situation closely and taking action if necessary to protect consumers' interests."

Consumer groups are also calling on the government to take action to protect passengers from such clauses. "Airlines are exploiting a loophole in consumer law to rip off passengers," said Which? director Richard Lloyd. "We urge the government to step in and ban 'no-show' clauses once and for all. It's time for airlines to put passengers first and stop playing fast and loose with the rules."

As the debate continues, passengers are left wondering what they can do to protect themselves from such clauses. "I had no idea that missing the first leg of my return flight could mean I was bumped off the second leg," said Sarah Johnson, a passenger who recently experienced the frustration of being affected by a "no-show" clause. "I was left stranded in a foreign airport with no way to get home. It was a nightmare."

With the controversy showing no signs of dying down, it remains to be seen whether airlines will eventually relent and remove "no-show" clauses from their contracts. In the meantime, passengers are advised to carefully read the fine print before booking their flights and to be aware of the potential risks of missing the first leg of their return journey.

At least 36 illegal miners are believed to have died in a copper mine owned by Glencore in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) on Thursday. The miners were killed when two 'galleries' overlooking an open excavation pit collapsed at the same mining site which claimed six lives in 2016. Glencore, the world's biggest mining company, confirmed that at least 19 illegal miners were killed when part of the open-pit mine in the Kolwezi area collapsed, and said further fatalities were possible. Richard Muyej, the governor of the DRC's Lualaba province, told Reuters that the accident had claimed the lives of at least 36 "clandestine artisanal diggers". The FTSE 100 company, which owns 75% of the Kamoto Copper Company (KCC) through its Katanga Mining subsidiary, blamed the illegal miners for trespassing at the copper mine and "putting their lives at risk". These miners were working along two 'benches', or narrow strips cut into the side of the open pit, which caved in, killing the workers. Glencore said it has observed a growing number of artisanal miners trespassing at the mine, and estimates that on average 2,000 illegal miners gather on the site every day. The "daily intrusions" have raised a "significant risk to its employees, operating equipment and the illegal artisanal miners themselves", Glencore said. In a statement Glencore said the "incidents" were not linked to the mine's operations, and would not affect production at the mine. The company said it was assisting search and rescue operations with the local authorities. It urged all illegal miners to "cease from putting their lives at risk by trespassing on a major industrial site". Deadly mining accidents are common in DRC, where unemployment is high and artisanal miners hunt for copper to sell, often in dangerous conditions. The incident has sparked widespread outrage and calls for improved safety measures to prevent such tragedies in the future. Human rights groups and local community leaders are demanding that Glencore take responsibility for the accident and provide compensation to the families of the victims.

"The company has a responsibility to ensure the safety of all individuals who enter its premises, including artisanal miners," said Muhindo Mwana, a local community leader. "We demand that Glencore takes immediate action to prevent such incidents from happening again."

The Democratic Republic of the Congo's government has also launched an investigation into the accident and has vowed to take action to prevent similar incidents in the future.

"This tragedy is a wake-up call for all of us," said the DRC's Minister of Mines, Martin Kabwelulu. "We will work with Glencore and other mining companies to ensure that all mining operations are conducted in a safe and responsible manner."

The accident has also highlighted the dangers faced by artisanal miners, who often work in hazardous conditions with inadequate safety equipment and training. Many artisanal miners are forced to work in dangerous conditions to make ends meet, and accidents like this one are a stark reminder of the risks they take every day.

As the investigation continues, Glencore has promised to provide support to the families of the victims and to work with local authorities to prevent similar incidents in the future. The company has also announced plans to increase its security measures at the mine to prevent illegal miners from entering the site.

The incident has also raised questions about the role of multinational companies like Glencore in the DRC's mining industry. Critics argue that companies like Glencore have a responsibility to ensure that their operations do not harm local communities and to provide safe working conditions for all miners, including artisanal miners.

As the debate continues, one thing is clear: the accident at the Kamoto Copper Company mine is a tragic reminder of the risks faced by miners in the DRC and the need for improved safety measures and greater accountability from mining companies.

My wife and I were migrated to Virgin Money credit cards last year after Virgin severed ties with MBNA which had previously been its card provider. Recently, Virgin wrote to us demanding disclosure of sensitive information such as our salaries, proof of identity and proof of source of funds that we use to pay our credit card bill. This is the first time in 20 years a credit card provider has sought such personal data, and the fact that the demand was signed by hand led me to suspect it may be fraud. I reported it to Virgin Money and it confirmed it had sent the letter, but was unable to share from which department it had originated, nor why it required the information. I elected not to reply and, without further notice, Virgin stopped both our cards, leaving my wife and myself stranded at opposite ends of the country. Multiple calls to Virgin Money received the same nonchalant reply. I was shocked and frustrated by Virgin Money's sudden decision to cancel our credit cards without warning. I had always been a loyal customer, and I couldn't understand why they would suddenly turn their back on us. I decided to take my concerns to the Financial Ombudsman Service, who advised me to write to Virgin Money's customer complaints department to try to resolve the issue.

I spent hours crafting a detailed letter explaining the situation and expressing my disappointment and frustration. I received a response from Virgin Money, which was essentially a generic apology and a promise to look into the matter. However, the response did not address my concerns or offer any solution to the problem.

I was left feeling helpless and vulnerable, with no credit cards and no way to access my money. I was forced to rely on the kindness of friends and family to get by, which was embarrassing and stressful. I was also worried about the impact on my credit score, which I had worked hard to maintain over the years.

As the days turned into weeks, I began to feel like I was being punished for doing nothing wrong. I had always paid my bills on time, and I had never been in debt. I couldn't understand why Virgin Money was treating me like a criminal. I was starting to lose hope, and I was beginning to wonder if I would ever be able to get my credit cards back.

"When it comes to an insatiable appetite and passion for business, an infectious enthusiasm for life and a boundless energy and determination to achieve results, Gavin Woodhouse is a man who delivers." So says Gavin Woodhouse, a 41-year-old entrepreneur who lives in a country home in the rolling Yorkshire countryside just outside Halifax. His business interests include care homes, hotels, leisure facilities and student accommodation and he has been listed as a director 137 times with Companies House. Woodhouse began his business career as a teenager cleaning cars. "I was always a clever little git that thought he knew something that they didn't, and one day somebody said: 'Put up or shut up' and I sort of thought I'd better put my money where my mouth is," he says. "My first experience as an entrepreneur was maybe working within the car industry and just seeing that cars needed cleaning. It was just a simple supply and demand. As he delved deeper into the world of entrepreneurship, Woodhouse's innovative spirit and keen eye for opportunity led him to explore various sectors, from hospitality to healthcare. His care home business, which he founded in 2005, has since grown to become one of the largest independent providers of care services in the UK.

Despite his impressive track record, Woodhouse is not one to rest on his laurels. He is always on the lookout for the next big thing, and his latest venture is a state-of-the-art student accommodation complex in Leeds. "I've always been fascinated by the student experience," he explains. "I think it's a really exciting time of life, and I wanted to create a place where students could live, learn, and thrive in a unique and supportive environment."

Woodhouse's commitment to excellence is evident in every aspect of his business, from the design and construction of his properties to the quality of the services he provides. His care homes, for example, offer a range of activities and amenities designed to promote independence, dignity, and overall well-being for his residents.

Despite his many business interests, Woodhouse is also passionate about giving back to his community. He is a keen supporter of local charities and has been involved in various fundraising initiatives over the years. "I believe that business and philanthropy go hand in hand," he says. "As a successful entrepreneur, I have a responsibility to use my resources to make a positive impact on the world around me."

As he looks to the future, Woodhouse is excited about the opportunities that lie ahead. With his boundless energy and determination, it's no wonder that he has become a respected figure in the business world. As he puts it, "I'm not one to shy away from a challenge, and I'm always looking for ways to push the boundaries and innovate. I'm excited to see what the future holds, and I'm confident that my passion and dedication will continue to drive my business forward."

My former colleague Norman Dewis, who has died aged 98, was for most of his working life the highly respected chief test driver for Jaguar, and was one of the last survivors from Jaguar's heyday of the 1950s and 60s. He was born in Coventry, the son of Florence (nee Wilday) and Cyril Dewis. His education was cut short when his father, a coal merchant and carter, died in 1934, and Norman had to find work. After a false start with Humber, he became an apprentice at the Armstrong Siddeley car company. At the outbreak of the second world war in 1939, Norman joined the RAF and became a rear gunner on Blenheims, until he was invalided out with a kidney infection. He then became an Air Ministry inspector. In 1945, he moved to Lea-Francis, where he became chief tester, but in 1952 he joined Jaguar as a test driver and development engineer, remaining there until his retirement in 1985. He soon became involved in disc brake tests, as Jaguar, together with the Dunlop company, was instrumental in developing this new form of brake. Norman had raced his own 500cc single-seater and took part in a number of races for Jaguar, starting with the 1952 Mille Miglia in which he co-drove with Stirling Moss in a Jaguar C-type. Although they did not finish, this was the first time that a car fitted with disc brakes had raced. In 1953, Norman set a speed record in an XK 120 at Jabbeke in Belgium, at 172.4mph. He was one of the Jaguar D-type drivers in the 1955 Le Mans. This race saw motor racing's worst accident when a Mercedes-Benz hit a group of spectators, resulting in more than 70 deaths, witnessed by Norman from the pit opposite. After he had completed his spell of driving, his co-driver went off course, leaving the D-type of Mike Hawthorn and Ivor Bueb to win. After his retirement from Jaguar, Norman continued to be involved in the motoring world, serving as a consultant and advisor to various companies. He was also a keen gardener and enjoyed spending time in his garden, where he would often experiment with new plant species. Norman was a family man and is survived by his wife, Margaret, whom he married in 1955, and their two children, David and Susan. He is also survived by his grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Norman's funeral will be held at Coventry Crematorium, followed by a private family burial. In lieu of flowers, the family has requested donations to the Coventry and Warwickshire Blood Bikes charity, which Norman supported throughout his life. Norman's legacy as a pioneer in the development of disc brakes and his contributions to Jaguar's success will be remembered by many in the motoring industry. His passing marks the end of an era, but his memories and achievements will live on through those who knew him.

David Shariatmadari has a point when he characterises resistance against neologisms such as "I was like…" as inconsistent and futile (Love Island is a lesson in how language, like, evolves, 22 June). However, a more worrying point, which he might have addressed, is the way in which – no doubt due to the same processes that lead to the introduction of such terms – single words or phrases come to dominate language, killing off any opposition, and ultimately impoverishing it; to the extent that, for instance, many people nowadays seem to have only a single superlative at their disposal, resulting in such things as a poster that hangs in my GP's surgery, asking: "Have you had great care today?" Jim Grozier Brighton, East Sussex • Anyone who feels upset by the overuse of "like" might turn to the American poet AE Stallings, who takes it for the title of her 2018 collection. a clever play on words. Stallings' poetry is a scathing critique of the way language is used and abused in modern society, and her title poem is a particularly biting commentary on the overuse of filler words like "like". In it, she laments the way that language is being reduced to a series of bland, soulless clichés, and longs for a return to a more expressive, more nuanced way of speaking.

It's a sentiment that resonates with many of us who are tired of the linguistic laziness that pervades so much of modern communication. But while Stallings' poem is a powerful critique of the status quo, it's also a call to arms - a reminder that language is a powerful tool that can be used to shape our perceptions of the world, and that we have the power to shape it ourselves.

As David Shariatmadari notes, language is constantly evolving, and it's up to us to decide what kind of language we want to use. Do we want to be stuck in a world of bland, overused phrases, or do we want to strive for something more? With poets like AE Stallings leading the charge, it's clear that there are still those who value the beauty and power of language, and who are willing to fight for its preservation.

Name: Interplanetary matriarchy. Appearance: Highly efficient. Age: The everlasting future. Matriarchy, eh? So you're saying that women are destined to rule the world? I think that's fairly obvious. And not just the world. Maybe the galaxy. Ah well. I suppose men had a good run. At an agreed signal, women will just kill all the men in their sleep, I suppose? I expect that's plan B. For now, I think they just intend to colonise space without taking any men along. But how can they colonise anything without having children? Don't they still need men in that department? Not exactly. All that the interplanetary matriarchy technically needs to get started is a supply of sperm. a supply of sperm. This revelation has sent shockwaves throughout the scientific community, with many experts scrambling to understand the implications of this new development.

"It's a game-changer," said Dr. Maria Rodriguez, a leading expert in reproductive biology. "For decades, we've been searching for a solution to the problem of reproduction in space. And now, it seems that women have found a way to bypass the need for men altogether."

The technology, known as "sperm harvesting," involves collecting and storing sperm from a large number of men, which can then be used to fertilize eggs in a laboratory setting. The resulting embryos can then be implanted in a surrogate mother, who will carry the child to term.

"It's a remarkable achievement," said Dr. John Lee, a renowned astrobiologist. "The implications are huge. It means that women can colonize space without having to worry about finding a mate. They can focus on building a new society, free from the constraints of traditional gender roles."

But not everyone is convinced. Some experts have raised concerns about the ethics of the technology, and the potential consequences for men.

"This is a huge step backwards for humanity," said Dr. David Patel, a sociologist. "We're talking about a society where men are no longer needed. It's a recipe for disaster. We need to think about the long-term consequences of this technology before we start implementing it."

Despite these concerns, the interplanetary matriarchy is forging ahead, with plans to establish a series of colonies on distant planets. The first colony is expected to be established on Mars within the next decade, with more colonies to follow on other planets and moons in the solar system.

"It's a new era for humanity," said the leader of the interplanetary matriarchy, a woman named Astra. "We're no longer limited by the constraints of traditional gender roles. We're free to build a new society, based on our own values and principles. And we're not going to let anything stand in our way."

All-female astronaut crews could reproduce in space without the help of accompanying men, new research suggests. The study found that frozen samples of sperm exposed to microgravity retained similar characteristics to sperm samples kept on the ground, raising hopes that a sperm bank could one day be set up in space to help populate new worlds. This could prove interesting for female astronauts, amid reports that future missions to Mars may involve women-only space crews. Helen Sharman, the first British astronaut, said at a conference in 2017 that there had been an unreleased Nasa report exploring sexual desires of space crew members during potential missions to Mars. Sharman said the report had recommended space crews of the same gender – "all men or all women" – because they have better team cohesion. Findings from the small preliminary study, involving sperm from 10 healthy donors, suggest that "the possibility of creating a human sperm bank outside of Earth" exists, according to the researchers. The researchers, led by Dr. Maria Rodriguez from the University of California, Los Angeles, used a specialized device to freeze and store the sperm samples in microgravity conditions, mimicking the environment of space. They then compared the characteristics of the frozen sperm to those of sperm samples stored on the ground. The results showed that the frozen sperm in microgravity retained similar morphology, motility, and DNA integrity as the sperm samples on the ground.

"This is a crucial step towards establishing a sperm bank in space," said Dr. Rodriguez. "It's not just about the technical feasibility, but also about the emotional and psychological aspects of reproduction in space. If we can demonstrate that sperm can be successfully frozen and stored in space, it could open up new possibilities for female astronauts to have children during long-duration missions."

The study's findings have significant implications for future space missions, particularly those involving all-female crews. With NASA's plans to send humans to Mars in the 2030s, the possibility of establishing a human sperm bank in space could become a reality. The researchers believe that their findings could also have applications for other areas of research, such as cryopreservation of other biological samples, like eggs and embryos.

The team is now planning to conduct further research to investigate the long-term effects of microgravity on sperm quality and to develop a system for storing and retrieving frozen sperm in space. While the idea of a sperm bank in space may seem futuristic, the researchers believe that it's an important step towards making humanity a multi-planetary species.

Waitrose has sold off three of its supermarkets to Lidl, sparking a wave of middle-class outrage. It's not just concern about access to venison meatballs or pistachio ice-cream – residents of Bromley in London, Oadby in Leicestershire and Wollaton in Nottinghamshire apparently fear their house prices could take a dive. Kal Kandola, 49, told the Telegraph: "We are regulars at Waitrose and not very happy about this at all. I have houses in Wollaton that I rent out. The issue of house prices is a concern as Wollaton is an affluent area." Homes near the upmarket supermarket chain enjoy the "Waitrose effect", commanding a 12% premium (£43,571) on the average home, according to research by Lloyds Bank last year. But the hand-wringing by local residents may be unnecessary. The value of homes near to budget supermarkets such as Lidl rose by a larger amount than those near a Waitrose – up 15% over the past four years, according to Lloyds. Despite the concerns, real estate experts say the impact on house prices will likely be minimal. "The 'Waitrose effect' is a myth," said James Mackintosh, a property expert at Lloyds Bank. "The presence of a high-end supermarket like Waitrose doesn't necessarily drive up house prices. It's the quality of the local schools, transport links, and community amenities that have a much greater impact on property values." In fact, some argue that the influx of budget-conscious shoppers to the area could even have a positive effect on local businesses. "Lidl's arrival could bring in a new customer base that might not have been there before," said Emma Taylor, owner of a nearby boutique. "We're excited to see how it will bring more foot traffic to the area." Meanwhile, Lidl has promised to invest £10 million in its new stores, creating hundreds of jobs and stimulating the local economy. As one resident, Sarah Jenkins, 35, put it: "I'm not worried about the house prices. I'm just excited to have a new supermarket with better prices on my favourite products."

Name: #GeneBragging Age: New for summer 2019. Appearance: Glamorous, photogenic, aspirational, related. Related to what? To one another. Who are? The #GeneBraggarts. I'm confused. Can we start again? The world's biggest football authorities, including those who run the Premier League, World Cup and Champions League, have called on Saudi Arabia to take action to stop a sophisticated, homegrown pirate TV and streaming service that is illegally broadcasting matches internationally. The strongly worded letter from the exasperated sports bodies – including Fifa, Uefa, Germany's Bundesliga, Spain's La Liga and Italy's Serie A as well as the Asian Football Confederation – comes after almost 18 months fruitlessly attempting to mount a legal challenge in Saudi Arabia to block the service, called beoutQ. "We collectively condemn in the strongest possible terms the ongoing theft of our intellectual property by the pirate broadcaster known as beoutQ and call on the authorities in Saudi Arabia to support us in ending the widespread and flagrant breaches of our intellectual property rights," the authorities said in a joint statement. The sporting bodies have said that nine legal firms in Saudi Arabia have failed to take on their copyright theft case and that they are now being forced to seek other means to shut down the broadcaster. "We have reached the conclusion, regrettably, that it is now not possible to retain legal counsel in the kingdom of Saudi Arabia which is willing or able to act on our behalf," the statement continued. "We see no alternative but to pursue beoutQ and a solution to this very serious problem of piracy by other means. The sports authorities are now exploring alternative options to shut down the pirate service, including working with international law enforcement agencies and collaborating with other broadcasters to share intelligence and coordinate efforts to disrupt beoutQ's operations.

The joint statement also accused beoutQ of not only stealing intellectual property, but also damaging the reputation of the sport and its players. "The ongoing theft of our intellectual property is not only a serious breach of our rights, but it also undermines the integrity of the sport and the value of the competitions we organize," the statement said.

The authorities also warned that the pirate service is not only affecting the sport, but also posing a significant financial risk to the clubs, leagues, and players involved. "The losses incurred by our competitions and our stakeholders as a result of this piracy are significant and we cannot continue to allow this to happen," the statement said.

The sports authorities are urging fans and consumers to be aware of the illegal broadcasts and to avoid using pirate services. "We urge all fans and consumers to be aware of the illegal broadcasts and to avoid using pirate services that are stealing our content," the statement said.

The authorities are also calling on the Saudi Arabian government to take action to stop the pirate service and to support the sport in its efforts to protect its intellectual property. "We call on the government of Saudi Arabia to take immediate action to stop the pirate service and to support us in our efforts to protect our intellectual property," the statement said.

The sports authorities are determined to take action to stop the pirate service and to protect the sport and its stakeholders from the negative impacts of piracy. "We will do everything in our power to stop this pirate service and to protect the sport and our stakeholders from the negative impacts of piracy," the statement said.

Giffgaff has been fined £1.4m for overcharging 2.6 million mobile phone customers over an eight-year period. An Ofcom investigation revealed the network, which is owned by O2's parent company Telefónica, overcharged users a total of almost £2.9m. The communications regulator said the billing mistake was "unacceptable" and imposed a further £50,000 fine because Giffgaff failed to provide accurate information during its investigation. Giffgaff, which overcharged customers from May 2011 to February 2019, has about 2.5 million customers. "Getting bills right is a basic duty for every phone company. But Giffgaff made unacceptable mistakes, leaving millions of customers out of pocket," Gaucho Rasmussen, the director of investigations and enforcement at Ofcom, said. "This fine should serve as a warning to all communications providers: if they get bills wrong, we will step in to protect customers." Ofcom said the fine would have been £2m but the penalty was reduced by 30% because Giffgaff agreed to settle the case and admitted the mistake. Giffgaff customers who pre-paid for "goodybags" – bundles of voice minutes, text messages and data – were in effect charged twice, the regulator said. This was because there was a delay in Giffgaff applying the bundles to customers' accounts after they paid for it, which meant calls and data they were using at the time came out of their pre-paid credit instead. The fine is a significant blow to Giffgaff, which has been a popular choice among budget-conscious consumers due to its affordable tariffs and innovative approach to customer service. The company has been praised for its transparent and community-driven approach, with customers able to earn rewards and influence the company's decisions through its online forums.

However, the overcharging scandal has raised concerns about the company's billing processes and accountability. Giffgaff has apologized for the mistake and has promised to take steps to prevent similar incidents in the future. The company has also offered refunds to affected customers, with an estimated £2.9 million being returned to customers.

The investigation has also sparked wider concerns about the accuracy of billing practices across the telecommunications industry. Ofcom has said that it will be increasing its scrutiny of billing practices, and has called on other providers to review their own processes to ensure they are accurate and transparent.

Giffgaff's parent company, Telefónica, has also faced criticism for its handling of the situation. The company has said that it is taking the matter seriously and is working to resolve the issue as quickly as possible. However, some have questioned whether the company did enough to address the problem sooner, and whether it has adequate measures in place to prevent similar mistakes in the future.

As the industry continues to grapple with the fallout from the scandal, customers are being urged to review their bills carefully and report any discrepancies to their providers. Ofcom has also set up a dedicated webpage for customers to report any billing issues, and has promised to take action against any provider found to be consistently breaching billing regulations.

Commuters have been advised to avoid travelling on key rail routes in London and the south-east on Thursday as record temperatures threaten to cause tracks to buckle. Train companies operating services into London from Kent, Sussex, Cambridge and other commuter-belt counties said they would be running fewer trains and imposing speed restrictions. They warned passengers to avoid travelling if possible. LNER, operator of the London-to-Scotland east coast line, also advised customers against travelling. Network Rail said in hot weather tracks can be 20C hotter than the surrounding air temperature, causing the steel rails to expand and buckle under pressure from trains. Tracks are less likely to buckle if trains run more slowly, it said. Southeastern Trains, which operates services into London from Kent and East Sussex, said it would run significantly fewer services on Thursday to let trains travel more slowly. The hot weather is expected to continue throughout the day, with temperatures forecast to reach up to 38C in some areas. This has led to concerns about the condition of the rail tracks, which are already under pressure due to the recent heatwave.

"We understand that this will cause inconvenience to many passengers, but we must prioritize the safety of our customers and staff," said a spokesperson for Southeastern Trains. "Running fewer trains and imposing speed restrictions is the best way to ensure that our tracks remain safe and secure."

Other train operators affected by the heatwave include Great Western Railway, which operates services from the west country and Wales, and Thameslink, which runs trains from the north and east of England.

Passengers have been advised to check with their train operators before travelling and to plan their journeys in advance. Those who do need to travel have been warned to expect delays and disruptions.

The heatwave has also caused problems for the London Underground, with some lines operating reduced services due to the high temperatures. Passengers have been advised to check the Transport for London website for the latest information before travelling.

The hot weather is expected to continue for the rest of the week, with temperatures forecast to remain high throughout the weekend. The Met Office has issued a heatwave warning, advising people to take precautions to stay cool and hydrated.

In the meantime, commuters are being advised to plan ahead and avoid non-essential travel. Those who do need to travel have been warned to expect delays and disruptions, and to check with their train operators before setting off.

Dozens of national newspaper journalists – not a few of them on the Guardian – who worked early in their careers for the Oxford Mail and Oxford Times will remember Anthony Price with nostalgic affection. He was an extremely genial, unflustered and unautocratic figure, his day job as editor of the weekly Oxford Times being not the most demanding in journalism. The two papers had a near monopoly, so most of the stories had already appeared verbatim in the Mail, an evening publication. But each had a distinct character, the Times being somewhat more staid and upmarket, selling self-consciously to the university dons and professional classes. As editor of the Oxford Times, Anthony Price had a unique understanding of the city's academic and cultural landscape, which he used to craft a publication that was both informative and entertaining. His relaxed and approachable nature made him a favorite among the university's professors and researchers, who would often stop by his office to discuss the latest developments in their fields. Despite the Mail's dominance, the Times remained a beloved institution, cherished for its thoughtful analysis and witty commentary. Under Price's guidance, the paper became a staple of Oxford's intellectual life, providing a platform for lively debate and discussion. His legacy continues to inspire generations of journalists and scholars alike.

The US justice department is opening a broad antitrust review into major technology firms, as criticism over the companies' growing reach and power heats up. The investigation will focus on growing complaints that the companies are unlawfully stifling competition. "The Department's review will consider the widespread concerns that consumers, businesses and entrepreneurs have expressed about search, social media, and some retail services online," the Department of Justice said in a statement. "Without the discipline of meaningful market-based competition, digital platforms may act in ways that are not responsive to consumer demands," added the assistant attorney general Makan Delrahim, of the antitrust division. The review will investigate practices of online platforms including Facebook, Alphabet's Google, Amazon and Apple. The investigation comes amid calls from lawmakers, including Democratic presidential candidates such as Elizabeth Warren, that the companies should face more scrutiny. The review is expected to be a comprehensive examination of the business practices of the four companies, which have grown to dominate various aspects of the digital economy. The investigation will likely focus on issues such as search engine manipulation, online advertising, and the collection and use of personal data.

The Justice Department's review is seen as a significant development in the ongoing debate over the power and influence of technology giants. Critics argue that the companies have used their size and influence to stifle competition and manipulate the market to their advantage.

"The dominance of these companies is not just a matter of their size, but also their ability to shape the rules of the game and influence the behavior of others," said Senator Amy Klobuchar, a Democrat from Minnesota who has been a vocal critic of the companies' practices.

The investigation is also expected to explore the companies' use of mergers and acquisitions to expand their reach and eliminate potential competitors. For example, Google's acquisition of Waze, a popular GPS navigation app, has been criticized for reducing competition in the mapping and navigation market.

The review is expected to take several months to complete, and could potentially lead to antitrust lawsuits or other regulatory actions against the companies. The companies have denied any wrongdoing and have argued that their size and influence are a result of their ability to innovate and provide valuable services to consumers.

The investigation is seen as a major test of the Justice Department's commitment to enforcing antitrust laws and promoting competition in the digital economy. It is also seen as a potential precedent for future investigations into the practices of other large technology companies.

The Crop Protection Association (CPA) criticises the RSA Food, Farming and Countryside Commission report, Our Future in the Land, for its absence of science (Letters, 22 July). As much as they'd like us to believe it, they do not have the monopoly on the scientific arguments. Good science is a rigorous and critical process of inquiry: it is far from perfect, neutral and incontrovertible. It was science that gave us DDT, thalidomide and lead in petrol; and science told us it would be fine to give antibiotics prophylactically to intensively reared livestock. We know now that the science was at best "incomplete", and it is fresh science that tells us that we must change. We should therefore apply the precautionary principle more carefully, given what we know now about the misplaced claims of science past. The CPA's criticism of the RSA report is not only unfounded, but also ignores the significant advances that have been made in crop protection research. The report's emphasis on sustainable farming practices and reducing chemical use is a welcome recognition of the need to rethink our approach to agriculture. By acknowledging the limitations of scientific knowledge and the importance of considering multiple perspectives, the report provides a framework for responsible decision-making.

Furthermore, the CPA's argument that science is not perfect and has led to mistakes in the past is a red herring. It is true that science has sometimes been misused or misinterpreted, but this does not justify a blanket rejection of scientific evidence. Instead, it highlights the need for continued investment in research and development, as well as a commitment to transparency and accountability in the scientific process.

In reality, the RSA report is a call to action, urging policymakers and industry leaders to work together to develop more sustainable and resilient food systems. It is a recognition that the current approach to agriculture is unsustainable and that we need to think differently about how we produce and consume food. By ignoring the report's findings and recommendations, the CPA is doing a disservice to the very farmers and communities it claims to represent.

Ultimately, the debate over the RSA report is not about science versus non-science, but about the kind of world we want to live in. Do we want to continue down the path of industrialized agriculture, with its reliance on chemicals and monocultures? Or do we want to work towards a more sustainable future, one that prioritizes people, planet, and prosperity? The choice is clear, and it is time for the CPA and others to join the conversation.

British Airways has lost its legal attempt to block planned strikes by pilots, which could take place next month and disrupt the travel plans of hundreds of thousands of passengers. The pilots union, Balpa, can now call strike dates with two weeks' notice. However. it has said it will not set dates until after further talks with the airline, which intends to take its case to the court of appeal. The high court on Tuesday dismissed BA's argument that the strike ballot, whose result was announced on Monday, was invalid. Some 93% of BA's 4,000 pilots voted to take industrial action after rejecting a three-year pay deal. Balpa's general secretary, Brian Strutton, said: "Although legally clear to do so, we have still not set any strike dates to give BA one last chance to commit to negotiating on pilots pay and rewards with us at Acas later this week." The airline's decision to appeal the ruling means that the dispute is unlikely to be resolved anytime soon, and passengers are likely to face disruption to their travel plans in the coming weeks. BA has already started to contact affected customers to offer alternative flights or refunds, but many are likely to be left frustrated by the uncertainty.

Balpa's decision to delay setting strike dates is seen as a conciliatory move, aimed at giving BA one last chance to negotiate a deal that satisfies the pilots' demands. The union has been pushing for a pay rise and improved working conditions, and is seeking to address what it sees as a significant pay gap between BA pilots and those at rival airlines.

The airline, however, remains adamant that the strike is unnecessary and that the pilots' demands are unrealistic. A spokesperson said: "We are extremely disappointed by the court's decision and will be taking this to the Court of Appeal. We believe that the strike is not justified and that we have made a fair offer to our pilots."

The dispute has sparked concerns about the impact on the airline's reputation and customer loyalty, as well as the potential economic consequences for the UK's aviation industry. The government has also been urged to intervene to prevent the strike from going ahead, with some MPs calling for mediation talks to be facilitated by the Department for Transport.

As the standoff continues, passengers are being advised to check with the airline for the latest information on their flights and to consider making alternative travel arrangements if necessary. With the summer travel season just around the corner, the prospect of strike action is likely to cause significant disruption and inconvenience to many travelers.

Shares in Ted Baker have jumped after reports that the fashion retailer's founder, Ray Kelvin, was considering teaming up with investors to buy the company. Kelvin quit as chief executive in March in the wake of allegations of inappropriate behaviour towards staff, including forced hugs. Reports at the weekend said Kelvin, who owns 35% of Ted Baker, was prepared to support a buyout to take the company private and work with its existing management. Shares in the business closed up 13.5% at 951p on Monday. The share price has more than halved since early January following the publication of two profit warnings, as it described "extremely difficult" trading conditions. In March 2018 the shares traded at £32.14, valuing Ted Baker at £1.4bn. The company is now valued at about £424m and Kelvin's stake is worth £148m. The potential buyout has sent shockwaves through the retail industry, with many analysts speculating about the motivations behind Kelvin's reported interest in taking the company private. Some have suggested that Kelvin may be seeking to restore his reputation and legacy, which was severely damaged by the allegations of inappropriate behavior. Others have speculated that he may be looking to capitalize on the company's undervalued stock price and reap a significant profit from his 35% stake.

Regardless of the motivations, the news has sparked renewed interest in Ted Baker's future, with many investors eager to see what will happen next. The company's existing management team has been tight-lipped about the reports, but insiders suggest that they are open to exploring any opportunities that could benefit the business.

The potential buyout has also raised questions about the future of Ted Baker's publicly traded status. If the company were to go private, it would mark a significant shift for the fashion retailer, which has been listed on the London Stock Exchange since 1993. The move could also have implications for the company's relationship with its investors and stakeholders, who have been increasingly vocal about their concerns over the company's performance.

Neil Woodford's stock-market-listed fund has announced its first major investment since the shuttering of its flagship sister vehicle last month. Woodford Patient Capital Trust confirmed on Monday that it was pumping £10m into Atom Bank, keeping its stake at 18%. It is part of a wider £50m fundraising by Atom Bank that also drew investment from the Spanish banking group BBVA and investment funds Perscitus and Toscafund. But Woodford's involvement in the funding round failed to excite investors. Instead, shares in the FTSE-250-listed fund fell 1.6% to a new low of 53.1p. It is the first major investment decision made by Patient Capital since 3 June, when Woodford made the shock decision to suspend his flagship Equity Income Fund after being overwhelmed by customer withdrawals. It followed a string of bad investments that caused the fund's performance to nosedive. Woodford was forced to block investors from withdrawing their money from the equity income fund in order to give himself time to sell off stakes in quoted stocks and unlisted companies that can be more difficult to sell. The move is seen as a significant departure from Woodford's usual investment strategy, which has been criticized for being overly focused on unquoted companies. Atom Bank, on the other hand, is a digital bank that has gained popularity among consumers for its user-friendly online platform and competitive interest rates. The investment is also a nod to Woodford's increasing focus on the fintech sector, which has been a key area of interest for the fund manager in recent months.

Despite the positive development, investors remain cautious about Woodford's ability to turn around the fund's fortunes. The Equity Income Fund's suspension has left many investors feeling burned, and there are concerns that the fund's investment decisions may not be as effective going forward. Woodford's team has been working to restructure the fund and address the liquidity issues that led to its suspension, but it remains to be seen whether these efforts will be enough to restore investor confidence.

In the meantime, Woodford's other funds, including the Patient Capital Trust, will continue to be monitored closely by investors and analysts. The trust's investment in Atom Bank may be seen as a positive step, but it is just one of many factors that will be considered in determining the fund's overall performance and potential for future growth.

A subsidiary of British Steel has been sold by the government to the French company Systra in a deal that protects 400 jobs. The deal is not expected to have any impact on discussions on the rest of British Steel, as exclusive talks continue between the government's official receiver, the state employee managing the sale, and Oyak, the Turkish military pension fund. York-based TSP Projects, which designs and builds large rail infrastructure projects, will be folded into Systra. The proceeds of the sale are likely to be allocated to lenders to British Steel, which collapsed into liquidation in May. Neither the government nor the companies disclosed the sale price but Systra will also take on TSP's £70m pension liabilities, a hangover from the company's days as a division of British Rail before privatisation. Craig Scott, the chief executive of TSP Projects, said the liquidation of British Steel had never threatened his company, which was performing well and counted firms including Network Rail, Siemens and Costain among its clients. "We would always have found a buyer," said Scott. He added that he was "pleased to get out from the association with British Steel in administration and to be able to get on with focusing on our business. The sale is seen as a positive outcome for the 400 employees of TSP Projects, who will now become part of Systra's UK operations. Systra, a leading global player in the rail industry, has a strong track record of integrating acquired businesses and has committed to maintaining the existing workforce and operations of TSP Projects. The company's clients, including Network Rail, Siemens, and Costain, are expected to continue to work with TSP Projects under its new ownership.

The sale is also a relief for the government, which had been working to find a buyer for TSP Projects to protect jobs and ensure the continuity of the business. The deal is seen as a vote of confidence in the UK's rail industry and a testament to the government's commitment to supporting British businesses.

In a statement, the government's official receiver, Mike Horton, welcomed the sale, saying: "We are pleased to have secured a buyer for TSP Projects, which will protect jobs and ensure the continuity of the business. This is a positive outcome for the employees, customers, and suppliers of TSP Projects, and we are grateful to Systra for its commitment to the business." The sale is expected to be completed in the coming weeks, pending regulatory approvals.

The downturn in casual dining delivered another blow to Pizza Express in the first half of the year while newer rival Franco Manca hit the spot as its menu of sourdough pizzas, green cola and vegan cheese appealed to changing consumer appetites. The contrasting fortunes were underlined as Pizza Express reported falling profits and put restaurant openings on hold, while Franco Manca attracted more customers and took advantage of falling rents to open more branches. Pizza Express said underlying profits fell 7.7% to £32.4m in the six months to the end of June. The chain opened just two new branches over the period and said the focus would be on improving existing sites and revamping its menu. Pizza Express's chief executive, Jinlong Wang, said: "We are taking a measured approach to growing our business in the UK and Ireland … We are now planning to focus our capital investment on upgrading our existing estate rather than adding more sites." Pizza Express opened its first restaurant in 1965 and expanded in the 1990s to become a mainstay for families seeking an inexpensive meal out. The chain was bought by Hony Capital, a Chinese private equity firm, in 2014 when casual dining was booming in the UK. However, the market for casual dining has struggled since 2016 after becoming overcrowded with chains that expanded too quickly. The shift in consumer preferences towards healthier and more sustainable options has also taken a toll on Pizza Express, with the chain's sales of its signature garlic bread and desserts declining. In contrast, Franco Manca's menu, which features sourdough pizzas made with natural yeast and no artificial additives, has resonated with customers seeking a more authentic and artisanal dining experience.

Franco Manca's success has been driven by its ability to adapt to changing consumer tastes, with the chain introducing vegan and gluten-free options to cater to the growing demand for plant-based and free-from food. The chain's focus on sustainability has also been a major draw, with Franco Manca using eco-friendly packaging and sourcing ingredients from local suppliers wherever possible.

Pizza Express, on the other hand, has struggled to keep up with the changing times. The chain's menu, which has remained largely unchanged for decades, has been criticized for being too bland and unexciting. The chain's attempts to revamp its menu with limited-edition offerings and seasonal specials have been met with mixed success, with some customers welcoming the changes while others have been disappointed by the lack of innovation.

The contrasting fortunes of Pizza Express and Franco Manca highlight the challenges faced by established casual dining chains in a rapidly changing market. As consumers become increasingly discerning and demanding, chains must adapt quickly to stay relevant or risk being left behind. For Pizza Express, the focus on upgrading its existing estate and revamping its menu is a crucial step in reversing its decline, while Franco Manca's commitment to sustainability and innovation has set it up for long-term success.

Hundreds of Apple workers across Europe who were employed to check Siri recordings for errors have lost their jobs after the company announced it was suspending the programme earlier this month. More than 300 employees have had their contracts ended in the company's Cork facility alone, according to former employees, with more sent home from other sites across Europe. The staff had been on paid leave since 2 August, the day Apple announced its decision to suspend the programme, referred to as "grading", as it conducted "a thorough review". The decision followed a story in the Guardian that revealed the workers frequently heard confidential medical information and couples having sex while checking the Siri recordings. The graders, employed through contracting firms, were sent home that Friday, with many told there was no work for them due to "technical errors". However, last week the contracting firms were told by Apple that the grading work would be terminated, leading to the mass job losses with little notice. Even among those employees who were concerned by the ethics of the programme, there has been anger about how the job losses have proceeded. "I'm relieved this information came out," said one former contractor who asked to remain anonymous due to a still-active non-disclosure agreement, "although I was involved in the work and I just lost my job. The sudden termination of the grading program has left many workers reeling, with some expressing shock and disappointment at the lack of notice or support from Apple. "It's like they just threw us away like trash," said another former contractor, who had been working on the program for over a year. "We were told there was a thorough review going on, but it seems like they just wanted to get rid of us."

The mass layoffs have also raised concerns about the potential impact on the workers' livelihoods. Many of the contractors were not employed directly by Apple, but rather through third-party firms, which means they do not have the same level of job security or benefits. "I'm now facing a uncertain future, with no idea how I'm going to pay my bills or support my family," said a third former contractor.

The controversy surrounding the grading program has also sparked debate about the ethics of such programs, and the need for greater transparency and accountability from tech companies. "This is a wake-up call for Apple and other tech giants," said a spokesperson for a worker advocacy group. "They need to recognize the value of the workers who are helping them make their products, and treat them with respect and dignity." As the fallout from the grading program continues to unfold, it remains to be seen what steps Apple will take to address the concerns of its former workers and the broader public.

We started work on a loft conversion in May last year. The standard L-shaped dormer came under permitted development rights which do not require planning permission. But when the work began we applied for an optional certificate of lawfulness from Lambeth council. It didn't review our application until September when it was rejected. It turned out that the planning department had unilaterally reinterpreted the rules in August 2018 without notifying residents, builders or architects. L-shaped dormers are now no longer considered a permitted development, although they are in other London boroughs. Six weeks later, we were served an enforcement notice. The government's guidance states that certificates of lawfulness are optional and many builders don't bother to apply. This means there may now be hundreds of "illegal" lofts in Lambeth. The notice demanded that we remove the dormer and restore the roof to its original state. We were given 28 days to comply, but we decided to appeal the decision. Our architect argued that the council's reinterpretation of the rules was unfair and that we had followed the guidance provided at the time of our application.

The case was heard by a planning inspector, who ultimately ruled in our favor. However, the inspector's decision was delayed by several months, leaving us with a significant financial burden. We had to continue paying our contractors to maintain the site, even though the work was stalled.

The experience has left us feeling frustrated and disillusioned with the planning process. We had done everything by the book, only to be caught out by the council's unexpected change in policy. A possible merger has been predicted by analysts who have speculated the two companies could get back together as they fight falling cigarette sales and the rise of vaping. Over the past year the e-cigarette category has grown 97% to $1.96bn and, according to Wells Fargo, Juul's sales grew 783% between June 2018 and June this year, reaching $942.6m. The potential merger has sent shockwaves through the tobacco industry, with analysts predicting that the combined entity would be a dominant force in the global market. However, not everyone is convinced that the merger is a good idea. Your headline (Single polypill reduces risk of heart attacks and strokes, study finds, 23 August) should really have been tempered by quoting the absolute rather than the relative risk-reduction figures. The 34% reduction in major cardiac events you quote is calculated from "on the ground" reduction in events from 8.8% over five years in those not on the polypill to 5.9% in those receiving it – that is a 2.9% chance of benefit over five years to the individual and with no effect on mortality. Archie Cochrane , the doyen of evidence-based medicine, said we should ask three questions of any intervention: can it work, does it work and is it worth it? The relative risk reduction you quote tells us of population benefit and answers the first two questions, but it is the absolute risk reduction that answers the "is it worth it?"question. Many patients would be reluctant to take a tablet if told there was a greater than 97% chance that they would derive no benefit from taking it over five years and it had no positive effect on their length of life. Add to that the differences between the UK and rural Iran where the study was carried out, plus the risk of medicalising healthy patients and the constant risk of side-effects, and surely the answer to "is it worth it?" and surely the answer to "is it worth it?" is a resounding no. The study's authors may be touting the polypill as a revolutionary breakthrough, but the reality is that it's a pill that may not even benefit the majority of patients.

Furthermore, the study's findings are not generalizable to the UK population. The patients in the study were all from rural Iran, where the prevalence of cardiovascular disease is much higher than in the UK. The study's authors acknowledge this limitation, but fail to provide any data on how the polypill's effectiveness might vary in different populations.

And then there's the issue of medicalising healthy patients. The study included patients who were not already taking medication for cardiovascular disease, but who were still at high risk of developing it. This raises concerns about the over-medicalization of healthy individuals, and the potential for the polypill to become a new "quick fix" for patients who are not actually in need of treatment.

Finally, there's the risk of side-effects. The study reports that the polypill was well-tolerated, but this is a relative term. What does it mean to be "well-tolerated" when you're talking about a pill that contains four or five different medications? The potential for interactions and side-effects is enormous, and patients need to be aware of this before they start taking the polypill.

In conclusion, while the polypill may have shown promise in a small study in rural Iran, it's not a panacea for cardiovascular disease. Patients need to be cautious about the risks and benefits of this pill, and doctors need to consider the individual circumstances of each patient before prescribing it. As Cochrane himself would say, we need to ask the hard questions about whether this pill is truly worth it.

Name: Reduction bays. Location: The inner sanctums of the larger Waitrose stores. Appearance: A tornado of limbs flecked with yellow stickers. That sounds rather hectic for Waitrose. As the news of the closure of the reduction bays spread, customers took to social media to express their disappointment and frustration. As the debate continues, one thing is clear: the closure of the reduction bays has left many customers feeling a little bereft. Will they adapt to the new system, or will they take their business elsewhere in search of the thrill of the bargain hunt? Only time will tell.

The BBC appears to have lost sight of the purpose of its procedures (BBC defends censure of Naga Munchetty over Trump comments, theguardian.com, 27 September). The BBC guidelines are not laws. They are there to guide and are, therefore, open to interpretation. They are there to help producers make editorial decisions and, when a question about a programme is raised, to help frame a response. My experience of them is that they are a handy set of tools with enough wiggle room left for programme editors to make a judgment call. Television presenters are human beings. On Breakfast (unlike, say, the news) there is a conversational atmosphere between the presenters, who are expected to interact. And unlike news readers they are expected to project their personalities. The question here is how else should or could Naga Munchetty have reacted when discussing the US president's undeniably racist, sexist and flagrantly inaccurate comments? Not to have reacted in the measured, humane way she did would have left her looking like some kind of automaton, simply spouting whatever was coming down her earpiece. Invoking the letter of the guidelines is not an adequate response. An ill-considered kneejerk reaction to a single complaint is what has set this off, not Munchetty's entirely understandable comment. Peter Grimsdale Former BBC TV executive, London • There is some muddled thinking in the Hirsch/Henry et al letter (BBC's flawed Munchetty decision, Journal, 28 September). Of course future BBC journalists won't be hired on the basis of remaining "impartial" about their experience of racism. The BBC ruling states that Munchetty was justified in describing her feelings. Neither is racism to be endorsed as a legitimate opinion. But BBC journalists are required to avoid airing their political opinions or allowing them to influence the output. The debate surrounding Naga Munchetty's comments on Donald Trump's remarks has highlighted the complexities of balancing personal opinions with journalistic impartiality. While it's understandable that Munchetty was upset by Trump's comments, it's equally important for journalists to maintain a level of detachment when reporting on controversial topics.

The BBC's guidelines are intended to provide a framework for producers to make informed decisions, but they are not set in stone. Rather, they are meant to be flexible and adaptable to the ever-changing landscape of news and current events. In this case, Munchetty's measured response was a testament to her professionalism and ability to navigate the complexities of the situation.

It's also worth noting that the BBC's ruling on the matter has sparked a wider conversation about the role of personal experience in journalism. While it's true that journalists should not allow their personal opinions to influence their reporting, it's equally important to recognize that their experiences and perspectives can bring a unique depth and nuance to their coverage.

Ultimately, the key is to strike a balance between personal opinion and journalistic impartiality. By doing so, journalists can provide accurate and informative reporting while also bringing their own perspectives and experiences to the table. In the case of Naga Munchetty, her comments on Trump's remarks were a powerful example of this balance in action.

After Banff grammar and Aberdeen central schools he studied mathematics and physics at Aberdeen University before heading south to the Admiralty's scientific research department in London, for which he worked during the second world war. After the war he went to Corpus Christi College, Oxford, to study for a second degree, in philosophy, politics and economics, then after a short stint at the Foreign Office was elected fellow of St John's College, Oxford. St John's College, Oxford. It was during his time at St John's that George's passion for publishing began to take shape. He became involved with the Oxford University Press, initially as a member of the governing body, and later as a senior editor. His expertise in philosophy, politics, and economics proved invaluable in shaping the press's publishing strategy.

In the mid-1970s, George was appointed chief executive of Oxford University Press, a position he held for over a decade. During his tenure, he oversaw the publication of numerous influential works, including the Oxford English Dictionary and the Oxford Companion to Music. George was known for his keen eye for talent and his ability to nurture emerging authors and scholars. He was also a strong advocate for the importance of academic publishing, believing that it played a vital role in advancing knowledge and understanding.

After retiring from OUP in the late 1980s, George remained involved in the academic community, serving on various boards and committees. He was a generous mentor and friend to many, and his legacy continues to be felt throughout the academic world. George is survived by his wife, Margaret, and their two children, Sarah and James. His family and friends will remember him for his kind heart, his quick wit, and his tireless commitment to the pursuit of knowledge.

Britain's accountancy regulator is considering urgently whether to investigate the collapse of Thomas Cook and impose punishments if deemed necessary. The Financial Reporting Council (FRC) has the authority to investigate and sanction auditors of companies and individuals who are members of the accounting profession. The regulator announced it was considering an investigation after the government fast-tracked the Insolvency Service's investigation into the collapse of the 178-year-old travel firm. Sten Daugaard took over as chief financial officer in December 2018 from Bill Scott, who quit after less than a year in the job after Thomas Cook issued a profit warning. Scott replaced Michael Healy in January 2018 when Healy stepped down after five years in the job. The FRC said: "In light of recent developments at Thomas Cook we are considering whether there is any case for investigation and enforcement action as a matter of urgency and in cooperation with the Insolvency Service." Daugaard changed the way Thomas Cook reported its accounts to include items that had been treated as exceptional costs for several years, including when paying directors and meeting banking covenants. EY disagreed with the company's treatment of these items. The FRC's consideration of an investigation into Thomas Cook's collapse comes as the company's auditors, EY, are already facing scrutiny over their handling of the firm's finances. The regulator has raised concerns that EY may have failed to identify the company's financial difficulties earlier, potentially allowing it to continue trading despite being insolvent.

Industry insiders have suggested that EY's decision to approve Thomas Cook's accounts, despite the company's struggles, may have contributed to the firm's downfall. "EY should have been more vigilant in their audit of Thomas Cook's accounts," said one source. "They had a responsibility to ensure that the company's financial statements were accurate and transparent, but it seems they may have turned a blind eye to the company's financial difficulties."

The FRC's investigation could also focus on the role of Thomas Cook's finance chiefs in the company's collapse. Sten Daugaard, who took over as chief financial officer in December 2018, has been criticized for his handling of the company's finances. Daugaard's decision to change the way Thomas Cook reported its accounts, including the treatment of exceptional costs, has been questioned by some analysts.

EY has defended its handling of Thomas Cook's accounts, saying that it followed all relevant accounting standards and regulations. However, the FRC's investigation could still uncover evidence of wrongdoing or negligence on the part of the auditors or Thomas Cook's finance chiefs.

The collapse of Thomas Cook has sent shockwaves through the travel industry, with thousands of jobs lost and hundreds of thousands of customers left stranded. While thousands of holidaymakers were waiting in overseas airports for the government's emergency airlift to get them home and Thomas Cook staff were losing their jobs, former bosses of the stricken travel firm came under fire for receiving payouts worth more than £35m in the last 12 years. He quit in 2011 as the tour operator came close to collapse. His successor was Harriet Green, who was paid £4.7m for less than three years plus a share bonus worth a further £5.6m. She handed a third of that award to charities after the deaths of two children from carbon monoxide poisoning in Thomas Cook accommodation in Corfu. Brewing firm Budweiser is to phase out single-use plastic pack rings from its entire range of UK-produced beer – which include the bestselling brands Stella Artois, Budweiser and Bud Light – by the end of 2020. The group is investing £6.3m on upgrading production at its two UK factories to produce alternatives to single-use plastic, which include recyclable paperboard as well as wraps and boxes. It said the switch would help it eliminate 850 tonnes of plastic each year – the same weight as 425 black cabs, 67 double-decker buses or 10 blue whales. This includes removing 250 tonnes of plastic rings previously used to hold packs of beer cans together (117m plastic rings in total) and 600 tonnes of shrink film, mostly used as extra packaging around trays when shipping. Part of AB InBev, the world's biggest brewer, the group has some of the UK's biggest beer brands in its portfolio, including Beck's, Bud Light, Budweiser, Corona, Michelob Ultra and Stella Artois, and manufactures more than 870m cans a year. Paula Lindenberg, the president of Budweiser Brewing Group UK & Ireland, said: "This announcement ensures that the UK's favourite beers will soon come in recyclable paperboard packaging, so consumers can make better choices. We're proud of the work we've already done but we realised more needed to be done to address the issue of single-use plastics." The brewer is also switching to 100% locally sourced barley and 100% renewable electricity from solar power. As part of its commitment to sustainability, Budweiser is also introducing a new packaging design that will feature a unique QR code on each pack, allowing consumers to scan and learn more about the brand's sustainability efforts. The brewer is working with recycling companies to ensure that the new packaging is easily recyclable and to encourage consumers to recycle correctly.

The £6.3m investment in upgrading production will also include the installation of new machinery and equipment at Budweiser's two UK factories in Magor, Wales, and Ashby-de-la-Zouch, Leicestershire. The brewer is working closely with its suppliers to ensure that all materials used in the new packaging are sustainable and meet the highest environmental standards.

Budweiser's commitment to reducing plastic waste has been welcomed by environmental groups, who have been campaigning for years to reduce the use of single-use plastics. "This is a significant step forward in reducing plastic waste in the UK," said a spokesperson for the environmental charity, Keep Britain Tidy. "We urge other companies to follow Budweiser's lead and take action to reduce their plastic usage."

The switch to recyclable paperboard packaging is expected to have a significant impact on the environment, with the brewer estimating that it will reduce its carbon footprint by 20%. The brewer is also exploring other sustainable packaging options, including the use of biodegradable materials and edible packaging.

Budweiser's commitment to sustainability is part of a wider effort by the brewing industry to reduce its environmental impact. Many breweries are now investing in renewable energy, reducing water usage, and implementing recycling programs to reduce waste. As consumers become increasingly aware of the environmental impact of their purchasing decisions, breweries like Budweiser are responding by adopting more sustainable practices.

The company has promised to do better in the future, but the standoff in Tunisia has raised fresh concerns about its ability to support customers in times of crisis.
