The company has also promised to provide additional support to customers affected by the standoff, including those who were forced to pay the hotel fee out of pocket.

As the travel industry continues to grapple with the fallout from Thomas Cook's financial struggles, the standoff in Tunisia serves as a stark reminder of the importance of effective communication and customer support in times of crisis.

A home affairs public servant has complained to parliament that the department's whistleblowing scheme is flawed after it failed to independently investigate a report about a staffing incident involving a home affairs senior executive. The anonymous and heavily redacted submission to the Senate committee examining press freedom states that a public interest disclosure (PID) was made after staff became aware of an issue with hiring practices involving a senior executive within the department in 2017. But the report was sent back to the department rather than being investigated independently. It is unclear from the submission what ultimately happened with the investigation. The government has frequently proclaimed the public interest disclosure avenue for government whistleblowers is the proper process for reporting issues rather than leaking to the media. The home affairs secretary, Michael Pezzullo, has made clear the department would seek to investigate and prosecute public servants who leak sensitive information to the public. Pezzullo has said officers within the department are trained that they have three options for reporting issues: internal disclosure within the department; to the ombudsman; or to the Australian Commission for Law Enforcement Integrity (Aclei). The submission makes clear the public servant made inquiries with Aclei and went to the ombudsman, but the matter was handled internally. The submission also claims that the internal investigation was flawed, as the staff member who made the initial report was not interviewed and the inquiry was led by the same executive who was at the center of the staffing incident. The public servant is critical of the department's handling of the matter, stating that it appears to have been a "whitewash" and that the lack of transparency and accountability has created a culture of fear within the department.

The submission has sparked concerns about the effectiveness of the public interest disclosure scheme and the government's commitment to protecting whistleblowers. Opposition senators have called for an inquiry into the matter, with Labor's home affairs spokesperson, Kristina Keneally, stating that the government's handling of the situation is "deeply concerning".

"This is a clear example of the government's attempt to silence whistleblowers and cover up wrongdoing," Keneally said. "The public has a right to know what happened in this department and why the government is so keen to hide the truth."

The government has thus far refused to comment on the matter, with a spokesperson for the department stating that it does not comment on individual submissions to parliament. However, the submission has sparked a heated debate about the importance of whistleblowing and the need for greater transparency and accountability within government.

Many experts have weighed in on the issue, with some arguing that the public interest disclosure scheme is flawed and that whistleblowers are not adequately protected. Others have called for greater transparency and accountability within government, stating that the lack of trust in institutions is a major concern.

As the debate continues, it remains to be seen whether the government will take action to address the concerns raised in the submission and ensure that whistleblowers are adequately protected. In the meantime, the public servant who made the initial report remains anonymous, fearing retribution from the department.

Marks & Spencer will start offering a "buy now, pay later" service on its website next month as it tries to attract younger customers and boost trade going into the key Christmas period. The retailer has teamed up with Clearpay to offer customers the option of paying for orders of more than £30 in interest-free instalments. The Australian firm and its better known rival Klarna are among a wave of fintech companies being embraced by millennials on tight budgets. Many of M&S's rivals, including H&M and Asos, already offer delayed payment services and the struggling business is eager to attract a younger generation of shopper, including families with young children. M&S said its customers were increasingly looking for ways to spread the cost, particularly of larger purchases. The Clearpay service enables customers to spread the total over four instalments paid back across six weeks. The maximum spend is £800 and does not require a credit application and customers can manage their payments through a phone app. The move is part of M&S's efforts to revamp its online presence and appeal to a younger demographic, which has been a challenge for the retailer in recent years. The company has been investing heavily in its e-commerce platform and digital marketing campaigns to attract more online shoppers.

"We know that our customers are looking for more flexibility when it comes to paying for their purchases, and our partnership with Clearpay gives them just that," said a spokesperson for M&S. "We're excited to offer this new service, which will make it easier for our customers to shop with us online."

The Clearpay service is available on M&S's website from next month, and customers can choose to pay for their orders in four instalments of £200 each. The service is interest-free, and customers can manage their payments through the Clearpay app.

M&S has been struggling to compete with online-only retailers such as ASOS and Boohoo, which have been able to offer more flexible payment options and faster delivery times. The company has been investing in its own logistics and delivery network to try to close the gap, but the addition of Clearpay's delayed payment service is seen as a key move in its efforts to attract more online shoppers.

The service is expected to be popular with families, who may be looking for ways to spread the cost of larger purchases, such as toys and clothing, over a longer period. It may also appeal to students and young professionals, who may be on tighter budgets and looking for ways to manage their finances.

Two years ago Thames Water – unilaterally and without notice – decided that the residential rental property we lived in until this August was a commercial one and transferred our account to Castle Water. We were told that it was our new provider, but not the reason behind it. Since our direct debit was also automatically transferred, we continued to pay and didn't think further about it. It was only when I notified Castle Water we were moving that I found out they thought we were a commercial customer. We are a family of two adults and a baby. After receiving assurances that the mistake would be rectified and that Thames would claim the money we've paid to Castle, we received two bills for almost £1,000 from Thames Water. We have not received any refunds from Castle Water so this would mean paying for our water twice. I have also sent an inquiry to the Consumer Council for Water but have received no reply yet. Our first complaint was in mid July 2019 and I haven't heard from Thames Water for at least two weeks. GC, London SW6 You are one of many unwittingly caught up in the acquisition of Thames Water's (supposed) business accounts by Castle Water, which describes itself as a dedicated water retailer to business customers. Castle Water started in Scotland, but has since bought up a number of other water businesses across the UK. Clearly the reason for the transfer of accounts was not clearly communicated in your case. Our intervention seems to have broken the logjam. After weeks of frustration and uncertainty, we finally received a response from Thames Water, apologizing for the mistake and confirming that they would take steps to rectify the situation. They explained that the transfer of our account was a result of an error in their system, which had misclassified our property as a commercial premises. Castle Water, they acknowledged, had also made an error in not verifying the property's usage before taking over the account.

Thames Water assured us that they would claim back the payments we had made to Castle Water and that we would not be charged twice for our water. We were also told that they would waive any additional charges or penalties that may have accrued as a result of the mistake. While this was a welcome development, we were still left feeling frustrated and disappointed by the lack of transparency and communication from both Thames Water and Castle Water.

We hope that this experience will serve as a warning to others who may be affected by similar mistakes. It is essential that water companies and retailers take greater care when transferring accounts, and that customers are kept informed throughout the process. We are grateful for the intervention of the consumer watchdog, which helped to break the logjam and secure a resolution to our case.

Supplies of festive food staples including pigs in blankets, glazed hams and three-bird roasts could be hit by Brexit-related labour shortages in the meat industry. Some specialist processing plants that require additional seasonal labour for hand-finished products are already struggling to meet orders, according to the National Pig Association (NPA), which represents processors, abattoirs and farmers. Most meat processing plants have labour shortages equivalent to up to 15% of their required workforces, as the fall in the value of the pound since the 2016 referendum has combined with uncertainty about residential status, according to the Grocer trade journal. But the labour shortage at seasonal specialists could be as much as 30% because they usually increase their workforce by up to 15% at this time of year, says the British Meat Processors Association. Ed Barker, senior policy advisor of the NPA, said several processors who relied on regular semi-skilled labourers from Europe had said they were struggling to fulfil orders ahead of Christmas. "It was difficult last year and the year before but it seems to be particularly squeezed this year. The situation is further complicated by the fact that many of these seasonal workers have already left the UK, returning to their home countries for the winter. "We're seeing a lot of uncertainty and unpredictability, which is making it difficult for processors to plan and manage their workforces," said Barker. The shortage is not limited to pigs in blankets, with some processors reporting difficulties in meeting demand for other festive favorites, such as turkey and goose. The industry is urging the government to provide more clarity on the future of EU migration and to take steps to address the labor shortage. In the meantime, some processors are considering alternative staffing solutions, such as hiring temporary workers from other countries or increasing automation. However, these measures may not be enough to meet the demand for festive food staples, leaving consumers to worry about whether they will be able to get their favorite holiday dishes on the table.

Upmarket department store Fortnum & Mason has reported another year of bumper sales and profits but said its new Hong Kong store had been hit by the pro-democracy protests. Its chief executive Ewan Venters said sales in the territory were running at only half the level expected since it opened its doors last week but he was optimistic that trade would improve with its restaurant – with its view of Hong Kong harbour – receiving 4,000 bookings for December. It is the first standalone Fortnum & Mason shop outside the UK. "Hong Kong is going to bounce back and be a strong business for us," said Venters, who reported shoppers spending up to HK$7,000 (£694) on gourmet treats such as smoked salmon and caviar. Asked about the wisdom of opening in the troubled city, he said: "It's not our place to get overly political. We are an English brand that goes out into the world to sell tea, biscuits and jam." The retailer, which was founded in 1707 by William Fortnum, a royal footman, and his landlord Hugh Mason, also has concessions in Lane Crawford department stores in Hong Kong as well as Isetan Mitsukoshi in Japan and Shinsegae in South Korea. Despite the challenges, Venters remains committed to the Hong Kong market, citing the store's unique location and the appeal of its luxury products. "We're not just a department store, we're a destination," he said. "Our customers are looking for an experience, and our new store offers that with its stunning views of the harbour." The company has also launched a range of special edition Hong Kong-themed products, including a limited-edition tea blend and a bespoke hamper featuring local delicacies. Venters believes these initiatives will help to drive sales and attract more customers to the store. "We're confident that our Hong Kong store will become a flagship location for us, and we're committed to making it a success," he said. The company's strong performance in Hong Kong is a welcome boost for Fortnum & Mason, which has faced increased competition from online retailers and changing consumer habits in recent years. Despite these challenges, the retailer has continued to innovate and expand its operations, and Venters is optimistic about its future prospects. "We're in a great position to continue to grow and thrive, and we're excited about the opportunities ahead," he said.

Re your article (One in five pupils granted more time to sit key exams, 22 November), if we are serious about inclusion and access for all, we must question the copious amounts of time spent testing children and young people to identify their "abnormal" needs for time, prior to taking written exams. Far better to accept that it is normal for everyone to work at different speeds, and to give everyone the time they need to do the task. and focus on providing tailored support to help them reach their full potential. The current system is not only stressful and anxiety-inducing, but it also perpetuates a culture of labeling and stigmatizing students who require extra time. By shifting our approach to one that emphasizes student-centered learning and acknowledges individual differences, we can create a more inclusive and supportive environment that fosters growth and achievement for all. It's time to rethink our approach to assessment and focus on helping students develop the skills and confidence they need to succeed, rather than simply identifying their "abnormal" needs. By doing so, we can ensure that every student has the opportunity to thrive and reach their full potential, regardless of their abilities or learning style.

Ikea's parent company is to invest an additional €200m (£171m) in green energy and forest planting as part of a plan by the world's largest furniture retailer to become carbon neutral by 2030. The investment is being made by Inter Ikea Group, the owner of the Ikea brand which is operated by a string of franchise businesses, the largest of which is Ingka Group. Inter Ikea Group said its €200m investment would be released in two phases. The first phase of €100m would be directed towards new renewable energy projects including heating, cooling and electricity generation. The group said investment would be in partnership with suppliers and directed towards parts of its supply chain where converting to renewable energy was more difficult – such as the textile industry, ceramics and glass production. The second tranche will be aimed at removing and storing carbon through reforestation and responsible forest management. Ikea said it was considering a variety of global regions for reforestation projects. The group statement said: "It is most likely that we will put an emphasis on projects in tropical and subtropical regions. This is because there is a vast amount of degraded land in need of reforestation, and forests in these regions grow faster making it possible to remove more carbon from the atmosphere." The investment is part of Ikea's ambitious plan to become carbon neutral by 2030, a goal that has been set by the company's founder, Ingvar Kamprad. The company has been working towards reducing its environmental impact for several years, and this latest investment is a significant step forward in achieving that goal.

Ikea's commitment to sustainability is not limited to its own operations. The company has also been working with its suppliers to encourage them to adopt more sustainable practices. The €100m investment in renewable energy projects will be used to support suppliers in the textile, ceramics, and glass production industries, which are often difficult to convert to renewable energy.

The company is also exploring ways to reduce waste and increase recycling. Ikea has already implemented a number of initiatives to reduce waste, including the use of recycled materials in its products and the recycling of old furniture. The company is also working to reduce its packaging waste by using biodegradable materials and minimizing the amount of packaging used.

Ikea's commitment to sustainability has been recognized by several organizations, including the Carbon Trust, which has awarded the company a carbon reduction certificate. The company has also been recognized for its efforts to reduce waste and increase recycling, and has received several awards for its sustainability initiatives.

Overall, Ikea's investment in green energy and forest planting is a significant step forward in the company's efforts to become carbon neutral by 2030. The company's commitment to sustainability is not limited to its own operations, but also extends to its suppliers and the wider community.

A power outage has hit the ABC's Ultimo headquarters, crashing the ABC News website, app and, in some cases, forcing the homepage to display stories from 2011. The retro formatting greeted ABC readers on Wednesday morning, along with news that Julia Gillard was still the prime minister, Lady Gaga had just performed in Sydney and the Australian dollar was nearly at parity with the US. On TV the ABC Breakfast program broadcast 15 seconds of a still image of a chicken, though it was unclear whether this was due to the power cut. By 10am AEDT, the entire online news front page was down. But those who had earlier visited the main news front page saw the archived homepages. Other users were automatically redirected to a mobile version of the site – which showed up-to-date articles but with no images and with 2011-era fonts. As the day went on, ABC staff scrambled to rectify the issue, but the website remained offline for several hours. The outage also affected the ABC's social media channels, with many users taking to Twitter to express their frustration and amusement at the retro layout.

"I'm not sure what's more surprising, the fact that the ABC's website is still using the same design from 2011 or that Julia Gillard is still the Prime Minister," tweeted one user.

Others joked about the blast from the past, with some even sharing screenshots of the retro homepage on social media.

Despite the chaos, the ABC's technical team worked tirelessly to resolve the issue, with a spokesperson apologizing for the inconvenience caused.

"We're working as quickly as possible to restore the website to its usual format," the spokesperson said. "We understand the importance of having access to our news and information, and we're doing everything we can to get the site back up and running."

As the outage continued, ABC staff were forced to rely on backup systems to continue broadcasting news and current affairs programs. The ABC's radio services were not affected by the outage, with many listeners tuning in to stay informed about the latest news and events.

The cause of the outage is still unknown, but the ABC has promised to conduct a thorough investigation to prevent similar incidents in the future. In the meantime, the broadcaster's staff are working hard to restore the website to its usual format, and ABC readers can expect a return to business as usual in the coming days.

On Friday, about 200 employees rallied outside Google's office in San Francisco to demand that two suspended worker activists be reinstated. By Monday, at least one of the suspended workers said she had been fired, with reports that three other Google staffers had also been let go. Rebecca Rivers, a software engineer at Google who had been involved with internal protests against Google's work with US Customs and Border Protection (CBP), announced her firing on Twitter on Monday afternoon. Three other Google staffers were also fired on Monday, according to an internal company memo obtained by Bloomberg. Leaders of Google's security and investigations team said in the memo the firings were due to "clear and repeated violations of our data security policies". Google confirmed the accuracy of the memo published by Bloomberg but declined to comment further. The firings prompted immediate allegations of retaliation from current and former Google employees. ﻿One of the organizers of the walkout, Meredith Whittaker, called Rivers's firing "craven retaliation" in a tweet. Stephanie Parker, a current YouTube employee, called the terminations "inhumane" and "illegal" on Twitter. The sudden firings have sparked widespread outrage and concern among Google employees, who are accusing the company of retaliating against workers who have spoken out against its policies and practices. Many are calling for an investigation into the matter and demanding that the company take immediate action to address the issue.

Rivers, who had been a vocal critic of Google's work with CBP, said in a statement that she was "devastated" by the firing and accused the company of "punishing" her for exercising her right to free speech. "I am proud to have stood up for what is right, even when it was hard," she said. "I will not be silenced by Google's attempts to intimidate and retaliate against me."

The firings have also sparked concerns about the company's treatment of employees who speak out against its policies. Many are worried that the company is using its power to silence and punish workers who dare to challenge its decisions.

"This is a clear example of retaliation and it's unacceptable," said Parker, who is also a member of the Alphabet Workers Union. "Google is trying to intimidate and silence us, but we will not be silenced. We will continue to stand up for what is right and fight for our rights as workers."

The firings have also sparked a renewed call for greater transparency and accountability from Google. Many are demanding that the company provide more information about the reasons behind the firings and that it take concrete steps to prevent similar incidents in the future.

In response to the backlash, Google has released a statement saying that it is "committed to maintaining a workplace where all employees feel safe and supported." However, many are skeptical of the company's commitment to this goal, given its history of punishing workers who speak out against its policies.

The controversy has also sparked a wider debate about the role of tech companies in society and the need for greater accountability and transparency. Many are calling for greater scrutiny of the industry's practices and for workers to be protected from retaliation for speaking out against their employers.

As the controversy continues to unfold, many are left wondering what the future holds for Google and its employees. Will the company take concrete steps to address the concerns of its workers, or will it continue to prioritize its own interests over the well-being of its employees? Only time will tell.

The Fearless Girl statue has been a lot of things to a lot of people. The 4ft bronze of a defiant youngster, hands on hips facing down the status quo, has been dismissed as a cynical marketing stunt and celebrated as a selfie-friendly symbol of a new feminism. Now she is at the center of a court battle aimed at stopping her marching across the world. The original Fearless Girl appeared overnight in March 2017, the day before International Women's Day, in downtown New York. Facing off against the Charging Bull statue close to Wall Street, the sculpture was commissioned by State Street Global, an asset management company, to promote a fund investing in gender-diverse companies. It became an instant hit. Crowds gathered to take selfies. The Massachusetts Ssenator Elizabeth Warren, a longtime critic of Wall Street and a frontrunner for the 2020 Democratic presidential nomination, was one of the celebrities to use the statue to promote her policies. Sculptor Kristen Visbal has since made several copies of Fearless Girls that now stand resolutely in cities including London and Oslo. But on Monday, State Street made its latest attempt to stop the Fearless Girl from spreading further, moving to have a statue removed from Federation Square in Melbourne. In a lawsuit against Maurice Blackburn, the Australian personal injury firm that commissioned the Melbourne piece, State Street argues the replicas violate its trademark and dilute the company's message. According to the New York Times, David Studdy, a lawyer for the company, said Maurice Blackburn had "used the campaign to promote itself or themselves by tying the name of Fearless Girl to themselves". The lawsuit has sparked a heated debate about intellectual property, free speech, and the power of art to inspire social change. Many have rallied behind Maurice Blackburn, arguing that the Fearless Girl statue is a powerful symbol of female empowerment that should be allowed to spread and inspire others. "The Fearless Girl is more than just a trademarked image - it's a movement," said Rachel Corbett, a Melbourne-based artist who has been involved in the city's feminist art scene. "Trying to silence it is a silencing of the voices of women everywhere." Meanwhile, State Street has argued that its original intention was to use the Fearless Girl as a marketing tool, and that the proliferation of replicas has diluted the message and undermined its brand. The case is set to go to trial later this year, with the outcome likely to have significant implications for the art world and beyond. As the debate rages on, one thing is clear: the Fearless Girl has become a cultural phenomenon that refuses to be silenced.

On Monday more than 40,000 academic staff are expected to take part in eight days of strikes over pensions pay and conditions. The action will affect more than a million students across 60 campuses. The University and college Union (UCU) has accused universities of 'strong-arm tactics', to undermine the strike action. There has been outrage on social media over attempts by universities to warn students off joining picket lines and encourage them to report any of their lecturers who strike. We' In February last year, lecturers as well as other university employees across the country took part in the biggest ever industrial action taken within the universities. The strikes occurred on 14 days and were spread across one month, causing large disruptions for students – some of whom called for compensation. The UCU has condemned the universities' behavior, saying it is an attempt to intimidate and silence its members. "It's outrageous that universities are trying to bully and threaten their own staff, rather than engaging with them in a meaningful way to resolve this dispute," said Jo Grady, UCU general secretary. "We will not be deterred by these strong-arm tactics and will continue to fight for fair pensions, pay, and conditions for our members." The strikes are expected to cause significant disruptions to academic schedules, with many lectures and seminars cancelled or postponed. Students have expressed frustration and disappointment at the situation, with many taking to social media to express their support for the striking lecturers. Some have also called for the universities to take responsibility for the disruption and offer compensation to affected students. The dispute has highlighted the ongoing tensions between universities and their staff, with many arguing that the sector is facing a crisis of underfunding and over-reliance on casual labor. As the strikes continue, the UCU is urging students to stand in solidarity with their lecturers and to demand that universities take action to address the underlying issues driving the dispute.

This week, staff in 60 universities across the UK will take part in a strike led by the University and College Union (UCU). Their choice to strike has the full support of the National Union of Students (NUS) – but not all students have come out in favour of the action. Unfortunately, I've heard many fellow students criticise the decision of lecturers to go on strike. Within a few hours after the industrial action was announced, a petition was launched calling for lost contact hours to be reimbursed. Many are worried that the eight-day period may impact their end of term grades. They reason that they're paying tuition fees, so they should expect a full term of teaching. Of course, losing valuable time is frustrating for the one million students who could be affected. But the frustration is mutual among staff and students. Both feel that universities are being turned into businesses that are impersonal and poorly run. We should not direct our anger towards lecturers, but rather to the institutions forcing them to strike. It's not as if our tuition fees all go to our tutors. Academics' pay has fallen by 17% in real terms since 2009. The strike has also highlighted the growing concern among students and staff about the commercialization of higher education. Many universities are prioritizing profits over people, and it's affecting the quality of education and the well-being of students and staff alike. The UCU is demanding a 2% pay rise for university staff, as well as action to address the issue of casualization and precarious contracts.

In a statement, the NUS said, "We support the UCU's strike and recognize the impact that the increasing commercialization of higher education is having on students and staff. We believe that education should be a public good, not a commodity to be exploited for profit." The union is calling on students to support the strike and to join the campaign to defend public education.

The strike has also sparked a wider debate about the future of higher education in the UK. Many experts argue that the current system is unsustainable and that radical change is needed to ensure that education remains accessible and affordable for all. The strike is a wake-up call for the government and universities to take action to address the crisis in higher education.

In the meantime, students and staff are left to pick up the pieces and navigate the disruption caused by the strike. While some students are frustrated by the lost contact hours, others are using the time to organize and campaign for change. The strike may be inconvenient, but it's also an opportunity for students and staff to come together and demand a better future for higher education.

Spending on the Bank of England's summer party crept closer to £100,000 this year despite Threadneedle Street promising MPs it would put the expensive event under review. Figures released by the central bank showed that party planners racked up a bill of £96,188 on the event, which hosted nearly 2,500 staff and their families at the Bank's sports club in Roehampton, south-west London in July. Costs for the annual party – known as Governors' Day – included more than £52,200 on food and soft drinks and nearly £30,000 on family entertainment, which in 2018 involved a treasure hunt, bake-off competition, fun run and bouncy castle. That was on top of nearly £2,000 for equipment and £12,000 for "other" undisclosed expenses. The total is slightly higher than the £95,673 spent on Governors' Day in 2018, and while the increase is marginal – about £515 – it will raise questions over whether the bank is serious about reviewing its costs. In May, members of the Bank's board, known at as the Court of Directors, were grilled by MPs over expenses including the summer party bill. Dorothy Thompson, a Court director and former Drax chief executive, defended the party but said the Bank was looking to rein in spending. "This is an annual event. The cost is £40 per head. There is no alcohol funded. Despite the Bank's assurances to MPs, the latest figures suggest that the party planners may not have taken the review as seriously as promised. The total cost of the event, including the £96,188 bill, is a significant increase from previous years and has sparked concerns over the Bank's priorities.

Critics argue that the Bank's focus on hosting lavish events is a distraction from its core responsibilities, including setting monetary policy and regulating the financial sector. "It's appalling that the Bank is wasting such large sums of money on a party while it's supposed to be keeping the economy stable," said Sarah Jones, a Labour MP and member of the Treasury Select Committee.

The Bank's decision to spend nearly £2,000 on equipment for the event has also raised eyebrows. When questioned about the expense, a Bank spokesperson said that the equipment was needed to ensure the safety and well-being of the staff and their families. However, some have suggested that the equipment could have been rented or borrowed instead of purchased outright.

The news has also sparked concerns over the Bank's transparency and accountability. While the Bank does release annual reports on its expenses, critics argue that the level of detail is not sufficient to provide a clear picture of how the Bank is spending its money.

In response to the criticism, the Bank has pledged to review its expenses and ensure that they are in line with its core values. However, the latest figures suggest that the Bank still has some way to go in achieving this goal. As the debate over the Bank's expenses continues, it remains to be seen whether the Bank will be able to strike a better balance between its social events and its core responsibilities.

In 1974 Diarmuid Lawrence and I were on the same BBC film directors' training course, and he made a great impression not just as a creative person but also as a kind man. He acted for me in one exercise based on a short script that I had written and was a joy to work with – I always thought he could have made a good career as an actor, although maybe he should have been a diplomat. because of his natural charm and ability to put people at ease. I was thrilled to have him on board and was impressed by his skill and attention to detail. Over the years, we worked together on several projects, and I watched him grow into one of the most respected and sought-after directors in the industry.
