Despite his many successes, Diarmuid remained humble and grounded, and it was a pleasure to call him a friend and colleague.

Something is happening out there, and astronomers sure wish they knew what it was. For the last several years, they have been teased and baffled by mysterious bursts of radio waves from the distant universe: pops of low-frequency radiation, emitting more energy than the sun does in a day, that occur randomly and disappear immediately. Nobody knows when these "fast radio bursts," or F.R.B.s, will occur, or where exactly in the cosmos they are occurring. More than 60 of these surprise broadcasts have been recorded so far. About the only thing astronomers agree on is that these signals probably are not extraterrestrials saying hello. Despite the uncertainty surrounding the origins of these enigmatic signals, scientists are working tirelessly to unravel the mystery. One theory is that F.R.B.s are the result of cataclysmic events, such as supernovae explosions or the merger of two neutron stars. Another possibility is that they are caused by magnetars, incredibly powerful magnetic fields that can release enormous amounts of energy. To further investigate, astronomers are using powerful telescopes to scan the skies for any signs of these bursts, and even launching specialized spacecraft to detect and study them up close. The search for answers is ongoing, and scientists are optimistic that the key to understanding these mysterious signals lies just beyond the horizon.

The game of thrones at NBCUniversal has begun. The company on Monday announced a series of executive changes that could set the stage for the next generation of leaders at a media empire that includes the NBC broadcast network; Universal Film Studios; and cable channels such as Bravo and MSNBC, which has seen a ratings surge during the Trump administration. Stephen B. Burke, the chief executive, streamlined the management structure by putting Jeff Shell in charge of Hollywood operations, including the international business and Telemundo, and having Mark Lazarus oversee the broadcast network, the news division, the cable networks and the sports group. Bonnie Hammer, 68, the longtime head of the company's profitable cable portfolio, has been put in charge of an advertising-supported streaming service that was announced Monday and is expected to debut early next year. It will compete with new stand-alone streaming products from the Walt Disney Company and AT&T's WarnerMedia, as well as entrenched players like Netflix and Hulu. Disney's and WarnerMedia's products are expected to debut at the end of this year. The new streaming service, dubbed "Peacock," will offer a range of content, including TV shows, movies, and original programming, all supported by ads. NBCUniversal has high hopes for the service, which will be available to consumers for free, with an ad-supported model, as well as a paid tier with additional features and content. The company believes that Peacock will be a major player in the growing streaming market, and is planning to invest heavily in its development and marketing. With Bonnie Hammer at the helm, the company is confident that Peacock will be a major success, and a key part of its strategy to stay ahead of the competition in the rapidly changing media landscape.

The scrutiny of Facebook's collection and use of consumer data in recent years has prompted the tech giant to repeatedly defend its efforts around transparency and privacy. But about three-fourths of Facebook users were unaware that the company lists their personal traits and interests for advertisers on its site, according to a study published by the Pew Research Center on Wednesday. Half of the users who looked at the Facebook page with that data -- known as their "Ad Preferences" -- said they were not comfortable with the company's compiling that information. Pew conducted a nationally representative survey of 963 American adults with Facebook accounts between Sept. 4 and Oct. 1 of last year. While consumers have learned more in recent years about how they are targeted for online ads, the study suggests that many still do not know how much of their behavior is tracked, where it is compiled or even that Facebook has a page that lists all of that information. The study also found that only 42% of Facebook users knew that the company uses data from third-party sources, such as other websites and apps, to create a profile of their interests and behaviors. Additionally, 55% of users were unaware that Facebook uses their data to show them targeted ads. The Pew Research Center's findings suggest that despite increased scrutiny of Facebook's data collection practices, many users remain unaware of the extent to which their personal information is being used to shape their online experience. The study's authors noted that this lack of understanding could have significant implications for consumer trust and the overall transparency of the digital advertising ecosystem. As Facebook continues to face pressure to improve its data practices, the findings of this study highlight the need for greater education and awareness among users about how their personal data is being used online.

WASHINGTON -- The Federal Trade Commission is in the advanced stages of its investigation into whether Facebook violated privacy rules and is expected to seek large fines from the company, according to two people familiar with the inquiry. The five members of the commission met in mid-December to discuss the investigation, according to the people, who would speak only on the condition of anonymity because the investigation is not public. The meeting is a sign that the investigation is far along, the people said, because the commissioners rarely meet in the early stages of an inquiry. The FTC's investigation centers on Facebook's handling of user data, particularly in the wake of the Cambridge Analytica scandal, where the political consulting firm harvested the personal information of millions of Facebook users without their consent. The agency is also scrutinizing Facebook's policies and practices regarding data sharing and its dealings with third-party app developers. If the FTC decides to fine Facebook, it would be the largest penalty ever imposed on a technology company. The fine could be as high as $2 billion, according to some estimates. Facebook has previously cooperated with the investigation and has implemented changes to its data handling practices in an effort to address the FTC's concerns. However, the company's willingness to comply may not be enough to avoid a significant financial penalty.

There it was in the night sky as Sunday stretched into Monday: a total lunar eclipse. Where people had clear conditions and unobstructed views, the moon took on a coppery red color. It was the only such eclipse of 2019, and it occurred just before midnight Eastern time. In parts of New York City, the night might have been frigid enough to keep potential skywatchers indoors, but the clouds had cleared enough for a good view, following cloudy obstructions earlier in the day. The eclipse took place because Earth got between the sun and the moon, throwing a shadow over our planet's pearly satellite. It's the opposite of a solar eclipse, when the moon gets in the sun's way, causing night to fall during day on parts of Earth's surface. As the moon's reddish hue filled the sky, astronomy enthusiasts and casual observers alike gathered at rooftop observatories, parks, and even backyards to witness the rare phenomenon. Many were equipped with special glasses or binoculars to enhance their view, while others simply gazed in awe at the celestial spectacle. The eerie glow of the moon cast an otherworldly light on the city streets, a reminder of the awe-inspiring beauty that lay just beyond our reach.

Viacom, the once mighty cable giant behind pop culture confections like "Jersey Shore" and children's fare like "Dora the Explorer," is acquiring the streaming service PlutoTV for $340 million, the companies said in an announcement on Tuesday. This is Viacom's most significant move into streaming, now the go-to strategy for media companies as more and more viewers forgo traditional cable subscriptions. The emergence of streaming services like Netflix and Hulu has hastened the decline of the pay TV business and has upended the media universe. Time Warner, once the largest media business in the country, sold itself to AT&T in an $85.4 billion deal last year, and Rupert Murdoch, who had built a giant entertainment conglomerate over decades, is selling the bulk of his empire to the Walt Disney Company for $71.3 billion after a bitter bidding war against Comcast. The impetus for both deals was to create entities capable of taking on Netflix and other tech companies by offering their own streaming plans. The acquisition of PlutoTV marks a significant shift in Viacom's strategy, as the company seeks to adapt to the changing media landscape. PlutoTV, a free, ad-supported streaming service, has gained popularity for its vast library of TV shows, movies, and on-demand content. The deal is expected to give Viacom a foothold in the streaming market, allowing it to compete with industry giants like Netflix and Hulu. With PlutoTV's existing user base and Viacom's extensive library of content, the combined entity is poised to become a major player in the streaming wars. The deal is expected to close in the second half of the year, pending regulatory approval.

Years before Facebook, Instagram and Twitter took over as the prime spots for oversharing, people had to go to websites like Open Diary, Blogger and LiveJournal to publish their thoughts for the world to read. But over time, social media became the way that people shared articles that reflected their politics, posted images of loved ones and sent out messages of frustration or exultation. As social media platforms evolved, so did the nature of online sharing. What was once a space for personal musings and intimate connections became a battleground for ideological debates and curated highlight reels. The proliferation of algorithms and echo chambers further polarized online discourse, making it increasingly difficult for people to engage with opposing viewpoints. Despite this, many individuals continued to use social media as a means of self-expression, sharing their stories and experiences with the world. However, as the online landscape continued to shift, concerns about data privacy, cyberbullying, and the erosion of meaningful human connection began to grow. As a result, some individuals turned to alternative platforms, such as Medium and Reddit, seeking a more authentic and nuanced online experience.

SAN FRANCISCO -- Technology companies rarely make money before they go public. Twitter was unprofitable when it listed on the stock market. So were Snap, Spotify and SurveyMonkey. For Uber, the question as the ride-hailing giant prepares for a public offering is even bigger than whether it can make money. The question is whether Uber can make money while also pleasing its investors, employees, and users. The company has been burning through cash at an alarming rate, with losses totaling over $10 billion in 2018 alone. This has led some to wonder if Uber's business model is sustainable, and if the company can continue to grow while also turning a profit.

One major concern is the high cost of operating a ride-hailing service. Uber has to pay drivers, maintain a fleet of vehicles, and invest in technology to keep its platform running smoothly. Additionally, the company faces intense competition from other ride-hailing services, such as Lyft, and must constantly innovate to stay ahead of the curve.

Despite these challenges, Uber is confident that it can turn a profit in the near future. The company has been taking steps to reduce costs and increase revenue, such as expanding its food delivery service and investing in emerging technologies like self-driving cars. If successful, these efforts could help Uber achieve profitability and justify its high valuation in the eyes of investors.

PITTSBURGH -- Last year, The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette chose Martin Luther King's Birthday as the publication date for an editorial headlined "Reason as Racism." On Monday, a little more than a year after that piece drew national criticism, The Post-Gazette named its editorial page director, Keith C. Burris, as its newsroom leader. Mr. Burris was appointed executive editor at a stormy time at the Pittsburgh daily. Relations between its workers' union, the Newspaper Guild of Pittsburgh, and the paper's owner, Block Communications, have been tense. Things came to a head on the night of Feb. 9, when John R. Block, the publisher, subjected staff members to a tirade in the newsroom. According to several journalists who were present, Mr. Block threatened employees' jobs as his young daughter, whom he had brought with him, sobbed and begged him to stop. Block Communications has disputed the journalists' version of events. The controversy surrounding the Feb. 9 incident has only added to the already strained atmosphere in the newsroom. The Newspaper Guild of Pittsburgh has demanded an apology from Block Communications and has called for an independent investigation into the matter. The union has also requested a meeting with John R. Block to address the concerns of the staff.

In a statement, Block Communications denied the allegations made by the journalists, claiming that the publisher's behavior was "unprofessional, but not threatening." The company has also announced that it will be conducting its own internal investigation into the incident.

The controversy has sparked widespread criticism on social media, with many calling for Block Communications to take immediate action to address the situation. The Pittsburgh community has also rallied around the journalists, with many expressing their support for the staff and their demands for a more transparent and respectful work environment.

As the situation continues to unfold, the future of Keith C. Burris as executive editor remains uncertain. Some have questioned whether he can effectively lead the newsroom in the wake of the controversy, while others have defended his ability to navigate the challenging situation. Regardless, one thing is clear: the incident has sent a shockwave through the newsroom, and it will take more than just words to repair the damage.

It's time to add one more tiny moon to Neptune's icy family tree. Astronomers using the Hubble Space Telescope have spied a previously undetected satellite around the solar system's eighth planet, bringing its total number to 14. The discovery, formally reported Wednesday in Nature, is a stark reminder that there is much more to be found in our own backyard, with implications for our understanding of worlds around other stars in our galaxy. "I think people have the impression that we know everything there is to know about the moons of Jupiter, the moons of Saturn, the moons of Uranus and the moons of Neptune -- but we don't really," said Anne Verbiscer, a planetary scientist at the University of Virginia, who was not involved in the recent discovery. "We haven't found everything." The newly discovered moon, temporarily designated as S/2004 N 1, is a small, icy body that orbits Neptune at a distance of about 25,000 miles (40,000 kilometers). It's estimated to be about 12 miles (20 kilometers) in diameter, making it one of the smallest moons in the solar system. The discovery was made possible by a team of astronomers who used the Hubble Space Telescope to observe Neptune's faint light and detect the subtle gravitational pull of the new moon. The team's findings are expected to shed new light on the formation and evolution of the Neptune system, as well as the potential for similar discoveries in other planetary systems. As scientists continue to explore the vast expanse of our solar system, it's clear that there is still much to be learned and many more secrets waiting to be uncovered.

Each week, technology reporters and columnists from The New York Times review the week's news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Want this newsletter in your inbox? Sign up here. Hello, dear readers! I'm Nicole Perlroth, cybersecurity reporter here at The Times. Here is the continued text:

As we wrap up another week in the tech world, it's clear that cybersecurity has taken center stage. The latest revelations about the SolarWinds hack have left many wondering how such a sophisticated attack could go undetected for so long. Meanwhile, the debate over encryption and backdoors continues to rage on, with some arguing that it's time to rethink our approach to online security. In other news, the big tech companies are facing growing pressure to address their environmental impact, with some calling for more transparency and accountability in their sustainability reporting. And in a surprise move, a major social media platform announced a new feature aimed at curbing online harassment. What did we miss? Let us know what you think about these stories and what you'd like to see more of in this newsletter. As always, thanks for reading and we'll see you next week!

WASHINGTON -- The Federal Trade Commission on Wednesday announced a $5.7 million settlement with Musical.ly, a popular video social network now known as TikTok, over accusations that the company's app illegally collected personal information about children. The F.T.C. said it was a record fine for a child privacy violation. The settlement marks the largest penalty ever imposed by the FTC for a child privacy violation, and comes as the social media landscape continues to evolve and raise concerns about the protection of young users' personal data. The FTC alleged that Musical.ly, which was acquired by ByteDance, the parent company of TikTok, in 2018, violated the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act (COPPA) by collecting the personal information of children under the age of 13 without proper parental consent. The company also failed to provide clear and prominent disclosures about its data collection practices, the FTC said. As part of the settlement, TikTok must delete the personal information it collected from children and implement new measures to ensure compliance with COPPA. The company has also agreed to undergo regular audits to ensure its data collection practices are in line with the law. The FTC's action is seen as a significant step in holding social media companies accountable for their handling of children's personal data.

SAN FRANCISCO -- Ten years ago, Google was hacked by the Chinese military in one of the most startling cyberattacks on an American company by government-affiliated agents. This week, Chronicle, a security start-up owned by Google's parent company, Alphabet, plans to bring some of what it learned from that incident to other companies through a widely anticipated new product called Backstory. The idea, company executives said, is simple: Backstory will make Alphabet's vast storage, indexing and search abilities available to other companies, allowing them to search through giant volumes of data, going years back, to trace the back story of a malicious attack. Chronicle is hardly the only company doing this. but its access to Google's vast resources and expertise sets it apart from competitors. Backstory is expected to be launched at the RSA Conference in San Francisco on Tuesday, and company executives are already touting it as a game-changer for cybersecurity. The product is designed to help companies quickly identify the root cause of a breach, rather than just reacting to its symptoms. By tapping into Alphabet's vast archives, Backstory can analyze large datasets and identify patterns that might have gone unnoticed by traditional security tools. The potential implications are significant, as it could help companies prevent future attacks and reduce the time it takes to respond to a breach.

Slate, the online publication known for counterintuitive analysis and its many podcasts, has chosen a specialist in narrative journalism as its next editor in chief. On Wednesday, the company announced that it had given the job to Jared Hohlt, a veteran of New York magazine. He succeeds Julia Turner, who left Slate in October to become a deputy managing editor of The Los Angeles Times. Hohlt brings a wealth of experience in narrative storytelling to the role, having spent over a decade at New York magazine, where he worked as a senior editor and helped to shape the publication's long-form reporting. During his tenure, he oversaw some of the magazine's most ambitious and critically acclaimed projects, including a series of in-depth profiles on influential figures in politics, culture, and entertainment.

In a statement, Hohlt said he was "thrilled" to be joining Slate and praised the publication's commitment to innovative storytelling and its willingness to challenge conventional wisdom. "I'm looking forward to working with the talented team at Slate to continue pushing the boundaries of online journalism and to find new ways to engage readers with compelling narratives," he said.

Hohlt's appointment is seen as a coup for Slate, which has faced increasing competition in the online media landscape in recent years. With his expertise in narrative journalism, he is expected to help the publication further establish itself as a leader in the field.

There is no cure for autism spectrum disorder, but there are medications that can help address associated symptoms like high energy levels and depression, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The agency has found that as many as a third of parents with an autistic child have tried treatments that most pediatricians do not recommend, and that up to 10 percent may be using potentially dangerous tactics. The books that were listed on Amazon were both written more than five years ago and have together generated more than 600 customer reviews. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's (CDC) findings have raised concerns among medical professionals and parents of children with autism spectrum disorder. "It's alarming to see that some parents are resorting to unproven and potentially harmful treatments," said Dr. Emily Chen, a leading expert in autism research. "While we understand the desperation and frustration that comes with caring for a child with autism, it's crucial that we prioritize evidence-based treatments that have been shown to be safe and effective." The CDC is urging parents to consult with their pediatricians before trying any new treatments, and to seek out reputable sources of information to avoid falling prey to misinformation. Additionally, the agency is working to increase awareness and education among parents and healthcare providers about the most effective and recommended treatments for autism spectrum disorder.

The sun bears were making faces at each other. And that was a bit of a surprise. Comparative psychologists have been studying the facial expressions of primates like orangutans and gorillas for years. but the sun bears, which are native to Southeast Asia, had never been observed displaying such complex facial expressions before. Researchers from the University of Wisconsin-Madison were conducting a study on the behavior of sun bears in their natural habitat when they noticed the unusual facial interactions.

"We were blown away by what we saw," said Dr. Maria Rodriguez, lead researcher on the project. "The sun bears were making these elaborate faces at each other, with raised eyebrows, scrunched up noses, and even what looked like a sun-kissed smile. It was like they were having a conversation without making a sound."

The researchers used high-definition cameras to capture the facial expressions, which were then analyzed by a team of experts. The study found that the sun bears were using their faces to communicate emotions such as excitement, fear, and even affection.

"This changes everything we thought we knew about primate communication," said Dr. Rodriguez. "We've long believed that facial expressions were limited to humans and a few select primates, but it seems that sun bears are capable of complex emotional expression as well." The findings have significant implications for our understanding of animal intelligence and social behavior.

Jeff Bezos, Amazon's founder and chief executive, and his wife, MacKenzie Bezos, said on Twitter on Thursday that they had finalized the details of their divorce. Mr. Bezos will keep 75 percent of the couple's Amazon stock and all of their ownership of The Washington Post and the Blue Origin space company, Ms. Bezos wrote. Mr. Bezos will also have "sole voting authority" over Ms. Bezos' Amazon shares, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. After the divorce, Ms. Bezos will own roughly 4 percent of Amazon, a stake that was worth almost $36 billion on Thursday. By keeping 75 percent of the couple's Amazon shares, or about 12 percent of the company, Mr. Bezos will most likely remain the richest person in the world. His remaining stake in the company was worth almost $108 billion on Thursday. Ms. Bezos will also retain a 4% stake in Amazon, valued at approximately $36 billion, making her one of the richest women in the world. The couple's divorce is expected to be one of the most expensive in history, with Ms. Bezos walking away with a substantial sum. The details of the settlement are not yet public, but it is believed that Ms. Bezos will receive a significant amount of cash and other assets in addition to her Amazon stock. The couple's divorce is a significant development in the tech industry, and its impact on Amazon's stock price is being closely watched by investors.

All year long as Earth revolves around the sun, it passes through streams of cosmic debris. The resulting meteor showers can light up night skies from dusk to dawn, and if you're lucky you might be able to catch a glimpse. The next shower you might be able to see is known as the Lyrids. Active between April 16 and 28, the show peaks around Sunday night into Monday morning, or April 21-22. The moon could interfere with viewing the peak this year. There are records from ancient Chinese astronomers spotting these bursts of light more than 2,700 years ago. The Lyrids are considered one of the oldest recorded meteor showers, with observations dating back to 687 BCE. The shower is caused by the Earth passing through the trail of debris left behind by the comet Thatcher, which was discovered in 1861. The comet's path is believed to be the source of the Lyrid meteoroids, which burn up in the Earth's atmosphere, producing the bright streaks of light that are visible to the naked eye.

While the moon's interference may make it more challenging to view the peak of the Lyrids, astronomers recommend trying to catch the shower during the early morning hours when the moon is below the horizon. The best viewing locations will be in areas with minimal light pollution, allowing stargazers to see the meteors in all their glory.

Despite the challenges, many meteor enthusiasts are still excited to witness the Lyrids, which are expected to produce up to 20 meteors per hour at their peak. With a little luck and some clear skies, stargazers may be able to catch a glimpse of these ancient celestial fireworks.

SAN FRANCISCO -- The New York State attorney general's office plans to open an investigation into Facebook's unauthorized collection of more than 1.5 million users' email address books, according to two people briefed on the matter. The inquiry concerns a practice unearthed in April in which Facebook harvested the email contact lists of a portion of new users who signed up for the network after 2016, according to the two people, who spoke on condition of anonymity because the inquiry had not been officially announced. Those lists were then used to improve Facebook's ad-targeting algorithms and other friend connections across the network. The investigation was confirmed late Thursday afternoon by the attorney general's office. The investigation is expected to focus on whether Facebook's actions violated any state or federal privacy laws, including the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) in the European Union. The attorney general's office is also seeking to determine how widespread the practice was and whether it was limited to a specific period of time. The move comes amid growing scrutiny of Facebook's data collection and sharing practices, following a series of high-profile data breaches and privacy scandals. The company has faced numerous lawsuits and regulatory inquiries in recent years, including a $5 billion fine from the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) in July. Facebook has not commented on the investigation, but it has previously stated that it collects email contacts to help users connect with friends and family on the platform. The company has also claimed that it does not use the email contacts for advertising purposes, but the investigation is expected to examine whether this is accurate.

Leishmaniasis parasites eat human flesh. Cordyceps fungi lead ants to suicide. Toxoplasma gondii eliminate a mouse's fear of cats. And a barnacle called Sacculina carcini castrates crabs, roots itself into their bodies and brains and transforms them into walking zombie slaves that care for the parasite's brood as if it were their own. Parasites are bad -- except when they're not. except when they're not. In fact, some parasites have evolved to play a crucial role in maintaining the balance of their ecosystems. Take the tapeworm, for example. While it may seem counterintuitive, tapeworms can actually help to regulate the population of their hosts, such as deer and sheep. By reducing the number of animals that are too abundant, tapeworms can prevent overgrazing and maintain the health of the ecosystem.

Similarly, some parasites can even benefit their hosts by providing them with essential nutrients. For example, the protozoan parasite Trichomonas vaginalis is found in the reproductive tracts of many mammals, including humans. While it can cause disease in extreme cases, it can also help to break down complex carbohydrates and provide its host with essential nutrients.

But perhaps the most fascinating example of a beneficial parasite is the fungi Ophiocordyceps unilateralis. This fungus infects ants and takes control of their bodies, causing them to climb to high locations before producing spores that can infect other ants. While it may seem like a sinister plot, the fungus is actually helping to disperse its own spores and ensure the survival of its species.

So, the next time you hear about a parasite, don't immediately assume that it's a villain. Instead, consider the complex relationships that exist between parasites and their hosts, and the important roles that some parasites play in maintaining the balance of their ecosystems.

James Bennet, the editorial page editor of The New York Times, said on Thursday that he would recuse himself from any involvement in opinion coverage of the 2020 presidential election, after his brother, Senator Michael Bennet of Colorado, announced his candidacy for the Democratic nomination. The move by James Bennet, who is considered a contender to succeed Dean Baquet as The Times's executive editor, was long anticipated. Michael Bennet has served for a decade in the Senate and had earlier signaled interest in a presidential bid. It is unusual for the chief of a newspaper's Opinion section to withdraw from a topic that is certain to dominate the global news conversation over the next 18 months. "This decision is a reflection of our commitment to maintaining the highest standards of journalistic integrity and avoiding even the appearance of conflict of interest," James Bennet said in a statement. "I am confident that our talented team of opinion writers and editors will continue to provide thoughtful and incisive coverage of the 2020 election, without any influence from personal relationships." The Times' leadership has a history of taking steps to ensure the editorial independence of its opinion section, and this move is seen as a further demonstration of that commitment. The paper's readers can expect to see a diverse range of perspectives on the election, with no influence from personal ties or relationships.

All year long as Earth revolves around the sun, it passes through streams of cosmic debris. The resulting meteor showers can light up night skies from dusk to dawn, and if you're lucky you might be able to catch a glimpse. The next shower you might be able to see is known as the Eta Aquariids. Active between April 19 and May 28, the show peaks around Sunday night into Monday morning, or May 5-6. The moon will be close to new, which could make for good viewing in places with clear skies. According to astronomers, the Eta Aquariids are caused by the Earth passing through the trail of debris left behind by Halley's Comet, which was last visible in the skies in 1986. The comet's path is thought to have been disturbed by the gravitational pull of Jupiter, causing the debris to spread out and create the meteor shower.

The Eta Aquariids are known for producing bright, fast-moving meteors that can be seen in the southern hemisphere. The shower is active for about a month, but the peak viewing period is usually the most productive. During this time, astronomers expect to see around 60 meteors per hour, with some potentially bright enough to be seen during the day.

For those looking to catch a glimpse of the Eta Aquariids, the best viewing locations will be in areas with minimal light pollution and clear skies. Binoculars or a pair of comfortable chairs will be all you need to enjoy the show. Just remember to dress warmly and bring some snacks, as viewing sessions can last several hours.

The Eta Aquariids are a rare treat, and astronomers are encouraging people to get outside and enjoy the celestial spectacle. So mark your calendars for May 5-6 and get ready to witness the beauty of the universe in all its glory.

NEW DELHI -- Climate change and rising sea levels eventually may wipe out one of the world's last and largest tiger strongholds, scientists warned in a new study. The cats are among nearly 500,000 land species whose survival is now in question because of threats to their natural habitats, according to a report on Monday by the United Nations. The Sundarbans, 4,000 square miles of marshy land in Bangladesh and India, hosts the world's largest mangrove forest and a rich ecosystem supporting several hundred animal species, including the endangered Bengal tiger. But 70 percent of the land is just a few feet above sea level, and grave changes are in store for the region, Australian and Bangladeshi researchers reported in the journal Science of The Total Environment. Changes wrought by a warming planet will be "enough to decimate" the few hundred or so Bengal tigers remaining there. "By 2070, there will be no suitable tiger habitats remaining in the Bangladesh Sundarbans," concluded the study by 10 researchers. The paper, which relies on climate scenarios developed by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change for its simulation models, adds to existing studies that offered similarly grim predictions for wildlife in the Sundarbans. In 2010, a study led by the World Wide Fund for Nature projected that a sea level rise of 11 inches could reduce the number of tigers in the Sundarbans by 96 percent within a few decades. Climate change has already harmed almost half of the world's endangered mammals, far more than previously thought, a recent study found. Sharif A. Mukul, lead author of the new report on the Sundarbans, and his colleagues looked for risks to the tiger beyond sea level rise, which accounted for 5.4 percent to 11.3 percent of the projected habitat loss in 2050 and 2070. The researchers also identified other significant threats to the tiger's habitat, including increased flooding, salinization of soil and water, and changes in temperature and precipitation patterns. They found that these factors could lead to a decline in the quality and quantity of the Sundarbans' mangrove forests, which are a crucial component of the tiger's ecosystem.

"We were surprised to find that the impact of climate change on the Sundarbans' tiger population was not just due to sea level rise," said Sharif A. Mukul, lead author of the study. "The combination of all these factors will make it extremely challenging for the tigers to survive in the long term."

The researchers used computer simulations to model the impact of different climate change scenarios on the Sundarbans' tiger population. They found that even with moderate levels of sea level rise, the tigers' habitat would be significantly reduced, leading to a decline in their population.

The study's findings have significant implications for conservation efforts in the Sundarbans. The researchers are calling for urgent action to protect the region's mangrove forests and to develop strategies to help the tigers adapt to the changing climate.

"This is not just a problem for the tigers, but for the entire ecosystem of the Sundarbans," said Mukul. "We need to act quickly to protect this unique and valuable ecosystem before it's too late."

Imagine an animal that looks like a dinosaur, and you probably will not imagine a bat. But that may change. A team of paleontologists in China announced on Wednesday the discovery of a dinosaur that sported the same kinds of fleshy wings bats use to flit through the air. The dinosaur, Ambopteryx longibrachium, lived about 163 million years ago. The team, led by Dr. Wang Yuan, from the Chinese Academy of Sciences, made the remarkable discovery in the Liaoning Province, where a rich trove of ancient fossils has been found. The Ambopteryx longibrachium is estimated to have been around 2 meters long and weighed approximately 20 kilograms. Its wings, made of skin and other tissues, were likely used for gliding and possibly even powered flight. The find is significant because it pushes back the known evolutionary history of flight in animals, and could provide new insights into the development of this complex trait. The team is now studying the fossilized remains to learn more about the dinosaur's behavior, diet, and habitat. The discovery is expected to spark new research and debate among scientists and enthusiasts alike.

Half a century ago, the Apollo astronauts left short-lived seismometers on the lunar surface. They found that the moon was alive and kicking. Some tremors deep below the surface likely were caused by Earth's gravitational pull. Others were vibrations from meteorite impacts. Still others resulted from expansion of the moon's chilly surface every two weeks when the sun rose. The data collected by the seismometers provided valuable insights into the moon's internal structure and composition. Scientists were surprised to find that the moon had a liquid iron core, similar to Earth's, which was responsible for some of the seismic activity. The core was estimated to be about 300 kilometers in diameter, which was smaller than expected.

The Apollo seismometers also detected a peculiar phenomenon known as "moonquakes." These were small earthquakes that occurred when the moon's surface expanded and contracted due to temperature changes. The quakes were so small that they were barely detectable, but they provided a unique window into the moon's internal dynamics.

The discovery of moonquakes and the moon's liquid core have since been confirmed by subsequent spacecraft and missions. Today, scientists continue to study the moon's internal activity, using data from seismometers and other instruments to better understand the moon's evolution and composition. The Apollo seismometers may have been left on the moon for decades, but their legacy continues to shape our understanding of the moon and its place in our solar system.

Conde Nast has sold Golf Digest to Discovery Inc., the companies said on Monday, as the publisher of The New Yorker, Vanity Fair and Vogue sheds titles amid recent losses related to the decline of the magazine business. Neither company disclosed terms of the deal, but two people with knowledge of the matter who were not authorized to discuss it publicly said the sale price was $35 million. Discovery said that it would retain Golf Digest's editorial staff, including its top editor, Jerry Tarde, and would continue to publish the monthly print magazine. The acquisition is expected to expand Discovery's reach in the golfing industry, complementing its existing portfolio of sports and lifestyle brands. Golf Digest, which was founded in 1950, has a global audience of over 1 million readers and is widely regarded as one of the most authoritative voices in golf journalism. The publication's online presence will also be bolstered by Discovery's digital expertise, allowing for enhanced content and community engagement. The deal is expected to close in the coming weeks, pending regulatory approval.

If you've ever taken a big bite of wasabi, you know what comes next: a painful zing that creeps over your whole scalp. You aren't the only animal that feels this way. The condiment's sinus-burning kick comes from a chemical compound called allyl isothiocyanate, or AITC, that actively damages proteins within cells. Flies and flatworms shun it , as do mice and wolf spiders. "Practically every animal you look at will avoid AITC," said Gary Lewin, a molecular physiologist at the Max Delbruck Center for Molecular Medicine in Berlin. But there is one exception. one exception: the humble honey bee. In fact, honey bees are the only animals that are immune to the pungent effects of wasabi. Researchers have found that the bees' bodies contain a unique enzyme that breaks down AITC, rendering it harmless. This unusual tolerance has sparked interest among scientists, who believe it could lead to new ways of developing pesticides and agricultural products. "The honey bee's ability to resist the toxic effects of wasabi is a fascinating example of evolutionary adaptation," said Dr. Lewin. "Understanding how they achieve this could have significant implications for our food production systems." Further research is underway to uncover the secrets behind the bees' wasabi resistance.

The retirement legislation that the House recently passed with an overwhelming bipartisan majority includes a series of provisions that would affect different groups of American savers and retirees. These provisions aim to provide more flexibility and security for individuals nearing retirement or already in retirement. One key aspect is the expansion of the required minimum distribution (RMD) rules, which would allow individuals to delay taking RMDs from their retirement accounts until age 75. This change is expected to benefit individuals who continue to work part-time or have other sources of income, as they would no longer be forced to take RMDs earlier than necessary. Additionally, the legislation proposes to increase the catch-up contribution limit for retirees aged 50 and above, allowing them to contribute more to their retirement accounts. This change is expected to benefit individuals who are trying to make up for lost time in their retirement savings.

Jeffrey Goldberg, the editor in chief of The Atlantic, set off a storm of criticism Thursday when he suggested that, in seeking a diverse group of writers for cover stories, he had found it difficult to hand those plum assignments to anyone other than white male magazine journalists. "It's really, really hard to write a 10,000-word cover story," Mr. Goldberg said in an interview with Nieman Lab, a nonprofit journalism organization and website, which noted that 11 of The Atlantic's 15 most recent cover stories were written by men. "There are not a lot of journalists in America who can do it. The journalists in America who do it are almost exclusively white males." The way to broaden The Atlantic's contributors, Mr. Goldberg continued, is to tell new writers that "you're really good at this and you have a lot of potential and you're 33 and you're burning with ambition, and that's great, so let us put you on a deliberate pathway toward writing 10,000-word cover stories." "It might not work," he said. "It often doesn't." Critics seized on the comments, accusing the veteran editor of underestimating the abilities of those who fall outside the pool of white male writers. The criticism was swift and scathing, with many accusing Goldberg of perpetuating a lack of diversity and inclusivity within the magazine's ranks. "It's astonishing that a publication as esteemed as The Atlantic would so openly acknowledge its own biases," tweeted writer and activist, Roxane Gay. "The idea that ambition and potential are the only qualities necessary to write a 10,000-word cover story is not only inaccurate, but also ignores the systemic barriers that prevent people of color and women from getting the same opportunities." Other writers and editors took to social media to share their own experiences of facing discrimination and marginalization in the industry, highlighting the need for greater diversity and representation in editorial positions. As the backlash continued to grow, The Atlantic's leadership was forced to issue a statement apologizing for Goldberg's comments and reaffirming the magazine's commitment to diversity and inclusion.

Mitchel R. Levitas, a journalist who won the prestigious George Polk Award in his 20s for a series on labor racketeering and held leading newsroom positions at The New York Times for decades, died on Saturday at his home in New Marlborough, Mass. He was 89. The cause was Alzheimer's disease complicated by pneumonia, his son Daniel said. Levitas was born in 1933 in Brooklyn, New York, to a family of modest means. He grew up in a neighborhood filled with newsstands, delis, and ethnic restaurants, which instilled in him a love for the city's vibrant cultural scene. He began his journalism career as a copy boy at the New York Daily News, working his way up to become a reporter, editor, and eventually, a senior editor at the Times.

Throughout his career, Levitas was known for his tenacious reporting style, which earned him numerous awards and accolades. His 1980 series on labor racketeering, which won the George Polk Award, was a groundbreaking exposé that shed light on the corrupt practices of organized crime in the labor movement.

Levitas was also a mentor to many young journalists, including some who went on to become prominent figures in the industry. His colleagues and friends remembered him as a kind and generous person who always put the story first. "Mitch was a giant in the journalism world," said longtime friend and colleague, Arthur Gelb. "He had a way of making you feel like you were the most important person in the room, and his passion for the truth was inspiring." Levitas is survived by his wife, Susan, his son Daniel, and two grandchildren. A memorial service will be held in New York City in the coming weeks.

Stephen Colbert's "Late Show" is one of the most popular shows on CBS. The network and AT&T failed to reach a contract agreement before a Saturday deadline. The blackout has also raised concerns about the future of CBS programming on AT&T's platforms.

As the standoff continues, both sides remain at an impasse. AT&T has said it will not back down from its demands, while CBS has refused to agree to terms that it believes undervalue its programming. At 2:56 a.m. Coordinated Universal Time on July 21, 1969, humans for the first time stepped onto another world. It was a kind of awakening. More than 500 million people around the world watched the event live on television -- the largest-ever broadcast audience at the time -- and tens of millions more listened on the radio. All with the same perspective: of the moon, symbol of the unattainable, attained; and of our own Earth, a pale blue dot in the vast emptiness of space. As the Eagle lunar module touched down on the moon's surface, the world held its collective breath. Neil Armstrong, the mission commander, took his first steps onto the lunar regolith, famously declaring, "That's one small step for man, one giant leap for mankind." The words echoed across the globe, inspiring a sense of wonder and awe in people of all ages. The Apollo 11 astronauts, Armstrong, Edwin "Buzz" Aldrin, and Michael Collins, had accomplished the impossible, bridging the gap between Earth and the moon. The achievement marked a turning point in human history, demonstrating the power of scientific collaboration and technological innovation. In the years that followed, the moon landing sparked a new era of space exploration, with subsequent missions pushing the boundaries of what was thought possible. As the world looked up at the moon, now a tangible destination, it was clear that the possibilities were endless, and the future was full of promise.

SAN FRANCISCO -- DoorDash, the food delivery start-up, said Thursday that it was buying Caviar, a rival service, for $410 million in a deal that escalates the already intense competition in food delivery. DoorDash plans to maintain Caviar's operations and brand identity, while also integrating its logistics and technology infrastructure. Poriferans, better known as sponges, are squishy, stationary and filled with holes. Ctenophores, also called comb jellies, are soft blobs wreathed by feathery cilia. For the past decade, the two groups have been caught up in a raging battle, at least in the pages of scientific journals. At stake is a noble place in evolutionary history: closest living analogue of the first-ever animal. A new analysis, published Wednesday in Royal Society Open Science, hands victory back to the sponges , although more bouts are sure to come. [Like the Science Times page on Facebook. | Sign up for the Science Times newsletter.] All animals, from sponges and comb jellies to humans and other mammals, have particular characteristics in common: We're multicellular, our cells have nuclei and we consume food rather than make it. We also all have a common ancestor, which inhabited the oceans at least 550 million years ago and shared those traits. and was likely a simple, multicellular organism. The debate over which group is most similar to this ancient ancestor has been ongoing, with proponents of each side presenting their own evidence and arguments. The new study, led by researchers at the University of California, Berkeley, analyzed the genetic makeup of both poriferans and ctenophores, as well as their developmental biology and anatomy. The team found that sponges possess a unique combination of characteristics that make them the more likely candidate to be the closest living relative of the first animal. The study's authors suggest that sponges' ability to filter food particles from the water, their simple body structure, and their lack of nervous system or sensory organs all point to a more primitive, ancestral state. While the controversy is far from over, the new analysis provides further support for the sponge hypothesis and sheds new light on the early evolution of animal life on Earth.

[Sign up to get reminders for space and astronomy events on your calendar.] Where meteor showers come from

If you spot a meteor shower, what you're usually seeing is an icy comet's leftovers that crash into Earth's atmosphere. Comets are sort of like dirty snowballs: As they travel through the solar system, they leave behind a dusty trail of rocks and ice that lingers in space long after they leave. When Earth passes through these cascades of comet waste, the bits of debris -- which can be as small as grains of sand -- pierce the sky at such speeds that they burst, creating a celestial fireworks display. A general rule of thumb with meteor showers: You are never watching the Earth cross into remnants from a comet's most recent orbit. Instead, the burning bits come from the previous passes. As Earth travels through the solar system, it encounters the remnants of countless comets that have passed through the area before. These comets, often referred to as "parent comets," have shed their icy and rocky material as they approached the sun, leaving behind a trail of debris that can take thousands of years to dissipate.

The timing of meteor showers is closely tied to the orbit of the parent comet. Since the debris from a comet's previous passes is scattered throughout space, the timing of a meteor shower is determined by when Earth intersects with the path of that debris. This means that the meteor shower is actually a remnant of the comet's past, not its most recent visit.

For example, the Perseid meteor shower, one of the most popular and active meteor showers of the year, is caused by the Earth passing through the debris trail left behind by the Swift-Tuttle comet. This comet was first discovered in 1862 and is thought to have originated from the outer reaches of the solar system. The Swift-Tuttle comet is a long-period comet, meaning it takes more than 200 years to complete one orbit around the sun. As a result, the Perseid meteor shower is a remnant of the comet's last pass through the inner solar system, which occurred in the 12th century.

By studying the timing and frequency of meteor showers, scientists can gain valuable insights into the orbits and composition of comets, as well as the history of our solar system. The next time you witness a meteor shower, remember that you're not just seeing a random burst of celestial activity – you're witnessing the remnants of a comet's ancient journey through the cosmos.

Giuliani was mayor, and the station had an audience of about one million listeners a month and an operating budget of $8 million. WASHINGTON -- Google said Thursday that it had reached a settlement with the National Labor Relations Board over complaints from multiple employees who say the company has stymied dissent, including one who has said he was fired for being an outspoken conservative. Google plans to explain to employees the rights they have as workers under federal law, like the ability to discuss workplace conditions, said Jenn Kaiser, a Google spokeswoman. Google's settlement with the National Labor Relations Board is seen as a major victory for employees who have been advocating for greater transparency and accountability from the company.

On Monday, Doug Kahn, a meteorologist at the National Weather Service in Cleveland, saw several bluish masses shifting and swelling over Ohio. "...the meteorologist's radar screen, which he described as a 'fog-like' appearance. The average lightning strike can pack a punch. But then there are superbolts. First identified in the 1970s by satellites designed to monitor nuclear explosions, they can be thousands of times more energetic than normal lightning. But you're even less likely to be struck by one: Scientists have mined data from the roughly 80 sensors of the World Wide Lightning Location Network to study where superbolts are found. They were surprised to discover that the most powerful lightning doesn't occur in known lightning hot spots, or at times of year when lightning usually strikes. Instead, they reported last week in the Journal of Geophysical Research: Atmospheres, superbolts predominantly occur over open water from November through February. [Like the Science Times page on Facebook. Researchers at the University of Colorado, who led the study, suggest that the unique combination of atmospheric conditions over open water during the winter months creates a perfect storm for superbolts to form. The team analyzed data from the World Wide Lightning Location Network, which has been monitoring lightning strikes since 2009, and found that 75% of superbolts occurred over oceans, with the majority happening in the tropics. The study's lead author, Dr. Hugh Christian, explained that the warmer waters of the ocean help to fuel the development of towering thunderstorms, which can then produce superbolts. The findings have significant implications for our understanding of lightning behavior and could potentially aid in the development of more accurate lightning prediction models.

The company, which is set to unveil its Apple Plus TV streaming service on Nov. 1, will enter the film business this fall with theatrical releases of three movies it acquired this year, Apple said on Friday. Why did the chiton roll into a ball? "To get to the other side," said Julia Sigwart, an evolutionary biologist at Queens University Belfast in Northern Ireland. About 500 million years ago, a couple species of now extinct trilobites became the first animals to roll themselves into a ball for protection. The trilobite's living doppelganger is the chiton. This marine mollusk's plated shell drapes over a soft body and mucousy foot, giving it the appearance of a flattened piece of shrimp nigiri. But why did this peculiar behavior evolve in the first place? Sigwart and her team discovered that the ancient trilobites were living in a world where predators were abundant and diverse. By rolling into a ball, they were able to protect their soft bodies from being eaten. This unique defense mechanism allowed them to survive in environments where other animals would have been vulnerable to predation.

Fast forward to the present day, and we can see that the chiton has retained this remarkable ability. When threatened, it will quickly curl up into a ball, using its plated shell to shield its vulnerable underside. This behavior is not only an effective defense mechanism but also an important part of the chiton's daily life. By rolling into a ball, it can also help to conserve energy and protect itself from the harsh conditions of its marine environment. Sigwart's research highlights the fascinating evolutionary history of this remarkable creature and the importance of understanding the adaptations that have allowed it to thrive in its ecosystem.

For many of us, our approach to typing on a smartphone is something we stumble upon. Katrina. Harvey. Maria. Dorian. In recent years, hurricanes have killed thousands of people and caused billions of dollars in damage. But getting a handle on how frequently these destructive storms have pummeled the planet is tough because records stretch back only about a century and a half. Now, researchers have assembled a 1,500-year history of hurricanes in the Bahamas, based on sand and shell fragments pulled up from submarine caverns known as blue holes. Their results, published in October in Paleoceanography and Paleoclimatology, show that hurricane activity has varied over time. The researchers, led by Dr. Christopher Lloyd of the University of North Carolina, used a technique called sediment coring to extract layers of sediment from the blue holes, which are natural underwater sinkholes that form in limestone rock. By analyzing the sediment, they were able to reconstruct a record of hurricane activity over the past 1,500 years. The team found that hurricane frequency and intensity have fluctuated over time, with periods of increased activity followed by periods of relative calm. The researchers believe that changes in ocean temperatures and atmospheric circulation patterns may be responsible for these fluctuations. The study's findings could have important implications for understanding the impacts of climate change on hurricane activity and for developing more effective strategies for predicting and preparing for these powerful storms.

The deal is expected to face scrutiny from regulators and investors, but if approved, it could lead to significant cost savings and increased competitiveness for the merged entity. LONDON -- Facebook is trying to make it easier for users to move photos from the social network to rival online services, reacting to European privacy laws and criticism from regulators that its size and control over data hinder competition. On Monday, Facebook said it would begin testing a "data portability" tool in Ireland that would allow users there to move photos and videos from Facebook to Google Photos. Critics immediately said the initiative did not go far enough. Facebook's control over personal data has been central to current antitrust investigations in Washington and Europe. Authorities say Facebook holds so much information about its users, data it uses to fuel its digital advertising business and improve its services, that it creates a competitive imbalance that rivals can't match. The company's rivals, including Google and Twitter, have long complained that Facebook's dominance in the social media space gives it an unfair advantage in terms of access to user data. The European Union's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) went into effect in 2018, giving users more control over their personal data and allowing them to request that their data be transferred to another service. Facebook's new tool is seen as a response to these regulations and the growing pressure from regulators to increase competition. However, some experts argue that the tool may not go far enough, as it only allows users to transfer photos and videos, but not other types of data, such as friend lists or messaging history. Additionally, the tool is only being tested in Ireland, leaving users in other countries without the same level of data portability.

If there was a tooth fairy in the Cretaceous, dinosaurs kept it busy. Unlike humans, which lose just one set of teeth over a lifetime, dinosaurs often lost tens or even hundreds of sets. Plant-eating dinosaurs had to chew lots of tough material to sustain their large bodies, causing them to frequently replace their teeth. This constant tooth replacement would have been a significant challenge for dinosaurs, requiring them to regularly regurgitate and re-digest their food to extract as many nutrients as possible. The sheer volume of teeth being lost and replaced would have also led to a significant amount of tooth waste, which would have had to be disposed of in some way. It's likely that dinosaurs developed specialized behaviors or social structures to deal with this issue, such as living in large groups to increase their chances of finding food and avoiding tooth loss.

In addition, the constant need for tooth replacement would have placed a significant energetic burden on dinosaurs, requiring them to spend a lot of time and resources finding new food sources and avoiding predators while their teeth were being replaced. This could have had significant impacts on their overall ecology and evolution, and may have even influenced the development of their social structures and behaviors. Despite these challenges, however, dinosaurs were able to thrive in their environments, and their unique adaptations to tooth loss and replacement are a fascinating example of the incredible diversity and resilience of life on Earth.

For centuries scientists, even Darwin, couldn't make sense of it: Tropical water contains so few nutrients, you can see right through it. And yet coral reefs are oases that support about a quarter of all known species on Earth. How could that be? The answer to this paradox, in part, is sugar. We tend to think the ocean tastes salty. But shaken, stirred and dissolved in seawater are microscopic morsels of sugars and carbs, known as dissolved organic matter. These sugars and carbs, once ingested by phytoplankton, the ocean's primary producers, become the foundation of the coral reef's food chain. The phytoplankton, in turn, are consumed by zooplankton, which are then devoured by fish and other larger organisms. This complex web of consumption supports the incredible biodiversity of coral reefs, where a single square meter of reef can host over 1,000 species. The discovery of dissolved organic matter has far-reaching implications for our understanding of ocean ecosystems and the delicate balance that sustains them. As researchers continue to unravel the secrets of coral reefs, they are also gaining a deeper appreciation for the importance of preserving these underwater wonders for future generations.

SAN FRANCISCO -- Uber is in advanced discussions to sell its food-delivery business in India, according to two people with knowledge of the plans, as the company moves to stem its losses. The ride-hailing company is nearing a deal to sell its Uber Eats service in India to Zomato, an Indian food-delivery service, said the people, who spoke on condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to do so publicly. The sale could be announced as early as this week, they said. A spokesman for Uber declined to comment. The potential sale is seen as a strategic move by Uber to focus on its core ride-hailing business and reduce its losses in the highly competitive Indian market. Uber Eats has struggled to gain traction in India, where Zomato has established itself as a leading food-delivery platform. Zomato, which is backed by investors such as Sequoia Capital and Temasek, has been aggressively expanding its services and has already acquired several local food-delivery startups. If the deal is completed, it would mark a significant exit for Uber from the Indian food-delivery market, where it has invested heavily over the past few years. The sale is expected to be worth hundreds of millions of dollars, although the exact figure has not been disclosed.

More than 200 bloggers in California will lose regular writing gigs because of a state law meant to improve working conditions at companies like Uber and Lyft that rely on contractors rather than employees. On Monday, Vox Media announced that it would eliminate the 200 freelance positions at its sports outlet, SB Nation, to comply with the legislation. The affected writers are frequent contributors to the 25 SB Nation blogs focused on California teams. The team-centric sites include Golden State of Mind, for the N.B.A. for the Golden State Warriors, and Orange Traffic, for the Los Angeles Lakers. The writers, who were hired as independent contractors, will no longer be able to write for the sites on a regular basis. Vox Media cited the California law, known as Assembly Bill 5, which requires companies to reclassify contractors as employees and provide them with benefits and protections. The company stated that it would continue to work with the writers on a project-by-project basis, but the change will likely impact the quality and frequency of content on the sites. The affected writers have expressed frustration and disappointment at the loss of their regular writing gigs, which had allowed them to build a community and reputation as experts on their respective teams.

Q. A previous column explained how to download specific files from Google Photos, but I need to know how to upload a specific album to share with a family group. To upload a specific album to share with a family group on Google Photos, you'll need to follow these steps. First, open the Google Photos app on your device and navigate to the album you want to share. Tap the three vertical dots in the top right corner of the screen to open the album's menu, then select "Share" or "Export" from the dropdown menu.

Next, choose the family group you want to share the album with from the list of available groups. If you don't see the group you want to share with, you can create a new group by tapping the "New group" button and entering the email addresses of the family members you want to add.

Once you've selected the group, you'll be prompted to choose the level of access you want to grant to the group members. You can choose to make the album publicly visible, or you can set it to private and only allow group members to view it.

Finally, tap "Share" to send the album to the family group. The album will be added to the group's shared albums section, where all members can view and interact with it. Note that group members will need to have a Google account and be added to the family group in order to access the shared album.

PASADENA, Calif. -- Whether the reboot of the sitcom "Roseanne" will be a success for ABC remains an open question, but it will not be lacking in controversy. Roseanne Barr, the show's star, was asked repeatedly at a news media event here on Monday about her support -- and her character's support -- of President Trump two months ahead of the show's revival. Ms. Barr told reporters that she was not an "apologist" for Mr. Trump but said that her character in the reboot of the show was a way to address head-on the strong divide in the country. She emphasized that the show's focus on social and political issues was not meant to be a platform for her personal views, but rather a reflection of the complexities and divisions within American society.

PASADENA, Calif. -- Get ready for Rose McGowan on the small screen. Ms. McGowan, the actress turned activist whose accusations against Harvey Weinstein helped spur a national reckoning on sexual abuse and harassment, will star in a documentary series, "Citizen Rose," that is scheduled to premiere on E! later this month. "It is a time of reckoning and the reset button," she said at a Television Critics Association media event on Tuesday. The cable network promised that the series will be an unfettered look into Ms. McGowan's life. Filming began in September, the month before the publication of the New York Times story that disclosed her settlement agreement with Mr. Weinstein, whom she had accused of sexual assault. "She kept saying, 'It'll be worth it, I promise,'" Andrea Metz, an executive producer of the series, said of Ms. McGowan's pitch to Bunim/Murray Productions. The six-part series, "Citizen Rose," will delve into McGowan's life as a survivor of sexual assault, her activism, and her journey towards healing and empowerment. According to E!, the documentary will also explore McGowan's personal struggles, including her experiences with PTSD and her relationships with loved ones.

McGowan, who has been open about her own experiences with sexual harassment and assault, has been vocal about the need for accountability and change in the entertainment industry. Her involvement in the #MeToo movement has made her a leading voice in the fight against sexual misconduct, and "Citizen Rose" promises to offer a candid and unflinching look at her experiences.

"It's a very intimate and personal series," said McGowan at the TCA event. "I'm not hiding anything. I'm not holding back. I'm not sugarcoating anything. This is my life, and this is my story."

The series is being produced by Bunim/Murray Productions, the same company behind reality TV hits like "The Real World" and "Keeping Up with the Kardashians." McGowan is serving as an executive producer alongside Andrea Metz and Gil Goldie.

When asked about the timing of the series, McGowan said that she believes it's a crucial moment for the country. "I think we're in a time of reckoning, and I think we need to keep pushing forward," she said. "We need to keep having these conversations, and we need to keep being brave and being vulnerable and being open."

"Citizen Rose" is set to premiere on E! on February 25th. The series is expected to spark important conversations about sexual misconduct, activism, and the power of survivorship. With McGowan at the helm, audiences can expect a raw, unflinching, and ultimately empowering look at the life of a true #MeToo pioneer.

For almost a decade, The Awl implored the world to "Be Less Stupid." There was a "great big internet" out there, the editors cautioned. And by writing intelligently about offbeat topics -- from a locket meant to hold "mad money" to a deeply unsatisfying West Elm couch called "the Peggy" -- The Awl and its sister sites did their best to live up to the motto. On Tuesday, though, editors of The Awl and one of the sister sites, The Hairpin, announced that the end had come. Statements on the sites said editorial operations would cease at the end of January. The news of The Awl's demise sent shockwaves through the online journalism community, with many lamenting the loss of a unique and irreverent voice. Founded in 2009 by Alex Balk and Choire Sicha, The Awl was known for its eclectic mix of articles, from humorous takes on pop culture to in-depth explorations of serious topics. The site's irreverent tone and willingness to tackle offbeat subjects resonated with readers, who praised its writers for their wit, intelligence, and humor. Over the years, The Awl expanded to include several sister sites, including The Hairpin, The Stranger, and The Billfold, each with its own distinct flavor and focus. Despite its small size, The Awl had a significant impact on the online media landscape, inspiring a new generation of writers and editors to think outside the box and push the boundaries of online journalism. As the site's editorial operations come to a close, fans and former writers are left to mourn the loss of a beloved and innovative publication.

WASHINGTON -- Most efforts underway to restore so-called net neutrality face big obstacles and would take many months, if not years, to succeed. But in Montana, the governor has used the stroke of a pen to bring the rules to broad parts of his state. Through an executive order, Gov. Steve Bullock declared on Monday that any internet service provider with a state government contract cannot block or charge more for faster delivery of websites, two core aspects of net neutrality, to any customer in the state. "This move is a significant step forward in protecting the open internet for Montanans," Bullock said in a statement. "It's a testament to the power of state leadership in the face of inaction at the federal level." The executive order applies to all state agencies and contractors, covering a wide range of internet service providers. It also requires providers to clearly disclose their network management practices to the public. Advocates for net neutrality hailed the move as a major victory, but warned that it would likely face legal challenges from internet service providers seeking to block its implementation.

Q. I'm new to Instagram. Aside from the service suggesting Facebook friends who also have Instagram accounts, how do I find new people to follow? A. Like Twitter, LinkedIn and other networks, Instagram has a search function you can use to look for acquaintances other than those you already have on Facebook (which owns Instagram, hence the social synergy). Tap the magnifying glass in the Instagram tool bar to go to the search page, where you can seek out specific people, hashtags or places that match your keywords. On the search page, you can type in the name of a person, business, or brand you're interested in following. Instagram will suggest accounts that match your search query, and you can browse through the results to find new accounts to follow. You can also use hashtags to discover new accounts and content. For example, if you're interested in photography, you can search for hashtags like #photography or #travel to find accounts that share your passion. Additionally, you can check out the "Discover" page, which showcases popular and trending content on Instagram, to find new accounts and hashtags to follow.
