A new chapter opened Thursday in the drama over the future of the $37 billion Redstone media empire, with CBS Corporation and Viacom announcing plans to explore a reunion, reigniting a plan that fizzled a little more than a year ago. In simultaneously released statements, CBS and Viacom -- which were part of the same company from 2000 to 2006 -- said that their boards had created special committees of independent directors to "evaluate a potential combination." Yet the companies cautioned that there could be "no assurance that this process will result in a transaction or on what terms any transaction may occur." The news of a potential reunion sent shockwaves through the media industry, with analysts speculating about the potential benefits and challenges of a merged entity. Some experts predicted that a combined CBS and Viacom would create a powerhouse in the entertainment industry, with a vast library of content and a strong presence in television, film, and digital media. However, others raised concerns about the potential for cultural clashes and conflicts between the two companies, which have distinct histories and operating styles. Despite the uncertainty, investors reacted positively to the news, with CBS and Viacom shares rising sharply in early trading. As the special committees begin their evaluation, one thing is clear: the future of Redstone media is about to get a whole lot more interesting.

HBO is getting into podcasts. The premium cable network has signed a deal with the hosts of the popular "Pod Save America" podcast to broadcast a series of hourlong TV specials later this year. The move comes just a week after HBO debuted the first of four specials from Jessica Williams and Phoebe Robinson, the hosts of the "2 Dope Queens" podcast. That special, which included an interview with Jon Stewart, received warm reviews. The "Pod Save America" specials, which will be produced by HBO and Crooked Media, the production company behind the popular podcast, will feature hosts John Podhoretz, Tommy Vietor, and Ben Rhodes discussing current events, politics, and culture. The specials will be taped in front of a live studio audience and will include interviews with notable figures from the worlds of politics, entertainment, and journalism.

The move into TV specials marks a significant expansion for "Pod Save America," which has been a staple of the podcasting world since its debut in 2016. The podcast, which covers a wide range of topics from politics to pop culture, has gained a large and dedicated following, and its hosts have become well-known for their witty banter and incisive analysis.

HBO's foray into podcasting is part of a broader trend in the entertainment industry, as traditional media companies look to capitalize on the growing popularity of podcasting. With the success of its first podcast special, "2 Dope Queens," HBO is clearly eager to continue exploring the format and partnering with popular podcasters. The "Pod Save America" specials are set to premiere later this year, and fans of the podcast are eagerly anticipating the opportunity to see their favorite hosts in a new and exciting format.

Security experts said they had uncovered evidence that the attack had been in the works since late last year. It was directed at the Pyeongchang Organizing Committee and incorporated code that was specifically designed to disrupt the Games or perhaps even send a political message. "This attacker had no intention of leaving the machine usable," a team of researchers at Cisco's Talos threat intelligence division wrote in an analysis Monday. "The purpose of this malware is to perform destruction of the host" and "leave the computer system offline." The researchers, who have been tracking the attack since January, believe that the malware was designed to cause widespread disruption during the Games, which took place from February 9 to 25. "We're seeing a lot of activity around the Olympic Games, and this is just one example of how attackers are trying to take advantage of the global attention," said John Hammond, a senior threat researcher at Talos.

The malware, which was designed to exploit vulnerabilities in the Windows operating system, was able to evade detection by security software and was only discovered when a team of researchers at Talos analyzed a sample of the code. "It's a very sophisticated piece of malware, and it's clear that the attackers put a lot of effort into making it difficult to detect," said Hammond.

The Pyeongchang Organizing Committee has been notified of the attack and is working with security experts to determine the extent of the damage and to prevent further incidents. "We take the security of the Olympic Games very seriously, and we are working closely with our partners to ensure that the Games are safe and secure for all participants and spectators," said a spokesperson for the committee.

The discovery of the malware has raised concerns about the potential for cyber attacks during major international events, and experts are warning that such attacks are likely to increase in the future. "As the world becomes more connected, we're seeing more and more attacks that are designed to disrupt critical infrastructure and cause widespread harm," said Hammond. "It's a very serious issue, and it's something that we need to take very seriously."

Q. Can I use Microsoft Office on a Chromebook? A. Chromebooks run Google's Chrome OS, which was introduced in 2009 as a streamlined operating system for netbooks and other lightweight laptops. While you cannot install the traditional Windows or Mac versions of Microsoft Office on a Chromebook and have the software actually work, Microsoft's Office apps for Android devices can now run on the newer Chromebook models that have the ability to download, install and run apps from the Google Play store. These apps, such as Microsoft Word, Excel, and PowerPoint, can be downloaded from the Google Play store and installed on compatible Chromebooks, allowing users to access and edit Microsoft Office files. However, it's worth noting that the Android apps may not have all the same features as the desktop versions of the software. Additionally, users can also access Microsoft Office files online through the Microsoft Office Online suite, which is accessible from any device with a web browser.

Keeping things frothy and fun would do just fine. Despite the effort to keep things light and entertaining, the ceremony still suffered from a decline in viewership, with a reported 19% drop from last year's numbers. As the industry continues to evolve, it remains to be seen how the Oscars will adapt to changing viewer habits and preferences.

Russ Solomon, who died on Sunday at 92, created what for many music fans was the ultimate music emporium: Tower Records, whose yellow-and-red color scheme, "No Music, No Life" slogan, and wide aisles stocked with LPs and CDs defined the retail music business in the pre-digital era. At its peak, the chain had nearly 200 stores in 15 countries and more than $1 billion in annual sales, before debt and shifting consumer habits forced it to close in 2006. Starting at his father's drugstore in Sacramento, where he sold used jukebox records as a teenager, Mr. Solomon built a retail empire that became known as much for its selection -- vast by brick-and-mortar standards -- as for the culture that surrounded it. Employees were opinionated aficionados, and Tower stores, open till midnight, were gathering places for fans. The locations on Sunset Boulevard in Hollywood and on Broadway in Greenwich Village became tourist meccas. As a testament to Russ Solomon's legacy, Tower Records' iconic stores remain a nostalgic reminder of a bygone era for many music enthusiasts. The chain's influence extended beyond its physical locations, with its website and mail-order catalog serving as a go-to destination for fans seeking rare and hard-to-find albums. Tower Records was also a pioneer in the realm of in-store performances, hosting intimate concerts and signings with legendary artists such as Bob Dylan, Bruce Springsteen, and David Bowie.

In the years following its closure, the Tower Records brand has been revived in various forms, including a series of one-day pop-up shops and a brief online relaunch. While these efforts have been well-received by fans, they pale in comparison to the original chain's impact on the music industry. Russ Solomon's vision of a store where music lovers could come together to discover new sounds and connect with like-minded individuals has yet to be replicated.

Despite the challenges faced by the retail music industry in the digital age, Tower Records' enduring popularity is a testament to the power of brick-and-mortar retail and the importance of human connection in the music discovery process. As the music world continues to evolve, Russ Solomon's legacy serves as a reminder of the value of fostering a sense of community and preserving the art of physical music retail.

Q. I want to buy a lightweight laptop, but I need to use CDs and DVDs, which none of these models have anymore. Is there any way to still use discs with these tiny computers? A. When it comes to modern laptop design, many manufacturers have tossed disc drives onto the same pile with floppy drives, Ethernet jacks and other technology considered obsolete -- thanks to cloud servers and wireless networks that have taken over a laptop's data storage and internet connection needs. The quest for smaller, lighter laptops with maximum space on the inside for a rechargeable battery has also pushed out these once-standard computer components. However, there are still ways to use CDs and DVDs with modern laptops. One option is to invest in an external CD/DVD drive, which can be connected to your laptop via USB. These drives are small, lightweight, and can be easily carried in a bag. Another option is to use a CD/DVD ripping software, which can convert your physical discs into digital files that can be stored on your laptop or accessed through cloud storage. Some laptops also offer a USB-C port that can be used to connect an external CD/DVD drive. Additionally, some manufacturers are still producing laptops with built-in disc drives, although these are becoming increasingly rare. If you're looking for a lightweight laptop with a disc drive, you may need to look for older models or consider a desktop computer with a disc drive.

On the soggy floor of one of the only remaining intact forests on the island nation of Singapore, the egg-sized heads of carnivorous creatures emerge from decaying leaves. They appear to be belching, or singing, or screaming out the catch phrase of their cousin in Hollywood -- "Feed me Seymour." This is Nepenthes ampullaria, an unusual pitcher plant found on the islands of Southeast Asia and the Malay Peninsula. And its "Seymour" is the worm larva of Xenoplatyura beaveri, a species of fungus gnat that develops inside the plant's mouth. When grown, it looks like a mosquito with big biceps. As the camera zooms in on the eerie scene, a faint humming noise fills the air, punctuated by the occasional belch-like sound from the pitcher plants. The camera crew, led by renowned botanist Dr. Maria Rodriguez, carefully navigates the dense underbrush to get a closer look at the unusual symbiosis. Dr. Rodriguez explains that the Nepenthes ampullaria has evolved to attract the fungus gnats, which are drawn to the sweet, sticky liquid produced by the plant. Once inside the plant's mouth, the gnats lay their eggs, which hatch into the worm-like larvae that feed on the plant's digestive enzymes. "It's a remarkable example of co-evolution," Dr. Rodriguez says, "where both species have adapted to each other's needs to survive in this unique environment." As the team continues to document the phenomenon, they notice that the plants seem to be responding to their presence, subtly shifting their positions to get a better view of the camera. It's as if they're trying to put on a show, feeding off the attention and admiration of the humans who have stumbled upon this peculiar corner of the natural world.

Q. The top menu bar of my Mac has become cluttered with these little icons that I rarely use and are more distracting than anything. Is there a way to turn them off? A. A common conundrum for many Mac users! The icons you're referring to are likely the "Sticky Notes" or "Notes" app icons that appear in the top menu bar. These icons allow you to quickly access your notes and reminders, but they can indeed become cluttered and distracting if you don't use them frequently.

Fortunately, you can easily remove these icons from your top menu bar to declutter your screen. To do so, follow these steps:

1. Click on the Apple menu and select "System Preferences."
2. Click on "Dock & Menu Bar."
3. Uncheck the box next to "Notes" or "Sticky Notes" in the "Menu Bar" section.
4. Click "OK" to save your changes.

Once you've completed these steps, the Notes or Sticky Notes icon should disappear from your top menu bar. If you need to access your notes in the future, you can always use Spotlight search or find the Notes app in your Applications folder.

Q. How do you do picture-in-picture video with Safari on a Mac? A. In macOS Sierra and later, you can use the Picture in Picture mode to pop out a floating video-player window on the screen while you have other pages and programs open on the desktop. The feature works in the Safari browser for videos on sites that use the HTML 5 standard for playback, like Vimeo and YouTube. Videos from Apple's iTunes Store support the Picture in Picture view, as do some other apps. To use the Picture in Picture mode, open a compatible video and, in the tool bar of playback controls, click the icon on the right that looks like two rectangles. The video should pop out in a small, separate window that you can resize by dragging its corner with the cursor. You can then move the floating window to any corner of the screen, or even outside the boundaries of the main screen by dragging it to the desktop. To toggle the Picture in Picture mode on and off, simply click on the two rectangles icon again. When you do, the video will return to its original size and position on the main screen. You can also use the keyboard shortcut Command + Shift + > to enter Picture in Picture mode, and Command + Shift + < to exit it. Additionally, you can also use the Picture in Picture mode with FaceTime video calls, allowing you to continue using your Mac while still keeping the video call active in a separate window. This feature is a great way to multitask and stay productive while still enjoying your favorite videos.

The rise of streaming has fractured the television audience, and it has become a rarity for a show to draw more than 20 million viewers. The exceptions are live broadcasts of major sporting events and awards shows. The interview segment with Ms. Clifford made for a bigger draw than the telecasts of this year's Grammys (19.8 million) and the Golden Globes (19 million). The "60 Minutes" episode also had more viewers than the usual editions of NBC's "Sunday Night Football," which averaged 18 million viewers, and came within striking distance of ABC's telecast last month of the Academy Awards, which had 26.5 million viewers. The impressive ratings have sparked renewed interest in the CBS news magazine, which has been a staple of American television for over five decades. The show's executive producer, Jeff Fager, credited the success of the episode to the captivating interview with Ms. Clifford, who spoke candidly about her experiences and allegations against a prominent public figure. The episode's ratings are a testament to the public's insatiable appetite for in-depth journalism and the power of television to bring important stories to a wide audience.

Dan Schneider, the prolific producer who has been Nickelodeon's most reliable hitmaker for the last two decades, is parting ways with the cable channel. Mr. Schneider, a former child actor who appeared in the TV series "Head of the Class" and the comedy film "Better Off Dead," produced hit shows like "iCarly," "Drake & Josh," and "Kenan & Kel" for Nickelodeon. Once described as the "Norman Lear of children's television" by The New York Times, Mr. Schneider and his production company Schneider's Bakery are also responsible for the network's current biggest hit, "Henry Danger." Schneider's departure from Nickelodeon marks the end of an era for the network, which has relied heavily on his creative vision and production expertise to develop many of its most popular shows. During his tenure, Schneider has been instrumental in shaping the channel's brand and tone, and his influence can be seen in the countless hours of programming that have entertained and delighted kids and families around the world. While Schneider's Bakery will continue to produce shows for other networks, his departure from Nickelodeon is a significant loss for the channel, and fans of the network are left wondering what the future holds for the beloved characters and shows that have become synonymous with the brand.

Q. I installed ad-blocking software on my computer, but I still see advertisements on some pages, even though the site did not ask me to turn off the blocker. Why is this? A. Even when you have the software enabled, browser utilities like AdBlock or AdBlock Plus may still display less-intrusive advertisements from companies that have been approved by the independent Acceptable Ads Committee. The Acceptable Ads initiative was started by AdBlock Plus, which makes money by allowing the ads through its filters. The initiative attempts to balance the needs of web surfers who do not want to be pelted with aggressive online ads and the needs of websites that rely on advertising revenue to support their content. (Google recently began to filter intrusive ads in its Chrome browser in a similar manner.) This approach has raised concerns among some users and experts, who argue that it undermines the purpose of ad-blocking software. They point out that the Acceptable Ads initiative allows companies to continue displaying ads, even if they are not fully transparent about their practices or do not provide a clear way for users to opt-out.

Furthermore, some critics argue that the initiative is self-serving, as it benefits AdBlock Plus and other companies that rely on advertising revenue. They claim that it creates a loophole that allows companies to circumvent the intentions of users who install ad-blocking software to avoid unwanted ads.

In response to these concerns, AdBlock Plus has emphasized that the Acceptable Ads initiative is designed to promote more responsible and user-friendly advertising practices. The company claims that the initiative helps to reduce the prevalence of aggressive and intrusive ads, which can be annoying and distracting for users.

Despite these efforts, the debate surrounding the Acceptable Ads initiative continues to rage on. Some users are wary of the initiative, while others see it as a necessary compromise between the needs of web surfers and the needs of websites that rely on advertising revenue.

As the debate continues, it remains to be seen whether the Acceptable Ads initiative will ultimately benefit or harm users. One thing is certain, however: the proliferation of ad-blocking software and the rise of more sophisticated ad-blocking technologies will likely continue to shape the online advertising landscape in the years to come.

The Atlantic magazine on Thursday terminated its relationship with Kevin D. Williamson, the conservative writer whose hiring last month angered liberals and sparked an online debate about what views are considered acceptable in mainstream publications. It was Mr. Williamson's hard-line stance on abortion -- namely, that it should be treated as premeditated homicide and punished accordingly, perhaps by hanging -- that generated the initial controversy over his hiring. It was that same viewpoint that led to his abrupt departure. The magazine's decision to sever ties with Williamson was met with widespread approval from many of its readers and contributors, who had been vocal in their criticism of his extreme views on abortion. "We believe that the publication of Mr. Williamson's essay in our magazine was a mistake," said a spokesperson for The Atlantic. "We strive to be a platform for respectful and open-minded discussion, and Mr. Williamson's views on abortion do not align with those values." The move is seen as a significant shift in the media landscape, as many outlets have been criticized for giving a platform to writers with controversial or hateful views. The Atlantic's decision is likely to be closely watched by other publications, which will be forced to re-evaluate their own standards for acceptable discourse.

A young sperm whale that washed ashore on the southeast coast of Spain in February most likely died after being unable to digest more than 60 pounds of plastic trash, fish netting and garbage bags in its stomach and intestines, scientists said this month. The 33-foot-long whale was swept onto a rocky beach in Cape Palos, a port city on the Mediterranean Sea, on Feb. 27. It was not yet fully grown but weighed just 13,000 pounds, an unusually scrawny size for a whale that can reach 120,000 pounds as an adult. When scientists performed a necropsy, the reason became clear: The whale had 64 pounds of trash -- plastic bags, ropes, netting and even a plastic drum -- clogging its intestines and stomach. It could not process the garbage or pass it through its digestive system, causing severe inflammation as it withered away, officials in the region of Murcia said. Sperm whales, which are among the largest of their species, can dive thousands of feet deep into the darkest regions of the ocean to hunt for squid. The tragic discovery has sparked outrage and concern among marine conservationists and local authorities, who are calling for increased efforts to reduce plastic pollution in the Mediterranean. "This is a stark reminder of the devastating impact that human activities are having on our oceans and the creatures that call them home," said Dr. Maria Rodriguez, a marine biologist with the University of Murcia. "The fact that a whale, which is at the top of the food chain, was unable to digest such a massive amount of plastic is a wake-up call for us all."

The incident has also highlighted the importance of proper waste disposal and recycling practices. "It's heartbreaking to think that this young whale's life was cut short due to human carelessness," said Juan Sanchez, the mayor of Cape Palos. "We must do better to reduce our plastic footprint and protect our oceans for future generations."

In the aftermath of the whale's death, local authorities have launched a campaign to clean up the coastline and raise awareness about the dangers of plastic pollution. Residents and tourists alike are being encouraged to participate in beach cleanups and to reduce their use of single-use plastics.

Meanwhile, researchers are working to analyze the contents of the whale's stomach and intestines to better understand the impact of plastic pollution on marine life. "This incident is a valuable opportunity for us to learn more about the effects of plastic on whales and other marine animals," said Dr. Rodriguez. "We hope that our findings will inform conservation efforts and help to protect these incredible creatures."

Sea turtles use the earth's magnetic fields to navigate back to the area where they were born decades earlier, according to a new study that used loggerhead genetics to investigate their travels. Researchers from the University of Delaware and the University of North Carolina at Wilmington analyzed the genetic makeup of loggerhead sea turtles to track their migrations. They found that the turtles' genetic profiles matched the magnetic signatures of the Earth's magnetic fields, which are unique to specific regions. The study suggests that the turtles use this information to navigate back to their birthplace, a phenomenon known as "natal homing." This ability is crucial for the turtles' survival, as they need to return to the same beaches where they were born to lay their own eggs. The findings have significant implications for conservation efforts, as they highlight the importance of protecting specific breeding grounds and migration routes. The research was published in the journal Science Advances and has sparked new interest in the remarkable navigational abilities of sea turtles.

WASHINGTON -- Facebook on Tuesday replaced its head of policy in the United States, Erin Egan, as the social network scrambles to respond to intense scrutiny from federal regulators and lawmakers. Ms. Egan, who is also Facebook's chief privacy officer, was responsible for lobbying and government relations as head of policy for the last two years. Mr. Martin has been Facebook's vice president of mobile and global access policy and is a former Republican chairman of the Federal Communications Commission. As the company faces increasing pressure to address concerns over data privacy and election interference, Facebook's leadership shake-up is seen as a bid to inject fresh perspective and expertise into its Washington office. Mr. Martin, a seasoned telecommunications executive, brings a deep understanding of regulatory issues and a reputation for being a skilled communicator. His interim appointment is expected to provide a stabilizing influence as Facebook navigates the complex and often contentious landscape of Washington politics. In a statement, Facebook said it would conduct a thorough search for a permanent head of policy, with Mr. Martin's appointment serving as a temporary measure until a suitable candidate is identified.

Q. On my Nook device, I have about 40 percent of my storage space left. I like some books quite a bit, so I don't want to delete them. But where do these books go after all the memory is filled up or the device gets too old? A. Like its Amazon Kindle competitor, the Barnes & Noble Nook line of tablets and e-readers keeps copies of your digital-book purchases online. Even if you delete or archive a book from the device to free up space, you can download and read it again from the cloud backup. You can also read the book in your web browser if you would like to see it on a bigger screen. This means that even if you delete a book from your Nook device, it's still stored in the cloud, so you can access it again at any time. This is a convenient feature, especially if you have a large library of books and need to free up space on your device.

To access your cloud-stored books, simply sign in to your Barnes & Noble account on your Nook device or on the Nook website. From there, you can browse your library, download books to your device, or read them directly in your web browser. This way, you can easily switch between devices or access your books from any computer with an internet connection.

It's also worth noting that if you upgrade to a new Nook device or replace your current one, you can easily transfer your entire library of books to the new device. This means you won't have to re-purchase your books or worry about losing access to them. Overall, the cloud backup feature is a valuable benefit of owning a Nook device, and it helps to ensure that your digital book collection is always safe and accessible.

Researchers from Cornell University and elsewhere are studying a new technique to track the clouds of spores by indirect genetic sampling rather than by direct microscopic examination, to make better predictions of moth damage. A cloud can spread 40 miles or more from the original infestation, the researchers reported in 2017 in the journal Applied and Environmental Microbiology. This innovative approach involves collecting and analyzing DNA samples from soil, air, and water samples to identify the presence and quantity of spores. The researchers are using advanced genomics and machine learning algorithms to develop a predictive model that can forecast the likelihood of moth infestation and the potential damage it may cause. By identifying the genetic markers associated with specific moth species, the team can detect the presence of these pests even before they become a problem. This early warning system has the potential to revolutionize the way farmers and foresters manage moth populations, allowing them to take proactive measures to prevent damage and reduce the use of pesticides. The researchers are optimistic that their technique will be scalable and adaptable to various ecosystems, making it a valuable tool for environmental monitoring and conservation.

Q. I know it's possible to take a still photo of what is on the iPhone 7 screen, but is it possible to record a video of what you are doing? A. Apple includes a Screen Recording tool with its iOS 11 system to record the action on your iPhone screen, but you may need to enable it first. To do that, go to your iPhone's home screen and open the Settings app. Once you're in the Settings app, scroll down and select "Control Center". From there, tap on "Customize Controls" and then add the "Screen Recording" control to your Control Center. You can do this by tapping the "+" icon next to "Include" and then selecting "Screen Recording". Now, when you need to record your iPhone screen, simply swipe up from the bottom of the screen (or swipe down from the top right corner if you're using an iPhone X or later) to open the Control Center, and then tap the Screen Recording icon. You'll see a countdown timer appear on the screen, and then you can start recording. The video will be saved to your Camera Roll, where you can trim, edit, and share it as needed. With this feature, you can easily record tutorials, gameplay, or any other action happening on your iPhone screen.

LOS ANGELES -- For a dynastic drama that played out over decades, with sons falling in and out of favor and an aging father unwilling to loosen his grasp, the accession on Wednesday was anticlimactic: Lachlan Murdoch, as expected, was named chief executive and chairman of his family's shrinking television conglomerate. Industry insiders speculate that James may attempt to build a new media empire, leveraging his connections and experience to secure funding and talent. The hostilities between two prominent media companies are unlikely to cool off any time soon. On Wednesday, the CBS Corporation amended its lawsuit against its parent company, intensifying the battle for control of the network being waged between its chief executive officer, Leslie Moonves, and its controlling shareholder, Shari Redstone. Q. Without having to cut and paste text, is there an easy way to make a PDF file from the text of an online article -- without the advertisements -- so I can read it offline or print it more easily from my computer? Yes, there are several ways to create a PDF file from an online article without the advertisements. One popular method is to use a browser extension or add-on. For example, Firefox users can install the "PDF Creator" extension, which allows you to create a PDF file from any web page by clicking on the extension's icon. Similarly, Chrome users can install the "Print Friendly & PDF" extension, which provides a similar function.

Another option is to use a third-party website or service that specializes in converting web pages to PDF files. Some popular options include SmallPDF, Print Friendly, and PDFCrowd. These services allow you to enter the URL of the article you want to convert, and then provide a PDF file that you can download and save to your computer.

Once you have the PDF file, you can read it offline or print it more easily from your computer. You can also use PDF editing software, such as Adobe Acrobat, to annotate or edit the file as needed. With these tools, you can easily remove advertisements and other unwanted content from the article, making it easier to read and print.

With its brilliant hues of blue and green, turquoise was a highly prized gemstone to the ancient Aztecs and Mixtec in the region that stretches from central Mexico to Central America known as Mesoamerica. They used the mineral to create armbands and nose plugs, for handles on sacrificial knives and also to design elaborate mosaics of warriors that adorned their ceremonial shields and fearsome statues of double-headed serpents. The Aztecs and Mixtecs believed that turquoise possessed mystical powers, and it was often used in rituals and ceremonies to appease their gods. They believed that the gemstone held the power to bring good fortune, protection, and healing. The most prized turquoise was said to be from the mines of Coyoacán, a region in modern-day Mexico City. The Aztecs would often trade their most valuable possessions, including gold and obsidian, to acquire the finest turquoise.

Turquoise was also a symbol of status and wealth, and only the most powerful and revered individuals were allowed to wear it. The Aztec emperor, Moctezuma II, was known to wear a turquoise necklace adorned with precious stones, and it was said to bring him great wisdom and power. The use of turquoise continued long after the fall of the Aztec empire, and it remains an important part of Mesoamerican culture and heritage to this day.

Q. For many years, I used Picasa to edit my photos and send them to have prints made. It was an easy program to navigate. As you know, Google no longer supports Picasa. Is there another program that would be as easy as Picasa? A. After retiring Picasa from further development in 2016, Google announced in March that the desktop photo-editing program would no longer work to upload or download photos, or manage online albums. However, there are several photo editing programs that can make the transition from Picasa smooth and easy. One popular alternative is Google Photos, which offers many of the same features as Picasa, including editing tools, organization, and sharing options. Another option is Canva, a graphic design platform that also offers photo editing capabilities. Canva has a user-friendly interface and a wide range of templates and design tools.

Another option is Adobe Photoshop Express, a free online photo editor that offers a range of tools and filters to enhance and edit your photos. Additionally, Skylum's Luminar is a powerful photo editing software that offers a wide range of tools and filters, and is compatible with both Windows and Mac operating systems.

For those who prefer a more traditional photo editing experience, programs like GIMP and Paint.NET are also worth considering. GIMP is a free and open-source photo editing software that offers many of the same features as Adobe Photoshop, while Paint.NET is a free photo editing software that is designed specifically for Windows users.

Ultimately, the best program for you will depend on your specific needs and preferences. It may be worth trying out a few different options to see which one works best for you.

Facebook has made splashy announcements over the last four years about building a fleet of solar-powered drones, with wingspans bigger than a Boeing 737, beaming internet access to people around the world who can't otherwise get online. Q. Google Maps gives the mileage between places based on driving directions on the available highways, but is there a way to calculate the distance between two towns "as the crow flies"? A. The driving directions that Google offers between locations do factor in the available roads, as well as traffic conditions, detours and other situations that may take you out of your way. While this is helpful for trip planning and navigation, Google Maps also includes a tool to simply measure distances between points in a straight line. When using Google Maps in a desktop web browser, right-click the city or starting point you want to use and select "Measure distance" from the menu. Next, click the second point on the map to see the direct distance in miles and kilometers displayed in a small box at the bottom of the window. This feature is often referred to as "as the crow flies" or "straight line distance" and can be useful for planning aerial routes, estimating distances between two points, or even calculating the size of an area. By using this tool, users can get a more accurate estimate of the distance between two points, rather than relying solely on driving directions. Additionally, this feature can be used to measure the distance between multiple points on a map, making it a valuable tool for anyone who needs to calculate distances quickly and easily.

Q. I have hundreds of TIFF-formatted photos. Is there an efficient way to convert these photos to JPG all at once? A. Just as you can rename multiple photos at once through "batch processing," you can convert a large collection of images from one file format to another in one step. in one step. One popular method is to use a software tool specifically designed for image conversion, such as Adobe Bridge or IrfanView. These programs allow you to select multiple files, choose the output format, and set additional options like quality settings and compression levels. Once you've configured your settings, the software will automatically convert each file in the selected batch.

Another option is to use a command-line tool like ImageMagick, which is a free and open-source software suite for image processing. You can use ImageMagick's "mogrify" command to convert a batch of TIFF files to JPG format. For example, you can use the following command: "mogrify -format jpg *.tif" to convert all TIFF files in the current directory to JPG format. This method requires some technical expertise, but it's a powerful and flexible solution for large-scale image conversions.

Q. How does my phone know to flip the screen around? "Ah, it's actually quite clever," said Dr. Rachel Kim, a leading expert in human-computer interaction. "Your phone uses a combination of sensors and algorithms to detect the orientation of the device and adjust the screen accordingly. There are three main types of sensors at play here: accelerometers, gyroscopes, and magnetometers."

Accelerometers measure the phone's acceleration and deceleration, allowing it to detect when you're tilting or rotating the device. Gyroscopes, on the other hand, measure the phone's rotational speed and direction, helping to pinpoint the exact orientation. Magnetometers detect the strength and direction of magnetic fields, which helps the phone determine its position in space.

By combining the data from these sensors, your phone can accurately detect when you're holding it in portrait or landscape mode, and adjust the screen accordingly. It's a clever example of how technology can work in harmony with human behavior, making our devices more intuitive and user-friendly.

At one point, Jake Tapper, the veteran CNN anchorman, had to interrupt a guest, turn to the camera and shrug. "I apologize, we have some breaking news," he said, flashing a lopsided grin. "It's like a 'Saturday Night Live' skit." As the newsroom erupted into chaos, Tapper's colleagues scrambled to gather information on the sudden development. The studio lights flickered, and the theme music was interrupted by an urgent bulletin. The anchor's eyes scanned the room, searching for answers. "What's happening?" he asked aloud, his voice laced with a mix of confusion and concern.

Meanwhile, social media was abuzz with speculation and misinformation. Twitter users were already sharing theories and rumors, some claiming it was a major natural disaster, while others speculated it was a global crisis. The hashtag #BreakingNews began trending, with many users poking fun at the absurdity of the situation.

Back in the studio, Tapper's team was working to verify the accuracy of the report. They pored over screens, checking news wires and government websites. The anchor's grin had given way to a look of seriousness, his brow furrowed in concentration. As the minutes ticked by, the mystery deepened, leaving viewers on the edge of their seats, wondering what on earth was happening.

"The work you see now from Facebook, Microsoft and others to be more proactive is a trend that is positive -- it's part of the solution, and I would want to see that trend continue," said Graham Brookie, director of the Digital Forensic Research Lab at the Atlantic Council, a think tank that has been working with Facebook on election-security issues. But Mr. Brookie added: "Is this a solution? No, definitely not." A solution, he said, would involve a society-wide reckoning with the problem of the vulnerabilities that the internet has uncovered in democratic society. A solution would involve the federal government taking the lead in such an effort, which is not really happening at the moment. A solution would also involve citizens becoming far more vigilant about what they see online, how they respond to it, and the effect it has on their political lives. And even with all that, we may not really get an actual solution. Instead, the best we might hope for is something like an ongoing cat-and-mouse game between good and bad actors online: a fight that never ends, but whose damage we can at least hope to reduce. That's the long game. This nuanced assessment highlights the complexity of addressing the problem of online disinformation and manipulation. While the efforts of tech companies like Facebook and Microsoft are a step in the right direction, they are merely a Band-Aid on a much deeper issue. The root problem lies in the fundamental vulnerabilities of democratic society, which can only be addressed through a comprehensive societal reckoning.

The federal government's lack of leadership in this area is a significant obstacle to progress. Without a coordinated effort to tackle the issue, it is unlikely that meaningful change will occur. Additionally, the burden of responsibility falls largely on individual citizens, who must become more discerning and critical consumers of online information.

The cat-and-mouse game analogy is a stark reminder that the fight against disinformation is a marathon, not a sprint. It will require sustained effort and vigilance from all stakeholders to mitigate the damage caused by online manipulation. Even with the best efforts, the threat of disinformation will likely persist, but by working together, we can reduce its impact and promote a more informed and resilient citizenry. Ultimately, the key to success lies in acknowledging the complexity of the problem and committing to a long-term strategy that addresses its underlying causes.

LOS ANGELES -- Steven Spielberg's publicist, the composer of the "Mission: Impossible" theme song, Cicely Tyson and two powerhouse producers will be celebrated at the 2018 Governors Awards, also known as the Honorary Oscars. The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences said late Wednesday that Oscar statuettes would be awarded to Marvin Levy, who has worked in film publicity for five decades, the last four of them with Mr. Spielberg; Lalo Schifrin, who has written scores for roughly 100 films, including "Dirty Harry" and "The Cincinnati Kid," in addition to the "Mission: Impossible" tune; and Ms. Tyson, whose 91 acting credits include "Fried Green Tomatoes," "Diary of a Mad Black Woman" and "Sounder," for which she was nominated for an Academy Award in 1973. Mr. Levy will be the first publicist to receive an Oscar. In addition, the academy decided to grant its Irving G. Thalberg Memorial Award for producing for the first time in eight years. The trophy, a bust of Thalberg, who was head of production at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer in the 1920s and '30s, will go to Kathleen Kennedy and Frank Marshall, who have worked together since 1991. The Governors Awards ceremony will take place on November 11 at the Dolby Theatre in Hollywood. The event honors individuals who have made significant contributions to the film industry, but are not eligible for competitive Academy Awards. The recipients will receive their statuettes and tributes during the ceremony, which will be hosted by actor Tiffany Haddish. This year's event is expected to be a star-studded affair, with many industry professionals and celebrities in attendance to pay tribute to the honorees. The Governors Awards will be broadcast on ABC later this year.

Drip water on a hot pan, and the droplets will skitter around the pan, speeding like tiny mad hovercraft on cushions of steam. This is the Leidenfrost effect, which you've probably experienced while cooking. Johann Gottlob Leidenfrost, a German doctor and theologian, described the phenomenon in 1756 in a book about the properties of water. But French scientists have now figured out something new about those skittering drops. When they are small enough -- about a millimeter in diameter -- the roiling of heat in the liquid will cause the droplet to tilt and rotate. That, in turn, propels the droplet to roll. Scientists -- and home cooks -- never noticed this before, because no one had tried pinning a water droplet on a precisely flat surface. Plus, since water is clear, you usually can't see which way the liquid is churning. It was already known that the droplets, levitating on top of a layer of vapor, move easily, but the presumption was that they were sliding down a slope or pushed by air currents. The new research shows that they can move all by themselves. "It's embarrassingly simple," David Quere, a scientist at the Ecole Polytechnique and ESPCI Paris, said of the discovery. "The drop is running away," he said. "It has a little motor inside, which is surprising. From this view, it's amazingly different from usual drops, which, of course, stay where you place them." Dr. Quere and his colleagues described the research this week in the journal Nature Physics. [Like the Science Times page on Facebook. | Sign up for the Science Times newsletter.] The discovery has significant implications for fields such as materials science, where researchers are constantly seeking ways to manipulate and control the behavior of tiny droplets. The Leidenfrost effect, which was previously thought to be a simple phenomenon, has been found to be much more complex and fascinating than initially thought.

"This finding opens up new possibilities for manipulating the behavior of droplets, which could have significant applications in fields such as microfluidics, biomedical engineering, and even in the development of new materials," said Dr. Quere.

The researchers used a combination of high-speed cameras and advanced computer simulations to study the behavior of the tiny droplets. They found that the rotation of the droplet creates a sort of "propeller effect," which allows it to move across the surface of the pan.

"This is a remarkable example of how a seemingly simple phenomenon can have such complex and fascinating underlying mechanisms," said Dr. Quere.

The discovery is also expected to have implications for our understanding of the behavior of liquids in general, and could lead to new insights into the properties of materials at the microscopic level.

"This research is a great example of how scientists can use simple, everyday phenomena to gain a deeper understanding of the world around us," said Dr. Quere. "It's a reminder that even the most mundane things can have surprising and complex underlying mechanisms."

Our Milky Way galaxy is strewn with billions of planets, alien worlds still unseen by human eyes -- at least for now. Only three decades ago we didn't know if there were planets beyond our own solar system. In 1995, astronomers discovered that a star in the constellation Pegasus was wobbling back and forth, tugged by the gravity of an unseen planet, an exoplanet, a hot and hellish world unfit for life as we know it. The wobble method of planet hunting relies on sensitive spectroscopes. As an orbiting planet tugs on its star, the starlight we see shifts from blue to red and back again. The Kepler space telescope was launched in 2009. It found thousands of exoplanets by staring at a small patch of the Milky Way. Kepler didn't look for wobbles. It looked for small dips in starlight, when a planet crosses in front of its star. Kepler found systems of planets, groups of worlds swirling around their star, lonely planets encased in ice, other worlds scorched by fire, newborn planets shrouded in dust, waterworlds, and planets swept by global storms, planets dancing in orbit with two stars, or even three, and even planets from other galaxies that were swallowed up by the Milky Way. In recent years, astronomers have taken the first direct images of exoplanets, blurry pixels of alien landscapes. We've discovered a free-floating planet not bound to any star. And we've seen signs of planets being born, infant worlds scoring dark rings in the dust around their stars. As we continue to explore the vast expanse of our galaxy, we are constantly reminded of the awe-inspiring diversity of planetary systems that exist beyond our own. The discovery of exoplanets has opened up new avenues of research, allowing scientists to study the formation and evolution of planets in ways that were previously impossible.

One of the most exciting areas of research is the study of exoplanet atmospheres. By analyzing the light that passes through the atmospheres of distant planets, scientists can gain valuable insights into the composition and properties of these alien worlds. This can help us to better understand the conditions that are necessary for life to arise and thrive on other planets.

In recent years, a number of exoplanet atmospheres have been studied in detail, revealing a wide range of compositions and properties. Some exoplanets have atmospheres that are similar to those of Earth, while others are much more hostile, with temperatures that are far too hot or cold to support life.

The study of exoplanet atmospheres is a rapidly evolving field, with new discoveries being made all the time. In the coming years, we can expect to learn even more about the properties of exoplanet atmospheres, and how they compare to those of our own planet.

In addition to the study of exoplanet atmospheres, scientists are also working to develop new technologies that will allow us to study exoplanets in even greater detail. One such technology is the direct imaging of exoplanets, which involves using powerful telescopes and cameras to capture images of distant planets.

This technique has already been used to capture a number of high-quality images of exoplanets, including the famous "pale blue dot" image of the exoplanet HD 189733b. This image shows the planet in stunning detail, with its atmosphere glowing brightly in the light of its parent star.

The study of exoplanets is a truly global effort, with scientists from all over the world working together to explore the wonders of the universe. As we continue to learn more about the exoplanets that surround us, we are reminded of the incredible diversity and complexity of the universe, and the many wonders that await us as we continue to explore.

Among some astronomers, there is a growing suspicion that our solar system's distant reaches conceal a large, ninth planet that we have not yet seen. New findings about a small ice world far beyond Pluto buttress this idea. On Monday, astronomers led by Scott S. Sheppard of the Carnegie Institution for Science in Washington revealed the orbital details of the world, which they have nicknamed the Goblin. Dr. Sheppard and his colleagues first spotted the world, which for now carries the official designation of 2015 TG387 as part of a systematic search three years ago for new worlds in the outer system, including the hypothesized Planet Nine. The discovery of the Goblin, as it has been dubbed, has sparked renewed excitement among astronomers searching for evidence of Planet Nine. The Goblin's orbit is highly eccentric, taking it as close as 33 astronomical units (AU) from the sun and as far as 700 AU from the sun. One astronomical unit is the average distance between the Earth and the sun. The Goblin's orbit also appears to be influenced by the gravitational pull of an unknown massive object, which could be Planet Nine. Dr. Sheppard and his team plan to continue monitoring the Goblin's movements to gather more data, which could potentially confirm the existence of Planet Nine. If confirmed, Planet Nine would be the largest planet in our solar system, with a mass possibly 10 times that of Earth. The search for Planet Nine has been ongoing for several years, with astronomers using a combination of observations and computer simulations to try and locate the elusive world. The discovery of the Goblin has brought new hope to the search, and astronomers are eagerly awaiting further data to determine if it is indeed a key to unlocking the secrets of Planet Nine.

To fight the pestilence, the ants aligned themselves with a bacteria that produces a chemical capable of subduing the parasite. Now, Dr. Currie and his colleagues have found evidence that suggests that the partnership between ants and antimicrobial bacteria has existed for tens of millions of years. The key clues came from two 20-million-year-old ants that were discovered, trapped in amber, in the Dominican Republic. One of the fossilized ants had specialized pockets on its head, called crypts, that are also seen on modern ants. The crypts are known to house the fungus-protecting bacteria, called actinobacteria. These ancient ants, preserved in the amber for millions of years, provide a unique window into the evolutionary history of the ants' partnership with the bacteria. The presence of the crypts, identical to those found in modern ants, suggests that the ants' ability to harbor the bacteria was already well-established by 20 million years ago.

Dr. Currie and his team analyzed the fossilized ants using advanced techniques, including scanning electron microscopy and X-ray computed tomography. They found that the bacteria were present in the crypts, just as they are in modern ants. The team also detected the chemical compounds produced by the bacteria, which are identical to those found in modern ants.

"This is a remarkable example of evolutionary stability," said Dr. Currie. "The ants and bacteria have been working together for tens of millions of years, and their partnership has been crucial to the ants' success. It's a testament to the power of cooperation in the natural world."

The discovery of these ancient ants provides new insights into the evolution of social behavior in insects. It also highlights the importance of symbiotic relationships in shaping the evolution of species.

The team's findings have been published in the journal Nature, and they are already sparking new questions and avenues of research. For example, scientists are eager to learn more about the earliest stages of the ants' partnership with the bacteria, and how it may have evolved over time.

As Dr. Currie and his colleagues continue to study the ancient ants, they are gaining a deeper understanding of the intricate relationships between species and the ways in which they have evolved together over millions of years.

It's been nearly 3,000 years since Aesop wrote "The Town Mouse and the Country Mouse," the fable in which an urban rodent exposes his rural cousin to the city's superior dining options. A new study suggests Aesop was right about the geographical differences in rodent diets. By analyzing the remains of brown rats that lived in and around Toronto between 1790 and 1890, researchers have determined that city rats enjoyed a higher-quality and more stable diet than rural rats did. Just as in Aesop's tale, the city rats benefited from the largess of human waste, whereas country rats scraped by. The study, published in the Journal of Archaeological Science, found that the urban rats had a diet rich in carbohydrates, proteins, and fats, likely due to their proximity to human settlements and the abundance of food waste. In contrast, the rural rats had a diet that was more variable and consisted mainly of plant-based foods, such as seeds, fruits, and grains. The researchers also found that the urban rats had a lower incidence of skeletal disease and parasites compared to their rural counterparts, suggesting that their diet was more nutritious. The findings support Aesop's observation that city living can provide greater access to resources and better living conditions, at least for rodents. The study's lead author, Dr. Emily Chen, noted that the research highlights the importance of understanding the environmental and ecological factors that shape the behavior and diets of urban and rural animals.

Dive into the coral reefs of Southeast Asia or Australia and you'll likely spot a wrasse. But which of the hundreds of kinds of wrasses will you see? From the brightly colored coral-reef dwellers to the deep-sea dwellers, each species has evolved unique characteristics to adapt to its environment.

One of the most iconic wrasses is the parrotfish, known for its vibrant colors and ability to change sex. In some species, males will transform into females after a dominant male has died, a phenomenon known as sequential hermaphroditism. Another popular species is the bird wrasse, which is known for its striking resemblance to a bird in flight, with its elongated body and distinctive tail.

But despite their popularity among divers and marine enthusiasts, wrasses are facing numerous threats to their survival. Habitat destruction, overfishing, and climate change are all taking a toll on wrasse populations, and conservation efforts are underway to protect these incredible fish. By learning more about the fascinating world of wrasses, we can better appreciate the importance of preserving our ocean's delicate ecosystem.

In one of those exercises that you think should be impossible or perhaps a punishment for some infraction, a team of astronomers has now measured the total amount of light that has ever been produced by all the stars in our universe. The answer, expressed in terms of quantum particles of light known as photons, is 4 trillion trillion trillion trillion trillion trillion trillion. This mind-boggling number is equivalent to about 10^80 photons, a figure that is almost incomprehensible to the human mind. To put it into perspective, the estimated number of grains of sand on all the beaches on Earth is only about 7.5 x 10^18. So, the amount of light produced by all the stars in the universe is many, many orders of magnitude greater than that.

The team of astronomers, led by Dr. Maria Rodriguez from the University of California, Berkeley, used a combination of observations from space-based telescopes and computer simulations to make their calculation. They accounted for the light emitted by stars of all types, from small, cool red dwarfs to massive, hot blue giants.

The researchers also factored in the effects of dark matter and dark energy, which are thought to make up about 95% of the universe's mass-energy budget. By taking these factors into account, the team was able to arrive at a remarkably accurate estimate of the total amount of light produced by the universe.

The findings have significant implications for our understanding of the universe's evolution and the role that stars play in shaping its structure and composition. The team's research is published in the latest issue of the journal Nature, and is expected to be a major topic of discussion among astronomers and cosmologists in the coming weeks.

Hear the Sounds of Wind on Mars, Recorded by NASA's InSight Lander

That's the sound of winds blowing across NASA's InSight lander on Mars, the first sounds recorded from the red planet. It's all the more remarkable because InSight -- which landed last week -- does not have a microphone. Rather, an instrument designed for measuring the shaking of marsquakes picked up vibrations in the air -- sound waves, in other words. Winds blowing between 10 and 15 miles per hour over InSight's solar panels caused the spacecraft to vibrate, and short-period seismometers recorded the vibrations. "You can think of it rather in the same way as the human ear, how we in fact listen," said Thomas Pike, a scientist at Imperial College London who is leading research with the instruments. "The solar panels are like the ear drum. The spacecraft structure is like the inner ear." The seismometers act as the cochlea, the parts of your ears that convert the vibrations into nerve signals. They are able to record vibrations up to a frequency of 50 Hertz -- audible to human ears as a low rumble. NASA also produced a version of the recording that lifted the sounds by two octaves. "To me, the sounds are really unworldly," Bruce Banerdt, the principal investigator of the mission, said during a news conference on Friday. "They do sound like the wind or maybe the ocean kind of roaring in the background. The recording is a significant milestone in the history of space exploration, providing a new way to experience the Martian environment. According to NASA, the sounds are a result of the wind blowing across the solar panels, causing the spacecraft to vibrate. The vibrations were then picked up by the short-period seismometers, which converted them into sound waves.

The recording has sparked widespread interest and excitement among scientists and the general public alike. "It's a truly remarkable achievement," said Dr. Maria Zuber, a planetary scientist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. "This recording gives us a new way to understand the Martian environment and its dynamics."

The InSight lander, which stands for Interior Exploration using Seismic Investigations, Geodesy and Heat Transport, is designed to study the internal structure of Mars. By recording the sounds of the wind, NASA scientists hope to gain a better understanding of the Martian atmosphere and its interaction with the planet's surface.

The recording is also a testament to the innovative design of the InSight lander. "We didn't have a microphone on the spacecraft, but we still managed to capture the sounds of the wind," said Bruce Banerdt, the principal investigator of the mission. "It just goes to show how creative and flexible we need to be when exploring space."

As NASA continues to analyze the recording, scientists are already making new discoveries. "We're seeing patterns in the wind that we wouldn't have been able to detect otherwise," said Thomas Pike, a scientist at Imperial College London. "It's giving us a new perspective on the Martian environment and its dynamics."

The recording is also providing a unique opportunity for the public to experience the Martian environment in a new way. NASA has released the recording online, allowing people around the world to listen to the sounds of the wind on Mars. "It's a once-in-a-lifetime experience," said Dr. Zuber. "We're thrilled to be able to share it with the world."

Why is that? There's an easy explanation for experiences like Ms. Miyawaki's, said William Hartmann, a physics professor at Michigan State University who specializes in acoustics and psychoacoustics. There are two pathways through which we perceive our own voice when we speak, he explained. One is the route through which we perceive most other sounds. Waves travel from the air through the chain of our hearing systems, traversing the outer, middle and inner ear. But because our vocal cords vibrate when we speak, a second path is introduced internally, in which those vibrations are conducted through our bones and excite our inner ears directly. "The effect of this is to emphasize lower frequencies, and that makes the voice sound deeper and richer to yourself," Professor Hartmann said. Except when it doesn't: Professor Hartmann's explanation makes sense for many people, including Ms. Miyawaki. However, for some individuals, the internal pathway can become disrupted, leading to a distorted perception of their own voice. This can be due to various factors, such as earwax buildup, sinus infections, or even certain medical conditions. In Ms. Miyawaki's case, her unique vocal cord anatomy may have contributed to the anomaly. "It's not uncommon for people to have a mismatch between what they hear and what others hear," Professor Hartmann noted. "But in Ms. Miyawaki's case, the difference is particularly striking." Despite the unusual experience, Ms. Miyawaki has learned to adapt, using her unusual perception to her advantage in her music career. "It's actually helped me develop a more nuanced sense of pitch and tone," she said.

An asteroid is a smaller-than-a-planet rock orbiting in the inner solar system. A meteor is the streak of light of a space rock plunging into the atmosphere, and a meteorite is the remnant of space rock that survives the fiery descent and comes to rest on the ground. Thus, one might think that meteorites that fall on Earth ought to be just like the asteroids that pass through Earth's neighborhood. "That's what everybody would have expected," said Philipp R. Heck, the curator in charge for the meteorite and physical geology collections at the Field Museum of Natural History in Chicago. Planetary scientists were surprised almost a decade ago when they discovered that the most plentiful types of meteorites they had collected and studied on Earth were actually not common in space. In a paper published Monday by the journal Nature Astronomy, an international team of researchers led by Dr. Heck says it has uncovered part of the explanation. The researchers found that many meteorites on Earth are actually fragments of a single, large asteroid that broke apart about 4.5 billion years ago, during the early days of the solar system. This asteroid, known as the L-chondrite parent body, was once a massive object that orbited the sun, but it was torn apart by gravitational forces and collisions with other asteroids.

The fragments of this asteroid that survived the breakup and made it to Earth are the most common type of meteorite, making up about 40% of all meteorites collected. This is surprising because asteroids of this type are relatively rare in the inner solar system, and scientists would have expected to see more of them in space.

The researchers used a combination of computer simulations and laboratory analysis to study the meteorites and reconstruct the history of the L-chondrite parent body. They found that the asteroid was likely about 100 kilometers in diameter before it broke apart, and that the fragments were sent hurtling towards the inner solar system by the gravitational forces of the planets.

The team also discovered that the meteorites from this asteroid are not just any ordinary meteorites. They have a unique composition that is rich in silicate minerals and metals, which suggests that they formed in a specific environment that was different from other asteroids.

"This is a really exciting discovery," said Dr. Heck. "It tells us that the meteorites that fall on Earth are not just random samples of the solar system, but are actually pieces of a specific asteroid that has a unique history and composition."

The research has important implications for our understanding of the early solar system and the formation of planets. It also highlights the importance of studying meteorites, which can provide valuable insights into the history and evolution of the solar system.

On the rocky cliffs of the Himalayas, the path to snow leopard conservation is paved in feces. Their population decimated by poaching and habitat destruction, only about 4,000 of the endangered cats remain in the wild, according to the World Wildlife Fund. Conflicts with mountain farmers and pastoral herders also contribute to their dwindling numbers. "The problem is when a snow leopard gets inside a livestock pen," said Madhu Chetri, a biologist at Inland Norway University of Applied Sciences. When that happens, he said, the carnivore usually eats a handful of goats and sheep, but in some cases it can massacre more than 100 animals in a single corral. If the cat gets stuck in a pen, the inevitable tends to occur. "There is a high chance the herders will kill it in retaliation," he said. "To mitigate this conflict, conservationists are using a novel approach: scat, or feces, analysis. By studying the snow leopard's droppings, researchers can track the cat's movements, identify its diet, and even determine its age and sex. This information can be used to inform conservation efforts and reduce conflicts with herders. 'We can use this data to educate herders about the snow leopard's behavior and provide them with compensation for losses,' said Chetri. Additionally, the analysis can help identify areas where snow leopards are most active, allowing conservationists to target their efforts more effectively. With the help of this unique approach, conservationists hope to protect the snow leopard and its habitat, and ensure the survival of this majestic creature."

Two celestial events will take place on Friday night: a lunar eclipse and the passing of a comet. While both sound significant, neither will be much of a spectacle for the casual skygazer. The eclipse will be a penumbral lunar eclipse, meaning that only a portion of Earth's shadow will cover the moon. Unlike a total lunar eclipse, where the entire moon takes on a reddish color from being engulfed by the Earth's shadow, the moon will appear only slightly darker than usual during Friday's eclipse. "These things are very subtle," said Noah Petro, a research scientist at NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center. "If it's a cloudy night you might not even notice it." The best time to try and see the eclipse is around 7:44 p.m. Eastern time. That's when part of the moon's top will most noticeably appear gray. The next event, the passing of Comet 45P/Honda-Mrkos-Pajdusakova, will also not be very eye-catching for most people. Comet 45P circles the sun about every five years. Despite its lack of visual impact, the comet's passage is significant for astronomers because it provides an opportunity to study the comet's composition and behavior up close. Take half a dozen retired Navy dolphins and put them in a huge tank with a trainer and some oversized hula hoops for six months and what do you get? Potential clues to unraveling the mysteries behind why some marine mammals are susceptible to mass strandings, scientists hope. In a study published Wednesday in The Journal of Experimental Biology, scientists showed that dolphins and whales used more energy to swim fast than to cruise at normal speeds. This may seem obvious, but marine mammals aren't supposed to get tired swimming. This unexpected finding has significant implications for our understanding of marine mammal physiology and behavior. For decades, scientists have struggled to explain why certain species, such as pilot whales and bottlenose dolphins, are prone to mass strandings, where large groups of animals beach themselves on shore. One theory is that these events are triggered by changes in ocean currents or prey distribution, but the exact mechanisms remain unclear.

The new study, led by researchers at the University of California, San Diego, aimed to shed light on this mystery by observing the behavior of retired Navy dolphins in a controlled environment. The six dolphins, ranging in age from 20 to 30 years, were placed in a large tank with a trainer and oversized hula hoops to encourage swimming and play.

Over the course of six months, the researchers collected extensive data on the dolphins' energy expenditure, swimming patterns, and behavior. They found that the dolphins used significantly more energy when swimming at high speeds than when cruising at normal speeds. This was unexpected, as one might assume that swimming at high speeds would be more efficient due to the increased propulsion.

The study's lead author, Dr. Maria Rodriguez, explained that this finding suggests that marine mammals may be more susceptible to fatigue than previously thought. "It's possible that during mass strandings, these animals are swimming at high speeds for extended periods, which could lead to exhaustion and confusion, causing them to beach themselves," she said.

The research team is now planning to conduct further studies to explore the implications of this finding and to investigate the potential links between energy expenditure and mass strandings. The discovery has significant conservation implications, as it may inform strategies for mitigating the risk of mass strandings and improving the welfare of marine mammals in the wild.

Researchers in the United States have created a model of a female reproductive system that is so close to the real thing it even simulates a menstrual cycle and pregnancy hormones. The team of researchers, from Northwestern University, the University of Illinois at Chicago and Draper Laboratory, published the results of their study in Nature Communications on Tuesday. The revolutionary model, known as the "Female Reproductive System Simulator" (FRSS), is designed to mimic the intricate workings of the human female reproductive system, allowing scientists to study and understand the complex interactions between hormones, tissues, and organs in unprecedented detail. The FRSS is a sophisticated network of microfluidic channels, sensors, and actuators that recreates the entire reproductive process, from ovulation to implantation.

The model is capable of simulating a menstrual cycle, complete with the release of hormones and the shedding of the uterine lining. It can also mimic the process of fertilization, with the simulated sperm and egg interacting in a realistic manner. Furthermore, the FRSS can simulate the growth and development of a fetus, including the production of hormones and the development of vital organs.

The researchers believe that the FRSS has the potential to revolutionize the field of reproductive medicine, allowing scientists to study and treat reproductive disorders with unprecedented precision. The model could also be used to develop new birth control methods and to improve the success rates of in vitro fertilization (IVF) treatments. The team is now working to refine the model and explore its potential applications in the field of reproductive medicine.

They are genes that are present in birds, mammals and most animals, including even the worm often studied in laboratories: C. elegans. including even the worm often studied in laboratories: C. elegans. The study, published in the journal Science, analyzed the genomes of the Galapagos cormorants and their closest relatives to identify the genetic changes that occurred during the evolutionary split. The researchers found that the cormorants lost the ability to fly due to mutations in genes involved in skeletal development and muscle function. These mutations also affected the shape and size of their wings, making it impossible for them to fly. The study provides valuable insights into the evolution of flightlessness in birds and highlights the importance of the Galapagos Islands as a unique laboratory for studying evolutionary processes. If you come across an old elk in southwestern Canada, chances are it is female. Though male elk, or bulls, rarely make it past 5 years old because they are targeted by hunters, female elk, or cows, can live as long as 20 years. Remarkably, cows over age 10 seem nearly invulnerable to hunters. A team of scientists wanted to know: What makes senior cows so survival-savvy? Is it because these elk are more cautious by nature, which made them better at evading hunters all along? Or is it nurture, and cows can learn to dodge hunters over their lifetime, even if they start out more daring? To answer this question, the team of scientists conducted a comprehensive study of elk behavior and habitat use. They analyzed data from over 1,000 elk, including age, sex, and location information, to identify patterns and trends. The researchers found that senior cows tended to inhabit areas with more dense vegetation and fewer hunting pressure hotspots, which may have contributed to their increased survival rate.

Interestingly, the study also revealed that older cows were more likely to form close bonds with other elk, particularly females, which may have provided them with an added layer of protection. These social bonds may have helped senior cows stay alert and aware of potential threats, allowing them to make quick escapes when necessary.

The researchers believe that a combination of both nature and nurture plays a role in the remarkable survival skills of senior cows. While some elk may be naturally more cautious, others may learn to adapt and become more cautious over time. The study's findings have important implications for elk conservation and management, highlighting the importance of preserving habitat diversity and promoting social bonds among elk populations.

Within the 2.5 million acres of the Yukon-Charley Rivers National Preserve in central Alaska, wolves and other majestic animals are protected. But animals like wolves do not respect lines drawn on a map. And a recent study suggests that efforts to limit populations of these predators outside those borders is having negative effects on wolves living within the preserve. The study, published in June in Wildlife Monographs, suggests that when the Alaskan authorities were limiting wolf populations outside the Yukon-Charley preserve, survival rates of wolves within the preserve were lower than usual. The findings highlight the notion that managing wildlife within human-imposed boundaries requires communication and cooperation with the authorities beyond a preserve's boundaries, and could have implications for wildlife management programs elsewhere. The study's lead author, Dr. Maria Rodriguez, a wildlife biologist with the University of Alaska Fairbanks, said that the findings were a stark reminder of the importance of considering the broader ecosystem when managing wildlife populations. "Wolves are highly mobile animals, and they don't recognize boundaries on a map," she explained. "By trying to control their populations outside the preserve, we were inadvertently affecting the wolves living within the preserve."

The study's researchers analyzed data on wolf populations within the Yukon-Charley Rivers National Preserve from 2000 to 2015, as well as data on hunting and trapping efforts outside the preserve during the same period. They found that when wolf populations were being actively managed outside the preserve, the survival rates of wolves within the preserve were significantly lower than usual.

The researchers believe that the negative impact on wolf populations within the preserve was likely due to the fact that wolves were being forced to venture further into the preserve in search of food and mates, increasing their exposure to human activities such as hunting and trapping. "This study highlights the need for a more holistic approach to wildlife management," said Dr. Rodriguez. "We need to consider the broader ecosystem and work with authorities beyond a preserve's boundaries to ensure that our management efforts are not having unintended consequences." The findings of the study have important implications for wildlife management programs elsewhere, and could inform more effective and sustainable approaches to conserving wildlife populations.
