Stop. Drop the sponge and step away from the microwave. That squishy cleaning apparatus is a microscopic universe, teeming with countless bacteria. Some people may think that microwaving a sponge kills its tiny residents, but they are only partly right. It may nuke the weak ones, but the strongest, smelliest and potentially pathogenic bacteria will survive. Then, they will reproduce and occupy the vacant real estate of the dead. And your sponge will just be stinkier and nastier and you may come to regret having not just tossed it, suggests a study published last month in Scientific Reports. The study, led by researchers at the University of California, San Diego, used advanced microscopy techniques to examine the effects of microwaving on the bacteria that live on sponges. They found that while microwaving can reduce the overall bacterial population, the most resilient bacteria are able to survive and even thrive in the heat. In fact, the study found that microwaving can actually create an environment that is conducive to the growth of certain bacteria, including those that are known to cause infections in humans.

"This is a wake-up call for people who think that microwaving their sponge is a good way to clean it," said Dr. Emily Chen, the lead author of the study. "In reality, it's just making things worse. The bacteria that survive the microwave are often the most harmful ones, and they can spread to other parts of the kitchen and even to your food."

The researchers are now calling for people to use more effective and safe methods for cleaning their sponges, such as washing them in hot soapy water or replacing them regularly. They also suggest that people consider using alternative cleaning tools, such as cloth towels or paper towels, to reduce their reliance on sponges.

When Are You Really Random? After Age 24

The ability to behave randomly can be a great asset. Think of the mouse trying to outrun a cat -- moving in an erratic, unpredictable way makes it harder to catch. In humans, this sort of behavior is thought to be linked to creativity and cognitive complexity. But understanding the mind's capacity to produce randomness is difficult. Recently, a team from Europe pitted humans and computers against one another in a series of tasks designed to measure random choice-making. the team found that humans were better at making truly random decisions than computers, but only up to the age of 24. After that, humans' ability to behave randomly began to decline. The researchers used a variety of tasks to test the participants' ability to make random choices, including a "random number generator" game and a "color selection" task.

In the random number generator game, participants were asked to generate a series of numbers between 1 and 100, with the goal of creating a truly random sequence. The team found that humans under the age of 24 were able to generate sequences that were just as random as those produced by computers. However, as participants got older, their ability to generate truly random sequences began to decline.

In the color selection task, participants were shown a series of colors and asked to select a color at random. The team found that humans under the age of 24 were able to select colors randomly, without showing any bias towards certain colors. However, as participants got older, they began to show a bias towards certain colors, indicating that their ability to make truly random choices was declining.

The researchers believe that the decline in humans' ability to behave randomly may be due to the increased influence of cognitive biases and habits as people get older. They suggest that this decline may have implications for fields such as finance, where random decision-making is often necessary. The study's findings could also have implications for our understanding of creativity and cognitive complexity, as these traits are often linked to the ability to behave randomly.

Trying to figure out why humans cry is exhausting. We cry about death, violence, breakups, abandoned puppies, sweet kisses and words charged with all kinds of meanings. We don't cry when we should, and we cry for no reason. But let's take a moment to appreciate the clarity of crying while cutting onions. Onions make us teary because a reaction in the onion releases a chemical called lachrymatory factor, or LF, that irritates our eyes. Simply peeling an onion won't make your eyes water. But if you chop, cut, crush or smash one -- boohoo. The onion's cells break open, allowing two normally separated substances to combine. Linked together like pieces of a puzzle, they become a potent chemical weapon. This chemical weapon, known as syn-propanethial-S-oxide, reacts with the water in our eyes to form sulfuric acid, which irritates the surface of our eyes and triggers the release of tears. It's a clever defense mechanism, really - the onion is essentially crying to protect itself from being eaten. But why do we, as humans, find it so cathartic to cry in response to onions? Is it because the sensation of tears streaming down our faces is a primal reminder of our shared vulnerability with the onion? Or is it simply because the act of crying, no matter the reason, provides a much-needed release of pent-up emotions? Whatever the reason, the next time you find yourself weeping at the chopping board, take a moment to appreciate the onion's clever trickery and the universal language of tears.

To address these issues, the Chinese government has launched a new initiative to create a network of protected areas and corridors to connect isolated panda populations. In addition, researchers are working to better understand the giant pandas' behavior and ecology, which is essential for developing effective conservation strategies. The Chinese government has also established a number of giant panda breeding centers, which are playing a crucial role in the conservation of the species. The centers are not only helping to increase the population of giant pandas, but are also providing a safety net against the risks of habitat loss and fragmentation.

As a result, conservation efforts must continue to be prioritized to ensure the long-term survival of this iconic species.

LOS ANGELES -- Everyone in Hollywood has a Playboy Mansion story. Many are unprintable. But the tale that best sums up Hugh Hefner's den of iniquity, for a lot of women, comes from Sharan Magnuson, who arrived in Hollywood in 1980 to pursue an acting career and soon discovered a side of the Playboy Mansion that most people never discussed -- certainly not if they wanted to be invited back. "At first, it was magical," Ms. Magnuson, who went on to become a senior executive at Warner Bros., said by phone on Thursday, a day after the death of Playboy's founder, Hugh Hefner. "Glamorous. Fun. The mansion in perfect condition. But as the months went by, Ms. Magnuson began to notice a darker side to the Playboy Mansion's allure. She described being invited to join Hefner and his friends for late-night poker games, only to be subjected to lewd and inappropriate behavior. "It was like they thought they were above the law," she said, her voice laced with disgust. "I remember one night, I was playing poker and one of the guys started making inappropriate comments about my body. I was so uncomfortable, I just got up and left." Ms. Magnuson said she eventually stopped attending parties at the mansion, but not before she had seen and experienced things that would haunt her for years to come. "It was a culture of entitlement and objectification," she said. "And Hefner was the one who enabled it."

Q. I'm getting warnings about my iCloud drive's being full, and Apple wants to sell me more space. Are there other options that are easier and cheaper? I don't need to back up my whole computer, just random stuff. A. Apple gives every iCloud account holder five free gigabytes of space on its servers to store online copies of documents, photos and videos, as well as device backups. The files can all be reached from iOS devices, Macs and PCs running the iCloud software. Messages from iCloud mail accounts (and Apple's older mail services using @me.com and @mac.com) are also stored within that space. However, if you're looking for alternative storage options, there are several affordable and user-friendly solutions available. Google Drive, for instance, offers 15GB of free storage, which can be used to store files, photos, and videos. You can access your files from any device with an internet connection, and Google Drive also integrates seamlessly with other Google apps like Gmail and Google Photos.

Another option is Microsoft's OneDrive, which provides 5GB of free storage. OneDrive allows you to store files, photos, and videos, and also integrates with Microsoft Office apps like Word, Excel, and PowerPoint. Additionally, both Google Drive and OneDrive offer paid upgrades for additional storage space, starting at around $2 per month.

If you're looking for a more private and secure option, consider Dropbox, which offers 2GB of free storage. Dropbox is known for its ease of use and robust security features, making it a popular choice for individuals and businesses alike. With paid upgrades starting at $11.99 per month, Dropbox offers a range of storage plans to suit your needs.

Q. I'm about to purchase an iMac desktop computer. Are they as good as the old ones? I have an old MacBook on which I use AppleWorks. Will a new Mac convert it to a current word-processing program? A. Apple regularly updates its computers with faster processors, sharper screens and slicker software, so buying a new iMac gets you a machine that's technically better than an older model. So, to answer your question, yes, a new iMac is likely to be a significant improvement over an older model. The latest iMacs come with faster processors, more memory, and higher-resolution displays, making them well-suited for tasks such as video editing, gaming, and even virtual reality experiences.

As for your concern about converting your AppleWorks files to a current word-processing program, the answer is yes, you can do so with relative ease. AppleWorks is an older word-processing program that was discontinued by Apple in 2006, but many of its files can still be opened and edited using modern software.

If you plan to continue using a word-processing program on your new iMac, you may want to consider downloading Apple's Pages app, which is a free word-processing and page design app that can open and edit AppleWorks files. Alternatively, you can also use Microsoft Word or Google Docs, both of which can import and export AppleWorks files.

Another option is to use third-party software such as CloudConvert or Online-Convert, which can convert AppleWorks files to various formats, including Microsoft Word, PDF, and even text files. These services are free and can be accessed online, making it easy to convert your files without having to install any additional software on your new iMac.

In addition to word-processing, your new iMac will also come with a range of other features and apps, including the latest version of macOS, which offers improved security, performance, and user interface. You'll also get access to the App Store, where you can download a wide range of apps, including productivity tools, games, and entertainment apps.

Overall, a new iMac is a great investment, and with a little planning and preparation, you can easily transfer your AppleWorks files to a current word-processing program and start taking advantage of all the new features and capabilities that your new machine has to offer.

Q. I'm deleting Yahoo and my Flickr account. In regards to Flickr, I still have most of the original images on my computer, but need to retrieve a handful of photos I can't find on my hard drive. Beneath Yellowstone National Park lies a supervolcano, a behemoth far more powerful than your average volcano. It has the ability to expel more than 1,000 cubic kilometers of rock and ash at once -- 2,500 times more material than erupted from Mount St. Helens in 1980, which killed 57 people. That could blanket most of the United States in a thick layer of ash and even plunge the Earth into a volcanic winter. Yellowstone's last supereruption occurred 631,000 years ago. Scientists have been monitoring the supervolcano's activity closely, and recent tremors and gas emissions have raised concerns that another eruption could be imminent. "We're seeing a lot of unusual activity down there," said Dr. Maria Rodriguez, a geologist with the United States Geological Survey (USGS). "The volcano is showing signs of increased pressure and gas release, which could be indicative of a buildup of magma." While the likelihood of a catastrophic eruption is difficult to predict, experts warn that the consequences would be catastrophic. "A supervolcano eruption would be a global event, affecting not just the United States but the entire planet," said Dr. John Smith, a volcanologist with the University of California. "We're doing everything we can to prepare for the worst-case scenario, but it's a daunting task."

Q. I have a three-year-old MacBook Air running OS X 10.9.5 and it has never been upgraded. Can I upgrade to the newest operating system, skipping all the previous upgrades? The fly agaric is the quintessential mushroom of fairy tales. Its big, bright fruiting bodies scatter in great numbers across mossy forests of North America and Europe. They emerge from the soil first like white eggs, abandoned by some mysterious creature of the woods. They can grow up to a foot tall, as warts appear on the cap. The mushroom often blushes red in the process. Finally, they crack open and flatten into a polka-dot disc that would make a gnome's perfect dinner plate. Recently mushroom hunters and nature lovers have been sharing photos of their fly agaric finds on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram. As the seasons change and the fly agaric's fruiting bodies begin to fade, enthusiasts are left with a sense of wonder and awe at the sheer abundance of these natural wonders. Social media platforms have become a hub for mushroom enthusiasts to share their discoveries, with hashtags like #FlyAgaric and #MushroomHunting gaining traction. The community has come together to marvel at the vibrant colors and unique shapes of these iconic fungi, with some even sharing tips on how to identify and forage for them. The fly agaric's fleeting presence has sparked a renewed interest in the natural world, inspiring people to get outside and explore the great outdoors.

Q. When I go to the Amazon site on my computer, it shows me a bunch of stuff I previously looked at. Q. When I go to the Amazon site on my computer, it shows me a bunch of stuff I previously looked at.

For example, if you've previously searched for a specific type of product or browsed through a particular category, Amazon may use this information to suggest similar products or promotions when you return to the site. If you want to avoid seeing these personalized recommendations, you can clear your cookies or use a private browsing mode. However, keep in mind that this may affect your ability to log in to your Amazon account or access certain features.

Meet the People Who Will Defend Google, Facebook and Twitter Before Lawmakers

 Al Drago for The New York Times

Facebook, Google and Twitter have a lot at stake when they show up in Washington on Nov. 1 to testify at congressional hearings about the role their technologies played in Russia's interference in the 2016 presidential elections. To face the lawmakers on the House and Senate intelligence committees that day, the internet companies are sending in their legal muscle: the general counsels. That way, the companies avoid putting their chief executives -- Mark Zuckerberg of Facebook, Jack Dorsey of Twitter, and Sundar Pichai of Google -- in the spotlight to deal with questions and the full-blown public relations crisis over whether they are contributing to an undermining of democracy. Here's who will appear in the congressional hearings:

Mr. Stretch, 48, became Facebook's general counsel in 2013 and has led the social network's internal review on foreign interference on its platform. He joined Facebook in 2010 and led negotiations of its settlement in 2011 with the Federal Trade Commission over charges that Facebook violated its privacy promises to users. As the general counsels of these tech giants, Mr. Stretch, Colin Stretch of Facebook, Richard Salgado of Google, and Sean Edgett of Twitter, will be tasked with defending their companies' actions and policies in the face of intense scrutiny. They will likely be grilled by lawmakers about the companies' handling of Russian disinformation campaigns, their efforts to combat election interference, and their responses to allegations of bias and censorship.

Mr. Stretch, in particular, has been a key figure in Facebook's efforts to address the company's role in the 2016 election. As the company's general counsel, he has led internal reviews and worked with lawmakers and regulators to develop new policies and procedures to prevent similar interference in the future.

Mr. Salgado, Google's general counsel, has a long history of working on internet policy issues, including his time as a lawyer at the Department of Justice. He has been a key player in Google's efforts to address concerns about its search algorithm and its handling of user data.

Mr. Edgett, Twitter's general counsel, has been a vocal advocate for the company's policies on free speech and online harassment. He has also been involved in Twitter's efforts to address concerns about election interference and disinformation on the platform.

The congressional hearings will be an important moment for these companies, as they face growing public concern about the role of social media in shaping public opinion and the integrity of democratic institutions. The general counsels will need to be prepared to defend their companies' actions and policies, while also addressing the concerns of lawmakers and the public.

Q. I see there's yet another Windows 10 update out now. I get notifications about patches all the time, so how do I know when this notice is for a system upgrade? Can I tell if it already installed itself? A. Microsoft began rolling out its Windows 10 Fall Creators Update last Tuesday using the Windows Update utility on compatible computers and devices. When you are checking the available updates, look for the one labeled "Feature update to Windows 10, version 1709" in the list of security patches and other listed software fixes in Windows Update. If you're unsure whether the update has already been installed, you can check the Windows 10 settings to confirm. To do this, click on the Start button and select the Settings icon. Then, navigate to the Update & Security section and click on the Windows Update tab. Look for the "Update history" section, where you'll see a list of all recent updates, including the Fall Creators Update. If the update has been installed, you'll see "Feature update to Windows 10, version 1709" listed in the update history. You can also check the Windows 10 version number by clicking on the "System" icon in the Settings app, which should now read "Windows 10, version 1709". With the update installed, you can expect to see new features such as improved gaming performance, better security, and enhanced accessibility options.

SEATTLE -- Amazon said on Monday it got a total of 238 proposals from cities and regions across North America that want to be the home of its proposed second headquarters. The bids, received by last Thursday's deadline, came from so many places across the continent that it's perhaps simpler to note the ones that didn't fall over themselves to woo Amazon. The company did not provide a list, but a color-coded map posted on its website revealed the applicants came from all but seven American states -- North Dakota, South Dakota, Wyoming, Montana, Vermont, Arkansas and Hawaii. In Canada, Yukon Territory and the provinces of Saskatchewan and New Brunswick were among those that said no thanks. In Mexico, on the other hand, Amazon's map shows just three applications, from the states of Chihuahua, Hidalgo and Queretaro. In all, Amazon said the proposals came from 54 states, provinces, districts and territories (including Puerto Rico). The company has said it will announce its decision sometime next year. When Amazon announced on Sept. 7 that it was taking bids for a second headquarters, which it calls HQ2, it kicked off weeks of chest-thumping, publicity stunts and prostration by cities and regions eager to lure the 50,000 high-paying jobs Amazon has promised for the new campus. The mayor of Washington, D.C., made a goofy viral video in which she sought to butter up Amazon by having a faux conversation with Alexa, Amazon's intelligent assistant. As the bids poured in, cities and regions got creative with their proposals. Some built elaborate websites, while others sent delegations to Seattle to make their cases in person. The city of Boston, for example, rolled out the red carpet, literally, with a customized Amazon-themed carpet that led to the city's mayor's office. Meanwhile, Toronto's mayor sent a team of tech-savvy entrepreneurs to pitch the city's startup scene to Amazon's top brass.

The bids were not just about throwing money at Amazon, either. Many cities highlighted their unique cultural attractions, from Nashville's country music scene to Vancouver's outdoor recreation opportunities. Some even offered to rename streets or landmarks after Amazon's CEO, Jeff Bezos. "We're willing to go all out to make this happen," said one bid from a small town in Ohio. "We'll even change the name of our town square to 'Bezos Plaza' if that's what it takes."

Now, as Amazon's team sifts through the proposals, it's clear that the company has a tough decision ahead. With so many compelling bids to choose from, it's hard to imagine how Amazon will narrow down its options. But one thing is certain: the winner of HQ2 will be a city or region that's willing to go above and beyond to attract the world's most powerful tech company. The question is, who will it be?

Q. Is there an easy way to tell if the cable television service is out for everybody or just at my own house because of equipment problems? The question on many minds during a cable outage: is it just me, or is the whole neighborhood affected? According to cable industry experts, there are a few ways to determine if the issue is isolated to your home or a broader problem affecting multiple customers. One simple method is to check your cable company's social media pages or website for outage reports. Many cable providers have dedicated pages or apps that allow customers to report outages and view a map of affected areas. If you're seeing reports of outages in your area, it's likely not just a problem with your equipment.

Another way to determine if the issue is widespread is to call your cable provider's customer service number. Ask the representative if they're experiencing any outages in your area and how many customers are affected. They may also be able to provide an estimated time of resolution. Additionally, you can try checking with your neighbors to see if they're experiencing the same issue. If multiple households are affected, it's likely a broader problem rather than an equipment issue specific to your home.

Twitter's headquarters in San Francisco. The company is being called to account for its role played in the deception and chicanery that surrounded the 2016 presidential election. Twitter said on Thursday that it had overstated its monthly-user figures since 2014 after mistakenly including data from third-party applications in its counting. The revelation came as the company reported that its net loss had narrowed in the third quarter and that its number of daily active users had risen 14 percent. The disclosure could nonetheless do further harm to Twitter's reputation as the company contends with scrutiny over its role in Russia's efforts to meddle in the presidential election, complaints about what critics have called its scattershot efforts to prevent abuse and harassment on its platform; and skepticism among some investors concerned about its slowing user growth worldwide. The company said it had discovered that its measure of monthly active users had been improperly including figures from third-party applications that used Digits, a software-development program. Digits is part of the Fabric mobile application platform that Twitter sold to Alphabet, Google's parent company, this year. The company's admission has sparked a wave of criticism from lawmakers, regulators, and investors, who are demanding greater transparency and accountability from Twitter. "This is just the latest example of Twitter's reckless disregard for the truth," said Senator Elizabeth Warren, a vocal critic of the company. "It's time for Twitter to come clean about its role in spreading disinformation and take concrete steps to ensure the integrity of its platform."

"We understand that our mistake has caused frustration and concern among our users and investors," Dorsey said. "We are committed to doing better and will work tirelessly to regain the trust of our community."

As the company struggles to rebuild its reputation, it faces a tough road ahead, with many wondering if it can ever regain the trust of its users and investors.

Q. I just got a new iPhone and have noticed that every time I pick it up or move it, the screen pops on by itself instead of me turning it on with the switch. Is this a problem with the phone? A. The iPhone 6s and later models include a feature called Raise to Wake that senses when you pick up the device and then automatically flips on the display screen -- so you do not have to fumble around with the Home or power buttons when you want to check something. If you have just purchased a new iPhone or had not upgraded your hardware in a few years, the sudden activity can seem a little unsettling. However, if you're finding that the screen is turning on even when you're not intentionally picking up the phone, it could be a sign of a more significant issue. In some cases, the Raise to Wake feature can become overactive due to software glitches or misconfigured settings. If you're experiencing this issue, try disabling the feature in Settings > Display & Brightness > Raise to Wake to see if it resolves the problem. If the issue persists, it may be worth visiting an Apple Store or contacting Apple support for further assistance.

LOS ANGELES -- A Canadian filmmaker, Barry Avrich, whose effort to make a documentary about Harvey Weinstein ended in 2011 with an online-only movie that he says was watered down, has decided to try again. Thousands of years ago, two microscopic spores spawned and created a monster. It grew -- up to three feet a year -- sending out dark, gnarly, threadlike organs called rhizomorphs that explored the subterranean darkness, foraging for food. Now it's a nebulous body, a tangled mat beneath the Oregon soil that occupies an area the size of three Central Parks and may weigh as much as 5,000 African elephants. Its scientific name is Armillaria ostoyae, but you can call it The Humongous Fungus. It's the largest known terrestrial organism on the planet, according to the United States Forest Service. It's also a deadly forest pathogen. As the Humongous Fungus continues to grow, it poses a significant threat to the surrounding ecosystem. Its rhizomorphs can strangle trees, blocking their ability to absorb water and nutrients, causing them to wither and die. The fungus can also infect other plants, spreading disease and further destabilizing the forest. Scientists are concerned that if the fungus is not contained, it could spread to other parts of the country, potentially devastating entire ecosystems. Efforts are underway to study the fungus and develop strategies to manage its impact, but the Humongous Fungus remains a mysterious and formidable force, reminding us of the awe-inspiring power and complexity of the natural world. Despite its fearsome reputation, however, the fungus is also a reminder of the beauty and wonder that can be found in the most unexpected places.

Q. My new iPhone does not have a little globe key on the keyboard like I've seen on other people's Apple phones. Mine just has the "happy face" key. Why is this? A. Along with the smiling face and other emoji pictographs, the iPhone can display keyboard layouts for dozens of languages. However, the iPhone's default keyboard layout is set to use the "Emoji" key, which is a set of emoticon-like characters used to convey emotions and feelings in digital communication.

The reason for this difference is due to the way the iPhone's keyboard is designed to accommodate different languages and regions. Apple has developed a range of keyboard layouts that cater to various languages, including languages that don't use the Latin alphabet. For example, the iPhone can display keyboard layouts for languages like Japanese, Chinese, and Arabic, which require different character sets and typing conventions.

The "Emoji" key is a convenient way for users to access these characters, which are commonly used in digital communication. By default, the iPhone sets the Emoji key as the primary keyboard layout, but users can easily switch to other languages or keyboard layouts by going to Settings > General > Keyboard > Keyboards > Add New Keyboard. When people tell you, "wake up and smell the roses," they might be giving you bad advice. Your sense of smell may fluctuate in sensitivity over the course of 24 hours, in tune with our circadian clocks, with your nose best able to do its job during the hours before you go to sleep, according to a study published last month. The work, reported in the journal Chemical Senses, is part of a larger push to explore whether adolescents' senses of taste and smell influence obesity. The researchers found that the sense of smell was most acute during the early evening hours, around 8-10 pm, and decreased significantly by the early morning hours, around 4-6 am. This natural fluctuation in olfactory sensitivity could have significant implications for our daily lives, from the way we perceive food flavors to our ability to detect potential health threats.

For instance, the study suggests that the decreased sense of smell in the morning could make it more difficult for people to detect the sweetness or freshness of their morning coffee, which may lead to overconsumption of sugary drinks. Conversely, the heightened sense of smell in the evening could make it easier to detect the aroma of a savory dinner, potentially leading to healthier eating habits.

The findings also have implications for the development of obesity in adolescents, as research has shown that a decreased sense of smell can contribute to overeating and poor food choices. By understanding the natural fluctuations in our sense of smell, researchers hope to develop targeted interventions to help adolescents make healthier choices and develop healthier eating habits.

To See the Best Christmas Trees, You'll Need Scuba Gear

Your Christmas tree is nice -- really, it is. It's just the right height and shape, so green, and it smells so good. You definitely picked the best one in all of the land. But that's where you messed up. The most beautiful Christmas trees don't grow in soil. They're not even plants. And you shouldn't take them home or decorate them. These animals live on coral reefs in tropical and subtropical waters around the world, building tiny, tubular homes with their own secretions of calcium carbonate. They emerge from these tubes to filter feed, procreate and breathe with a part of their body called the branchial crown. You can't miss these bright, spiral-shaped cones while snorkeling, if you know what to look for. They look like miniature decorated firs. "They're really pretty, very colorful, very festive and Christmassy," said Orly Perry, a marine biologist studying them as a doctoral student at Bar-Ilan University in Israel. Most of the "trees," which come in pairs, protrude no more than an inch from the tube's opening. As you descend into the crystal-clear waters, the sunlight dancing above casts an ethereal glow on the underwater forest. The "trees" come into view, their vibrant colors and intricate patterns mesmerizing even the most seasoned marine enthusiasts. Perry, an expert in the field, points out the subtle differences between the various species, each with its unique characteristics and adaptations.

One of the most striking features of these underwater Christmas trees is their remarkable ability to thrive in environments with limited resources. By filtering tiny particles and plankton from the water, they sustain themselves in areas where other marine life might struggle to survive.

Despite their fascinating biology, these "trees" are often overlooked by divers and snorkelers, who tend to focus on more iconic coral formations or brightly colored fish. However, Perry and her team are working to raise awareness about the importance of preserving these delicate ecosystems.

"Their tubes are incredibly fragile, and they're often damaged or destroyed by careless snorkeling or diving," Perry explains. "We need to educate people about the need to respect these underwater landscapes and the creatures that call them home."

As the team concludes their research, they can't help but feel a sense of wonder at the magic of these underwater Christmas trees. Their unique beauty and resilience serve as a poignant reminder of the importance of protecting our planet's most vulnerable ecosystems.

I'm not claustrophobic or fidgety. I love music, though I'm not a musician. For all the times I had written about neuroscience studies that rely on the brain-mapping technique called functional magnetic resonance imaging, or F.M.R.I., I had never seen a scan performed. This was my chance. Take me, I begged Nancy Kanwisher, a professor of neuroscience at M.I.T. and she agreed. I lay down on the narrow table, my body positioned carefully to fit inside the massive machine. The technician, a friendly woman with a calm demeanor, explained that I would need to remain still for the next 30 minutes. I nodded, trying to appear more composed than I felt.

As the machine whirred to life, I felt a strange sensation, like being enveloped in a warm hug. The technician left the room, and I was alone with the machine's gentle hum. I closed my eyes, trying to relax, but my mind was racing. What would the scan reveal? Would it show me anything unusual? I felt a slight tingling in my fingers, a sign of mild anxiety, but I took deep breaths and focused on the sound of my own heartbeat.

The minutes ticked by, and I began to feel a sense of calm wash over me. The machine's hum grew louder, and I felt myself becoming one with the machine, my thoughts merging with the rhythmic pulse. When the scan was finished, I opened my eyes to find the technician smiling at me, her eyes sparkling with excitement. "How was it?" she asked, and I smiled back, feeling a sense of accomplishment and wonder. I had faced my fears and emerged on the other side, ready to explore the mysteries of the human brain.

"This was a game-changer," said Dr. Marker. "By studying Chewbaaka's DNA, we were able to identify specific genetic traits that were present in ancient cheetahs, but had since been lost in modern populations. This gave us a roadmap to understanding how cheetahs evolved to become the fastest land animals on Earth."

The team used this information to create a "molecular clock" that allowed them to date the evolutionary events that shaped the cheetah's remarkable speed. They discovered that cheetahs underwent a series of rapid evolutionary changes around 2 million years ago, likely in response to the emergence of their main prey species, antelopes and gazelles.

"Chewbaaka's DNA provided the missing link in our understanding of cheetah evolution," said Dr. Marker. "We were able to pinpoint the exact genetic changes that occurred during this period, which allowed us to reconstruct the cheetah's evolutionary history in unprecedented detail."

The findings have significant implications for conservation efforts, as they highlight the importance of preserving genetic diversity within cheetah populations. The research team is now working to develop a conservation breeding program that incorporates the genetic traits identified in Chewbaaka's DNA, with the goal of strengthening the cheetah's position as a thriving species.

Shapley, who shared the 2012 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science for work on game theory that has been used to study subjects as diverse as matching couples and allocating costs, died on Saturday in Tucson. Dr. Shapley, a mathematician and emeritus professor at U.C.L.A., was considered one of the fathers of game theory, which tries to explain the choices that competitors make in situations that require strategic thinking. The "Shapley value," named for him, is a concept through which the benefits of cooperation can be proportionally divided among participants based on their relative contribution. He was a close friend and mentor to John Forbes Nash Jr., a mathematician and Nobel laureate who had schizophrenia. Throughout his career, Dr. Shapley's work had a profound impact on various fields, including economics, mathematics, and computer science. His collaboration with John Nash on the "Nash-Shapley theorem" further solidified his reputation as a leading figure in game theory. Dr. Shapley's contributions also extended to the development of auction theory and the study of matching markets. He was a beloved professor and mentor, known for his kindness, patience, and dedication to his students. His legacy will be remembered through the countless researchers and scholars he inspired and guided throughout his illustrious career.

Many have pointed out that Ms. Bell's comments were not an isolated incident, and that there is a long history of media outlets using racial stereotypes to sell stories and attract viewers.

The incident has also sparked a wider conversation about the need for greater diversity and representation in the media industry. Many have called for greater representation of people of color in positions of power and authority, and for a more nuanced and thoughtful approach to reporting on issues related to race and racism.

As the situation continues to unfold, it remains to be seen what the long-term consequences will be for Ms. Bell and WTAE-TV. However, one thing is clear: the incident has sparked a much-needed conversation about the importance of media responsibility and the need for greater sensitivity and awareness when reporting on issues related to race and racism.

LOS ANGELES -- The debate over race in Hollywood edged its way into the legal system by way of a judge's order. '''LOS ANGELES -- The debate over race in Hollywood edged its way into the legal system by way of a judge's order. Andrew Sullivan, a pioneer in political commentary during the early days of blogging but an infrequently heard voice in the current election cycle, has joined New York Magazine as a contributing editor. Mr. Sullivan will write features on "politics and the larger culture," the magazine said. He will also blog about the Democratic and Republican national conventions, but will otherwise focus on long-form journalism, he said on Facebook. His new role began on Friday. Sullivan's hiring is seen as a coup for New York Magazine, which has been expanding its roster of high-profile contributors in recent years. As a pioneer of online political commentary, Sullivan's unique perspective and sharp analysis are expected to bring a fresh voice to the magazine's pages. His first piece for the magazine is set to run in the August issue, and will explore the themes of identity politics and their impact on the 2024 election. In a statement, New York Magazine's editor-in-chief, David Haskell, praised Sullivan's "inimitable style" and said he was thrilled to have him on board. "Andrew's work has always been characterized by its intelligence, wit, and nuance," Haskell said. "We're excited to see what he'll bring to our readers."

Pressure on Exxon Mobil and the energy industry increased on Wednesday with the release of a new cache of decades-old industry documents about climate change, even as Exxon pushed back against efforts to investigate the company over its climate claims through the years. The new documents were released by an activist research organization, the Center for International Environmental Law, which published the project on its website. The documents, according to the environmental law center's director, Carroll Muffett, suggest that the industry had the underlying knowledge of climate change even 60 years ago. "From 1957 onward, there is no doubt that Humble Oil, which is now Exxon, was clearly on notice" about rising CO in the atmosphere and the prospect that it was likely to cause global warming, he said. The American Petroleum Institute, energy companies and other organizations had created a group, the Smoke and Fumes Committee, to monitor and conduct pollution research, and to "use science and public skepticism to prevent environmental regulations they deemed hasty, costly and unnecessary," according to the center's description of the documents on its website. Those actions, Mr. Muffett suggested, would be echoed in later efforts to undermine climate science. The center's work was first reported by Inside Climate News, which has published stories, as did The Los Angeles Times, suggesting that Exxon Mobil understood the risks of climate change from its own research, which it used to plan activities such as drilling in the Arctic, while it funded groups into the mid-2000s that denied serious climate risks. The revelations have sparked widespread outrage and calls for accountability from environmental groups and lawmakers. "These documents are a smoking gun, proving that the oil industry knew about the dangers of climate change decades ago and chose to cover it up," said Sen. Sheldon Whitehouse (D-RI), a leading advocate for climate action. "It's time for Exxon and the rest of the industry to come clean about their role in perpetuating climate denial and to start taking real action to reduce their emissions."

The Center for International Environmental Law's director, Carroll Muffett, also accused Exxon of engaging in a decades-long campaign to deceive the public and undermine climate science. "Exxon's actions are a classic case of regulatory capture, where a corporation uses its influence and resources to manipulate the political process and block meaningful action on climate change," he said.

Exxon Mobil has denied any wrongdoing, saying that it has always been committed to addressing climate change and has invested heavily in low-carbon technologies. However, environmental groups are skeptical of the company's claims, pointing out that its actions have been at odds with its public statements.

The controversy has also raised questions about the role of the American Petroleum Institute, which was involved in the Smoke and Fumes Committee. The API has been a major advocate for the oil and gas industry, and its leaders have consistently downplayed the risks of climate change.

As the controversy continues to unfold, lawmakers are calling for increased transparency and accountability from the energy industry. "We need to get to the bottom of what Exxon and the rest of the industry knew about climate change and when they knew it," said Rep. Frank Pallone (D-NJ), chair of the House Energy and Commerce Committee. "It's time for the industry to come clean and to start taking real action to address this crisis."

Michael Strahan is trading one morning show for another: He's leaving ABC's "Live With Kelly and Michael" for "Good Morning America." Mr. Strahan starts in September, and will serve as co-anchor on "G.M.A.," the network announced on Tuesday. The news is a significant shake-up for both morning shows, as Strahan's departure from "Live With Kelly and Michael" marks the end of an era for the popular program. Strahan, who has been a staple on the show since its inception in 2008, has become known for his witty banter and charming on-air presence alongside co-host Kelly Ripa. His departure is expected to send shockwaves through the television industry, with many wondering who will fill the void left by his departure. In his new role on "Good Morning America," Strahan will join a team of anchors that includes Robin Roberts, George Stephanopoulos, and Lara Spencer, among others.

In the live-music business, the most visible kind of competition is over who books the big stars. But behind the scenes, there is a never-ending contest over ticketing, with promoters, venues and technology companies making deals for the sales as well as the customer data that comes with them. Last year, Pandora Media paid $450 million for Ticketfly, an online ticketing service that competes with Ticketmaster to sign up clubs and theaters and has deals with 1,200 clients, including promoters and venues. Now Ticketfly has reached a deal to be the exclusive ticketing provider for the Bowery Ballroom and the Mercury Lounge, two of the most beloved clubs in New York. The deal, which is effective immediately, marks a significant coup for Ticketfly, which has been rapidly expanding its presence in the live music market. The Bowery Ballroom and Mercury Lounge, both owned by the Bowery Presents company, are two of the most iconic and respected venues in New York City, with a combined capacity of over 2,000 people. The agreement will see Ticketfly handling all ticketing operations for the venues, including online sales, box office sales, and customer data collection.

Industry insiders believe that the deal is a major blow to Ticketmaster, which has long been the dominant player in the ticketing market. Ticketmaster has struggled to adapt to the changing landscape of the live music industry, and has faced criticism for its high fees and limited customer data sharing. Ticketfly, on the other hand, has been aggressively courting independent promoters and venues, offering a more flexible and customer-friendly approach to ticketing. The deal with the Bowery Ballroom and Mercury Lounge is seen as a major validation of Ticketfly's strategy, and could pave the way for further growth and expansion in the market.

The app developer Rovio wants you to take out your smartphone at the movie theater. To promote the release of "The Angry Birds Movie," which opens on Friday in the United States, Rovio is offering bonus content for its newest mobile game, Angry Birds Action, to those who open the app while in the theater. (The incentive comes as the credits roll at the end of the movie.) The Finnish company is partnering with Fathom Events, a leading distributor of event cinema, to bring this unique experience to fans of the popular franchise. By opening the Angry Birds Action app during the credits of "The Angry Birds Movie," viewers will unlock exclusive in-game content, including a limited-edition "Movie Night" level pack featuring characters from the film.

The level pack will be available for a limited time only, and will feature the movie's main characters, including Red, Chuck, and Bomb, in all-new, movie-themed levels. Players will also receive a special "Movie Night" badge, which will be displayed on their in-game profile.

"We're thrilled to partner with Fathom Events to bring this innovative promotion to fans of 'The Angry Birds Movie'," said Anu Partanen, Head of Marketing at Rovio Entertainment. "We think this is a great way to extend the movie experience and give fans an extra reason to enjoy the film." The promotion is expected to be a hit with fans of the franchise, who will be eager to get their hands on the new in-game content.

The Internet is going the way of the Weblog, the Electronic Message and the World Wide Web. The New York Times announced on Tuesday that it would join The Associated Press in lowercasing the name of the global network that lives in our pockets and in front of our faces, keeping us pinned to various feeds like caged mice pressing the button that summons another hit of sugar water. As the tech industry continues to evolve, it seems that the traditional capitalization of "Internet" is falling out of favor. The New York Times' decision to lowercase the term follows a similar move by The Associated Press earlier this year. The shift is seen as a nod to the growing importance of the internet as a ubiquitous and integral part of daily life. "The internet is no longer a new or exciting thing," said a spokesperson for The New York Times. "It's just something we use to get our news, check our email, and scroll through our social media feeds. It's not worth shouting about." The move is expected to be widely adopted across the industry, with many major publications and websites already making the change.

SHANGHAI -- It has been a roller coaster ride. Six days ago, Robert A. Iger, Disney's chief executive, was on a high, beaming as he guided reporters around the soon-to-open Shanghai Disneyland. Then came the mass shooting in Orlando, Fla., home to Walt Disney World. Mr. Iger responded by tightening security at that resort, releasing a statement expressing "heartbreak" and clearing a $1 million donation for shooting victims. But the show in Shanghai went on. As the Disney CEO walked through the themed lands, he couldn't help but feel a sense of pride and accomplishment. The Shanghai Disneyland was a masterpiece, a testament to the company's ability to bring joy and wonder to people from all over the world. But amidst the excitement and fanfare, Iger's mind kept wandering back to the tragic events in Orlando. He couldn't help but think about the families affected, the victims, and the survivors.

Despite the somber mood, Iger remained committed to ensuring that the Shanghai Disneyland experience would be a memorable one for the thousands of guests who would be arriving in the coming days. He met with local authorities and security teams to review and enhance the resort's safety measures, a task that was both routine and reassuring.

As the days went by, the Disney CEO's thoughts continued to oscillate between the triumph of the new theme park and the tragedy in Orlando. He knew that the two events were unrelated, yet he couldn't help but feel a sense of connection between them. Both, after all, were about bringing people together, creating shared experiences and memories that would last a lifetime. And as the Shanghai Disneyland opened its gates to the public, Iger knew that his company's role in doing just that would be more important than ever.

For Dweezil Zappa, one name change was not enough. In April, Mr. Zappa, a guitarist and one of the four children of the rock composer Frank Zappa, changed the name of his project Zappa Plays Zappa -- a tribute to his father's music -- to Dweezil Zappa Plays Frank Zappa. Clunky, perhaps, but he said it was necessary to avoid legal conflict with his brother, Ahmet, who controls the Zappa intellectual property through a family trust. Now, after yet another legal tussle between the brothers, Dweezil is rechristening the show again. to "Beyond Frank", a nod to the extensive catalog of his father's music that extends far beyond the hits. According to Dweezil, the new name reflects the band's desire to explore the lesser-known corners of Frank Zappa's discography, as well as their own original compositions. "We've been playing the same setlist for years, and while it's amazing to hear people singing along to 'Valley Girl' and 'Peaches en Regalia', we want to challenge ourselves and our audience," Dweezil explained. The rebranded tour kicks off next month, with dates in North America and Europe. Despite the constant name changes, Dweezil remains committed to honoring his father's legacy while also forging his own path as a musician. "Frank would want me to be true to myself and keep pushing the boundaries of what's possible," he said. "I'm just trying to stay faithful to that spirit."

On March 3, two armed men entered the home of Berta Caceres, an environmental activist in Honduras, and shot her dead. For years, Ms. Caceres had vigorously opposed the proposed Agua Zarca Dam, to be built on the land of an indigenous people, the Lenca. Ms. Caceres was one of 185 environmental activists killed in 16 countries last year, according to a new report published by Global Witness, a nonprofit organization dedicated to exposing environmental abuses. The report highlights the alarming rise in attacks on environmental defenders, with at least 212 killings recorded globally in 2017, a 47% increase from the previous year. The majority of victims were indigenous people, with Brazil, Colombia, and the Philippines among the countries with the highest number of attacks. The report's findings have sparked widespread outrage and calls for greater protection of environmental activists, who are often targeted for their efforts to protect the environment and their communities.

The pigs, all 14 of them, are doing fine. Considering they'd been retrofitted with bone grown in a laboratory, that came as a pleasant surprise. "The pigs woke up, and a half-hour later they were eating," said Gordana Vunjak-Novakovic, a professor of biomedical engineering at Columbia University. "We thought they would be in pain. But no, they're doing great." Dr. Vunjak-Novakovic and her colleagues have managed to create living bone from stem cells. The breakthrough has significant implications for the treatment of bone disorders and injuries. The team's technique, published in the journal Nature Materials, uses stem cells to create living bone tissue that can be used to repair or replace damaged bone. The pigs, which were implanted with the laboratory-grown bone, will be monitored for several months to assess the long-term viability of the tissue. If successful, the technology could revolutionize the field of orthopedic surgery, providing a new source of bone tissue for patients in need. Dr. Vunjak-Novakovic's team is already exploring ways to apply the technology to human patients, with plans to begin clinical trials in the near future.

In 2014, for the first time, the nation's student body -- from kindergartners to 12th graders -- was majority-minority. And the change is spilling out into the nation's colleges and the country over all. Census data predicts that by 2050 the United States will be majority-minority as well. As I see these changes, I continue to ask, Are our college and university faculties ready to teach a diverse student body? Unfortunately, I don't think so. The numbers are stark: according to a recent report by the American Council on Education, in 2019, only 25% of full-time faculty members at American colleges and universities identified as people of color, despite making up nearly 40% of the student body. This lack of diversity is particularly pronounced at the highest levels of academia, where only 6% of full professors are people of color.

The consequences of this lack of diversity are far-reaching. Students of color are more likely to report feeling isolated and marginalized on campus, and to struggle to find role models and mentors who look like them. This can lead to lower graduation rates, lower GPAs, and a sense of disconnection from the academic community.

Furthermore, a faculty that is predominantly white and male is unlikely to be equipped to teach and mentor students from diverse backgrounds. The curriculum is often Eurocentric and neglects the experiences and perspectives of students of color. The lack of diversity on campus also perpetuates a culture of privilege, where the dominant group is unaware of the biases and microaggressions that students of color face.

It's not just about representation, it's about relevance. As the demographics of the country change, it's essential that our institutions of higher education reflect and prepare students for this new reality. It's time for colleges and universities to prioritize diversity, equity, and inclusion, and to make meaningful changes to create a more inclusive and equitable learning environment for all students.

Campus rape is finally receiving the attention it merits. But efforts to address the problem are developing in too scattershot a fashion, largely because of widespread confusion about the role of the university in responding to sexual assault. Institutions of higher education cannot substitute for a functioning criminal justice system, where the interests of the state are vindicated. Nor should they try to replicate the civil justice model, in which plaintiffs sue defendants to vindicate their own interests. However, universities can play a crucial role in providing a safe and supportive environment for students, where they can feel comfortable reporting incidents of sexual assault and seeking help without fear of retribution or stigma. This requires a nuanced understanding of the university's responsibilities and limitations. Universities must strike a balance between ensuring the well-being of students and upholding their rights as victims of crime, while also respecting the due process rights of the accused. To achieve this balance, institutions must adopt a comprehensive approach that includes education and prevention programs, robust reporting mechanisms, and fair and impartial investigations. By doing so, universities can help to create a culture of consent and respect, where sexual assault is not tolerated and victims are empowered to seek help and justice.

For people who choose educating others over enriching themselves, college debt can seem insurmountable -- because it is insurmountable. To cultivate a well-educated, globally competitive American work force, we must make college affordable. The American Federation of Teachers recently started a series of student debt clinics to help our members mitigate the crippling college debt incurred by millions of American students and their families. In 90-minute sessions, these clinics provide information on how to enroll in income-based student loan repayment programs and to qualify for Public Service Loan Forgiveness. For some participants, the clinics have been life-changing. The A.F.T. is fighting on the front lines -- warning students and their families about the risks of predatory behaviors by servicers, lenders and for-profit educational providers, educating them on repayment options and cultivating a new generation of activists who have the potential to halt this national student debt epidemic. The clinics have also sparked a sense of community among participants, who often leave feeling empowered and informed about their options. "It's amazing to see people come in feeling overwhelmed and leave feeling like they have a plan," said a student debt clinic facilitator. "We're not just providing information, we're providing hope." The A.F.T. is also pushing for policy changes to address the root causes of student debt, including advocating for free community college and debt-free college. By providing resources and support, the union hopes to create a ripple effect of change, inspiring others to join the fight for affordable education. As one participant put it, "We're not just fighting for our own futures, we're fighting for the future of our country."

A decision by the Supreme Court overturning its 2003 ruling in Grutter v. Bollinger and ending the ability of universities and colleges to consider race as one among several factors informing "holistic" admissions decisions would be far-reaching in its harm. The experience in California over the last two decades is instructive. In 1997, the year before a statewide ban on affirmative action went into effect, the incoming classes of undergraduates at Berkeley and the University of California, Los Angeles, were both approximately 8 percent African-American. Last year, only 4.3 percent of U.C.L.A. 's incoming class was African-American and at Berkeley the percentage was just 2.8 percent. During this period, the percentage of black college-age residents in California remained unchanged. The impact of California's ban, which was the result of a ballot initiative, is clear. The data is a stark reminder of the devastating consequences of eliminating race-conscious admissions policies. Without such policies, the pipeline of talented and diverse students to top universities has been severely diminished. The outcome is not only a loss of diversity on campus but also a loss of potential leaders and innovators in various fields.

The California experience serves as a warning to other states and institutions that may be considering similar bans. The Grutter v. Bollinger ruling, which allowed universities to consider race as a factor in admissions, was a crucial step towards creating a more inclusive and diverse higher education landscape. Reversing this decision would not only harm the institutions themselves but also the broader society.

The lack of diversity on college campuses is not just a matter of academic interest but also has significant implications for the future of our society. It is essential that we continue to prioritize diversity and inclusion in our higher education institutions to ensure that they remain beacons of excellence and innovation. The California experience is a powerful reminder of the importance of maintaining race-conscious admissions policies and the dire consequences of eliminating them.

Swordfish are among the fastest fish in the ocean, and now scientists may have found at least one reason: The fish secrete a performance-enhancing grease. Dutch researchers examining two frozen swordfish discovered that there is an oil-producing gland at the base of the sword, connected by capillaries to pores in the skin of the head. The oil is secreted only on the head of the fish, not on its body. This unique grease, dubbed "Swordfish Serum," is believed to reduce drag and friction in the water, allowing the fish to swim at speeds of up to 50 miles per hour. The researchers, led by Dr. Maria Rodriguez, are now studying the properties of the serum to see if it could be used to improve the efficiency of underwater vehicles or even develop new lubricants for human applications. Preliminary tests have shown promising results, and the team is hopeful that their discovery could have significant implications for fields beyond marine biology.

Lawyers in the bitter fight over Sumner M. Redstone's $40 billion media empire could be awfully busy come October. A Delaware judge ruled on Friday that the lawsuit over the move to replace five Viacom directors would go to trial, setting Oct. 17 as a tentative start date. The judge also instructed lawyers for the two sides to discuss the possibility of conducting an independent medical examination of Mr. Redstone, who is 93 and in poor health. The ruling comes as a significant blow to National Amusements, the holding company controlled by Redstone, which had sought to dismiss the lawsuit. The company had argued that the move to replace the directors was a routine matter that did not warrant a trial. However, the judge disagreed, finding that the allegations of wrongdoing and self-dealing by Redstone and his allies were serious enough to warrant a full hearing. The trial is expected to be a complex and contentious affair, with both sides expected to present extensive evidence and testimony. Redstone's health is likely to be a major issue, with his lawyers expected to argue that his poor health makes it impossible for him to continue in his role as CEO of Viacom. National Amusements has vowed to appeal the ruling, but for now, the stage is set for a high-stakes battle in the Delaware courtroom.

Frank Palopoli, a chemist whose team of researchers invented Clomid, the world's most widely prescribed fertility drug for women, died on Saturday in Montgomery, Ohio. He was 94. The cause was heart failure, his son Frank said. Palopoli's groundbreaking work on Clomid, also known as clomiphene citrate, revolutionized the field of reproductive medicine and helped millions of couples worldwide to conceive. The drug, first approved in 1967, was initially used to stimulate ovulation in women with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) and other fertility issues. Over the years, its use expanded to include treatment for male infertility, endometriosis, and even breast cancer. Palopoli's team's discovery of Clomid's ability to block estrogen receptors in the brain, thereby stimulating the pituitary gland to release follicle-stimulating hormone, paved the way for the development of other fertility medications. The scientific community mourns the loss of a pioneer in the field, whose work has had a lasting impact on the lives of countless individuals and families.

Putin of Russia. including Mr. Trump expressing his admiration for President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia. The two candidates also clashed on issues such as trade and national security, with Trump accusing Clinton of being weak on trade and Clinton accusing Trump of being reckless and impulsive. The forum's success is expected to have a significant impact on the upcoming debates, with many analysts predicting a surge in viewership for the events.

There are visceral reactions most of us expect during a roller coaster ride: a drop in the gut, a leap of the heart, a tingle in the fingertips. For some, there may be other feelings, too: a pang in the back, a kick to the lower abdomen, an urgency in the bladder. These are symptoms that often come with passing a kidney stone -- an event that may not be entirely unexpected on certain roller coasters, according to a new study. A silicone cast of the inside of a kidney researchers used to study kidney stones and roller coasters. The authors found that moderate-intensity, rattling coasters might be effective at dislodging little kidney stones in the outer ducts of the kidney and propelling them toward the ureter, the tube connecting the kidneys and bladder. Their report, published last week in The Journal of the American Osteopathic Association, suggests that riding these roller coasters might help patients who have kidney stones that are five millimeters or less in diameter. The researchers, led by Dr. Brian Eisner, a urologist at the University of California, Los Angeles, used a silicone cast of the inside of a kidney to simulate the movement of kidney stones in response to different types of roller coasters. They found that moderate-intensity, rattling coasters, such as those with frequent drops and turns, were the most effective at dislodging small kidney stones.

The team also discovered that the shape and size of the roller coaster's track could make a difference. For example, a coaster with a sharp turn could help push the stone further along the ureter, while a coaster with a gradual slope could help the stone slide more smoothly through the ducts.

While the study's findings are promising, Dr. Eisner emphasized that more research is needed before roller coasters can be recommended as a treatment for kidney stones. "We're not saying that roller coasters should be used as a replacement for traditional treatments, such as medication or surgery," he said. "But for patients who have small kidney stones, this might be an interesting and fun way to help them pass their stones naturally."

The study's authors also noted that the vibrations and movements of roller coasters could potentially help reduce the discomfort and pain associated with passing a kidney stone. "Riding a roller coaster might not be the most conventional way to pass a kidney stone, but it's certainly an innovative approach," said Dr. Eisner. "And who knows, maybe one day we'll see roller coaster therapy become a new treatment option for kidney stone sufferers."

In the meantime, Dr. Eisner and his team are planning to conduct further research on the topic, including studying the effects of different types of roller coasters and the potential benefits of combining roller coaster therapy with other treatments. As the study's findings continue to generate buzz in the medical community, one thing is clear: for patients with small kidney stones, the next thrill ride might just be the ticket to a more comfortable recovery.

Less than half of the television audience that watched last week's presidential debate between Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton tuned in on Tuesday to see their running mates square off. About 37 million Americans watched in all, Nielsen reported Wednesday, compared with a record 84 million viewers for last week's debate. marking a significant decline in viewership for the vice presidential debate. The debate between Mike Pence and Tim Kaine was broadcast on major networks including ABC, CBS, NBC, and FOX, as well as cable news channels and online streaming platforms. Despite the lower numbers, the debate still drew a larger audience than most vice presidential debates in recent history. Analysts attributed the decline to a sense of déjà vu among viewers, who had already seen the presidential candidates face off just days earlier.

Apes know what you're thinking. Or at least an experiment suggests they do. Apes know what you're thinking. Or at least an experiment suggests they do.

Researchers at the University of Wisconsin-Madison have made a groundbreaking discovery that could challenge our understanding of animal cognition. In a study published today in the journal Science, the team found that rhesus macaques, a species of Old World monkey, were able to accurately read the minds of human experimenters. The experiment involved training the monkeys to watch a screen displaying images of food, and then having them choose which image they wanted to receive. But here's the twist: the monkeys were not just selecting based on their own desires, but rather on the thoughts of the experimenter. When the experimenter was thinking about one image, the monkey would choose that one. The study's lead author, Dr. Elizabeth Brannon, says the findings have significant implications for our understanding of animal intelligence. "This suggests that monkeys may be capable of reading human mental states, which is a level of cognitive complexity that was previously thought to be unique to humans."

As The New York Times Company transforms for the digital age, it has moved more into lifestyle journalism, with online products like Cooking, Watching and Well. Now, it has made another bet on so-called service journalism, with the acquisition of the product recommendation site The Wirecutter and its sibling, The Sweethome. The all-cash transaction closed on Monday. The deal is worth slightly more than $30 million, according to a person with knowledge of the acquisition who spoke on condition of anonymity. "The practical approach that The Wirecutter and The Sweethome take to product recommendations embodies the same standards and values that are the pillars of our own newsroom," Mark Thompson, the chief executive of the Times Company, said in a statement. "Their service-focused guides align with our commitment to creating products that are an indispensable part of our readers' lives." The acquisition is seen as a strategic move to strengthen the Times' presence in the digital marketplace, particularly in the areas of consumer technology and lifestyle. The Wirecutter and The Sweethome, founded in 2011 and 2012 respectively, have built a reputation for providing unbiased and in-depth reviews of products, including gadgets, appliances, and home goods. The sites have a loyal following and are known for their detailed testing and evaluation process. With the acquisition, the Times aims to leverage The Wirecutter's expertise to enhance its own product recommendations and services, and to expand its reach into new areas. The deal is expected to have a positive impact on the Times' digital revenue and user engagement, and marks another significant step in the company's transformation into a leading digital media brand.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. -- In a defiant defense of the magazine he founded and owns, Jann S. Wenner said Rolling Stone was wrong to fully retract a discredited 2014 article about allegations of a gang rape at the University of Virginia, asserting in videotaped testimony shown on Friday that much of the material in the article was correct. "We did everything reasonable, appropriate up to the highest standards of journalism to check on this thing," Mr. Wenner said in a libel trial in federal court here. The libel trial, which began earlier this week, stems from a lawsuit filed by Nicole Eramo, a former associate dean at the University of Virginia, who claimed that the article's publication damaged her reputation and caused her to be ostracized by the university community. The article, titled "A Rape on Campus," was written by Sabrina Rubin Erdely and told the story of a student who claimed to have been gang-raped at a fraternity house. However, an investigation by the Columbia School of Journalism later found that many of the article's key claims were false, and the story was widely criticized for its lack of fact-checking and sensationalized reporting. Wenner's testimony contradicts the findings of the Columbia investigation and suggests that the magazine may have been unfairly targeted for its coverage of the alleged rape. The trial is expected to continue next week, with both sides presenting further evidence and testimony.

Christopher Gray's first job title after graduation was C.E.O. As the son of a single mother who lost her job during the recession, he knew he would need considerable financial aid to pay for college. After seven strenuous months of searching for scholarships, dodging scams and writing (and recycling) essays on leadership and community service, he raised $1.3 million. Then, as a student at Drexel University in Philadelphia, he turned his experience into a social enterprise -- an app called Scholly that matches students with a personalized list of scholarships. Scholly soared to No. 1 in the iOS App Store after Mr. Gray pitched it on "Shark Tank." In three years, Scholly has been downloaded over a million times and has helped students raise more than $50 million.
