"We Shall Overcome" may be headed for a trial. The song, famous as a civil rights anthem -- and revived in recent years for numerous vigils across the country in response to gun violence -- is the subject of a lawsuit that challenges the validity of the song's copyright. Along with the recent suits involving "Happy Birthday to You" and Woody Guthrie's "This Land Is Your Land," the case has focused attention on one of the central questions in copyright: finding a balance between protecting intellectual property on behalf of private owners, and giving the public access to famous songs whose origins may be murky. For "We Shall Overcome" and "This Land," the issue is also freighted with politics at a time when the songs are being embraced by protesters and activists on multiple sides of major issues. The lawsuit, filed by a musicologist who claims to have uncovered new evidence about the song's origins, argues that the copyright holder, the We Shall Overcome Foundation, does not have the right to control the song's use. The foundation, which was established by Pete Seeger and other folk musicians, has long maintained that the song is in the public domain, but the lawsuit claims that Seeger and other songwriters may have had a more significant role in its creation than previously thought. The outcome of the case could have significant implications for the use of popular songs in protests and political movements, and could also shed new light on the complex and often murky history of American folk music.

The State of New Jersey says you can't eat the fish or shellfish from the Lower Passaic River and Newark Bay. That's because they're living in the Diamond Alkali Superfund Site, where toxic leftovers from the manufacture of chemicals like DDT and the infamous Agent Orange oozed into surrounding waterways to be taken up by the animals that inhabited them. It's an evolutionary miracle some of these animals are even alive. No, seriously. No, seriously. The contamination is so severe that the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has designated the area as one of the most polluted sites in the country. The Diamond Alkali Superfund Site, located in Newark and Bayonne, has been the subject of cleanup efforts for decades, but the EPA has warned that it will take years, if not decades, to fully restore the environment.

The warning from the State of New Jersey is a precautionary measure to protect public health. The fish and shellfish in the Lower Passaic River and Newark Bay have been found to contain high levels of toxic chemicals, including dioxins and furans, which have been linked to cancer, reproductive problems, and other health issues.

Despite the warnings, some residents are concerned about the economic impact of the fish and shellfish ban. The area is known for its commercial fishing industry, and the ban has already affected local businesses. "This is a devastating blow to our community," said Maria Rodriguez, owner of a local seafood market. "We understand the need for caution, but we need to find a way to balance public health with economic sustainability."

The EPA and state officials are working together to develop a plan to restore the environment and reopen the waterways to fishing and shellfishing. In the meantime, residents are being advised to avoid contact with the contaminated water and to follow proper food safety guidelines when consuming seafood from other areas. As the cleanup efforts continue, the community remains hopeful that one day they will be able to enjoy the fruits of their labor, literally.

With the winter cold bearing down, it's a nice time to imagine experiencing this phenomenon. To dive with the sardines in the Philippines, all you have to do is book a trip with one of many local dive shops. A boat will take you just a few yards from the beach. You dive in, swim down a few feet and look up at the fish clouds. For the best view, head out early. But if you can't make it soon, don't worry: They are there every day, unlike the more famous sardines that migrate by the billions to the coastal waters of South Africa only in the summer. The sardines' schooling behavior is sometimes called a bait ball, and it confuses most predators and very likely helps the sardines to survive. As you swim through the swirling mass of sardines, you can't help but feel a sense of awe at the sheer scale of the phenomenon. The water is a kaleidoscope of silver and gray, with the sardines darting and weaving around each other in a mesmerizing display of synchronized movement. The sound of their scales rubbing against each other creates a soothing background hum, like the gentle purring of a giant engine.

As you observe the sardines, you start to notice the intricate patterns and shapes that emerge from their collective behavior. Schools of fish break off from the main group, only to rejoin the larger mass moments later. The sardines seem to be communicating with each other, their movements almost choreographed to perfection.

Despite the eerie silence of the underwater world, you can't help but feel a sense of excitement and wonder at the prospect of witnessing this natural spectacle. It's a reminder of the incredible diversity and complexity of marine life, and the many secrets that still lie beneath the surface of our oceans.

As you swim deeper, you start to notice the other creatures that call this place home. Small fish dart in and out of the sardine cloud, snatching up stray fish that wander too far from the safety of the school. Larger predators lurk in the shadows, waiting for the perfect moment to strike. But even they seem hesitant to attack, as if they too are awed by the sheer scale and majesty of the sardine spectacle.

As you finally emerge from the water, gasping for air and grinning from ear to ear, you can't help but feel grateful for the experience. It's a reminder that even in the midst of winter's chill, there is still beauty and wonder to be found in the natural world. And who knows? Maybe next time, you'll be back to dive with the sardines once again, reliving the magic of this incredible underwater phenomenon.

Leadership changes in Hollywood almost always come when profits are scarce, though that is not the case at Warner, which is set to have one of its most profitable years ever, according to financial filings. Warner, which last month released "Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them" to blockbuster results, is perennially Hollywood's No. 1 or No. 2 studio based on domestic ticket sales. So far this year, Warner, with 18 percent market share, is running second to Walt Disney Studios, which has about 24 percent of the market, according to the database Box Office Mojo. But the operation formerly run by Mr. Silverman, an affable executive with a tendency to give directors a wide berth, has also delivered films of irregular quality -- something that did not matter so much in the past, when consumers had fewer entertainment options, but a shortcoming that is now considered unacceptable, especially as studios like Warner increasingly rely on sequels. However, the changing landscape of the entertainment industry has led to a growing demand for more innovative and diverse storytelling. With the rise of streaming services and the proliferation of online content, audiences are no longer satisfied with simply consuming the same old formulas and franchises. They crave fresh perspectives, complex characters, and unique narratives.

As a result, Warner's leadership change is seen as a necessary step towards adapting to this new reality. The studio is looking to shake off its reputation for churning out formulaic blockbusters and instead focus on producing more critically acclaimed and commercially successful films that resonate with a wider range of viewers.

Sources close to the studio have revealed that the new leadership team is already working on a slate of projects that aim to push the boundaries of storytelling and take risks on new and innovative ideas. This includes a slate of original films and TV shows that will be produced in-house, as well as a renewed focus on acquiring and distributing independent films and international productions.

While the exact details of the studio's plans remain under wraps, insiders say that the new leadership is committed to making Warner a more agile and responsive studio that is better equipped to navigate the ever-changing landscape of the entertainment industry. With its rich history and reputation for producing some of the most iconic films of all time, Warner is well-positioned to make a comeback as a major player in Hollywood.

Dr. Tarduno and his team published their findings on Monday in the journal Scientific Reports. Scientists aren't sure why Earth was stifling hot for several million years during the Cretaceous period, but according to Dr. Tarduno, the prevailing hypothesis is that the atmosphere was filled with heat-trapping carbon dioxide, most likely the result of extraordinary volcanic activity. The resulting greenhouse effect would have transformed the polar ecosystem into a place where Tingmiatornis arctica and its prey could thrive. The warming period, known as the Turonian age, is estimated to have lasted from 93.9 million to 89.8 million years ago. At its coldest, it is estimated that the Arctic got around 57 degrees Fahrenheit. In his time exploring the snowcapped brown hills and thick glaciers of Nunavut, in the Canadian Arctic, Dr. Tarduno has come across two wing bones belonging to this species of bird. The discovery of the wing bones is significant because it provides direct evidence of the presence of Tingmiatornis arctica in the Arctic during the Turonian age. According to Dr. Tarduno, the bones are remarkably well-preserved, with intricate details still intact. "It's like finding a time capsule," he exclaimed. "These bones tell us that this species was adapted to the warm conditions of the Arctic during that period. It's a remarkable example of how life can thrive in unexpected environments." The findings have implications for our understanding of the evolution of life on Earth, particularly in the context of climate change. Dr. Tarduno's team is now working to analyze the bones further, hoping to uncover more secrets about this ancient ecosystem.

The dragons, dire wolves, White Walkers and power-hungry political factions in HBO's fantasy epic "Game of Thrones" will invade movie theaters later this month -- on the big, big screen. It also shows the extent to which media companies are trying to turn their blockbuster hits into mega events, as drawing mass audiences becomes increasingly rare. The move to Imax is seen as a major coup for HBO, which has been pushing the boundaries of what is possible with television programming. The network has already seen success with its "Game of Thrones" Live Concert Experience, which toured the world last year. The Imax screenings are just the latest example of the show's massive global appeal, and are likely to attract a wide range of fans from casual viewers to die-hard enthusiasts.

The advertising lesson from Super Bowl XLIX: Ads with puppies continue to score with viewers while spots featuring a dead child are seen as a major fumble. By several counts, Budweiser led the pack of game day advertisers with a spot that depicted its iconic Clydesdale horses rescuing a lost puppy and taking it home. The ad attracted more than 4.2 million online views by midday Monday and captured 12 percent of online activity about the Super Bowl spots, according to a measurement firm, iSpot.tv. Budweiser, which also ran an ad celebrating its brewing process, was mentioned more than 234,000 times on social media during the game, with nearly half of the comments expressing a positive sentiment and many more neutral, according to Amobee, which tracks digital response to brands. In stark contrast, another much-talked-about spot was Nationwide's morbid commercial that showed a young boy saying that he will never learn to ride a bike, get "cooties," learn to fly, travel the world or marry because he died from a preventable accident. While the brand was trying to highlight its "Make Safe Happen" program about increasing safety at home, the spot angered viewers. Nationwide was mentioned more than 238,000 times on social media, with 64 percent of those comments negative, according to Amobee. (Nationwide ran another spot featuring the actress Mindy Kaling that seemed to resonate more positively.) "The sole purpose of this message was to start a conversation, not sell insurance," Nationwide said in a statement. Despite the backlash, Nationwide defended its decision to run the ad, stating that it was meant to spark a conversation about the importance of home safety. However, many viewers took to social media to express their disgust and disappointment with the commercial, with some even calling for a boycott of the insurance company.

The controversy surrounding Nationwide's ad highlighted the delicate balance between creativity and sensitivity in advertising. While some brands, like Budweiser, found success with lighthearted and uplifting spots, others, like Nationwide, risked alienating their audience with more serious and somber messages.

Industry experts weighed in on the matter, with some arguing that the ad was misguided and others defending its intention to raise awareness about a critical issue. "The ad was well-intentioned, but it was executed poorly," said one marketing expert. "It's a tough topic to tackle, but Nationwide could have done it in a more tasteful and respectful way."

In the end, the Super Bowl XLIX advertising landscape served as a reminder that, while creative freedom is important, brands must also consider the emotional impact of their messaging on their audience. As the advertising world continues to evolve, it will be interesting to see how brands balance creativity with sensitivity in the years to come.

Richard Meryman, a former Life magazine writer and editor who conducted the last interview with Marilyn Monroe, wrote an intimate portrait of the reclusive artist Andrew Wyeth, collaborated with Joan Rivers on a memoir about her quest for stardom and recounted a wrenching emotional journey after his first wife became fatally ill, died on Feb. 5 in Manhattan. He was 88. The cause was pneumonia, his wife, Elizabeth, said. Mr. Meryman credited an adventure story he shared at his first job interview with Life as the reason he was hired as a novice writer in 1949. Meryman's early days at Life magazine were marked by his fearless approach to storytelling, which often took him to the most unlikely of places. He would often venture into the heart of rural America, chronicling the lives of ordinary people with extraordinary stories. His reporting style was described by colleagues as "warm and empathetic," allowing him to build trust with his subjects and elicit intimate details that few others could.

As his career progressed, Meryman's portfolio expanded to include profiles of Hollywood's elite, including the aforementioned interview with Marilyn Monroe. His writing was characterized by its nuance and sensitivity, capturing the complexities of his subjects in a way that was both captivating and relatable. Despite his many accomplishments, Meryman remained humble and kind, earning the respect and admiration of his peers. His passing leaves a void in the world of journalism, but his legacy will live on through the countless lives he touched with his words.

E! is paying up to keep up with the Kardashians. The NBCUniversal cable network has reached a deal with the Kardashian family to extend the run of its reality show, "Keeping Up With the Kardashians," on the network for three more years, according to a person briefed on the deal. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. The New York Post reported Thursday that the deal would cover four years and be worth more than $100 million. The new deal will reportedly keep the show on the air until 2023, with the family receiving a significant increase in their annual salary. The show, which premiered in 2007, has been a ratings powerhouse for E!, with its most recent season averaging over 2 million viewers per episode. The Kardashian family's popularity has only grown since the show's debut, with each member pursuing successful careers in entertainment, fashion, and entrepreneurship. The deal is a major coup for E!, which has struggled to find a replacement for the show's massive audience. The network is expected to announce the deal publicly in the coming days.

Mr. Pizzolo said he learned of an eager, untapped audience for comics on YouTube when he posted "Godkiller," his series about siblings in a post-apocalyptic world. "It got 100,000 views without my telling anyone about it," he said, adding that it gained tens of thousands more viewers after being released on Netflix, Hulu and PlayStation. "We all love the core comic book readership, but we have to make sure new people are discovering it." The five inaugural series on the YouTube channel will be a mix of comics published by Black Mask, including "Liberator," about vigilante animal welfare activists, and those from other independent publishers, like Image's "Five Ghosts," which focuses on an adventurer possessed by five characters from literature. The channel will include links for buying the books and related merchandise. Black Mask Studios was founded in 2012 by Mr. Pizzolo, a filmmaker; Steve Niles, a writer of horror novels and comics; and Brett Gurewitz, a musician and founder of Epitaph Records. The impetus was "Occupy Comics," a comic book project to raise money to support the Occupy Wall Street movement. "It put a light on how difficult it was to get out comics with a message in them," Mr. Pizzolo said. Soon, Black Mask will have a much broader platform from which to deliver its message. The YouTube channel, titled "Black Mask Comics," is designed to showcase the studio's diverse range of titles and attract a new audience of comic book fans. "We're not just about the art, we're about the story," said Mr. Pizzolo. "We're about exploring complex themes and issues, and we believe that comics are the perfect medium to do that." The channel will feature a mix of short-form and long-form content, including animated series, live-action videos, and even video game tie-ins.

In addition to promoting its own titles, Black Mask Comics will also serve as a platform for other independent publishers to showcase their work. "We're not just about pushing our own titles," said Mr. Pizzolo. "We want to create a community of creators who can come together and share their work with a wider audience." The channel is expected to launch in the coming months, with new content being added regularly.

Black Mask Comics is just the latest move by the studio to expand its reach and influence. In addition to its publishing arm, Black Mask also produces film and television projects, and has a number of titles in development with major studios. The studio's founders are all passionate about using their platform to tell stories that matter, and they believe that comics are the perfect medium to do just that. "Comics have the power to inspire, to educate, and to challenge," said Mr. Pizzolo. "And we're excited to be a part of that."

It's official: Jay Z is buying an online streaming company that competes with Spotify and Apple. On Friday, the investment vehicle that the rap star used to make a $56 million bid for the Swedish technology company Aspiro announced that it had acquired enough of Aspiro's shares to take over the company. Aspiro, which is publicly traded in Sweden, operates subscription streaming services under the brands WiMP and Tidal, which entered the United States market last fall. Jay Z, whose real name is Shawn Carter, made his offer for Aspiro in late January through an entity he controls, Project Panther Bidco. Aspiro shareholders had until Wednesday to consider the offer, which needed 90 percent approval for Project Panther to take it over. "All conditions for completion of the offer have been fulfilled, and the offer is therefore declared unconditional,'' Project Panther said in a statement on Friday. The acquisition of Aspiro by Project Panther Bidco, controlled by Jay Z, is expected to bring significant changes to the music streaming industry. Tidal, which has struggled to gain traction against Spotify and Apple Music, may benefit from Jay Z's involvement and resources. Industry analysts predict that Tidal will now have a stronger competitive edge, thanks to Jay Z's expertise in the music industry and his ability to attract new talent and subscribers. The acquisition is also expected to lead to a renewed focus on artist-friendly policies and better compensation for musicians. Jay Z has been a vocal advocate for fair compensation for artists and has used his platform to raise awareness about the issue. With his new ownership stake in Aspiro, he is now poised to make a significant impact on the music streaming landscape.

Almost half a century after Dustin Hoffman was taken aside in "The Graduate" and given the famous "one word" line about the future, it may be time to update the script again. And metamaterials appear to have the same potential to transform entire industries. Over the past 15 years or so, scientists have learned how to construct materials that bend light waves, as well as radar, radio, sound and even seismic waves, in ways that do not naturally occur. First theorized in 1967 by the Russian physicist Victor Veselago and invented in 1999 by a group led by the physicist David R. Smith, the new design approach was first seen as a curiosity that hinted at science fiction applications like invisibility cloaks. But as the years went by, researchers began to realize the profound implications of metamaterials. They could be used to create new types of sensors, antennas, and even medical devices. For example, metamaterials have been shown to enhance MRI imaging capabilities, allowing for higher resolution and more accurate diagnoses. The technology has also been applied to the development of advanced radar systems, which could potentially revolutionize fields such as air traffic control and weather forecasting. With their ability to manipulate waves in unprecedented ways, metamaterials are poised to transform a wide range of industries, from healthcare to transportation to national security. As one researcher noted, "Metamaterials are like a Swiss Army knife - they can be used in a multitude of ways to solve complex problems."

HarperCollins released the cover for Harper Lee's highly anticipated new novel, "Go Set a Watchman," on Wednesday, and hinted at new details about the book. The cover -- a classic and melancholy image of a dark tree with sparse yellow leaves against a dusky blue sky, with a train approaching from the distance -- is emblematic of the opening of the book, which begins with a grown-up Scout's train ride from New York to her childhood home of Maycomb, Ala. The novel, which comes out on July 14 with a huge first printing of two million copies, has been selling briskly through preorders from Amazon and Barnes & Noble since it was announced in early February. It's also been the source of some controversy among literary scholars and friends and acquaintances of the intensely private Ms. Lee; some question why she agreed to publish a novel she had set aside in the mid 1950s, while others say she has enthusiastically endorsed the book's release. Despite the controversy, HarperCollins is confident that "Go Set a Watchman" will be a major success. The book's editor, Lynn Nesbit, said in a statement that the novel is a "masterpiece" that will surprise readers with its nuanced exploration of issues like racism, morality, and the complexities of human relationships. Lee's original manuscript was rediscovered in the archives of her attorney, and HarperCollins worked closely with her to prepare the book for publication. The publisher has also released a series of quotes from Lee's friends and acquaintances, who describe her as being "thrilled" and "excited" about the book's release. With its unique blend of nostalgia and social commentary, "Go Set a Watchman" is poised to become a major literary event of the summer.

LONDON -- Jeremy Clarkson has reached the end of the road, at least with the BBC. LONDON -- Jeremy Clarkson has reached the end of the road, at least with the BBC.

The popular TV presenter and motoring journalist has been dropped by the British Broadcasting Corporation after a physical altercation with a producer on the set of his show "Top Gear". The incident, which occurred on March 10, left the producer with a facial injury and Clarkson with a suspended sentence for common assault.

The BBC announced the decision to sever ties with Clarkson in a statement, saying that "the incident was not acceptable" and that the company "cannot condone or ignore" the behavior. Clarkson, 54, has been a fixture on British television for over two decades, and his shows have been hugely popular around the world. The future of "Top Gear" is now uncertain, but rumors are circulating that the show may continue without Clarkson. A new host is reportedly being sought, and the BBC is expected to make an announcement in the coming days.

I stared at it, trying to understand how that was even possible. I'd signed something else, hadn't I? A lower rate, I must have. It was 2000, I was 24, making less than $30,000 a year, and the American Airlines Citibank Card was the first I'd ever had. It was shiny and silver, with the old airline logo at the top. Get miles! Live like other people in New York! Welcome, kid. Foreshadowing what was to come, I couldn't remember the credit limit, only what I bought. A gold, strapless Nicole Miller dress for a glamorous friend's sister's wedding. As I gazed at the statement, a sense of unease crept over me. The total balance was a staggering $12,000, with interest charges piling up at an alarming rate. I felt like I'd been punched in the gut. How could I have racked up such a massive debt? The memories came flooding back - the countless nights out with friends, the impulse buys at trendy boutiques, the mistaken assumption that I could afford it all. The gold dress, once a symbol of my carefree youth, now seemed like a reckless indulgence. I felt like I was drowning in a sea of debt, and the weight of it was suffocating me. I knew I had to take action, but where did I even begin?

HBO, the premium entertainment network, is strengthening its relationship with Vice, the maverick media company and news organization. It announced on Thursday that it would broadcast a daily half-hour Vice newscast. The program is to run five days a week for 48 weeks a year. Richard Plepler, chief executive of HBO, said it would have its debut this year. For Vice, which already produces a newsmagazine show for HBO, the deal forges an even closer relationship with a prestigious and successful media brand, a partnership that helped bring Vice an Emmy last year. The newscast, titled "Vice News Tonight," will feature a team of Vice journalists and correspondents reporting on global news, politics, and culture. The program will air weeknights at 7:30 PM ET on HBO, and will be available on demand on HBO's streaming platforms. The partnership between HBO and Vice is seen as a bold move by both companies, as they seek to challenge the dominance of traditional news networks. The deal also marks a significant expansion of Vice's reach and influence, as its programming will now be available to millions of HBO subscribers worldwide.

An ancient hominid known as Little Foot may have lived at roughly the same time as Lucy, another famous human forebear, a new study has found. The research, published in the journal Nature, suggests that early hominids may have been far more diverse than previously thought. Discovered in a cave in South Africa in the early 1990s, Little Foot (named for his tiny feet) was first thought to be about 4 million years old. The initial estimate was based on the age of the surrounding rock formations, but new dating techniques have pushed the estimated age of Little Foot to around 3.3 million years old. This puts him in the same time frame as Lucy, the famous 3.2 million-year-old Australopithecus afarensis fossil discovered in Ethiopia in 1974. The study's lead author, Dr. Bernhard Zipfel, suggests that Little Foot may have been a member of a previously unknown human ancestor species, or possibly a previously unknown population of a known species. The discovery has significant implications for our understanding of human evolution, and could potentially rewrite the narrative of our species' origins.

Davidson College students don't take dirty clothes home to Mom. Why would they? For 95 years, Davidson, a liberal arts school near Charlotte, N.C., has done students' laundry free. and it's a tradition that's been passed down through generations of students. According to college officials, the laundry service is a way to alleviate one of the biggest stressors of college life: doing chores. "We want our students to focus on their studies and extracurricular activities, not on mundane tasks like laundry," said Dr. Jane Smith, Vice President of Student Affairs. The college employs a team of dedicated laundry staff who work tirelessly to ensure that every student's clothes are clean and fresh. The service is available 24/7, and students can even request special care for delicate items. It's a perk that has become an integral part of the Davidson College experience, and one that students love. "It's amazing to have one less thing to worry about," said junior Emily Johnson. "I can focus on my studies and enjoy my college experience without having to worry about dirty laundry."

When James Oseland was editor in chief of Saveur, the food magazine, he had dinner one night with Maria Rodale, the chief executive of the publisher Rodale. There, at ABC Kitchen near Union Square, they ran into Alice Waters, the acclaimed chef and champion of sustainable food. "We took it as a pretty amazing sign," Mr. Oseland said last week at Rodale's office in Midtown Manhattan. Ms. Rodale recalled Mr. Oseland saying it was "just like being blessed by the pope." The encounter sparked a conversation about the future of food media, and the potential for Saveur to play a leading role in shaping the industry's direction. Rodale, known for its commitment to organic and sustainable living, was looking to expand its reach and influence through its publications. Oseland, who had a deep respect for Waters' work at Chez Panisse, saw an opportunity to merge his passion for food writing with Rodale's mission. "It was like a moment of clarity," Oseland said. "I realized that we could use our platform to promote not just great food, but also the people and practices that make it possible." The meeting ultimately led to Oseland joining Rodale as editor-in-chief, where he oversaw a transformation of Saveur into a leading voice on sustainable food and culture. The partnership with Waters, who would later become a frequent contributor to the magazine, was just the beginning of a new era for the publication.

The celebrity talk show host Dr. Mehmet Oz plans to respond aggressively on Thursday to doctors who have criticized his medical advice and questioned his faculty position at Columbia University, a spokesman for the show said on Monday. In a strongly worded email sent last week to the university, 10 physicians wrote that Dr. Oz, the vice chairman of Columbia's surgery department, had shown "an egregious lack of integrity by promoting quack treatments and cures in the interest of personal financial gain." In particular, the doctors attacked Dr. Oz's "baseless and relentless opposition to the genetic engineering of food crops." Dr. Oz will address the letter in the lead segment of his syndicated, daytime talk show, "The Dr. Oz Show," on Thursday, a spokesman for the show said. According to the spokesman, Dr. Oz will use the platform to "set the record straight" and "correct the misinformation" spread by the 10 physicians. The show's producers have promised a lively and confrontational segment, featuring Dr. Oz's rebuttals to the criticisms and a live audience reaction. The move is seen as a strategic attempt to boost ratings and reassert Dr. Oz's authority in the medical community. The university has so far declined to comment on the matter, fueling speculation about the potential fallout for Dr. Oz's faculty position. The controversy has also sparked a heated debate on social media, with many viewers expressing support for Dr. Oz's right to share his opinions, while others have called for his resignation from the university.

Richard Corliss, whose well-informed and spirited movie reviews appeared in Time magazine for 35 years, died on Thursday in Manhattan. He was 71. His wife, Mary, said the cause was complications of a stroke. He had been in a hospice care center. Richard Corliss was a beloved figure in the film world, known for his erudite and engaging writing style. He joined Time magazine in 1977, and his reviews quickly became a staple of the publication's entertainment section. Corliss's reviews were not only informative but also infused with his trademark wit and humor. He was particularly known for his ability to distill complex ideas and themes into accessible language, making him a favorite among both casual moviegoers and industry insiders.

Throughout his career, Corliss wrote about some of the most iconic films of all time, including "Star Wars," "E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial," and "The Silence of the Lambs." He was also a keen observer of cinematic trends, and his reviews often provided insightful commentary on the state of the film industry. Corliss's writing was widely admired, and he received numerous awards and honors for his work, including a Peabody Award and a National Board of Review Award.

In addition to his work at Time, Corliss was also a prolific author, penning several books on film history and criticism. His most recent book, "Talking Pictures: How to Watch Movies," was published in 2013. Corliss's death is a significant loss to the film community, and his legacy will continue to be celebrated through his enduring body of work. He is survived by his wife, Mary, and their two children. A memorial service will be held in the coming weeks.

Thomas R. Shepard Jr., who as the last publisher of Look magazine oversaw its sudden and rapid descent from record advertising revenue and circulation to its demise, died on April 29 in Sarasota, Fla. He was 96. The cause was pneumonia, said his son, Rocky. Mr. Shepard, a salesman with missionary zeal, was named publisher in 1965, during the heyday of mass general-circulation magazines driven by newsstand sales, lavish photographic spreads and alluring articles. That was before television began vying for advertising revenue and eyeballs, and crippling postal rate increases obliterated profit margins. Collier's had already folded in 1957, but by the late 1960s Look, Life and The Saturday Evening Post were still slugging it out. As publisher, Mr. Shepard was determined to keep Look relevant, investing heavily in new technologies and editorial innovations. He launched a popular weekly news magazine, Look Week, and introduced a tabloid-style format to appeal to a younger audience. Despite these efforts, the magazine's circulation continued to decline, and in 1971, the company was sold to Cowles Communications. Mr. Shepard remained publisher until 1978, when he was forced out due to disagreements with the new owners. He went on to work as a consultant and writer, but his legacy as the last publisher of Look magazine remained a testament to his entrepreneurial spirit and dedication to the industry.

A newly described horned dinosaur with peculiar ornamentation was a close relative of Triceratops, paleontologists have found. The dinosaur had a longer nose horn than Triceratops, and two small horns above its eyes. But its most distinctive feature was a radiating frill, a set of large, pentagonal plates like a crown atop its head. The discovery was made in the Gobi Desert of Mongolia, where a team of researchers from the American Museum of Natural History and the Mongolian Academy of Sciences excavated a nearly complete skeleton of the new species, which they have named Styracosaurus albertensis. The dinosaur is estimated to have lived around 70 million years ago, during the Late Cretaceous period. According to the team's lead researcher, Dr. Emily Chen, the unique frill on Styracosaurus albertensis is unlike anything seen before in a dinosaur, and is likely to have played a significant role in the animal's behavior and social interactions. Further study of the skeleton is underway to learn more about this fascinating new species.

All chimpanzees will be designated as endangered under the Endangered Species Act, the United States Fish and Wildlife Service announced Friday. The move follows a petition filed in 2010 by Jane Goodall, The Humane Society of the United States and other groups to eliminate a longstanding distinction between the legal status of captive chimpanzees, which were previously listed as "threatened," and their wild counterparts, which have been deemed "endangered" for decades. With the new designations, chimpanzees held in captivity in the United States will receive the same protections as wild chimps under the Endangered Species Act. Biomedical research, interstate trade, and export and import of captive chimpanzees will now require permits issued by the Fish and Wildlife Service. The decision is expected to have significant implications for the use of chimpanzees in scientific research, as well as their treatment and welfare in captivity. Critics of the previous distinction between captive and wild chimpanzees had argued that it was arbitrary and failed to recognize the close genetic and behavioral ties between the two populations. The new designation is seen as a major victory for animal welfare advocates, who had long argued that chimpanzees are intelligent, social, and emotional beings that deserve greater protection and respect. The Fish and Wildlife Service will now work to develop new regulations and guidelines for the care and management of captive chimpanzees, and to ensure that any permits issued for biomedical research or other purposes are subject to rigorous review and approval.

Here are ideas from experts on how older Americans can get the most value from their travel dollars:

# Prioritize the places you want to visit and your approximate annual budget. "Decide where you want to spend your money," said Anne Scully, president of McCabe World Travel in McLean, Va. "What's the hardest trip? Do it first." # Figure the approximate cost of the entire trip before you go. "Look at the final price," Ms. Scully said, including "what you pay when you leave the hotel or the ship." Cruises and all-inclusive trips can make it easier to calculate the final cost before you travel. "Additionally, consider traveling during the off-season or during shoulder season, when prices tend to be lower. Many popular destinations also offer senior discounts or special promotions, so be sure to ask about these when booking. It's also important to prioritize your spending, focusing on experiences and activities that are most important to you, rather than trying to visit every attraction or eat at every restaurant. By doing so, you can get the most value from your travel dollars and create lasting memories."

Campus-affiliated accounts may come with fees that can add up if students don't use the accounts carefully. Some campus debit cards, for instance, charge fees when students make purchases using their PINs, rather than with a signature -- a fee not typically seen with traditional checking accounts. And some may charge hefty overdraft fees for debit transactions -- that is, fees charged for overdrawing the account, according to a study this year by the Center for Responsible Lending. That means it is important for students to clearly understand the terms of any account they are offered and to make sure they are using it in a way that minimizes fees, said Meredith Turner, chief governmental officer with the California State Student Association. "Read the fine print," she said. "Students need to be aware of the fees associated with their accounts and make smart financial decisions to avoid unnecessary charges," Turner emphasized. According to the Center for Responsible Lending, some campus debit cards charge monthly maintenance fees, ATM fees, and even fees for low balances. These fees can quickly add up, leaving students with a surprise bill at the end of the month. To avoid these fees, Turner recommends that students opt for accounts with no monthly maintenance fees, no ATM fees, and no overdraft fees. Additionally, students should review their account statements regularly to catch any errors or unauthorized transactions. By being mindful of these fees and taking steps to minimize them, students can save money and make the most of their campus-affiliated accounts.

"For his development of theory and methods for analyzing discrete choice." The Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science has a rich history of honoring outstanding contributions to the field. The prize is awarded annually by the Sveriges Riksbank Prize in Economic Sciences in Memory of Alfred Nobel, and is considered one of the most prestigious awards in economics.

Over the years, the prize has recognized a diverse range of achievements, from the development of new economic theories to the application of economic principles to real-world problems. The laureates have come from all over the world, and have made significant contributions to our understanding of the economy and its role in society.

In recent years, the prize has been awarded to economists who have made significant contributions to the fields of behavioral economics, experimental economics, and macroeconomics. For example, in 2017, the prize was awarded to Richard Thaler, who is known for his work on behavioral economics and the concept of "nudges."

The Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science is not only a recognition of individual achievement, but also a celebration of the importance of economic science in addressing some of the world's most pressing challenges. The prize is a reminder of the power of economic analysis to inform policy and improve people's lives, and serves as a motivation for future generations of economists to continue making groundbreaking contributions to the field.

IF you're ready to file your 2013 federal income tax return, you can do so starting now. The official start of tax-filing season arrived later than anticipated because of a delay caused by last year's government shutdown. If you are expecting to seek help from the Internal Revenue Service with your tax questions, you may find this to be a frustrating year. Taxpayers are likely to encounter reduced service from the agency because of continued cuts in its budget and staff, according to the annual report of the National Taxpayer Advocate, the office charged with representing the interest of taxpayers. The National Taxpayer Advocate's report highlights the struggles taxpayers may face in getting assistance from the IRS, citing a significant decrease in the number of telephone assistors and a reduction in the hours of operation for the agency's toll-free hotline. The report also warns that the IRS's automated systems may not be able to provide accurate answers to taxpayers' questions, leading to further frustration. As a result, tax professionals and advocates are urging taxpayers to seek help from qualified tax preparers and to be patient when dealing with the IRS. Despite these challenges, the IRS is urging taxpayers to file their returns as soon as possible to avoid potential penalties and interest.

Mutual of Omaha said it did not comment on pending legal matters. John Hancock did not respond to a request for comment. Women typically account for about two-thirds of the long-term-care insurance claims paid annually, said Jesse Slome, spokesman for the American Association for Long-Term Care Insurance, an industry group. Last year, companies paid $7.5 billion in claims. The effect is that women will now pay several hundred dollars more a year in long-term-care premiums than a man would for a comparable policy, according to the association's 2014 report, based on data from insurers. (The new gender-based premiums apply to new policies, not policies that were in place before the change took effect.) If you are a single 55-year-old man in good health buying a new policy, you can expect to pay $925 a year, on average, for a policy providing $164,000 in current benefits, without any built-in inflation protection. If you are a woman of the same age and health, though, you will pay an average of $1,225 a year for the same policy -- a difference of $300, or more than 30 percent. The difference in premiums is greater if you buy a policy that builds in inflation protection of 3 percent, compounded annually, for your benefits. (Your pool of benefits under this option would grow to $325,000 at age 80.) The same 55-year-old healthy man would pay $1,765 a year for that policy, but a woman would pay $2,307. A typical single woman will pay an average of 12 percent more than in 2013, the association found. The gender-based pricing disparity is not unique to long-term-care insurance, but it is a significant departure from the industry's previous approach. Many insurance companies, including Mutual of Omaha and John Hancock, have traditionally used actuarial tables to determine premiums based on age, health, and other factors, without considering gender. The change is likely driven by the increasing number of women seeking long-term-care insurance, as well as the growing recognition of the financial burden that caregiving can place on families.

Industry experts say that the new pricing structure is intended to reflect the reality that women are more likely to need long-term care services, due to their longer lifespan and higher risk of developing chronic health conditions. "The data is clear: women are more likely to need long-term care, and they are more likely to require longer periods of care," said Slome. "This pricing structure is a reflection of that reality."

However, some critics argue that the new pricing structure is unfair and could disproportionately affect women who are already more likely to be caregivers for their loved ones. "This change could have a significant impact on women who are already shouldering a disproportionate burden of caregiving," said Barbara Hughes, a financial planner and advocate for women's financial empowerment. "It's essential that policymakers and regulators take a closer look at this issue and consider the potential consequences for women's financial security."

In the latest chapter of the debit card fee wars, the banks and Federal Reserve were dealt a victory on Friday when a federal appeals court overturned a lower court's decision. The ruling means that the amount banks collect from retailers when consumers swipe debit cards can remain as is, and not be reduced further. The takeaway message for consumers: Nothing much will change, at least for now. The court's decision was seen as a major win for the banking industry, which had argued that the fees were necessary to cover the costs of processing debit transactions. The fees, which are typically around 1-2% of the transaction amount, have been a contentious issue for years, with merchants and consumer advocates arguing that they are too high and unfairly burden small businesses and individuals.

The Federal Reserve had initially proposed capping the fees at 12 cents per transaction in 2010, but the banking industry successfully lobbied to have the rule changed. The current fee structure has been in place since 2011, and has been the subject of ongoing controversy.

Consumer advocates expressed disappointment with the ruling, arguing that it would allow banks to continue to profit from the fees. "This decision is a blow to consumers and small businesses, who will continue to be charged excessive fees for debit transactions," said a spokesperson for the Consumer Federation of America. "We will continue to push for reforms to ensure that these fees are fair and reasonable."

IT'S July, prime time for swimming, hiking and slurping watermelon. But if both you and your spouse work and you have school-age children, you may have another perspective on summer: as the season when you must juggle your schedule and scrounge up affordable child care until school reopens. In about 60 percent of two-parent households with children under 18, both parents work, according to Pew Research Center, a subsidiary of the Pew Charitable Trusts. As the summer months approach, many families are left scrambling to find affordable and reliable childcare options. With both parents working, the pressure to find a solution can be overwhelming. According to a recent survey, 70% of parents reported feeling stressed about finding childcare during the summer break. This can lead to a financial burden, with many families forced to spend a significant portion of their income on summer camps, babysitters, and other childcare arrangements. As a result, many parents are turning to online communities and social media groups to share resources and advice on how to navigate the summer childcare conundrum. Despite the challenges, many parents are finding creative solutions to ensure their children remain safe and engaged during the summer months.

Secretary of Education Arne Duncan announced on Thursday that states could delay the use of test results in teacher-performance ratings by another year, an acknowledgment, in effect, of the enormous pressures mounting on the nation's teachers because of new academic standards and more rigorous standardized testing. Using language that evoked some of his fiercest critics, Mr. Duncan wrote in a blog post, "I believe testing issues today are sucking the oxygen out of the room in a lot of schools," and he added that teachers needed time to adapt to new standards and tests that emphasize more than simply filling in bubbled answers to multiple-choice questions. Over the past four years, close to 40 states have adopted laws that tie teacher evaluations in part to the performance of their students on standardized tests. This flexibility, Mr. Duncan said, would allow states to focus on other measures of teacher effectiveness, such as classroom observations and student feedback, which he believes are more meaningful indicators of a teacher's performance. The move is seen as a significant shift in the Obama administration's approach to teacher evaluation, which has been criticized by many educators and union leaders for its emphasis on standardized testing.

In a statement, the American Federation of Teachers, one of the largest teachers' unions, welcomed the announcement, saying it was "a recognition that the current system is broken and that we need to move towards a more comprehensive and nuanced approach to evaluating teacher effectiveness." The union has long argued that the current system is too reliant on standardized tests and does not take into account the many factors that affect student performance, such as poverty and lack of resources.

The decision is also seen as a response to growing concerns about the impact of high-stakes testing on students and teachers. Many educators and parents have complained that the emphasis on testing has led to a narrowing of the curriculum, with teachers feeling pressure to focus on test-preparation rather than more creative and engaging teaching methods. By giving states more flexibility, Mr. Duncan is hoping to encourage a more balanced approach to teaching and learning.

Texas A&M, New Mexico State and Utah State, all land-grant universities, pay tribute to their agricultural roots. 4. Central Michigan University (Chippewas) and the University of Illinois (Fighting Illini) have changed mascots but retained their tribal names. 's list of institutions with "hostile and abusive" Indian nicknames and mascots. The trend towards rebranding and reevaluation of Native American-inspired mascots has been ongoing in recent years, driven in part by growing concerns about cultural sensitivity and the potential for harm caused by such imagery. Many institutions have chosen to abandon their Native American-themed mascots altogether, opting instead for more neutral or inclusive branding.

For example, the University of North Dakota's Fighting Sioux, once a proud symbol of the school's athletic teams, was retired in 2015 after years of controversy and debate. Similarly, the University of Nebraska's Cornhuskers dropped their Native American-inspired "Husker Red" mascot in favor of a more generic, agricultural-themed branding.

The shift away from Native American-themed mascots is seen by many as a step towards greater cultural understanding and respect. "It's about time," said Dr. John Smith, a Native American studies professor at the University of Arizona. "These mascots are a relic of a bygone era, and it's long overdue that institutions take a more thoughtful and respectful approach to representing Native American cultures." As the debate continues, it remains to be seen which institutions will follow suit and which will hold fast to their traditional branding.

PHILADELPHIA -- The United States Department of Education is investigating complaints that plans to close or reorganize public schools in Philadelphia, Detroit and Newark discriminate against black and Hispanic students, as well as those with disabilities, a department official confirmed on Monday. Community activists from those cities and 15 others are scheduled to meet Tuesday with Education Secretary Arne Duncan to urge a moratorium on school-closing plans until agreements can be reached on alternatives. Jitu Brown, a community organizer from the South Side of Chicago, said the community representatives would seek immediate action on the civil rights complaints, and would urge officials to halt school closings, stop plans to turn public schools over to private contractors, end "phaseouts" in which schools cease to accept new students so that numbers dwindle, and stop the practice of combining public schools with charter schools. The community representatives will also demand that the department provide resources to support the reopening of closed schools and the revitalization of underperforming schools. "We're not just asking for a moratorium, we're asking for a fundamental shift in the way that our schools are governed and supported," said Brown. The meeting comes as tensions between community activists and city officials continue to escalate, with many arguing that the school closures disproportionately affect low-income and minority students.

TOKYO -- The recent monetary push by Japan does not amount to currency manipulation and is a legitimate and much-needed effort to lift its economy out of deflation, the country's central banker said on Thursday after new figures showed an unexpected economic contraction in the fourth quarter. "Monetary policy seeks only to stabilize the economy," Masaaki Shirakawa, the governor of the Bank of Japan, told reporters in Tokyo after the bank decided to stand pat on policy moves for now, maintaining its benchmark rate goal of zero to 0.1 percent and holding off on expansion of an asset-buying program. Shirakawa emphasized that the Bank of Japan's actions were not intended to devalue the yen or gain a competitive advantage, but rather to stimulate domestic demand and boost economic growth. He noted that the country's economy had been struggling with deflation for over a decade, and that the central bank's measures were necessary to break this cycle. The bank's decision to maintain its current policy settings was seen as a sign of caution, given the uncertain global economic outlook and the potential risks of inflation. Despite this, many economists believe that further monetary easing may be necessary in the future to achieve the bank's inflation target of 2%. The Bank of Japan's next policy meeting is scheduled for March, and many are expecting the bank to take further action to stimulate the economy.

Days after Diana Natalicio became president of the University of Texas at El Paso in 1988, the first woman to hold that job, a local newspaper ran an illustration of her as Wonder Woman. As she begins her 26th year at the helm -- the longest tenure at the head of a Texas public university among current presidents -- that depiction remains apt. Under Ms. Natalicio's leadership, UTEP's budget has grown to roughly $400 million from about $65 million, and research expenditures are up to about $76 million from $6 million. The university's enrollment has also increased significantly, with over 25,000 students now calling UTEP home. Natalicio's commitment to diversity and inclusion has also led to a significant growth in the number of underrepresented minority students, with the university now boasting a student body that is 80% Hispanic. Under her leadership, UTEP has also become a hub for research in areas such as engineering, computer science, and health sciences. Natalicio's tenure has also seen the university establish partnerships with major corporations and organizations, providing students with opportunities for internships, research collaborations, and career advancement. As she celebrates her 26th year as president, Natalicio's legacy at UTEP is one of transformation, growth, and a commitment to excellence.

"Every member of every city council that's struggling with these issues, who takes their job seriously, is looking for solutions," Mr. Sweet said. "No one wants to talk about it, and no one really wants to go there. But if Calpers can be forced to take a haircut in Stockton, then what's to stop another city from saying, 'Gee, we'll file for bankruptcy and cut in half our $10 million pension contribution?' "

He and other public finance lawyers said that what happens in Stockton could help guide Detroit, which is not in Chapter 9 but was recently put under emergency management by the state of Michigan. Calpers is a $252 billion giant that administers pensions for California state employees and many municipal workers. It calculates how much its member cities must set aside each year, bills them, collects the money, invests it and sends retirees their benefits. When Calpers's investments lose money, as they did in the stock market crash, the bills increase. In 2011, Stockton paid a little more than $20 million to Calpers -- about double what it paid to run its public libraries. Its payments are expected to nearly double in the next 10 years, making Calpers the city's biggest creditor. Stockton says it has no choice but to keep paying, even as it pares other costs, including its payments to bondholders. It says that if it cuts the rate at which its workers build up their pensions, workers will leave -- especially the police, who have been recruited with the promise of large, early pensions. Last year, Stockton asked Calpers for a "hardship exemption," allowing it to slow down its contributions. The implications of the Stockton case are far-reaching, with some experts warning that it could set a dangerous precedent for other cities struggling with pension obligations. "This is a slippery slope," said Robert J. Szczerba, a public finance lawyer at Jones Day. "If Calpers can be forced to take a haircut, then what's to stop other cities from doing the same? It's a Pandora's box." Szczerba noted that many cities are facing similar pension obligations, and the threat of bankruptcy is a real one. "Cities are going to have to start making some tough decisions," he said. "They can't just keep kicking the can down the road." The situation is particularly dire in Detroit, where the city's pension fund is severely underfunded. While Detroit has not filed for bankruptcy, the state of Michigan has taken control of the city's finances, and officials are working to restructure the city's debt. The fate of Detroit's pension fund remains uncertain, but experts say that the city's situation is likely to be closely watched by other cities facing similar challenges. "This is a wake-up call for cities everywhere," said Szczerba. "They need to start thinking about the long-term consequences of their pension obligations."

PARIS -- In its first such agreement with a European country, China signed a free-trade deal with Iceland on Monday as Beijing reached out for allies at a time when many of its trading partners are wary of its increasing economic might. The accord, meant to eliminate most tariffs over the next few years, was signed by trade officials in Beijing during a state visit by Prime Minister Johanna Sigurdardottir of Iceland. When completed, it will unite two hugely mismatched economies: Iceland's 2011 gross domestic product of $14 billion was little more than a rounding error in China's G.D.P. that year of $7.3 trillion. Trade between the countries is small by global standards. Iceland's exports to China last year, mainly fish, totaled $61 million, while it imported Chinese goods and services valued at $341 million. But while Iceland cannot offer much in the way of significant new market growth, it could help China in its quest for more influence in the Arctic, as global warming and polar ice retreat make that area increasingly accessible. China is seeking to join the Arctic Council, an intergovernmental body that promotes cooperation in the region, as a permanent observer. Iceland, though not a member of the European Union, enjoys access to the single market through its membership in the European Free Trade Association and the European Economic Area. But China would not gain backdoor access to the European market through the trade deal. Iceland had been negotiating membership but suspended talks in January amid widespread domestic opposition. The agreement with Iceland is seen as a strategic move by China to expand its economic influence in the Arctic region, which is expected to become more accessible due to climate change. China has been increasingly interested in the region's natural resources, including oil, gas, and minerals, and has been investing heavily in Arctic infrastructure development. The country has also been seeking to join the Arctic Council, an intergovernmental body that promotes cooperation in the region, as a permanent observer.

In exchange for the trade deal, China is expected to provide Iceland with financial and technological support for its fishing industry, which is a significant contributor to the country's economy. The agreement also includes provisions for cooperation in areas such as tourism, education, and culture.

The deal has been welcomed by Icelandic businesses, which see it as an opportunity to expand their exports to China and increase their competitiveness in the global market. However, some critics have raised concerns about the potential impact of the agreement on Iceland's economy and the country's ability to maintain its independence in the face of increasing Chinese influence.

Despite these concerns, the Icelandic government has emphasized the benefits of the agreement, including the potential for increased trade and investment between the two countries. The deal is also seen as a symbol of Iceland's commitment to diversifying its economy and reducing its dependence on traditional industries such as fishing.

The agreement with Iceland is part of China's broader strategy to expand its economic influence in Europe, which has been a key focus of the country's foreign policy in recent years. China has been seeking to increase its trade and investment ties with European countries, and has been actively promoting its Belt and Road Initiative, a massive infrastructure development project that aims to connect China with Europe and other parts of Asia.

Overall, the agreement between China and Iceland is seen as a significant development in the country's relations with Europe, and is likely to have far-reaching implications for the region's economy and politics.

Finance ministers from leading global economies on Saturday avoided a public rift with Japan over policies driving down the value of its currency, while keeping up pressure on Germany to help lift growth in Europe. At the end of two days of talks among the Group of 7 finance ministers outside London, other nations appeared to accept -- at least for now -- Japan's explanation that its new monetary efforts were meant to stimulate its domestic economy, rather than to drive down the yen on international currency markets. The chancellor of the Exchequer in Britain, George Osborne, said on Saturday that ministers from the G-7, made up of the United States, Germany, Japan, Britain, Italy, France and Canada, had reaffirmed earlier commitments on exchange rates and agreed to make sure policies are "oriented towards achieving domestic objectives." Other officials described the talks as in-depth and positive. The finance ministers also emphasized the importance of continued cooperation to address global economic challenges, including the ongoing impact of the COVID-19 pandemic and the need for sustainable and inclusive growth. In a joint statement, the G-7 ministers expressed their commitment to promoting free and fair trade, while also acknowledging the need for countries to take measures to protect their domestic industries. The statement also highlighted the importance of international cooperation to address global issues such as climate change and inequality. Despite the tensions over the yen, the G-7 ministers were able to find common ground and maintain a united front, with many officials describing the talks as constructive and productive. The meeting concluded with a sense of optimism and a renewed commitment to working together to promote global economic stability and growth.

Mr. Gee, who in 2007 became the first public university president to earn more than $1 million, had a base salary last year of $830,439, the highest among the 212 chief executives included in the Chronicle report. He is known for prodigious fund-raising energy, which has brought the university more than $1.6 billion since he took the post, and for the lavish lifestyle his job supports, including a rent-free mansion with an elevator, a pool and a tennis court and flights on private jets. and a collection of high-end art pieces and rare books. Despite his impressive salary and benefits, Mr. Gee has faced criticism from some faculty members and students who feel that his compensation is excessive, particularly given the university's rising tuition rates and budget cuts in other areas. However, his supporters argue that his fund-raising prowess has brought in significant revenue and helped to enhance the university's reputation and academic programs. Under his leadership, the university has also made significant strides in research and innovation, with several major breakthroughs and discoveries in fields such as medicine and technology. Despite the controversy surrounding his compensation, Mr. Gee remains a highly respected figure in the academic community, known for his vision and leadership.

PARIS -- Air traffic controllers in France have planned three days of strikes beginning Tuesday, to protest a proposal by the European Commission to accelerate the integration of air traffic management systems across the Continent. In addition, their counterparts in several other European countries were expected to take more limited labor action this week. France's civil aviation authority made contingency plans over the weekend, asking airlines serving the country's airports in Paris, Lyon, Nice, Marseille, Toulouse and Bordeaux to reduce their flight schedules by 50 percent from Tuesday morning until late Thursday to ease the burden on those airports, which were expected to face significant disruption. Unions in more than a half dozen other countries, including Belgium, Hungary, Italy and Portugal, were likely to join in work-to-rule and other more symbolic actions on Wednesday, said Koen Reynaerts, a spokesman for the European Transport Workers' Federation in Brussels, which represents more than 25,000 workers involved in managing air traffic across the region. The strikes are expected to cause significant disruptions to air travel across Europe, with thousands of flights potentially affected. The European Commission's proposal aims to streamline air traffic management by 2025, but the unions argue it will lead to job losses and increased working hours. The federation's secretary-general, Luca Visentini, warned that the strikes would "send a strong signal" to the European Commission that the workers will not accept the proposed changes without a fight. As the strikes approach, travelers are advised to check with their airlines for updates on flight schedules and to plan ahead for potential delays and cancellations. The European Commission has said it is willing to negotiate with the unions, but has thus far refused to withdraw the proposal. The dispute highlights the ongoing tensions between the European Union's efforts to integrate its member states' economies and the concerns of workers who fear they will be negatively impacted by the changes.

It looks like the great American mortgage sale is finally coming to an end. While rates on home loans are likely to remain modest by traditional standards, the ultralow borrowing costs that encouraged millions of homeowners to refinance and helped revive the moribund housing market are quickly becoming a memory. As yields on 10-year government bonds rise amid signs that the economy is improving and that the Federal Reserve will reduce bond purchases, mortgage rates have quickly followed. Rates on 30-year fixed mortgages hit 4.25 percent on Thursday, up from 4.12 percent on Wednesday morning before the Fed chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, signaled the central bank might begin easing back on stimulus efforts later this year. As recently as May, the average interest rate on a 30-year fixed mortgage stood at 3.5 percent, close to the lowest in decades. They are either already set at relatively high levels, like most credit card borrowing costs, or tied to short-term interest rates, which the Fed has indicated will not rise before 2015. This shift in mortgage rates is expected to have a significant impact on the housing market, as many homeowners who were previously able to snag ultralow rates may struggle to afford refinancing or purchasing a new home. According to analysts, the rise in rates could also slow down the pace of home sales, as buyers may be deterred by the increased costs. Additionally, the Fed's potential reduction in bond purchases could lead to a further increase in long-term interest rates, making it even more challenging for borrowers to secure affordable mortgages. As a result, many experts are predicting a more modest pace of growth for the housing market in the coming months.

HONG KONG -- The Chinese central bank reassured investors worried about a lingering credit squeeze and declared that it had already been selectively supporting bank liquidity, as Chinese stock markets swung wildly again Tuesday after several days of volatility. The central bank, People's Bank of China, eager to rein in soaring lending growth and financial risk, initially refrained from intervening as bank-to-bank interest rates soared last week, but then apparently released more money for lenders. Uncertainty over the central bank's position produced wide trading swings Tuesday, with the main Chinese stock indexes dropping to their lowest levels since early 2009 before recovering most of the day's losses near the end of trading. as the Shanghai Composite Index rallied 2.3% to close at 2,901.14, just shy of its opening levels. The Shenzhen Composite Index, which tracks smaller companies, gained 3.1% to 1,002.21. Despite the late-day rebound, investors remained cautious, with many wondering what the central bank's next move would be. Analysts pointed out that the PBOC's selective support of bank liquidity was a positive sign, but warned that more decisive action was needed to address the underlying credit issues. Meanwhile, the yield on the 10-year Chinese government bond rose to 4.15%, the highest level since 2014, as investors sought safer assets. The Chinese currency, the yuan, also strengthened against the US dollar, closing at 6.87 per dollar. Despite the market volatility, economists remained optimistic about China's economic prospects, citing the country's strong fundamentals and the government's efforts to reform the financial system.

PARIS -- Global stocks fell and oil rose above $100 a barrel on Wednesday as concern about the political crises in Egypt and Portugal added to traders' growing anxieties. Egypt was at the center of geopolitical concern after President Mohamed Morsi on Tuesday night defied an army ultimatum that he resign, raising the risk that the country would descend into bloodshed and chaos. "Egypt's not a major oil producer compared with Libya next door," said Damian Kennaby, director of research for oil market services at IHS Cambridge Energy Research Associates in London. "But there's a whole lot of 'what if' going on right now, and that's being built into the oil price." and into the global economy. The situation in Egypt is particularly concerning because of its strategic location in the Middle East, with many oil tankers passing through the Suez Canal. The uncertainty surrounding the crisis has led to a surge in demand for safe-haven assets such as gold, which rose 1.5% to a two-month high. Meanwhile, investors are also eyeing the situation in Portugal, where a bailout package is being negotiated, and the potential impact on the eurozone's fragile economic recovery. "The markets are getting nervous, and it's not just about Egypt," said Jim Reid, a strategist at Deutsche Bank. "The world is facing a perfect storm of uncertainty, and it's only a matter of time before it starts to affect growth."

LONDON -- The Bank of England kept its benchmark interest rate unchanged on Thursday amid tentative signs that Britain's economic recovery is strengthening. The central bank held its interest rate at 0.5 percent, already a record low, and also made no change to its program of economic stimulus, leaving the target at 375 billion pounds, or about $570 billion. The British government had reported last week that the economy in the second quarter had grown 0.6 percent from the previous quarter and that all main industries were reporting faster growth for the first time in three years. The decision to keep interest rates steady was widely expected by economists, who noted that the UK's economic growth has been slow and uneven since the Brexit referendum in 2016. Despite the recent signs of improvement, many remain cautious about the potential impact of Brexit on the economy. "While the recent data has been encouraging, it's still early days and we need to see more evidence of sustained growth before we can be confident that the economy is out of the woods," said Rachel Winterbottom, an economist at Investec. The Bank of England's governor, Mark Carney, also emphasized the need for caution, saying that the bank would continue to monitor the economy closely and be prepared to take action if necessary. Despite the uncertainty, the decision to keep interest rates unchanged was welcomed by many businesses, which had been concerned about the impact of higher borrowing costs on their finances.

The International Monetary Fund warned in a report that a persistent recession and the government's failure to accelerate overhauls may create an 11 billion-euro hole in Greece's finances over the next two years. The concerns come as Greece received 4 billion euros, or $5.3 billion, in aid late Wednesday from its so-called troika of creditors: the I.M.F., the European Commission and the European Central Bank. The latest financing gap may require Greece's European creditors to consider giving it debt relief and more money so that it can meet the requirements of its current 172 billion-euro bailout program, which came on top of a 110 billion-euro bailout program given in 2010, the I.M.F. said. The IMF's warning has sent shockwaves through the financial markets, with investors growing increasingly anxious about Greece's ability to service its debt. The country's economy has been struggling to recover from a deep recession, and the IMF's report suggests that the situation may be worse than previously thought. Greece's government has been under pressure to implement reforms and austerity measures, but the country's debt crisis has made it difficult to implement these measures.

The IMF's report also highlighted the need for Greece's creditors to provide more support to the country. The report stated that the country's debt burden is unsustainable and that debt relief and more financing will be needed to avoid a default. The report's findings are likely to increase pressure on Greece's creditors to provide more support to the country, and may also lead to a re-evaluation of the country's debt burden.

The European Commission, the European Central Bank, and the IMF have all made it clear that they are committed to supporting Greece, but the country's debt crisis remains a major challenge. The IMF's report highlights the need for a comprehensive solution to Greece's debt crisis, and it is likely that the country's creditors will need to work together to find a solution.

HONG KONG -- China's economy is cooling, and Asia's once-rosy prospects look less shiny than they did two years ago, but this has not deterred Sotheby's from choosing Hong Kong as the place to sell a rare multimillion-dollar diamond in October. despite the economic uncertainty, the auction house believes the city's reputation as a hub for luxury goods and its growing importance as a global financial center make it an ideal location for the sale. The rare diamond, known as the "Blue Moon of Josephine," is expected to fetch between $30 million and $50 million at the auction, which will be held on October 12. The gemstone, a 12.08-carat fancy vivid blue diamond, was once owned by Napoleon Bonaparte's wife, Empress Josephine, and has been certified by the Gemological Institute of America as one of the most valuable diamonds in the world. Sotheby's has already received interest from collectors and investors from around the globe, and the auction is expected to be highly competitive.
