MOSCOW -- After years of delay, the largest oil field outside the Middle East started producing crude on Monday, offering a valuable new deposit to meet the world's rising energy needs. The first oil to flow from the Kashagan field, in Kazakhstan, was just a trickle. But a consortium of oil companies, including Exxon Mobil and ConocoPhillips of the United States, have ambitious plans to increase production over the next several years. "This is one of the most complicated projects in the world," Claudio Descalzi, the chief operating officer for exploration and production at Eni, the Italian oil company involved in the project, said in a telephone interview. "It's really an historical moment. The Kashagan field, which is located in the Caspian Sea, is expected to produce up to 1.5 million barrels of oil per day at its peak, making it one of the largest oil fields in the world. The consortium of oil companies has invested billions of dollars in the project, which has been plagued by delays and technical challenges. However, with the first oil now flowing, the companies are confident that they can meet their production targets and make the project a financial success. "We're very proud of what we've accomplished," said Descalzi. "It's a great achievement for all of us." The Kashagan field is expected to be a major contributor to the world's oil supply for decades to come, and its production is expected to help meet growing demand for energy.

MADRID -- Spain is on track to meet the 2013 budget deficit target it agreed on with its European Union partners and should emerge from recession before the end of the year, the economy minister said on Monday. The minister, Luis de Guindos, also said the government would not require additional one-time austerity measures as part of the 2014 budget that it will present this month. "De Guindos expressed confidence that Spain's economy will return to growth in the third quarter of this year, driven by a rebound in exports and a recovery in domestic demand. He also highlighted the country's progress in implementing structural reforms, which he said had improved the business environment and boosted competitiveness. The minister's comments came as Spain's central bank released data showing that the country's economy shrank by 1.2% in the first quarter of 2013, less than the 1.4% contraction forecast by economists. The data suggests that Spain's economy is slowly stabilizing, and de Guindos' optimistic outlook has been welcomed by investors, who have driven up the value of the country's bonds and stocks in recent weeks."

The Social Security Administration's Web site says it is now processing some spousal retirement claims and paying them when due. If you and your spouse live in a state where same-sex marriage is sanctioned, and you meet other criteria (see below), the application should be straightforward. An unresolved question, however, is whether couples who were legally married in one state but moved to another state that doesn't recognize gay marriage can get the same benefits. That's because the Social Security Administration currently uses a "place of residence" standard in deciding spousal benefits. Susan Sommer, senior counsel with the gay rights group Lambda Legal, said Social Security had instructed its staff to accept and hold such applications, pending further legal clarification. "We're awaiting guidance, and we're really hopeful," she said. The agency also is holding other types of applications for now, like those for survivor benefits when one spouse dies. However, Ms. Bonauto said she was encouraged by the case of 83-year-old Herb Burtis, a musician and voice teacher in Western Massachusetts. Mr. Burtis had applied for survivor benefits after his husband died in 2008. after his husband died in 2008. Although the couple had married in Vermont, where same-sex marriage is legal, they had moved to Massachusetts, which does not recognize gay marriage. Initially, the Social Security Administration denied Mr. Burtis' application, citing the "place of residence" standard. However, with the help of the GLAD Legal Advocates for Women and the Massachusetts Gay & Lesbian Political Caucus, Mr. Burtis appealed the decision and was ultimately granted the survivor benefits.

This case has sparked hope for other couples in similar situations. "It's a huge victory for Herb and for all of us who are fighting for equality," said Mary Bonauto, GLAD's legal director. "It shows that the Social Security Administration is willing to listen and to make changes when they're presented with compelling evidence and legal arguments."

The Social Security Administration's willingness to reconsider its stance on same-sex marriage benefits is a significant step forward, but it's still unclear how the agency will ultimately decide to handle claims from couples who were married in one state but live in another. "We're waiting to see how the agency will interpret the law and how it will apply it to different situations," said Sommer.

In the meantime, same-sex couples who were married in a state that recognizes gay marriage but now live in a state that does not should consider applying for spousal benefits. "It's a good idea to apply and to seek legal representation if your application is denied," said Bonauto. "We're seeing a lot of progress and a lot of momentum, and we're hopeful that eventually, all couples will have equal access to these benefits."

Of course, the 1 percent or top 0.1 percent is not a static figure. Every year, millions of individuals and households move up or down the income scale depending on their earnings, investments and age. Fortunes wax and wane as new tech gurus graduate from college and top lawyers head into retirement. Still, economists said that people holding considerable capital -- de facto, the already rich -- have done well during the recovery. Moreover, the 1 percent tends to be sticky, and perhaps even more so in bad times than in good times, Mr. Saez said. One study by the Treasury economists Gerald Auten, Geoffrey Gee and Nicholas Turner found that a quarter to a third of 1 percenters in a given year stayed in the 1 percent for all of the following five. . Thus, the profile of wealth in the United States, before the recession and after, has remained much the same. The prototypical high-net-worth individual is coastal, educated, older, white and male, Mr. Friedman said. The investor and chief executive of Berkshire Hathaway, Warren E. Buffett, might not be coastal, but the other categories apply, and with cash on hand and an appetite for acquisitions during the recovery, his net worth has increased by about $10 billion over the last year. Technology has minted hundreds of new top earners too, also generally men, but often much younger. David Duffield of Workday and Elon Musk of Tesla, among others, have benefited from the tech boom. Still, fields like finance, medicine and energy continue to be top moneymakers, with financiers and owners of their own or family businesses dominating the ultra-high-net-worth category. Three big interconnected economic phenomena have driven the boomerang among the country's top earners, economists said: stocks, houses and loans. The surge in stock markets, particularly in the tech sector, has been a major driver of wealth creation for the top 1 percent. As the Dow Jones and S&P 500 indices have reached record highs, many investors have seen their portfolios swell in value. Additionally, the housing market has continued to recover, with prices in many areas of the country reaching pre-recession levels. This has created a sense of wealth and security for those who own homes, and has also driven up property values, allowing many to tap into their equity and use it to invest in other assets.

Loans, particularly for mortgages and business ventures, have also played a crucial role in fueling the wealth of the top 1 percent. With interest rates at historic lows, many individuals and businesses have been able to borrow money at affordable rates, allowing them to invest in new ventures, expand their operations, or purchase additional properties. This has created a virtuous cycle, where those who are already wealthy are able to accumulate even more wealth by investing in assets that appreciate in value.

Economists note that this concentration of wealth among the top 1 percent is not unique to the United States. Many other developed countries are experiencing similar trends, as the global economy becomes increasingly interconnected and wealth becomes more concentrated among a small group of individuals. However, the scale and scope of the problem in the United States is particularly pronounced, with some arguing that it poses significant risks to the overall economy and society.

Critics argue that the concentration of wealth among the top 1 percent is not only a problem of economic inequality, but also a threat to social cohesion and economic stability. When a small group of individuals holds such a large proportion of the wealth, it can create a sense of disconnection and disillusionment among the rest of the population, leading to social unrest and political instability. Furthermore, when the wealthy are able to accumulate wealth at such a rapid pace, it can create a sense of complacency and risk-taking, leading to reckless investments and financial bubbles that can have devastating consequences for the broader economy.

WASHINGTON -- Lael Brainard, the country's top financial diplomat, is leaving her post at the end of the week, a Treasury official said. Some have speculated that the White House might choose her for a position on the Federal Reserve's board of governors. The sudden departure of Lael Brainard has sent shockwaves through the financial community, with many speculating about her next move. A Treasury official confirmed that Brainard will leave her position as Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs on Friday, but would not comment on the rumors surrounding her potential appointment to the Federal Reserve.

Brainard, a longtime Democrat and economist, has been a key player in shaping the country's international economic policy. Her departure comes at a critical time, as the US is facing growing trade tensions with China and ongoing negotiations with other major economies.

If Brainard were to join the Federal Reserve, she would bring a wealth of experience and expertise to the table. As a member of the Fed's board of governors, she would play a crucial role in setting monetary policy and guiding the country's economic recovery.

Several sources close to the White House have confirmed that Brainard is being considered for the position, but a formal announcement has yet to be made. The timing of her departure and the rumors surrounding her potential appointment have left many wondering what's next for Brainard and the Federal Reserve.

The German economy expanded faster than any other Group of 7 nation last year, official data showed Wednesday, but the stress of the euro crisis and a slowing global economy appear to be already weighing on output. Germany expanded by 3 percent last year from 2010, the Federal Statistical Office said in Wiesbaden. The strong growth was driven by a surge in exports, particularly to other European countries, which helped to offset a decline in domestic consumption. However, the country's trade surplus has also increased, sparking concerns about the impact on other European economies. The European Central Bank has been monitoring the situation closely, and some economists are warning that Germany's strong growth could exacerbate the crisis in other countries. Meanwhile, the International Monetary Fund has cut its global growth forecast, citing slowing economies in the United States and Asia. The German government has urged caution, saying that the country's economy is still vulnerable to external shocks. Despite this, many analysts are predicting that Germany will continue to outperform its peers in the coming year.

PARIS -- Stocks fell modestly in Europe on Monday, after confirmation that Spain had slumped back into recession in the first three months of 2012. The Spanish economy contracted by 0.3 percent in the January-March quarter, the same rate of contraction as in the last quarter of 2011, the National Statistics Institute said in Madrid. The common definition of a recession is two consecutive quarters of real economic decline. The news sent shockwaves through the financial markets, with investors already nervous about the eurozone's fragile economic recovery. The Dow Jones Euro Stoxx 50 index, which tracks the performance of 50 leading European companies, fell 0.6% to 2,443.15, while the FTSE 100 in London dropped 0.5% to 5,864.65. The German DAX index was down 0.7% to 7,141.35, while the French CAC 40 index lost 0.8% to 3,514.15. Analysts warned that the Spanish recession could have a ripple effect on other countries in the region, particularly those with significant trade ties with Spain. "This is a major setback for the Spanish economy and could have far-reaching consequences for the entire eurozone," said economist Maria Rodriguez. "The eurozone needs to act quickly to address this crisis and prevent a wider economic downturn."

L. Rafael Reif, an electrical engineer who has been the provost of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology for the last seven years, has been chosen as the institution's next president. Mr. Reif, 61, will assume the presidency on July 2, succeeding Susan Hockfield, who in February announced her plans to resign. Reif's appointment marks a significant milestone in MIT's history, as he becomes the first provost to be promoted to the presidency in over 50 years. A renowned expert in electrical engineering and computer science, Reif has played a crucial role in shaping MIT's academic and research agenda during his tenure as provost. Under his leadership, the institute has made significant strides in areas such as artificial intelligence, data science, and cybersecurity. Reif's presidency is expected to focus on building on this momentum, with a particular emphasis on fostering interdisciplinary collaboration and driving innovation in emerging fields. He will also be tasked with navigating the complex challenges facing higher education, including rising costs and changing student demographics.

Hoping to stave off a brewing trade war, Mexican tomato growers said on Thursday that they would agree to significant increases in the minimum price at which their products can enter the United States and to establish a system to bolster compliance and enforcement. Their offers come as the Commerce Department considers whether to end a 16-year-old agreement between the United States and some Mexican growers that American tomato farmers say keeps the price of Mexican tomatoes so low that they can barely compete. The proposal, which was presented to the Commerce Department, aims to address concerns from American tomato farmers that Mexican imports are undercutting their market share. The agreement, known as the Tomato Suspension Agreement, was put in place in 2008 to prevent a surge of Mexican tomatoes from entering the US market and harming American growers. However, Mexican growers argue that the agreement has become outdated and is no longer necessary. Under the new proposal, Mexican growers would agree to a minimum price of 21 cents per pound, up from the current 12 cents, and establish a system to ensure that all imports meet US safety and quality standards. The proposal is seen as a crucial step in avoiding a trade war between the two countries, which could have significant economic implications for both nations. If accepted, the agreement would be in place for five years, with annual reviews to ensure compliance.

Money troubles interfere with the academic performance of about one-third of all college students, and a similar number of students regularly skip buying required academic materials because of the costs, according to a survey released on Thursday. In an era of stagnant incomes and rising tuition and student debt, the burden of college costs on families and former students is well documented. The survey, conducted by the National Endowment for Financial Education (NEFE) and the Financial Literacy and Education Commission (FLEC), found that 32% of college students reported that financial stress was affecting their academic performance, with many students feeling overwhelmed by the pressure to balance schoolwork with part-time jobs and other responsibilities. Additionally, 31% of students said they had skipped buying required academic materials, such as textbooks or software, due to the high costs. The survey also found that many students were struggling to make ends meet, with 44% reporting that they had to take on part-time jobs to help pay for their education. The findings highlight the need for colleges and universities to provide more financial support and resources to students, as well as for policymakers to address the rising costs of higher education.

Surveys of consumer and business confidence in recent weeks have plummeted to recession-era lows. With such uncertainty, businesses have also recently curtailed spending on capital investments like computers, delivery trucks and other equipment, apparently in anticipation of higher tax rates and the destructive side effects of government cutbacks. Given that capital expenditures have been weak recently, some economists believe businesses will start spending more if Congress ends or at least delays the risk of severe fiscal tightening. "You would think there must be for most businesses a list of projects they'd like to do which they've just been pushing a little bit into the future because they haven't been able to justify taking the risk because they don't know what's around the corner," said Nigel Gault, chief United States economist for IHS Global Insight. "When they know more about the future, and what tax rates they'll be paying, they will be able to dust off those plans and finally execute them." Improving access to credit helps these capital expenditures become not only more attractive, but also more accessible. Commercial and industrial loans have been rising in recent months, according to the Federal Reserve. This increased access to credit is expected to have a positive impact on the economy, as businesses will be able to invest in their operations and expand their capacity. According to the Federal Reserve, commercial and industrial loans have been rising steadily over the past few months, with the total outstanding balance reaching a record high. This surge in lending is a sign that banks are becoming more confident in the economy and are willing to take on more risk.

Additionally, the recent decline in interest rates has made borrowing more attractive for businesses. With interest rates at historic lows, businesses are able to secure loans at a lower cost, making it easier for them to invest in their operations. This is particularly beneficial for small and medium-sized businesses, which often rely on credit to finance their growth.

The increased access to credit and the improving business sentiment are expected to have a ripple effect on the economy, boosting economic growth and creating new jobs. As businesses invest in their operations and expand their capacity, they will need to hire more workers to meet the increased demand. This will not only help to reduce the unemployment rate but also increase consumer spending, as workers will have more disposable income.

The Federal Reserve has also taken steps to support the economy by keeping interest rates low and implementing quantitative easing policies. These measures have helped to increase the availability of credit and stimulate economic growth. While there are still some risks to the economy, including the potential for a global trade war and the ongoing uncertainty surrounding the government's fiscal policies, the improving business sentiment and increased access to credit are expected to provide a boost to the economy in the coming months.

DENVER  Secretary of Education Arne Duncan, convening a two-day labor-management conference here on Tuesday, argued that teachers' unions can help solve many of the challenges facing public schools. But as the conference opened, that view was under challenge in a number of state capitals. Republicans in several states have proposed legislation in recent weeks that would bar teachers' unions from all policy discussions, except when the time comes to negotiate compensation. "except when the time comes to negotiate compensation," said Rep. Tim Higgins, a sponsor of the bill in the Colorado legislature. "We want to make sure that teachers' unions are focused on their core mission: representing the interests of their members, not trying to dictate educational policy." The proposals have been met with fierce resistance from teachers' unions, who argue that they have a critical role to play in shaping education policy. "We're not just advocating for our members' interests, we're advocating for the interests of our students and our schools," said Barbara Kerwin, president of the Colorado Education Association. As the debate continues, Secretary Duncan's message at the conference in Denver is being closely watched by education policymakers across the country.

FRANKFURT -- Amid growing expectations that Greece will have to restructure its debt, the German finance minister, Wolfgang Schauble, warned Thursday that a default could have grave and unpredictable consequences. But Mr. Schauble's comments left room for a less radical solution in which Greece might be given more time to pay its debts. "Germany's finance minister, Wolfgang Schauble, emphasized that a default would not only harm Greece, but also have far-reaching implications for the entire European economy. He cautioned that a default could lead to a loss of confidence in the eurozone, causing a credit crisis and even a recession. However, Schauble also left the door open for a more nuanced approach, suggesting that Greece could be granted an extension on its debt repayment schedule or even a temporary reduction in its debt burden. This would allow Greece to avoid default while still addressing its financial struggles. The comments come as international creditors prepare to meet with Greek officials to discuss the country's debt crisis."

The American trade deficit shrank unexpectedly in April after the United States sold $175.6 billion in goods and services overseas, the most exports on record, the government reported on Thursday. The Commerce Department report said that exports of goods were $126.4 billion and services $49.1 billion, while total imports were $219.2 billion, resulting in a trade deficit of $43.7 billion, the lowest since December. The deficit in March was revised down to $46.8 billion from $48.2 billion, the department said. The surprise drop in the trade deficit was attributed to a surge in exports of aircraft, autos, and agricultural products, which helped to offset a rise in imports of goods such as oil and electronics. Economists had been expecting a larger trade deficit, and the news was seen as a positive sign for the US economy. The report also showed that the country's trade deficit with China, a major source of concern for the Trump administration, narrowed to $23.2 billion in April from $25.1 billion in March. The improved trade numbers come as the US and China are engaged in high-stakes trade talks aimed at resolving their differences and avoiding further tariffs.

PARIS -- European finance ministers said on Saturday that they had moved closer to a comprehensive solution for the debt crisis during a two-day gathering of officials from the Group of 20 industrial nations, despite a number of unresolved problems that could still widen the scope of the crisis. With Europe's economic and financial woes weighing on prospects for global growth, officials said they had agreed to take "all necessary measures needed to stabilize the financial system" and to contain the troubles. The ministers also announced a plan to inject an additional €100 billion into the European Financial Stability Facility (EFSF) to support struggling member states, particularly Greece, Ireland, and Portugal. The move was seen as a significant step towards stabilizing the eurozone, which has been plagued by concerns over sovereign debt and banking sector instability. In a statement, the ministers emphasized the need for a coordinated approach to address the crisis, saying that "the financial system is interconnected and that a problem in one country can quickly become a problem for the entire global economy." The meeting concluded with a sense of urgency and a commitment to work together to address the pressing issues, as officials acknowledged that the road ahead would be long and challenging.

The interior is just as impressive, with floor-to-ceiling glass walls and a sleek, modern aesthetic.

The library's collection is a treasure trove of rare and unique materials, including ancient manuscripts, rare books, and historical documents. The special collections room is a particular highlight, featuring items such as the original manuscripts of famous authors and historical artifacts.

But the Mansueto Library is more than just a repository of knowledge - it's also a collaborative workspace. The building features numerous study areas, meeting rooms, and collaborative workspaces, making it the perfect place for students and faculty to work together on projects. With its cutting-edge technology and innovative design, the Mansueto Library is poised to become a model for future libraries and a hub of intellectual activity on the University of Chicago campus.

Budget cuts may have taken more than $30 million out of the Brownsville Independent School District's budget for the next two years, but administrators say they are working to preserve financing for one key pot of money: the chess budget. This academic year, it totals $400,000. Despite the significant budget cuts, district officials are determined to maintain their investment in the chess program, which has seen remarkable growth and success in recent years. "We believe that the benefits of chess education far outweigh the costs," said Superintendent, Maria Rodriguez. "Our students have shown significant improvements in critical thinking, problem-solving, and cognitive development, and we're committed to continuing this program." The district plans to allocate the $400,000 budget towards hiring additional chess coaches, purchasing new equipment, and hosting regional tournaments. With the program's popularity on the rise, district officials are confident that the investment will pay off in the long run.

The Silicon Valley entrepreneur James Anthony says he is often surprised to find that other developers for the iPhone and iPod Touch have the exact same programming education he does. They, too, learned the secrets of Apple's hit mobile devices from the Stanford course on iPhone applications, which was introduced in fall 2008 to a packed lecture hall. But while Mr. Anthony took the class as a senior at Stanford, many other members of Apple's burgeoning developer community have tuned in to free video recordings of lectures at iTunes U, where it is often one of the most popular downloads. Stanford's online class, Mr. Anthony says, "is pretty much the primary way to learn about iPhone development right now." As a result, Mr. Anthony has started a community of like-minded developers, where they can share knowledge, resources, and collaborate on projects. The group, called "Stanford iPhone Devs," has grown to over 5,000 members, with many of them going on to create successful apps that have topped the charts. "It's amazing to see how many talented developers are out there, and how much innovation is happening outside of the traditional academic setting," Mr. Anthony said. The Stanford course has also attracted developers from all over the world, including countries such as India, China, and Brazil. The global reach of the course has been facilitated by the availability of the video recordings on iTunes U, which have been viewed over 1 million times. The success of the course has also led to the creation of similar online courses on iPhone development at other universities, further expanding the global community of developers.

As part of the project to develop new ways to evaluate teachers, researchers have recruited 3,000 teachers in seven school systems  Dallas; Denver; Charlotte, N.C.; Hillsborough County, Fla.; Memphis; New York; and Pittsburgh  who allowed themselves to be videotaped in their classrooms. (As part of the agreement, only researchers can view the tapes, not school administrators). Participants include teachers of grades four through nine in regular public schools. To demonstrate the project for The New York Times, The Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation asked teachers in Charlotte and Memphis to volunteer to tape additional classes, not bound by the confidentiality provisions. One who volunteered was Rachael Maher, who teaches seventh-grade math at Alexander Graham Middle School in Charlotte. Rachael Maher's classroom was a typical seventh-grade math class, with students working on worksheets and discussing fractions. Maher, a 10-year veteran teacher, was energetic and engaging, moving around the room to help students who were struggling. As she taught, she encouraged her students to think critically and to explain their thinking. The cameras captured every moment, from Maher's enthusiastic explanations to her gentle corrections of students' mistakes. The goal of the project, Maher said, was to create a more accurate and comprehensive evaluation system, one that would focus on teaching practices rather than just test scores. "I think it's a great opportunity for teachers to showcase what we do every day," Maher said. "We're not just teaching, we're shaping minds."
